[Tech', Search', Search', Subscribe', SpaceX', SpaceX and Boeing Win 4 More NASA Manned Missions to Space', Brainstorm Health', My Crystal Ball Reading for Obamacare', diesel emissions scandal', Volkswagen Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels', CEO Daily', Trump\u2019s Industrial Policy, Part II', Photograph by Bloomberg via Getty Images', Fortune 500', Amazon Faces Questions Over How It Lists Prices', Leena Rao', Updated: Sep 22, 2016 10:55 PM UTC | Originally published: Sep 21, 2016', Amazon',  came under fire Monday after ', ProPublica ', reported', u" that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. The article pointed out that Amazon's strategy hurt shoppers, many of whom end up paying extra at checkout, and ran counter to its professed philosophy of putting customers first.", u"The article raised questions about whether Amazon's is trying to unfairly profit by funneling customers to more expensive products. The company has said previously that it ranks items based on the data it receives from its millions of customers and how they buy on the site.", For example, Amazon said its ranking favors items that ship for free and that can get to customers faster. The technology also takes into account other factors such as price, and the rating of the seller.', Related', Blue Ribbon Companies', Will Tech Titans, Pressured By Trump, Create More U.S. Factory Jobs?', Blue Ribbon Companies', Will Tech Titans, Pressured By Trump, Create More U.S. Factory Jobs?', Shipping is a big factor, Amazon says, because data shows that customers decide to buy products primarily based upon free shipping and shipping speed. Items sold or fulfilled by Amazon fall into the Prime subscription offering, which charges consumers $99 annually to get anything from toilet paper to diapers to books delivered to them in two days or less. Amazon also offers the ability for items to be included in Super Saver Shipping (which requires no Prime membership and ships orders above $49 for free).', In a statement to ', Fortune', , an Amazon spokesperson said: "The vast majority of our items ordered \u2013 9 out of 10 \u2013 can ship for free. The sorting algorithms the article refers to are designed for that 90% of items ordered, where shipping costs do not apply."', u"Of course, by prioritizing faster shipping (a.k.a. Prime-eligible items), Amazon is strongly encouraging more of its shoppers to sign up for Prime. That's a benefit for Amazon, as Prime members spend more than non-Prime members on the site. A recent ", Consumer Intelligence Research Partners study',  estimates that Prime shoppers spent about $1,200 on average last year, compared to about $500 for non-members.', u"However, ProPublica asserts that under Amazon's ranking systems, shoppers who are not Prime members can end up paying more for products if the fail to scroll more deeply into results. According the report, TheHardwareCity.com was selling superglue for $6.75 with free shipping. Fat Boy Tools was selling the same super glue for $7.27 with free shipping. But the algorithm ranked a the same glue sold by Amazon, which cost slightly more, $7.80, higher. But for non-Prime members or those who weren't interested in Super Saver Shipping, shipping costs for the Amazon glue amounted to $6.51, which increased the total price to $14.31.", Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has ', long said', u" that key to Amazon's mission is putting the customer first. ProPublica says that its algorithms don't do that.", Get Data Sheet', , ', Fortune\u2019s',  technology newsletter.', u"Other data backs up Amazon's belief that free shipping dominates purchase decisions. According to a ", 2015 comScore study,',  58% of online shoppers reported adding items to their shopping cart in order to qualify for free shipping.', It\u2019s no secret that Amazon believes its competitive advantage is in getting products to its customers faster than other retailers. The company has been exploring using drones to deliver packages to shoppers in 30 minutes and is also deploying fleets of planes and trucks to make speedier deliveries. In turn, more customers are seeking faster shipping, especially around the holidays.', The ', allure',  for many outside merchants to use and pay for Amazon to handle its shipping is to sell to Amazon\u2019s estimated 50 million Prime members. Merchants are eligible to be part of Prime delivery only if they are enrolled in the fulfillment program. Merchants must pay Amazon anywhere from $1.50 to $100 per order, depending on size and weight, for the service\u2014plus a standard fee.', ProPublica ', says', u" that some merchants can't afford to pay these fees, citing a number of examples. But merchants who don't pay for fulfillment, may also be at a disadvantage because of Amazon's rankings.", For more on Amazon, watch:', u"Besides shipping, it's also worth mentioning that there are other benefits to using Amazon's fulfillment program for merchants. As part of the program, merchants ship their items to an Amazon warehouse, and Amazon takes care of the rest including packaging the items, processing customer payments, and customer service.", Amazon has also been experimenting with letting certain merchants sell to Prime members without using fulfillment services. Amazon is working with a set of larger merchants that already have warehouses across the U.S. and are able to deliver within the Prime two-day window. Because these merchants don\u2019t need fulfillment services, they don\u2019t pay the same fees to Amazon but get access to Amazon\u2019s negotiated shipping prices with companies like ', UPS', , which are much lower than standard rates.', Correction, Sept. 22, 3:20 pm: An earlier of version of this article incorrectly said that search results considered seller ratings in the order of results. In fact, it was product listings. up for \u003Cspan\u003ETHE POWER SHEET\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and get insights, updates, and opinion on leadership and leaders","submitURL":"https:\u002F\u002Fpages.email.fortune.com\u002Fweb-opt-in\u002F","extraPostData":{"newsletter_name":"POWER_SHEET","source":"article","success_url":"https:\u002F\u002Fpages.email.fortune.com\u002Fthank-you\u002F"}}},"sectionList":"autos|careers|energy|executive-travel|finance|fortune-insiders|health|international|leadership|luxury|mpw|retail|sports|tech|the-21-century-coportation|venture|photography","isProduction":true}},"auth":{"isLoaded":false,"isVisible":false,"cookiePrefix":"ti-verify","authFlag":false},"scroll":{"isScrollAtTop":true,"isAboveTheFold":true},"editorialArticle":{"loaded":true,"loading":false,"data":{"id":1803984,"date":"2016-09-21T17:17:55","date_gmt":"2016-09-21T21:17:55","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1803984"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-09-22T18:55:06","modified_gmt":"2016-09-22T22:55:06","slug":"amazon-pricing-algorithms","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F21\u002Famazon-pricing-algorithms\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2d4pNH8","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Amazon Faces Questions Over How It Lists Prices"},"content":{"plain":"Amazon came under fire Monday after ProPublica reported that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. The article pointed out that Amazon&#8217;s strategy hurt shoppers, many of whom end up paying extra at checkout, and ran counter to its professed philosophy of putting customers first. The article raised questions about whether Amazon&#8217;s is trying to unfairly profit by funneling customers to more expensive products. The company has said previously that it ranks items based on the data it receives from its millions of customers and how they buy on the site. For example, Amazon said its ranking favors items that ship for free and that can get to customers faster. The technology also takes into account other factors such as price, and the rating of the seller. Shipping is a big factor, Amazon says, because data shows that customers decide to buy products primarily based upon free shipping and shipping speed. Items sold or fulfilled by Amazon fall into the Prime subscription offering, which charges consumers $99 annually to get anything from toilet paper to diapers to books delivered to them in two days or less. Amazon also offers the ability for items to be included in Super Saver Shipping (which requires no Prime membership and ships orders above $49 for free). In a statement to Fortune, an Amazon spokesperson said: &#8220;The vast majority of our items ordered \u2013 9 out of 10 \u2013 can ship for free. The sorting algorithms the article refers to are designed for that 90% of items ordered, where shipping costs do not apply.&#8221; Of course, by prioritizing faster shipping (a.k.a. Prime-eligible items), Amazon is strongly encouraging more of its shoppers to sign up for Prime. That&#8217;s a benefit for Amazon, as Prime members spend more than non-Prime members on the site. A recent Consumer Intelligence Research Partners study estimates that Prime shoppers spent about $1,200 on average last year, compared to about $500 for non-members. However, ProPublica asserts that under Amazon&#8217;s ranking systems, shoppers who are not Prime members can end up paying more for products if the fail to scroll more deeply into results. According the report, TheHardwareCity.com was selling superglue for $6.75 with free shipping. Fat Boy Tools was selling the same super glue for $7.27 with free shipping. But the algorithm ranked a the same glue sold by Amazon, which cost slightly more, $7.80, higher. But for non-Prime members or those who weren&#8217;t interested in Super Saver Shipping, shipping costs for the Amazon glue amounted to $6.51, which increased the total price to $14.31. Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has long said that key to Amazon&#8217;s mission is putting the customer first. ProPublica says that its algorithms don&#8217;t do that. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Other data backs up Amazon&#8217;s belief that free shipping dominates purchase decisions. According to a 2015 comScore study, 58% of online shoppers reported adding items to their shopping cart in order to qualify for free shipping. It\u2019s no secret that Amazon believes its competitive advantage is in getting products to its customers faster than other retailers. The company has been exploring using drones to deliver packages to shoppers in 30 minutes and is also deploying fleets of planes and trucks to make speedier deliveries. In turn, more customers are seeking faster shipping, especially around the holidays. The allure for many outside merchants to use and pay for Amazon to handle its shipping is to sell to Amazon\u2019s estimated 50 million Prime members. Merchants are eligible to be part of Prime delivery only if they are enrolled in the fulfillment program. Merchants must pay Amazon anywhere from $1.50 to $100 per order, depending on size and weight, for the service\u2014plus a standard fee. ProPublica says that some merchants can&#8217;t afford to pay these fees, citing a number of examples. But merchants who don&#8217;t pay for fulfillment, may also be at a disadvantage because of Amazon&#8217;s rankings. For more on Amazon, watch: Besides shipping, it&#8217;s also worth mentioning that there are other benefits to using Amazon&#8217;s fulfillment program for merchants. As part of the program, merchants ship their items to an Amazon warehouse, and Amazon takes care of the rest including packaging the items, processing customer payments, and customer service. Amazon has also been experimenting with letting certain merchants sell to Prime members without using fulfillment services. Amazon is working with a set of larger merchants that already have warehouses across the U.S. and are able to deliver within the Prime two-day window. Because these merchants don\u2019t need fulfillment services, they don\u2019t pay the same fees to Amazon but get access to Amazon\u2019s negotiated shipping prices with companies like UPS, which are much lower than standard rates. &nbsp; Correction, Sept. 22, 3:20 pm: An earlier of version of this article incorrectly said that search results considered seller ratings in the order of results. In fact, it was product listings. Clarification, Sept. 22 3:20 pm: The article&#8217;s headline has been updated to remove non-Prime customers from the title.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E came under fire Monday after \u003Cem\u003EProPublica \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.propublica.org\u002Farticle\u002Famazon-says-it-puts-customers-first-but-its-pricing-algorithm-doesnt\"\u003Ereported\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. The article pointed out that Amazon&#8217;s strategy hurt shoppers, many of whom end up paying extra at checkout, and ran counter to its professed philosophy of putting customers first.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe article raised questions about whether Amazon&#8217;s is trying to unfairly profit by funneling customers to more expensive products. The company has said previously that it ranks items based on the data it receives from its millions of customers and how they buy on the site.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor example, Amazon said its ranking favors items that ship for free and that can get to customers faster. The technology also takes into account other factors such as price, and the rating of the seller.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EShipping is a big factor, Amazon says, because data shows that customers decide to buy products primarily based upon free shipping and shipping speed. Items sold or fulfilled by Amazon fall into the Prime subscription offering, which charges consumers $99 annually to get anything from toilet paper to diapers to books delivered to them in two days or less. Amazon also offers the ability for items to be included in Super Saver Shipping (which requires no Prime membership and ships orders above $49 for free).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a statement to \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, an Amazon spokesperson said: &#8220;The vast majority of our items ordered \u2013 9 out of 10 \u2013 can ship for free. The sorting algorithms the article refers to are designed for that 90% of items ordered, where shipping costs do not apply.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOf course, by prioritizing faster shipping (a.k.a. Prime-eligible items), Amazon is strongly encouraging more of its shoppers to sign up for Prime. That&#8217;s a benefit for Amazon, as Prime members spend more than non-Prime members on the site. A recent \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F07\u002F11\u002Famazon-prime-customers\u002F\"\u003EConsumer Intelligence Research Partners study\u003C\u002Fa\u003E estimates that Prime shoppers spent about $1,200 on average last year, compared to about $500 for non-members.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, ProPublica asserts that under Amazon&#8217;s ranking systems, shoppers who are not Prime members can end up paying more for products if the fail to scroll more deeply into results. According the report, TheHardwareCity.com was selling superglue for $6.75 with free shipping. Fat Boy Tools was selling the same super glue for $7.27 with free shipping. But the algorithm ranked a the same glue sold by Amazon, which cost slightly more, $7.80, higher. But for non-Prime members or those who weren&#8217;t interested in Super Saver Shipping, shipping costs for the Amazon glue amounted to $6.51, which increased the total price to $14.31.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=56GFhr9r36Y\"\u003Elong said\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that key to Amazon&#8217;s mission is putting the customer first. ProPublica says that its algorithms don&#8217;t do that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u2019s\u003C\u002Fem\u003E technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOther data backs up Amazon&#8217;s belief that free shipping dominates purchase decisions. According to a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.comscore.com\u002FInsights\u002FPress-Releases\u002F2015\u002F3\u002FGlobal-Study-Reveals-Online-Shoppers-Want-More-Flexibility\"\u003E2015 comScore study,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E 58% of online shoppers reported adding items to their shopping cart in order to qualify for free shipping.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt\u2019s no secret that Amazon believes its competitive advantage is in getting products to its customers faster than other retailers. The company has been exploring using drones to deliver packages to shoppers in 30 minutes and is also deploying fleets of planes and trucks to make speedier deliveries. In turn, more customers are seeking faster shipping, especially around the holidays.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F12\u002F21\u002Famazon-sellers\u002F\"\u003Eallure\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for many outside merchants to use and pay for Amazon to handle its shipping is to sell to Amazon\u2019s estimated 50 million Prime members. Merchants are eligible to be part of Prime delivery only if they are enrolled in the fulfillment program. Merchants must pay Amazon anywhere from $1.50 to $100 per order, depending on size and weight, for the service\u2014plus a standard fee.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EProPublica \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.propublica.org\u002Farticle\u002Famazon-says-it-puts-customers-first-but-its-pricing-algorithm-doesnt\"\u003Esays\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that some merchants can&#8217;t afford to pay these fees, citing a number of examples. But merchants who don&#8217;t pay for fulfillment, may also be at a disadvantage because of Amazon&#8217;s rankings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFor more on Amazon, watch:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"video-wrapper\"  data-ratio=\"0.56363636363636\" type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\tbrightcove.createExperiences();\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBesides shipping, it&#8217;s also worth mentioning that there are other benefits to using Amazon&#8217;s fulfillment program for merchants. As part of the program, merchants ship their items to an Amazon warehouse, and Amazon takes care of the rest including packaging the items, processing customer payments, and customer service.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon has also been experimenting with letting certain merchants sell to Prime members without using fulfillment services. Amazon is working with a set of larger merchants that already have warehouses across the U.S. and are able to deliver within the Prime two-day window. Because these merchants don\u2019t need fulfillment services, they don\u2019t pay the same fees to Amazon but get access to Amazon\u2019s negotiated shipping prices with companies like \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fups-48\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EUPS\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which are much lower than standard rates.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ECorrection, Sept. 22, 3:20 pm: An earlier of version of this article incorrectly said that search results considered seller ratings in the order of results. In fact, it was product listings. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EClarification, Sept. 22 3:20 pm: The article&#8217;s headline has been updated to remove non-Prime customers from the title.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Amazon"]}," came under fire Monday after ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["ProPublica "]},{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.propublica.org\u002Farticle\u002Famazon-says-it-puts-customers-first-but-its-pricing-algorithm-doesnt"},"content":["reported"]}," that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. The article pointed out that Amazon's strategy hurt shoppers, many of whom end up paying extra at checkout, and ran counter to its professed philosophy of putting customers first."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The article raised questions about whether Amazon's is trying to unfairly profit by funneling customers to more expensive products. The company has said previously that it ranks items based on the data it receives from its millions of customers and how they buy on the site."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For example, Amazon said its ranking favors items that ship for free and that can get to customers faster. The technology also takes into account other factors such as price, and the rating of the seller."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Shipping is a big factor, Amazon says, because data shows that customers decide to buy products primarily based upon free shipping and shipping speed. Items sold or fulfilled by Amazon fall into the Prime subscription offering, which charges consumers $99 annually to get anything from toilet paper to diapers to books delivered to them in two days or less. Amazon also offers the ability for items to be included in Super Saver Shipping (which requires no Prime membership and ships orders above $49 for free)."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In a statement to ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]},", an Amazon spokesperson said: \"The vast majority of our items ordered \u2013 9 out of 10 \u2013 can ship for free. The sorting algorithms the article refers to are designed for that 90% of items ordered, where shipping costs do not apply.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Of course, by prioritizing faster shipping (a.k.a. Prime-eligible items), Amazon is strongly encouraging more of its shoppers to sign up for Prime. That's a benefit for Amazon, as Prime members spend more than non-Prime members on the site. A recent ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F07\u002F11\u002Famazon-prime-customers\u002F"},"content":["Consumer Intelligence Research Partners study"]}," estimates that Prime shoppers spent about $1,200 on average last year, compared to about $500 for non-members."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["However, ProPublica asserts that under Amazon's ranking systems, shoppers who are not Prime members can end up paying more for products if the fail to scroll more deeply into results. According the report, TheHardwareCity.com was selling superglue for $6.75 with free shipping. Fat Boy Tools was selling the same super glue for $7.27 with free shipping. But the algorithm ranked a the same glue sold by Amazon, which cost slightly more, $7.80, higher. But for non-Prime members or those who weren't interested in Super Saver Shipping, shipping costs for the Amazon glue amounted to $6.51, which increased the total price to $14.31."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=56GFhr9r36Y"},"content":["long said"]}," that key to Amazon's mission is putting the customer first. ProPublica says that its algorithms don't do that."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", "]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune\u2019s"]}," technology newsletter."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Other data backs up Amazon's belief that free shipping dominates purchase decisions. According to a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.comscore.com\u002FInsights\u002FPress-Releases\u002F2015\u002F3\u002FGlobal-Study-Reveals-Online-Shoppers-Want-More-Flexibility"},"content":["2015 comScore study,"]}," 58% of online shoppers reported adding items to their shopping cart in order to qualify for free shipping."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It\u2019s no secret that Amazon believes its competitive advantage is in getting products to its customers faster than other retailers. The company has been exploring using drones to deliver packages to shoppers in 30 minutes and is also deploying fleets of planes and trucks to make speedier deliveries. In turn, more customers are seeking faster shipping, especially around the holidays."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F12\u002F21\u002Famazon-sellers\u002F"},"content":["allure"]}," for many outside merchants to use and pay for Amazon to handle its shipping is to sell to Amazon\u2019s estimated 50 million Prime members. Merchants are eligible to be part of Prime delivery only if they are enrolled in the fulfillment program. Merchants must pay Amazon anywhere from $1.50 to $100 per order, depending on size and weight, for the service\u2014plus a standard fee."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["ProPublica ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.propublica.org\u002Farticle\u002Famazon-says-it-puts-customers-first-but-its-pricing-algorithm-doesnt"},"content":["says"]}," that some merchants can't afford to pay these fees, citing a number of examples. But merchants who don't pay for fulfillment, may also be at a disadvantage because of Amazon's rankings."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["For more on Amazon, watch:"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"4565779133001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Besides shipping, it's also worth mentioning that there are other benefits to using Amazon's fulfillment program for merchants. and Boeing Win 4 More NASA Manned Missions to Space"},"content":{"plain":"NASA has awarded four additional contracts to SpaceX and Boeing for manned flights to and from the International Space Station. On Tuesday, the administration announced that Boeing, headed by Dennis Muilenburg, and SpaceX, run by Elon Musk, had been awarded the additional missions\u2014bringing each of their total number of NASA contracts to send people into space to six. &#8220;Awarding these missions now will provide greater stability for the future space station crew rotation schedule, as well as reduce schedule and financial uncertainty for our providers,&#8221; Phil McAlister, director, NASA\u2019s Commercial Spaceflight Development Division said in a statement. \u201cThe ability to turn on missions as needed to meet the needs of the space station program is an important aspect of the Commercial Crew Program.\u201d The Commercial Crew Program was created by NASA as a way to put astronauts into space using the private sector. But both Boeing and SpaceX will first have to pass their spacecrafts through NASA certification. &nbsp; Boeing is scheduled to test an uncrewed version of its proposed flight, the CST-100 Starliner, in June 2018, followed by its crewed flight test in August 2018. SpaceX is expected to demonstrate an uncrewed version of its Crew Dragon flight to the space station in November 2017, followed by a crewed test in May 2018.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fvideo\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fspacex-will-launch-in-january\u002F\"\u003ENASA has awarded four additional contracts\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to SpaceX and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fboeing-24\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EBoeing\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for manned flights to and from the International Space Station.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn Tuesday, the administration announced that Boeing, headed by Dennis Muilenburg, and SpaceX, run by Elon Musk, had been awarded the additional missions\u2014\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fvideo\u002F2014\u002F09\u002F17\u002Fnasa-chooses-spacex-boeing\u002F\"\u003Ebringing each of their total number of NASA contracts to send people into space to six\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E&#8220;Awarding these missions now will provide greater stability for the future space station crew rotation schedule, as well as reduce schedule and financial uncertainty for our providers,&#8221; Phil McAlister, director, NASA\u2019s Commercial Spaceflight Development Division \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nasa.gov\u002Ffeature\u002Fmission-awards-secure-commercial-crew-transportation-for-coming-years\"\u003Esaid in a statement\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. \u201cThe ability to turn on missions as needed to meet the needs of the space station program is an important aspect of the Commercial Crew Program.\u201d\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Commercial Crew Program was created by NASA as a way to put astronauts into space using the private sector. Crystal Ball Reading for Obamacare"},"content":{"plain":"This essay appears in today\u2019s edition of the Fortune Brainstorm Health Daily. Get it delivered straight to your inbox. Good morning. The battle over the battle of Obamacare repeal comes to a sort-of head today as both President Obama and Vice President\u2013elect Mike Pence march to Congress to shore up their respective troops. The pep talks won\u2019t change much. Like some staged Civil War reenactment, both sides will initially hurl themselves at each other with their rhetorical Bowie knives and revolvers. But the real fight will almost certainly slog on for months, as Kelsey Snell and Mike DeBonis have reported in the Washington Post. In terms of procedure, one oft-mentioned strategy is for Republican Congressional leaders (who have only a slim majority in the Senate) to use a convoluted parliamentary workaround called \u201cbudget reconciliation\u201d to strip away the financial circuitry and plumbing of the Affordable Care Act, even as they leave the legislative framework standing. Think of that approach as marauders rushing into a new construction project and absconding with all the electrical wiring and copper pipes. But there have been increasing cries\u2014including late yesterday from the American Medical Association, the influential guild for U.S. physicians\u2014not to dismantle the existing, if flawed, Affordable Care Act before settling upon a replacement. Even some diehard Obamacare antagonists, such as Sen. Rand Paul, have upped their warnings about killing the nearly seven-year-old legislation in piecemeal fashion without having a full substitute at the ready. So what would that replacement look like? Well, let me grab my crystal ball. Hmm, I see something\u2026.faint, but ah yes, it\u2019s becoming more clear. There\u2019s a bill\u2014many months from now. It makes sure not to pull the rug out from the 20 million or so Americans who have gotten health insurance under the ACA. (They have to have coverage of some kind, of course.) And this bill keeps the provisions that Donald Trump says he wants to keep\u2014and that millions of American voters want to keep\u2014like those that prevent insurers from blacklisting people with preexisting medical conditions and that allow parents to include their slacker twentysomething kids on their own policies. And natch, this legislation has mechanisms that makes sure there\u2019s an intact marketplace of insurers, and that people aren\u2019t freeloading off of the hefty premiums paid by hardworking Americans: This is a conservative plan, after all. Sure, some will scoff and say it looks an awful lot like Obamacare. But it\u2019s nothing like it. This bill, for instance, has a rock-ribbed Republican name. Yes, I can see the letters getting sharper now in the crystal ball: Freedom-care.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis essay appears in today\u2019s edition of the \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFortune \u003Cem\u003EBrainstorm Health Daily. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetbrainstormhealth\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGet it delivered\u003C\u002Fa\u003E straight to your inbox.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGood morning. more.","parent":0,"count":2154,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1894022,"date":"2017-01-04T08:32:22","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:32:22","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1894022"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T08:32:22","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:32:22","slug":"volkswagen-driver-lawsuit-germany-over-diesels","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fvolkswagen-driver-lawsuit-germany-over-diesels\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iP3yE2","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Volkswagen Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels"},"content":{"plain":"German consumer rights champion myRight filed the first legal test case against Volkswagen in Germany on Tuesday, raising pressure on the carmaker to compensate customers in Europe over the emissions scandal. Europe&#8217;s largest automaker has pledged billions to compensate U.S. owners of Volkswagen (VW) diesel-powered cars, but has so far rejected any compensation for the 8.5 million affected vehicles in Europe where different legal rules weaken the chances of affected customers winning a pay out. Instead, VW is in the process of removing the illicit software that cheated emissions tests and insists the technical fixes will inflict no loss of value on car owners in Europe. It hopes to have completed repairs to all affected vehicles by the end of the year. MyRight, which has gathered more than 100,000 VW owners through its website, has accused VW of breaching European Union law by selling cars with software that was banned under EU rules, according to the 93-page legal document seen by Reuters. Rather than seeking compensation for a decline in value, the lawsuit aims to force VW to repurchase the vehicles at the original price, myRight founder Jan-Eike Andresen said. MyRight has mandated U.S. law firm Hausfeld to pursue the claims. Hausfeld represents aggrieved VW owners and shareholders on both sides of the Atlantic. The purpose of the proceedings by myRight is to act as a model &#8211; resolving generic or common issues for other related cases. However, unlike in a U.S. class action, it does not have the legal effect of resolving all individual claims. To read Fortune&#8217;s in-depth account of the Volkswagen scandal, click here. Wolfsburg-based Volkswagen, has said the software fitted into the engine at the center of the scandal, the EA 189, does not violate European law and declined comment on the myRight suit. &#8220;We have taken note that myRight has announced the submission of diesel lawsuits for Jan. 3. The lawsuits have not yet been made available to us which is why we cannot comment on the contents at the moment,&#8221; the carmaker said. VW is already facing criminal investigations in Germany on the suspicion that it misled investors by withholding knowledge of the diesel scandal for over a year. The company&#8217;s stock fell by more than a third when it finally disclosed the scale of its legal problems with the Environmental Protection Agency and California Air Resource Board. It has since paid over $15 billion to settle the claims of those two agencies and enact remedial measures. &nbsp;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EGerman consumer rights champion myRight filed the first legal test case against Volkswagen in Germany on Tuesday, raising pressure on the carmaker to compensate customers in Europe over the emissions scandal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEurope&#8217;s largest automaker has pledged billions to compensate U.S. owners of Volkswagen (VW) diesel-powered cars, but has so far rejected any compensation for the 8.5 million affected vehicles in Europe where different legal rules weaken the chances of affected customers winning a pay out.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EInstead, VW is in the process of removing the illicit software that cheated emissions tests and insists the technical fixes will inflict no loss of value on car owners in Europe. Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels","mt_seo_keywords":"Volkswagen, VW, emissions, diesel, lawsuit, Germany, MyRight, buyback, consumers","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"Volkswagen, VW, emissions, diesel, lawsuit, Germany, MyRight, buyback, consumers","short_title":"Volkswagen Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels","og_title":"Volkswagen Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels","og_description":"Not a class action, but a possible precedent for millions of other cases","twitter_text":"Volkswagen faces its first driver lawsuit in Germany over dirty diesels. It could be a precedent for millions of others","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iP3yE2","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fvolkswagen-driver-lawsuit-germany-over-diesels\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fvolkswagen-driver-lawsuit-germany-over-diesels\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1803812,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F501835780.jpg","alt":"Volkswagen Continues To Struggle With Emissions Cheating Consequences","caption":"The lawsuit is a test of Germany's traditional reluctance to impose heavy penalties on its companies.","credit":"Photograph by Sean Gallup\u2014Getty Images","description":"A Volkswagen logo and hood ornament in the colors of the German flag is visible on the front grille of a car on December 17, 2015 in Berlin, Germany. Volkswagen is continuing to struggle with the consequences of its emissions cheating scandal, in which the company admitted it had installed software designed to deliver manipulated results for nitrous oxide emissions during testing conditions in 11 million of its diesel-engine cars worldwide.","title":"Volkswagen Continues To Struggle With Emissions Cheating Consequences"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":446713511,"name":"diesel emissions scandal","slug":"diesel-emissions-scandal","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":169754,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":21,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":6688,"name":"Autos","slug":"autos","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46736,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and analysis of the automobile industry, from the latest cars to the latest executive shakeups at GM, Ford, Chrysler, and other motor vehicle manufacturers.","parent":0,"count":3395,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1894000,"date":"2017-01-04T08:01:18","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:01:18","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1894000"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T08:07:17","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:07:17","slug":"trumps-industrial-policy-part-ii","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Ftrumps-industrial-policy-part-ii\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iHOE55","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Trump\u2019s Industrial Policy, Part II"},"content":{"plain":"Good morning. My post yesterday about Trump\u2019s industrial policy was followed within hours by an announcement from Ford that it will kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico and increase employment at a Michigan plant by 700 people instead. CEO Mark Fields said it was the right decision for the business, but also called it a \u201cvote of confidence\u201d in Trump\u2019s economic agenda. Expect more companies to follow suit. The combination of Trump\u2019s big stick \u2013 his bully Twitter pulpit plus the threat of punitive tariffs \u2013 combined with his even bigger bag of carrots \u2013 potential reductions in taxes, particularly on repatriated earnings, and in regulations \u2013 is a powerful combination. It\u2019s only a matter of time before Apple, IBM, and other companies follow suit. Never mind the fact that Trump\u2019s attacks on companies are neither very precise nor entirely fair. Yesterday, he went after GM \u2013 whose chief executive Mary Barra sits on his jobs council \u2013 for selling Chevrolet Cruzes assembled in Mexico to U.S. car dealers, when in fact almost all of the Cruzes sold in the U.S. last year were assembled in Lordstown, Ohio. As we now all know, factual accuracy is not the President-elect&#8217;s strong suit. Historically, this sort of meddling in markets was decried by free-market conservatives on the right. Yet Trump\u2019s latest moves are being criticized mainly from the left \u2013 with press outlets like Salon (Trump&#8217;s latest con job), Slate (Ford isn&#8217;t adding American jobs because of Donald Trump), and MSNBC arguing Trump is exaggerating his own role, or that the number of workers involved is relatively small. What these critics miss is that after decades of debating the merits of first Japanese-style and then Chinese-style national industrial policies, the U.S. suddenly has one of its own. Even before assuming office, Trump has tilted the playing field in a significant way. And it is going to be fascinating to watch the results.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EGood morning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMy post yesterday about Trump\u2019s industrial policy was followed within hours by an announcement from Ford that it will kill \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump\u002F\"\u003Ea planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and increase employment at a Michigan plant by 700 people instead. CEO Mark Fields said it was the right decision for the business, but also called it a \u201cvote of confidence\u201d in Trump\u2019s economic agenda.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExpect more companies to follow suit. The combination of Trump\u2019s big stick \u2013 his bully Twitter pulpit plus the threat of punitive tariffs \u2013 combined with his even bigger bag of carrots \u2013 potential reductions in taxes, particularly on repatriated earnings, and in regulations \u2013 is a powerful combination. TALKING","description":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003EOut-Foxed.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EIt's shaping up to be a big week for two powerful women who helped make Fox News the juggernaut it is today. First, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmegyn-kelly-leaving-fox-for-nbc\u002F\"\u003EMegyn Kelly made headlines\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ewith her decision to leave the network, instead signing with competitor NBC News. Kelly was apparently lured by NBC's offer of a three-part role: She will reportedly host her own daytime news program, anchor a Sunday night news show, and take regular part in the network\u2019s special political programming. No financial terms of the deal were disclosed, but as the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fbusiness\u002Fmedia\u002Fmegyn-kelly-nbc-fox-news.html?hp&amp;action=click&amp;pgtype=Homepage&amp;clickSource=story-heading&amp;module=second-column-region&amp;region=top-news&amp;WT.nav=top-news\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENew York Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E put it\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \"even a modest raise would place her among television\u2019s highest paid journalists.\" (For a look at what her hire means for the future of NBC News, check out \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fnbc-megyn-kelly\u002F\"\u003Ethis piece\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by \u003Cem\u003EFortune'\u003C\u002Fem\u003Es Mathew Ingram.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThe second piece of news came from Gretchen Carlson, who was fired by Fox in June of last year and who then sued former network chief Roger Ailes. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fgretchen-carlson-today-show-host\u002F\"\u003ECarlson returned to the small screen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the first time yesterday, co-hosting a segment of the \u003Cem\u003EToday Show.\u003C\u002Fem\u003EShe used the appearance to announce that she issetting up a fund to \"empower women and young girls\"\u2014and that she plans to become a regular columnist for our fellow Time Inc. publication \u003Cem\u003EMotto\u003C\u002Fem\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EOf course, Kelly and Carlson have more than a former network in common\u2014both have said that they were sexually harassed by Roger Ailes. While the two newswomen have many advantages that other victims of harassment lack, it is a pleasure to see any woman who's had to deal with such toxic behavior go on to bigger and better things.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},{"title":"ALSO IN THE HEADLINES","description":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E[bs_bullet_primary]\u003Cstrong\u003ECruze craziness\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EGM is the latest company to be threatened via Twitter (of course) by Donald Trump. If you\u2019re interested in it, be a leader. Don\u2019t let the world tell you girls can\u2019t lead. [\u002Fbs-quote]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"}]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"og_image":null,"negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fthe-broadsheet-january-4th-3\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fthe-broadsheet-january-4th-3\u002F?source=dam","mt_seo_title":"The Broadsheet: January 4th"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893164,"link":"","alt":"","caption":"The carmaker had been harshly criticized by President-elect Donald Trump.","credit":"","description":"Ford Motor Co [fortune-stock symbol=\"f\"] on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival [f500link]General Motors[\u002Ff500link] Co with the threat of a \"big border tax\" over compact cars made in Mexico.\r\n\r\nFord CEO Mark Fields called the move \"a vote of confidence\" in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. He said Ford would have made the same decision even if Trump had not been elected.\r\n\r\nFord will cancel plans unveiled in April to spend $1.6 billion to build the new plant in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, a project Trump urged the automaker to abandon and called an \"absolute disgrace\" during the election campaign.\r\n\r\nThe No. 2 U.S. automaker also said it would invest $700 million to expand the Flat Rock, Michigan factory and would make new electric, hybrid and autonomous vehicles there.\r\n\r\nTrump's efforts to browbeat the U.S. car industry show he may go further than other modern presidents to try to influence corporate decisions, especially those related to trade and investment.\r\n\r\nIn a Twitter post hours before Ford's announcement, Trump wrote, \"General Motors is sending Mexican made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border. Make in U.S.A. or pay big border tax!\" GM, the largest U.S. automaker, said making some of the Cruze cars in the plant in Coahuila, Mexico was part of its strategy to serve global customers, not sell those vehicles in the United States.\r\n\r\nTrump's GM tweet was his latest broadside aimed at an American company over jobs, imports and costs even before he takes office on Jan. 20.\r\n\r\nMexico's government said it regrets Ford's decision and has ensured that the company will reimburse San Luis Potosi state for any costs associated with the investment.\r\n\r\n\"Obviously, this isn't a good decision for us,\" said Mexico's economy minister, Ildefonso Guajardo.\r\n\r\nFord said it still will shift production from Michigan of its Focus compact car to an existing plant in Hermosillo, Mexico. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford's investment in Flat Rock.\r\n\r\nFord spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus.\r\n\r\nFord shares closed up about 3.8 percent. GM shares rose about 0.9 percent.\r\n\r\n\u003Cstrong\u003ETRUMP NOTIFIED\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\r\n\r\nTop Ford executives personally notified Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence of their decision. Fields praised tax and regulatory proposals advocated by Trump and his fellow Republicans who control Congress.\r\n\r\n\"Our view is that we see a more positive U.S. manufacturing business environment under President-elect Trump and the pro-growth policies and proposals that he's talking about, so this is a vote of confidence for President-elect Trump and some of the policies that they may be pursuing,\" Fields said.\r\n\r\nUnion workers gathered at the Flat Rock factory cheered Fields' announcement. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said.\r\n\r\nTrump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. Trump also accused Mexico of sending criminals and rapists into the United States and vowed to build a border wall to combat illegal immigration.\r\n\r\nSince winning the Nov. 8 election, Trump has targeted a wide range of American companies also including [f500link]United Technologies[\u002Ff500link] Inc, [f500link]Boeing[\u002Ff500link] Co and [f500link]Lockheed Martin[\u002Ff500link] Corp. Trump also has touted decisions by companies to keep some production in the United States, including United's Carrier unit in Indiana.\r\n\r\nTrump previously vowed to hit companies that shift production from America to other countries with a 35 percent tax on their exports into the United States. He also has denounced the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada.\r\n\r\nFields said there were no negotiations between Ford and the incoming president over canceling the Mexico plant or investing in Michigan.\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E[fortune-brightcove videoid=5269310978001]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\nFord will build a battery electric SUV with a 300-mile (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020.\r\n\r\nGM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. All of the sedan versions sold in the United States, about 185,500, were built at its Lordstown, Ohio plant. About 4,500 hatchback Cruze versions were assembled in Mexico and sold in the United States.\r\n\r\n\u003Cem\u003EThis story has been updated.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\r\n\r\n&nbsp;","title":"Ford Cancels a $1.6 Billion Mexico Plant and Adds 700 Jobs in Michigan"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":58962834,"name":"broadsheet","slug":"broadsheet-2","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":112680,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":626,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":20466,"name":"Careers","slug":"careers","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46729,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News you can utilize to develop and advance your career and how to position yourself to get that great new job. ","parent":0,"count":4368,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893984,"date":"2017-01-04T07:17:13","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T12:17:13","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893984"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T07:17:13","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T12:17:13","slug":"amazon-marketplace-sales","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Famazon-marketplace-sales\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hQEdfO","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Amazon\u2019s Third-Party Sellers Had Record-Breaking Sales in 2016"},"content":{"plain":"Amazon.com amzn shipped 50 percent more items this holiday season than last for third-party vendors and doubled the amount for 2016 overall, the retail giant said on Wednesday. The news offers new data points for investors who are hoping Amazon will post a profit for the fourth quarter when it announces results in the coming weeks. Seattle-based Amazon, known for its roller coaster results in years past, has forecast that operating income would range from nothing to $1.25 billion. Amazon, the world&#8217;s largest online retailer, has said the 2016 holiday was its best-ever shopping season. However, high spending on warehouses and video production are expected to drag on profits. More sellers are paying the company to store, pack and ship their goods through the Fulfillment by Amazon service. Amazon more than doubled the items it delivered for other sellers in 2016 from the year prior to exceed two billion, a spokesman said. Active sellers using the fulfillment service rose more than 70 percent in the year, Amazon said on Wednesday. It did not specify the total number of vendors. &nbsp; Third-party sales were &#8220;record-breaking&#8221; in 2016, Peter Faricy, vice president for Amazon Marketplace, said in the statement. Amazon takes a cut of the proceeds. Amazon will likely top its profit-margin guidance for the fourth quarter, Morningstar analyst R.J. Hottovy said in a research note last week. Price competition seemed subdued in December and Amazon avoided delivery bottlenecks it experienced in 2015, he said. Cyber Monday, a shopping spree four days after Thanksgiving, is another indicator. Shoppers ordered more than 28 million items from third-party sellers this year, versus more than 23 million items on Cyber Monday in 2015, Amazon said. Amazon is building its own fleet of planes to handle the rise in orders and supplement shipping that it contracts out to companies like FedEx Corp and United Parcel Service Inc . Data reviewed by Reuters and interviews with airport officials show that Amazon has loaded these aircraft with big but lightweight boxes, helping it dodge fees from cargo carriers increasingly pricing based on volume rather than weight. The company does not disclose the revenue it generates from its Fulfillment by Amazon service. Chief Executive Jeff Bezos has said that close to 50 percent of the units purchased on Amazon come from third-party vendors. Clicks on product advertisements paid for by third-party sellers grew 150 percent, Amazon said.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon.com\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"amzn\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazon-com-18\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eamzn\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E shipped 50 percent more items this holiday season than last for third-party vendors and doubled the amount for 2016 overall, the retail giant said on Wednesday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe news offers new data points for investors who are hoping Amazon will post a profit for the fourth quarter when it announces results in the coming weeks. Amazon takes a cut of the proceeds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon will likely top its profit-margin guidance for the fourth quarter, Morningstar analyst R.J. Hottovy said in a research note last week. Price competition seemed subdued in December and Amazon avoided delivery bottlenecks it experienced in 2015, he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECyber Monday, a shopping spree four days after Thanksgiving, is another indicator. Shoppers ordered more than 28 million items from third-party sellers this year, versus more than 23 million items on Cyber Monday in 2015, Amazon said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon is building its own fleet of planes to handle the rise in orders and supplement shipping that it contracts out to companies like \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffedex-58\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFedEx\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Corp and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fups-48\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EUnited Parcel Service\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Inc . Data reviewed by Reuters and interviews with airport officials show that Amazon has loaded these aircraft with big but lightweight boxes, helping it dodge fees from cargo carriers increasingly pricing based on volume rather than weight.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe company does not disclose the revenue it generates from its Fulfillment by Amazon service. Chief Executive Jeff Bezos has said that close to 50 percent of the units purchased on Amazon come from third-party vendors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EClicks on product advertisements paid for by third-party sellers grew 150 percent, Amazon said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Amazon.com"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"amzn"},"content":[]}," shipped 50 percent more items this holiday season than last for third-party vendors and doubled the amount for 2016 overall, the retail giant said on Wednesday."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The news offers new data points for investors who are hoping Amazon will post a profit for the fourth quarter when it announces results in the coming weeks. Seattle-based Amazon, known for its roller coaster results in years past, has forecast that operating income would range from nothing to $1.25 billion."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Amazon, the world's largest online retailer, has said the 2016 holiday was its best-ever shopping season. However, high spending on warehouses and video production are expected to drag on profits."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["More sellers are paying the company to store, pack and ship their goods through the Fulfillment by Amazon service. Amazon more than doubled the items it delivered for other sellers in 2016 from the year prior to exceed two billion, a spokesman said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Active sellers using the fulfillment service rose more than 70 percent in the year, Amazon said on Wednesday. It did not specify the total number of vendors."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5264565774001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Third-party sales were \"record-breaking\" in 2016, Peter Faricy, vice president for Amazon Marketplace, said in the statement. Amazon takes a cut of the proceeds."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Amazon will likely top its profit-margin guidance for the fourth quarter, Morningstar analyst R.J. Hottovy said in a research note last week. Daily: Wednesday, 4th January"},"content":{"plain":"Good morning. My post yesterday about Trump\u2019s industrial policy was followed within hours by an announcement from Ford that it will kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico and increase employment at a Michigan plant by 700 people instead. CEO Mark Fields said it was the right decision for the business, but also called it a \u201cvote of confidence\u201d in Trump\u2019s economic agenda. Expect more companies to follow suit. The combination of Trump\u2019s big stick \u2013 his bully Twitter pulpit plus the threat of punitive tariffs \u2013 combined with his even bigger bag of carrots \u2013 potential reductions in taxes, particularly on repatriated earnings, and in regulations \u2013 is a powerful combination. It\u2019s only a matter of time before Apple, IBM, and other companies follow suit. Never mind the fact that Trump\u2019s attacks on companies are neither very precise nor entirely fair. Yesterday, he went after GM \u2013 whose chief executive Mary Barra sits on his jobs council \u2013 for selling Chevrolet Cruzes assembled in Mexico to U.S. car dealers, when in fact almost all of the Cruzes sold in the U.S. last year were assembled in Lordstown, Ohio. As we now all know, factual accuracy is not the President-elect&#8217;s strong suit. Historically, this sort of meddling in markets was decried by free-market conservatives on the right. Yet Trump\u2019s latest moves are being criticized mainly from the left \u2013 with press outlets like Salon (Trump&#8217;s latest con job), Slate (Ford isn&#8217;t adding American jobs because of Donald Trump), and MSNBC arguing Trump is exaggerating his own role, or that the number of workers involved is relatively small. What these critics miss is that after decades of debating the merits of first Japanese-style and then Chinese-style national industrial policies, the U.S. suddenly has one of its own. Even before assuming office, Trump has tilted the playing field in a significant way. And it is going to be fascinating to watch the results. More news below.
