ts\u002F1893953\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893953\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893953\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893953\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893953\u002Fprimary_section"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893953\u002Fbrand"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:meta":[{"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iyZn19","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[{"title":"Top News","description":"\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003ESenate Moves to Repeal Obamacare\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Senate moved to dismantle the Affordable Care Act on its first day in session. According to \u003Cem\u003EThe Wall Street Journal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R. Ky.) will open debate on a budget resolution Wednesday that could allow the GOP-controlled chamber to repeal much of the ACA with a simple majority vote. Whether it will do so without having a replacement law is another question. [bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.wsj.com\u002Farticles\u002Fsenate-moves-to-dismantle-health-law-1483491985\" source=\"WSJ, Subscription required\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003EEuro, Yuan Rebounds Halt Dollar Rally\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESigns of life in Europe and Chinahalted the dollar\u2019s march higher. Consumer inflation in the Eurozone rose to its highest in over three years in December at 1.1% thanks largely to energy prices. More importantly, the Eurozone\u2019s composite purchasing managers\u2019 index for December hit its highest level since May 2011, as the German, French and Spanish economies all powered ahead. Much more of that, and the ECB may have to start tapering its bond purchases faster than it thinks (although the risk of Italy upsetting the applecart hasn\u2019t gone away). IHS Markit, which compiles the PMI surveys, estimates global manufacturing grew at its fastest pace in three years in December. Separately, the Chinese yuan also bounced back strongly after some nudges and winks from Beijing to state banks about unwelcome capital outflows. [bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fdollar-new-high\u002F\" source=\"Fortune\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003ETillerson in Line for $180 Million Payoff\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExxonMobil and its outgoing CEO Rex Tillerson agreed to sever all financial ties if the Texan is confirmed as Secretary of State. Under the agreement, Exxon will transfer the equivalent of some 2 million previously allotted but unvested shares into a trust (which will not be allowed to invest in Exxon). Tillerson will also sell over 600,000 vested shares worth around $54 million. The deal looks like a cleaner break than that engineered by George W. Bush\u2019s vice-president Dick Cheney, who kept hundreds of thousands of stock options in Halliburton and sold them gradually during his time in office. Keeping the interests of his employer of over 30 years at an emotional arm\u2019s length may be a little harder, one imagines. [bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fexxon-mobil-rex-tillerson-secretary-state\u002F\" source=\"Reuters\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary]\u003Cstrong\u003EVW's Emissions Campaign Moves to the Home Front\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELawyers representing German owners of tainted Volkswagen diesel vehicles have filed the first lawsuit in Germany seeking compensation for damages from the emissions scandal. VW has so far tried to satisfy such complaints with recalls and technical fixes, arguing all along that the devices didn\u2019t breach (badly-written) EU rules anyway, and that compensation was therefore not appropriate. While Germany generally avoids punitive legal settlements against companies, the sheer numbers involved create a material risk for VW: some 8 million cheating cars were sold in Europe, compared to only 600,000 in the U.S.. Owners have claimed they have suffered losses through lower resale values andhigher fuel bills. German law doesn\u2019t allow class actions. The suit in question represents a single VW buyer, and its outcome may be used as a precedent for similar cases. [bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-volkswagen-emissions-lawsuit-idUSKBN14N1FF\" source=\"Reuters\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},{"native_sponsor":"Deloitte","native_description":"\u003Cp\u003E[bs-title]10 Trends in Risk[\u002Fbs-title]\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n[bs-content]What should you consider when managing risks in 2017? This report from Deloitte profiles 10 trends that have the potential to significantly alter the risk landscape for companies around the world.[\u002Fbs-content]\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n[bs-link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww2.deloitte.com\u002Fus\u002Fen\u002Fpages\u002Frisk\u002Farticles\u002Ffuture-of-risk-ten-trends.html?id=us:2pm:3em:ftnceoadv1:awa:adv:01031\" source=\"Read more\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},{"title":"Around the Water Cooler","description":"\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003EJudge Halves J&amp;J Hip Joint Damages\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA district court judge almost halved the $1 billion damages bill handed to Johnson &amp; Johnson last year for its faulty DePuy Pinnacle hip implants. Judge Ed Kinkeade in Dallas upheld a jury\u2019s findings that the implants were defectively designed and that the companies failed to warn consumers about the risks, but cited \u201cconstitutional considerations\u201d in trimming the damages. J&amp;J had stopped selling the metal-on-metal Pinnacle devices in 2013. It has already paid over $2.5 billion to settle more than 7,000 lawsuits related to them. [bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-johnson-johnson-verdict-idUSKBN14O0DF\" source=\"Reuters\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003ETesla Misses Deliveries Goal\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETesla missed its target of 80,000 deliveries in 2016. At 76,230, they were well below the 80,000-90,000 Elon Musk had originally hoped to ship, and even below the reduced guidance of 79,000. Delays in the transition to its new automated driving hardware caused deliveries to dip to 22,000 from the 24,500 it posted in the three months to September. The company\u2019s shares fell 2% in after-hours trading because the market had hoped that the 70% surge in deliveries in the third quarter represented a step change in its fortunes. However, net orders for the Model S and X were still up 24% from the third quarter, and up 52% from a year earlier, suggesting that Teslastill has momentum going into a make-or-break year when it aims to launch the Model 3, its first mass-market vehicle. [bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ftesla-deliveries-2016-goal\u002F\" source=\"Fortune\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003EToshiba Hit by Fresh Accounting Allegations\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EToshiba shares fell more than 5% after fresh allegations of false accounting at the Japanese conglomerate. Media reported that Japan\u2019s securities watchdog suspects it of padding its profits by 40 billion yen ($339.59 million) over three years. The revelations add to a series of accounting troubles swirling around Toshiba, which was downgraded by ratings agencies last week after it admitted it may face a multi-billion dollar writedown over its U.S. nuclear business. The new investigation could open the way to formal criminal charges against the company and its former executives, according to \u003Cem\u003EReuters\u003C\u002Fem\u003E.[bs_link link=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ftoshiba-profit-padding-accounting\u002F\" source=\"Fortune\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003EPotemkin Sends His Regards \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced his personal challenge for 2017 would be to visit and meet people in every U.S. state by the end of the year, in an attempt to understand better why globalization and technology has \u201ccontributed to a greater sense of division than I have felt in my lifetime.\u201d Zuckerberg\u2019s post said the trip would take in \u201csmall towns and universities, visits to our offices across the country, meetings with teachers and scientists, and trips to fun places you recommend along the way,\u201d which sounds like the kind of Filter Bubble that Potemkin prepared for Catherine the Great back in the day. After that, you can already hear the cynics saying, Zuckerbergwill retire to his secure, luxurious and painstakingly concealed complex in California to contemplate what he has learned about division. [bs_link link=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Fzuck?fref=ts\" source=\"Facebook\"]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESummaries by Geoffrey Smith Geoffrey.smith@fortune.com;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E@geoffreytsmith\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","native_sponsor":"Deloitte"}]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"mt_seo_keywords":"ceo daily","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"ceo daily","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fceo-daily-wednesday-4-january\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fceo-daily-wednesday-4-january\u002F?source=dam","mt_seo_title":"CEO Daily: Wednesday, 4th January"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893164,"link":"","alt":"","caption":"The carmaker had been harshly criticized by President-elect Donald Trump.","credit":"","description":"Ford Motor Co [fortune-stock symbol=\"f\"] on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival [f500link]General Motors[\u002Ff500link] Co with the threat of a \"big border tax\" over compact cars made in Mexico.\r\n\r\nFord CEO Mark Fields called the move \"a vote of confidence\" in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. He said Ford would have made the same decision even if Trump had not been elected.\r\n\r\nFord will cancel plans unveiled in April to spend $1.6 billion to build the new plant in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, a project Trump urged the automaker to abandon and called an \"absolute disgrace\" during the election campaign.\r\n\r\nThe No. 2 U.S. automaker also said it would invest $700 million to expand the Flat Rock, Michigan factory and would make new electric, hybrid and autonomous vehicles there.\r\n\r\nTrump's efforts to browbeat the U.S. car industry show he may go further than other modern presidents to try to influence corporate decisions, especially those related to trade and investment.\r\n\r\nIn a Twitter post hours before Ford's announcement, Trump wrote, \"General Motors is sending Mexican made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border. Make in U.S.A. or pay big border tax!\" GM, the largest U.S. automaker, said making some of the Cruze cars in the plant in Coahuila, Mexico was part of its strategy to serve global customers, not sell those vehicles in the United States.\r\n\r\nTrump's GM tweet was his latest broadside aimed at an American company over jobs, imports and costs even before he takes office on Jan. 20.\r\n\r\nMexico's government said it regrets Ford's decision and has ensured that the company will reimburse San Luis Potosi state for any costs associated with the investment.\r\n\r\n\"Obviously, this isn't a good decision for us,\" said Mexico's economy minister, Ildefonso Guajardo.\r\n\r\nFord said it still will shift production from Michigan of its Focus compact car to an existing plant in Hermosillo, Mexico. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford's investment in Flat Rock.\r\n\r\nFord spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus.\r\n\r\nFord shares closed up about 3.8 percent. GM shares rose about 0.9 percent.\r\n\r\n\u003Cstrong\u003ETRUMP NOTIFIED\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\r\n\r\nTop Ford executives personally notified Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence of their decision. Fields praised tax and regulatory proposals advocated by Trump and his fellow Republicans who control Congress.\r\n\r\n\"Our view is that we see a more positive U.S. manufacturing business environment under President-elect Trump and the pro-growth policies and proposals that he's talking about, so this is a vote of confidence for President-elect Trump and some of the policies that they may be pursuing,\" Fields said.\r\n\r\nUnion workers gathered at the Flat Rock factory cheered Fields' announcement. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said.\r\n\r\nTrump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. Trump also accused Mexico of sending criminals and rapists into the United States and vowed to build a border wall to combat illegal immigration.\r\n\r\nSince winning the Nov. 8 election, Trump has targeted a wide range of American companies also including [f500link]United Technologies[\u002Ff500link] Inc, [f500link]Boeing[\u002Ff500link] Co and [f500link]Lockheed Martin[\u002Ff500link] Corp. Trump also has touted decisions by companies to keep some production in the United States, including United's Carrier unit in Indiana.\r\n\r\nTrump previously vowed to hit companies that shift production from America to other countries with a 35 percent tax on their exports into the United States. He also has denounced the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada.\r\n\r\nFields said there were no negotiations between Ford and the incoming president over canceling the Mexico plant or investing in Michigan.\r\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E[fortune-brightcove videoid=5269310978001]\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\r\nFord will build a battery electric SUV with a 300-mile (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020.\r\n\r\nGM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. All of the sedan versions sold in the United States, about 185,500, were built at its Lordstown, Ohio plant. About 4,500 hatchback Cruze versions were assembled in Mexico and sold in the United States.\r\n\r\n\u003Cem\u003EThis story has been updated.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\r\n\r\n&nbsp;","title":"Ford Cancels a $1.6 Billion Mexico Plant and Adds 700 Jobs in Michigan"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":345093422,"name":"CEO Daily","slug":"ceo-daily-2","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":128203,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":571,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":7885,"name":"Leadership","slug":"leadership","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46727,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and advice on leadership, management, jobs, careers, CEOs and anyone who aspires to the C-suite.","parent":0,"count":20253,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893212,"date":"2017-01-04T06:00:03","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T11:00:03","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893212"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T06:00:05","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T11:00:05","slug":"stocks-2017-trump-january-effect","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fstocks-2017-trump-january-effect\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iLC3ee","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why the Stock Market \u2018January Effect\u2019 Is No Longer Very Effective"},"content":{"plain":"January appears to have less of a pull on the market than it used to. Stock investors have long looked to January to tell them where the market might be headed for the rest of the year. And for good reason: Over the long haul, the-first-month-of-the-year indicator has seemed to work pretty well. Historically, stocks have tended to rise in January. And in general, when stocks were up at the end of January, eleven months later shares logged a positive year; when January was down, shares ended the year in the red. Only 27% of the time since 1929 have the market and January parted ways, according to data from Standard &amp; Poor&#8217;s. That seems like good news for 2017 (based on a very small sample size). The Dow Jones industrial average rose 119 points on Tuesday, or 0.6%, on the first trading day of 2017. Let the good times roll. The problem: Recently, the market connection between January and the rest of the year has been pretty lousy. During the past 11 years, stocks as measured by the S&amp;P 500 have fallen six times in January. Yet the market has ended down in only two of those six years. The divergence was particularly big last year. In 2016, the market had its worst start of the year since 1896, which Reuters, at the time, noted was seven years before the Wright brothers took flight and 12 years before Ford began selling the Model T. (On Tuesday, Ford scrapped plans to move some of its car production to Mexico.) The market ended the first month of last year down just over 5%. Nonetheless, in part thanks to the Trump Bump, 2016 ended up being a pretty good year for stocks, up 9.5%. Overall, the last few years have resulted in a lot of false negatives and false positives for the January indicator. And 2016 wasn&#8217;t the only year of big divergence. In 2009, for instance, the market dropped more than 8% in the first 31 days of the year. By March, though, the market was rebounding from the financial-crisis slump, and stocks ended that year up nearly 24%. In 2015, the January indicator worked, but just barely. Stocks fell 3% in January, but ended the year down just 1%. Erase January, and stocks were actually up the other 11 months of that year. Not exactly the bloodbath that January would have predicted. Even the first order January Effect\u2014that stocks tend to rise in January\u2014hasn&#8217;t been bankable lately. Again, of the past 11 years, only five have had up Januarys. What&#8217;s going on? One answer could have to do with index funds. More and more money has been shifting into passive investing\u2014funds that blindly track an index. Active fund managers typically sell some stocks in December either to lock in positive returns for the year, or to realize losses (for tax purposes), and then go on a buying spree in January. In the past, that in turn may have created momentum for the stock market for the rest of the year (or at least for a few months), as emotion-driven humans reacted to the spree and dove into the stock market, not wanting to miss out. Index investing, in contrast, lacks those behavioral quirks. Jeff Rubin, the director of research at investment firm Birinyi Associates, believes the January effect has waned because the January trade became too predictable. In order to capture the month&#8217;s gains, more investors have been buying stocks in December, leaving fewer left to buy in January. What&#8217;s more, the growing degree of market timing around the first 31 days of the year made January&#8217;s gains or losses an increasingly poor representation of how people actually thought about stocks or the economy. &#8220;The more people who pile into any trade, the less it works,&#8221; says Rubin. Another answer could be that in an era of historically low interest rates, the stock market, except for the disastrous 2008, has generally been up. Yes, Januarys in which the stock market has risen have been good predictors\u2014five out of the past five have coincided with up years. But, as a post on stock blog Seeking Alpha points out, that&#8217;s because the market has gone up in nine of the past 11 years. There are a number of better-than-average reasons to doubt the predictive powers of this January&#8217;s results, if stocks do finish the month with gains. The biggest is President-elect Donald Trump: Actions he may take to stymie global trade, for example, could hobble stocks. Add to that the fact that the Federal Reserve has indicated that it plans more interest rate increases this year. What&#8217;s more, as my colleague Shawn Tully writes this week, it looks likely that Wall Street&#8217;s big bet on soaring earnings could be a fantasy. So stocks could continue to rise in January, even past Dow 20,000, as investors remain on a Trump high. But don&#8217;t let that fool you. January&#8217;s ability to predict the stock market&#8217;s future is weaker than ever.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EJanuary appears to have less of a pull on the market than it used to.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStock investors have long looked to January to tell them where the market might be headed for the rest of the year. And for good reason: Over the long haul, the-first-month-of-the-year indicator has seemed to work pretty well. Historically, stocks have tended to rise in January. And in general, when stocks were up at the end of January, eleven months later shares logged a positive year; when January was down, shares ended the year in the red. Only 27% of the time since 1929 have the market and January parted ways, according to data from Standard &amp; Poor&#8217;s.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat seems like good news for 2017 (based on a very small sample size). The Dow Jones industrial average rose 119 points on Tuesday, or 0.6%, on the first trading day of 2017. Let the good times roll.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe problem: Recently, the market connection between January and the rest of the year has been pretty lousy. During the past 11 years, stocks as measured by the S&amp;P 500 have fallen six times in January. Yet the market has ended down in only two of those six years.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe divergence was particularly big last year. In 2016, the market had its worst start of the year since 1896, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-usa-dow-history-idUSKBN0UL2M520160107\"\u003Ewhich \u003Cem\u003EReuters\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, at the time, noted\u003C\u002Fa\u003E was seven years before the Wright brothers took flight and 12 years before Ford began selling the Model T. (On Tuesday, Ford \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmexican-peso-weakens-ford-factory-canceled\u002F\"\u003Escrapped plans to move some of its car production to Mexico.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E) The market ended the first month of last year down just over 5%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ciframe id=\"fortune-iframe-embed-328b44bdffac1773a216a60c7b419447a3720342\" class=\"responsive-iframe\" src=\"\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002FLwIPD\u002F1\u002F?iframe_id=fortune-iframe-embed-328b44bdffac1773a216a60c7b419447a3720342\" width=\"545\" height=\"483\" frameborder=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENonetheless, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F09\u002Ftrump-stock-market-dow-close-goldman-sachs\u002F\"\u003Ein part thanks to the Trump Bump\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, 2016 ended up being a pretty good year for stocks, up 9.5%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOverall, the last few years have resulted in a lot of false negatives and false positives for the January indicator. And 2016 wasn&#8217;t the only year of big divergence. In 2009, for instance, the market dropped more than 8% in the first 31 days of the year. By March, though, the market was rebounding from the financial-crisis slump, and stocks ended that year up nearly 24%.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 2015, the January indicator worked, but just barely. Stocks fell 3% in January, but ended the year down just 1%. Erase January, and stocks were actually up the other 11 months of that year. Not exactly the bloodbath that January would have predicted.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEven the first order January Effect\u2014that stocks tend to rise in January\u2014hasn&#8217;t been bankable lately. Again, of the past 11 years, only five have had up Januarys.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-wrapper\"  data-ratio=\"0.56363636363636\" data-pos=\"5\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cobject id=\"bc-video-5261879233001-5\" class=\"BrightcoveExperience\"\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"bgcolor\" value=\"#FFFFFF\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"width\" value=\"550\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"height\" value=\"310\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"playerID\" value=\"3160175193001\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"playerKey\" value=\"AQ~~,AAAB668kGak~,LMlvL4u4ShOTHD9z00VquajMOcH97tcW\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"isVid\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"isUI\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"videoSmoothing\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"seamlessTabbing\" value=\"false\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"swliveconnect\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"dynamicStreaming\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"autoStart\" value=\"false\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"@videoPlayer\" value=\"5261879233001\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"linkBaseURL\" value=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iLC3ee\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"includeAPI\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"templateLoadHandler\" value=\"Fortune_onTemplateLoad\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"templateReadyHandler\" value=\"Fortune_onTemplateReady\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"wmode\" value=\"opaque\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"adServerURL\" value=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpubads.g.doubleclick.net\u002Fgampad\u002Fads?env=vp&#038;gdfp_req=1&#038;impl=s&#038;output=xml_vast2&#038;iu=\u002F8484\u002Ffort\u002Fvideo_bc\u002Ffinance_bc&#038;sz=1000x1&#038;cust_params=tags%3Dbigbanks%2Cmorganstanley%2Crbc%2Cwallstreet%2Cwallstreetpredictions%2Cwellsfargo%26ch%3Dfinance%26topic%3Dwallstreet&#038;unviewed_position_start=1&#038;correlator=%5Btimestamp%5D\"\u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fobject\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003Cscript type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\tbrightcove.createExperiences();\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat&#8217;s going on?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne answer could have to do with index funds. More and more money has been shifting into passive investing\u2014funds that blindly track an index. Active fund managers typically sell some stocks in December either to lock in positive returns for the year, or to realize losses (for tax purposes), and then go on a buying spree in January. In the past, that in turn may have created momentum for the stock market for the rest of the year (or at least for a few months), as emotion-driven humans reacted to the spree and dove into the stock market, not wanting to miss out. Index investing, in contrast, lacks those behavioral quirks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EJeff Rubin, the director of research at investment firm Birinyi Associates, believes the January effect has waned because the January trade became too predictable. In order to capture the month&#8217;s gains, more investors have been buying stocks in December, leaving fewer left to buy in January. What&#8217;s more, the growing degree of market timing around the first 31 days of the year made January&#8217;s gains or losses an increasingly poor representation of how people actually thought about stocks or the economy. &#8220;The more people who pile into any trade, the less it works,&#8221; says Rubin.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnother answer could be that in an era of historically low interest rates, the stock market, except for the disastrous 2008, has generally been up. Yes, Januarys in which the stock market has risen have been good predictors\u2014five out of the past five have coincided with up years. But, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fseekingalpha.com\u002Farticle\u002F4033880-bitter-reality-stock-market-january-effect?page=2\"\u003Eas a post on stock blog Seeking Alpha points out,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that&#8217;s because the market has gone up in nine of the past 11 years.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere are a number of better-than-average reasons to doubt the predictive powers of this January&#8217;s results, if stocks do finish the month with gains. The biggest is President-elect Donald Trump: Actions he may take to stymie global trade, for example, could hobble stocks. Add to that the fact that the Federal Reserve has indicated that it plans more interest rate increases this year. What&#8217;s more, as my colleague Shawn Tully writes this week,\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fstocks-expensive-earnings-growth\u002F\"\u003E it looks likely that Wall Street&#8217;s big bet on soaring earnings could be a fantasy. \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo stocks could continue to rise in January, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F21\u002Fdow-20000-milestone-look-back\u002F\"\u003Eeven past Dow 20,000\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, as investors remain on a Trump high. But don&#8217;t let that fool you. January&#8217;s ability to predict the stock market&#8217;s future is weaker than ever.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["January appears to have less of a pull on the market than it used to."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Stock investors have long looked to January to tell them where the market might be headed for the rest of the year. And for good reason: Over the long haul, the-first-month-of-the-year indicator has seemed to work pretty well. Historically, stocks have tended to rise in January. And in general, when stocks were up at the end of January, eleven months later shares logged a positive year; when January was down, shares ended the year in the red. Only 27% of the time since 1929 have the market and January parted ways, according to data from Standard &amp; Poor's."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["That seems like good news for 2017 (based on a very small sample size). The Dow Jones industrial average rose 119 points on Tuesday, or 0.6%, on the first trading day of 2017. Let the good times roll."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The problem: Recently, the market connection between January and the rest of the year has been pretty lousy. During the past 11 years, stocks as measured by the S&amp;P 500 have fallen six times in January. Yet the market has ended down in only two of those six years."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The divergence was particularly big last year. In 2016, the market had its worst start of the year since 1896, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-usa-dow-history-idUSKBN0UL2M520160107"},"content":["which ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Reuters"]},", at the time, noted"]}," was seven years before the Wright brothers took flight and 12 years before Ford began selling the Model T. U.S. President-elect Donald Trump, who has promised to either renegotiate or scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), has said overhauling trade policy will be a top priority after he takes office on Jan. 20. Canada sends 75% of its exports to the United States and could suffer from changes to NAFTA, which also includes Mexico. Ford Motor f on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Trump, who turned his attention toward General Motors gm with the threat of a &#8220;big border tax&#8221; over compact cars made in Mexico. In the video address, Trudeau and David MacNaughton, the Canadian ambassador to Washington, stressed the closeness of ties between the neighbors. &#8220;We&#8217;ve built an economic relationship that supports jobs in every Congressional district. We are the largest international customer for goods and services made in the USA,&#8221; said Trudeau, who was filmed in his office in front of the U.S. and Canadian flags. MacNaughton said Canada was ready to work with Congress to make the lives of citizens in both nations better and more prosperous. Christine Constantin, a spokeswoman for the Canadian embassy in Washington, said ambassadors had sent video greetings to the two previous opening sessions of Congress. For more on Canada-U.S. relations, watch Fortune&#8217;s video: Trudeau, who has made ties with the United States a priority, was asked by the embassy to appear in the video, she said. Trudeau spokesman Cameron Ahmad declined to elaborate on the video, saying the prime minister&#8217;s message spoke for itself. In the run-up to the 2016 U.S election, Canadian diplomats fanned out across the country to stress that Canada is the top export destination for 35 U.S. states and that nine million U.S. jobs depend on trade with Canada.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EPrime Minister Justin Trudeau reached out in a video address to the new U.S. Congress on Tuesday to stress how tightly linked the economies of Canada and the United States are, amid fears of a protectionist Trump administration.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EU.S. President-elect Donald Trump, who has promised to either renegotiate or scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), has said overhauling trade policy will be a top priority after he takes office on Jan. 20.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECanada sends 75% of its exports to the United States and could suffer from changes to NAFTA, which also includes Mexico. Taco Has Been Described as \u2018Cat Food\u2019 But Americans Eat 554 Million Each Year"},"content":{"plain":"Fans of fast food chain Jack in the Box jack may or may not be surprised to learn that the company&#8217;s best-selling item is its long-running and much maligned taco. The Wall Street Journal reports that 554 million of the tacos are eaten every year, despite many customers proclaiming they are &#8220;vile&#8221; and &#8220;disgusting.&#8221; The company\u2014better known for its burgers\u2014creates its tacos by putting a tortilla wrapped with beef filling into the fryer, and then topped with hot sauce, lettuce and American cheese. This combination, atypical for tacos, have led to doubts whether the concoction Jack in the Box cooks up even is a taco. Customers have described the fillings as oily and gooey, especially if it&#8217;s not immediately consumed. As one Twitter user puts it, &#8220;they&#8217;re more like a wet envelope of cat food.&#8221; Jack in the Box tacos aren&#39;t tacos. They&#39;re more like a wet envelope of cat food. When you eat them you&#39;re just mailing yourself diarrhea. &mdash; Mike Primavera (@primawesome) October 22, 2016 But many people have taken to social media to express their love, disgust, or a simultaneous gushing of love and disgust for the Jack in the Box taco, reports Business Insider. One first-time eater of the taco summed up her experience to the Journal as: &#8220;This is vile and amazing.&#8221; @primawesome I wasn&#39;t knocking Jack in the Box tacos. I&#39;m saying that despite how gross they are, I love them more than my own mother. &mdash; Mike Primavera (@primawesome) October 22, 2016 For more on fast food, watch this video: Despite the complicated feelings Americans have towards its tacos, Jack in the Box is cashing in, according to Business Insider. Wall Street Lawyer Is Said to Be Donald Trump\u2019s New Pick for SEC Chair"},"content":{"plain":"Wall Street lawyer Jay Clayton, who has worked on high-profile initial public offerings such as Alibaba Group, is a leading candidate to head the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission in the Trump administration, two sources familiar with the matter said on Tuesday. Clayton is a partner at Sullivan &amp; Cromwell who specializes in public and private mergers and offerings, an area that requires expertise on complex securities regulations and corporate governance. Clayton was not available to comment. He met with President-elect Donald Trump on Dec. 22 and appears to have overtaken a former U.S. Attorney, Debra Wong Yang, whose name had been floated as a top candidate in early December. Yang declined to comment. Clayton&#8217;s name surfaced relatively recently and he is one of a handful of other top contenders. Besides Yang, other names mentioned include former SEC commissioner Paul Atkins, lawyer Ralph Ferrara, and at least one candidate who used to work at a prominent Wall Street hedge fund, but whose name could not be learned. Activist investor Carl Icahn, who has been tapped by Republican Trump to play a bigger role in his administration, has been interviewing many of the of the potential SEC candidates. During the height of the 2008 financial crisis, Clayton worked on major deals involving big banks, including Barclays Capital&#8217;s acquisition of Lehman Brothers&#8217; assets, the sale of Bear Stearns to JP Morgan Chase, and the U.S. Treasury Department&#8217;s capital investment in Goldman Sachs , according to his law firm&#8217;s web site. The position of SEC chair will be very important to Wall Street investors and executives at Fortune 500 companies at a time when Trump has promised to roll back regulation in a variety of areas. Current SEC Chair Mary Jo White is slated to depart at the end of the Obama administration. Trump is to be sworn in as president on Jan. 20. For more on top jobs in the Trump administration, watch Fortune&#8217;s video: Under White, a former federal prosecutor, the SEC&#8217;s focus on enforcement increased. While some of the cases have involved big firms, the SEC has also sought to crack down on relatively minor violations, in the hopes it will deter bigger problems down the road. Some investors have said they would like to see the chair be an expert not only in enforcement matters, but have a greater understanding of markets and trading issues as U.S. firms face greater competition for global capital.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWall Street lawyer\u003Cspan class=\"highlight\"\u003E Jay \u003C\u002Fspan\u003EClayton, who has worked on high-profile initial public offerings such as Alibaba Group, is a leading candidate to head the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission in the Trump administration, two sources familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EClayton is a partner at Sullivan &amp; Cromwell who specializes in public and private mergers and offerings, an area that requires expertise on complex securities regulations and corporate governance.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EClayton was not available to comment.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHe met with President-elect Donald Trump on Dec. 22 and appears to have overtaken a former U.S. Attorney, Debra Wong Yang, whose name had been floated as a top candidate in early December.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYang declined to comment.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EClayton&#8217;s name surfaced relatively recently and he is one of a handful of other top contenders. Said to Be Donald Trump's New Pick for SEC Chair","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j7ZAJM","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fdonald-trump-sec-jay-clayton\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fdonald-trump-sec-jay-clayton\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893949,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F130425838.jpg","alt":"SEC Approves Systemic-Risk Reporting Rule For Hedge Fund Firms","caption":"","credit":"Andrew Harrer\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","description":"The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) seal is displayed outside headquarters in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Wednesday, Oct. 26, 2011. Photographer: Andrew Harrer\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","title":"SEC Approves Systemic-Risk Reporting Rule For Hedge Fund Firms"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":447816745,"name":"trump administration","slug":"trump-administration","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":183688,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":73,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":7885,"name":"Leadership","slug":"leadership","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46727,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and advice on leadership, management, jobs, careers, CEOs and anyone who aspires to the C-suite.","parent":0,"count":20253,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893860,"date":"2017-01-04T03:56:51","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T08:56:51","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893860"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T03:57:31","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T08:57:31","slug":"ford-and-toyota-just-became-allies-in-an-unusual-agreement","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fford-and-toyota-just-became-allies-in-an-unusual-agreement\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j7iXTB","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Ford and Toyota Just Became Allies in an Unusual Agreement"},"content":{"plain":"Automakers are scrambling to offer connectivity to their increasingly tech-savvy consumer base and offer seamless integration between cars and smartphones. But not all are keen to connect with systems developed by Apple or Google. Ford Motor f and Toyota Motor tm have formed a consortium to accelerate the deployment of open source software aimed at giving consumers more options in how they connect and control their smartphone apps. The organization is called the SmartDeviceLink (SDL) Consortium, a reference to an open source software version of Ford&#8217;s AppLink. Mazda Motor mzday , PSA Group, Fuji Heavy Industries fujhy , and Suzuki Motor szkmy , are the first automaker members of the consortium. Suppliers Elektrobit ebttf , Harman har , Luxoft lxft , QNX, and Xevo have also joined the nonprofit organization. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. The formation of the consortium follows Toyota&#8217;s announcement last January that it planned to use the SDL software in its cars to give drivers command and control of smartphone apps through dashboard buttons, display screens, and voice recognition tech. Toyota plans to commercialize an infotainment system using SDL around 2018. The unusual agreement between the typically competitive companies showed the wariness of some automakers to hand over control to third-party companies\u2014namely Apple aapl and Google googl . Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are two connectivity systems that allow a smartphone to take over a car\u2019s center screen. Once users plug their smartphones into the car\u2019s USB ports, the phones&#8217; maps and navigation, music, and selected apps are integrated onto the central screen. Ford and Toyota argue that an open source code is a better approach, because developers and automakers working together can increase the quality and security of the software. If the industry adopts the software, developers would gain access to millions of vehicles and their drivers worldwide, while participating companies would still be able to retain control over the level of access outside parties have to vehicle data, the companies said. Ford has abandoned Apple&#8217;s and Google&#8217;s offerings, however. The company has taken an all-of-the-above approach to connectivity in the car. It&#8217;s keeping Sync, the in-car communications and entertainment system that lets you use your voice to make a call, listen to music, and select apps with its AppLink technology. At the same time, Ford is also adding Apple CarPlay and Android Auto to new models.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EAutomakers are scrambling to offer connectivity to their increasingly tech-savvy consumer base and offer seamless integration between cars and smartphones. Summers Says Investors Are Too Blas About the Risks of Donald Trump\u2019s Presidency"},"content":{"plain":"Markets are underestimating the potential for fiscal turbulence under a Donald Trump presidency that poses &#8220;enormous risks to the global economy,&#8221; according to Harvard professor and former U.S. Treasury Secretary Larry Summers. During an interview with Bloomberg Television on Tuesday, Summers said that the global economy was entering a period of &#8220;extraordinary uncertainty,&#8221; with the possibility of protectionist measures and unprecedented changes to foreign policy looming. \u201cThis is probably the largest transition ideologically and in terms of substantive policy that we\u2019ve seen in the U.S. in the last three quarters of a century,\u201d Summers said. \u201cThose kinds of transitions have to be\u2014given the central role of the U.S. in the global system\u2014matters of enormous uncertainty. I don\u2019t think that\u2019s fully recognized by markets.\u201d For more on Larry Summers, watch Fortune&#8217;s video: U.S.-driven political risk has yet to rumble markets, and investors are staying positive as Trump&#8217;s Jan. 20 inauguration draws closer. The S&amp;P 500\u2014bullish on economic growth and fiscal stimulus packages\u2014rose almost 10% in 2016 and is close to a record high, Bloomberg reports. The Dow Jones also climbed 13% last year. But Summers sees scant cause for optimism. He described the Navarro-Ross paper, published in September to outline Trump&#8217;s plans for trade and growth as &#8220;beyond voodoo economics.&#8221; \u201cThe logic of it, the arguments made, are so far out of the mainstream of any kind of responsible economic thinking that they are the economic equivalent of creationism,\u201d Summers said.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMarkets are underestimating the potential for fiscal turbulence under a Donald Trump presidency that poses &#8220;enormous risks to the global economy,&#8221; according to Harvard professor and former U.S. Treasury Secretary Larry Summers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.bloomberg.com\u002Fnews\u002Farticles\u002F2017-01-03\u002Fsummers-says-markets-underestimating-risks-of-trump-presidency?cmpid=socialflow-facebook-business&amp;utm_content=business&amp;utm_campaign=socialflow-organic&amp;utm_source=facebook&amp;utm_medium=social\"\u003Einterview\u003C\u002Fa\u003E with Bloomberg Television on Tuesday, Summers said that the global economy was entering a period of &#8220;extraordinary uncertainty,&#8221; with the possibility of protectionist measures and unprecedented changes to foreign policy looming.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cThis is probably the largest transition ideologically and in terms of substantive policy that we\u2019ve seen in the U.S. in the last three quarters of a century,\u201d Summers said. \u201cThose kinds of transitions have to be\u2014given the central role of the U.S. in the global system\u2014matters of enormous uncertainty. Sends Its First Freight Train to London"},"content":{"plain":"China has begun its first freight train service to London from Yiwu, a famed wholesale market town in the eastern province of Zhejiang, the Xinhua news agency reported. The train will travel for 18 days over more than 7,500 miles (12,000 km) to reach Britain from China, Xinhua said. It will pass through Kazakhstan, Russia, Belarus, Poland, Germany, Belgium and France before arriving in London. The train journey is one of the world&#8217;s longest, according to CNN. Former British Prime Minister David Cameron raised some eyebrows with allies by pitching Britain as the pre-eminent gateway to the West for investment from China and proposing to make London the main international trading centre for offshore yuan. Prime Minister Theresa May has said the relationship with China remains &#8220;golden&#8221; as she seeks to bring in billions of dollars in Chinese investment as Britain prepares to leave the European Union.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EChina has begun its first\u003Cspan class=\"highlight\"\u003E freight \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"highlight\"\u003Etrain \u003C\u002Fspan\u003Eservice to London from Yiwu, a famed wholesale market town in the eastern province of Zhejiang, the \u003Cem\u003EXinhua\u003C\u002Fem\u003E news agency reported.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe\u003Cspan class=\"highlight\"\u003E train \u003C\u002Fspan\u003Ewill travel for 18 days over more than 7,500 miles (12,000 km) to reach Britain from China, Xinhua said. A public official there said the crime was prompted by the victims&#8217; resemblance to &#8220;westerners.&#8221; As commenters called out the government for what seemed like justification for the attack and the online conversation snowballed, some men chimed in with the age-old response that &#8220;not all men&#8221; commit these kinds of acts. Women were quick to dismiss that tired argument. &#8220;Stop diluting the issue,&#8221; one wrote. The &#8220;not all men&#8221; defense had a moment back in 2014 when it was mocked mercilessly in Internet memes that skewered it as tone deaf and characterized it as missing the point completely. Around that same time, writer Jess Zimmerman argued in a Time magazine piece that the &#8220;not all men&#8221; argument was actually an odd step forward from other perennial responses like &#8220;what about the men?&#8221; and \u201cpatriarchy hurts men too.\u201d While infuriating, at least the former acknowledges that rape, sexism, and misogyny are serious issues. From the &#8220;not all men&#8221; level, Zimmerman wrote, men could progress to the next stages of awareness. That would entail them recognizing that they are unavoidably sexist sometimes because they were socialized that way, and to be anti-sexist, they have to actively work against that socialization. If the response to this weekend&#8217;s attack in Bangalore is any indication, we&#8217;re not to that level yet. @clairezillman &nbsp; &nbsp;","rendered":"\u003Cp style=\"text-align:left;\"\u003EOn New Year&#8217;s Eve in Bangalore, India, several women claimed they were molested and heckled in a crowd of thousands. British millennials has halved in the past generation, with men and women starting on near-even footing. But women continue to fall behind men in their 30s. When baby boomers were in their 20s, the gender pay gap was 16%; it was 9% for Generation X. ","parent":0,"count":4368,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893838,"date":"2017-01-04T01:31:40","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T06:31:40","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893838"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T01:31:40","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T06:31:40","slug":"trump-russia-hacking-intelligence-briefing","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Ftrump-russia-hacking-intelligence-briefing\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iBMa5O","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Trump Says His Intelligence Briefing on Russian Hacking Has Been \u2018Delayed\u2019"},"content":{"plain":"President-elect Donald Trump said on Tuesday that a briefing he is to receive from U.S. intelligence officials on allegations of Russian hacking of the U.S. election had been delayed until Friday. In a tweet, Trump voiced continued skepticism about the extent of Russia&#8217;s cyber hacking. He and top advisers believe Democrats are trying to delegitimize his Nov. 8 election victory by accusing Russian authorities of helping him. &#8220;The &#8216;Intelligence&#8216; briefing on so-called &#8216;Russian hacking&#8217; was delayed until Friday, perhaps more time needed to build a case. Very strange!&#8221; Trump tweeted. It was not clear when the briefing originally had been scheduled to take place. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Trump, who has cast doubt on U.S. intelligence agencies&#8217; conclusion that Russia hacked Democratic Party computers, said over the weekend he would discuss the hacking allegations on Tuesday or Wednesday. With his tweet, he suggested he would not address the subject until he had been briefed by intelligence officials. Trump has scheduled a Jan. 11 news conference in New York. He is expected to discuss separating himself from his far-flung business empire, and other topics, including Russia, are likely to come up. U.S. intelligence officials have said they are confident Russia was behind the hacks of political figures in an effort to help Trump win the presidential election. For more on cybersecurity and the incoming White House administration, watch Fortune&#8217;s video: President Barack Obama retaliated to the hacking last week by ordering 35 Russian intelligence officials expelled from the United States and two Russian compounds shut down. Trump told reporters on Saturday at his Palm Beach, Florida, resort that he knew &#8220;things that other people don&#8217;t know&#8221; about the hacking, &#8220;so we cannot be sure&#8221; who was responsible. He said any computer was subject to hacks. &#8220;It&#8217;s very important. If you have something really important write it out and have it delivered by courier the old fashioned way,&#8221; Trump said, adding: &#8220;No computer is safe, I don&#8217;t care what they say.&#8221;","rendered":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EPresident-elect Donald\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E Trump \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Esaid on Tuesday that a briefing he is to receive from U.S.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E intelligence \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Eofficials on allegations of Russian hacking of the U.S. election had been delayed until Friday.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn a tweet,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E Trump \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Evoiced continued skepticism about the extent of Russia&#8217;s cyber hacking. C-suite.","parent":0,"count":20253,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893844,"date":"2017-01-04T00:42:14","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T05:42:14","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893844"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T04:26:53","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T09:26:53","slug":"samsung-quarterly-profits-chip-screen","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fsamsung-quarterly-profits-chip-screen\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hQLH16","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why Investors Are Betting On Samsung\u2019s Best Quarterly Profit in 3 Years"},"content":{"plain":"Samsung Electronics ssnlf is likely to forecast its best quarterly profit in nearly three years on Friday, analysts said, with robust memory chip sales easing the pain of the costly failure of a flagship smartphone. The South Korean firm discontinued sales of the Galaxy Note 7 phones after some of the devices caught fire, warning of a $2.1 billion hit to its profit in the fourth quarter of 2016 due to expenses tied to an ongoing global recall and lost sales. But investors are betting a surge in sales of memory chips and organic light-emitting diode screens for smartphones will translate to strong earnings growth for the October-December period and through 2017. Samsung&#8217;s operating profit likely rose for a second straight quarter to 8.4 trillion won ($7 billion) over October-December, according to a Thomson Reuters StarMine SmartEstimate derived from a survey of 15 analysts, up 37% from a year ago and the highest since the first quarter of 2014. &#8220;We look for the memory business to post a big earnings improvement and contribute 50% of its (Samsung&#8217;s) total operating profit for Q416,&#8221; Daiwa said in a report. Memory chip prices have spiked recently on demand for more firepower on mobile devices. But it is the sales of the higher-end 3D NAND chips which have rallied significantly, helping Samsung rake in profits given it is ahead of its rivals such as Toshiba tosbf and SK Hynix in the mass production of these chips, analysts said. For more on Samsung, watch Fortune&#8217;s video: Samsung&#8217;s semiconductor profit likely surged to a record 4.5 trillion won for the fourth quarter and 13.1 trillion won for 2016, Eugene Investment said in a report, adding chip earnings will grow further this year on firm demand. HDC Asset Management&#8217;s fund manager Park Jung-hoon agreed that the components business outlook appeared &#8220;pretty solid.&#8221; &#8220;We&#8217;ll have to see how the mobile business does &#8230; but I think Samsung&#8217;s operating profit should be able to come in somewhere around mid-30 trillion won range (this year).&#8221; For the recently ended quarter, Samsung&#8217;s mobile earnings likely rebounded from the dismal third quarter on healthy sales of the Galaxy S7 and S7 edge smartphones, analysts said. Hyundai Securities expects Samsung&#8217;s mobile division&#8217;s operating profit at 2.2 trillion won, in line with a year earlier and up sharply from 99 billion won in July-September. The company&#8217;s shares hit a record 1.831 million won on Tuesday this week ahead of the earnings forecast on Friday. They surged 43% in 2016\u2014the most since 2012\u2014suggesting investors did not expect a serious business impact from Samsung&#8217;s name being dragged into a growing political scandal in the Seoul on January 28, 2016. Slowing global demand for smartphones as well as memory chips dealt a blow to Samsung Electronics as it reported a 40 percent on-year drop in fourth-quarter net profit.  AFP PHOTO \u002F JUNG YEON-JE \u002F AFP \u002F JUNG YEON-JE        (Photo credit should read JUNG YEON-JE\u002FAFP\u002FGetty Images)","title":"SKOREA-ECONOMY-SAMSUNG-EARNINGS"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":2449302,"name":"Global 500","slug":"global-500","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":156716,"taxonomy":"person","description":"","parent":0,"count":0,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":4269,"name":"Finance","slug":"finance","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46730,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and analysis on the business of finance, including hedge funds, markets, mergers and acquisitions, private equity, venture capital, and Wall Street.","parent":0,"count":18937,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893820,"date":"2017-01-04T00:02:51","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T05:02:51","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893820"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T00:02:51","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T05:02:51","slug":"transunion-equinox-fined-credit-scores","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Ftransunion-equinox-fined-credit-scores\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iBCDLZ","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"TransUnion And Equifax Have Been Fined $23 Million For Deceiving Customers Over Credit Scores"},"content":{"plain":"A U.S. regulator on Tuesday ordered credit reporting agencies TransUnion and Equifax efx to pay more than $23.2 million in fines and restitution for deceiving consumers about the usefulness and cost of credit scores they bought. The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said the payments also resolve charges that TransUnion and Equifax lured consumers into enrolling in credit services advertised as free or costing only $1, but which could cost more than $200 a year. TransUnion will reimburse $13.93 million to consumers and pay a $3 million civil fine, while Equifax will reimburse $3.8 million and pay a $2.5 million civil fine, the CFPB said. Both companies will also modify their marketing practices, including by obtaining consent to enroll in credit-related services where fees kick in after free trials, and making it easier for consumers to cancel products they do not want. The CFPB said the wrongful conduct had occurred at TransUnion since July 2011 and at Equifax between July 2011 and March 2014, and violated the Dodd-Frank financial reform law. Many lenders rely on credit scores from TransUnion, Equifax and rival Experian experian-plc when lending money. But the CFPB said TransUnion and Equifax falsely represented that the credit scores they sold to consumers were the same scores that lenders used. &#8220;Credit scores are central to a consumer&#8217;s financial life and people deserve honest and accurate information about them,&#8221; CFPB Director Richard Cordray said in a statement. For more on credit report companies, watch Fortune&#8217;s video: Neither Chicago-based TransUnion nor Atlanta-based Equifax admitted or denied wrongdoing. TransUnion spokesman David Blumberg and Equifax spokeswoman Ines Gutzmer said their respective companies believe they have complied with applicable laws, and are committed to better educating consumers about their credit. Experian was not charged. A spokesman for the CFPB had no immediate additional comment. TransUnion, Equifax and Experian are among the 10 companies about which the CFPB receives the most consumer complaints. Several large banks and mortgage lenders are also on that list. In 2015, the credit reporting agencies agreed to improve how they fix mistakes and address disputes, under a separate settlement with 31 state attorneys general.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA U.S. regulator on Tuesday ordered credit reporting agencies TransUnion and Equifax \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"efx\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fequifax-801\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eefx\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E to pay more than $23.2 million in fines and restitution for deceiving consumers about the usefulness and cost of credit scores they bought.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said the payments also resolve charges that TransUnion and Equifax lured consumers into enrolling in credit services advertised as free or costing only $1, but which could cost more than $200 a year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETransUnion will reimburse $13.93 million to consumers and pay a $3 million civil fine, while Equifax will reimburse $3.8 million and pay a $2.5 million civil fine, the CFPB said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBoth companies will also modify their marketing practices, including by obtaining consent to enroll in credit-related services where fees kick in after free trials, and making it easier for consumers to cancel products they do not want.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe CFPB said the wrongful conduct had occurred at TransUnion since July 2011 and at Equifax between July 2011 and March 2014, and violated the Dodd-Frank financial reform law.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMany lenders rely on credit scores from TransUnion, Equifax and rival Experian \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"experian-plc\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fexperian-plc\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eexperian-plc\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E when lending money.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut the CFPB said TransUnion and Equifax falsely represented that the credit scores they sold to consumers were the same scores that lenders used.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Credit scores are central to a consumer&#8217;s financial life and people deserve honest and accurate information about them,&#8221; CFPB Director Richard Cordray said in a statement.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFor more on credit report companies, watch Fortune&#8217;s video:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp admitted or denied wrongdoing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETransUnion spokesman David Blumberg and Equifax spokeswoman Ines Gutzmer said their respective companies believe they have complied with applicable laws, and are committed to better educating consumers about their credit.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EExperian was not charged. A spokesman for the CFPB had no immediate additional comment.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETransUnion, Equifax and Experian are among the 10 companies about which the CFPB receives the most consumer complaints. Several large banks and mortgage lenders are also on that list.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn 2015, the credit reporting agencies agreed to improve how they fix mistakes and address disputes, under a separate settlement with 31 state attorneys general.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A U.S. regulator on Tuesday ordered credit reporting agencies TransUnion and Equifax ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"efx"},"content":[]}," to pay more than $23.2 million in fines and restitution for deceiving consumers about the usefulness and cost of credit scores they bought."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said the payments also resolve charges that TransUnion and Equifax lured consumers into enrolling in credit services advertised as free or costing only $1, but which could cost more than $200 a year."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["TransUnion will reimburse $13.93 million to consumers and pay a $3 million civil fine, while Equifax will reimburse $3.8 million and pay a $2.5 million civil fine, the CFPB said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Both companies will also modify their marketing practices, including by obtaining consent to enroll in credit-related services where fees kick in after free trials, and making it easier for consumers to cancel products they do not want."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The CFPB said the wrongful conduct had occurred at TransUnion since July 2011 and at Equifax between July 2011 and March 2014, and violated the Dodd-Frank financial reform law."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Many lenders rely on credit scores from TransUnion, Equifax and rival Experian Fines TransUnion And Equifax For Deceit Over Credit Scores","mt_seo_description":"A U.S. regulator ordered credit reporting agencies TransUnion and Equifax to pay more than $23.2 million in fines and Customers","og_title":"TransUnion And Equifax Fined $23 Million For Deceiving Customers","og_description":"Neither company admitted or denied wrongdoing.","twitter_text":"TransUnion and Equifax have been fined $23 million for deceiving customers over credit scores","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iBCDLZ","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Ftransunion-equinox-fined-credit-scores\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Ftransunion-equinox-fined-credit-scores\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893847,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fgettyimages-171223332.jpg","alt":"Excellent Credit Score","caption":"","credit":"courtneyk\u002FGetty Images","description":"Excellent Credit Score with pen and calculator","title":"Excellent Credit Score"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":446239758,"name":"credit reports","slug":"credit-reports","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":169514,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":2,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":4269,"name":"Finance","slug":"finance","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46730,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and analysis on the business of finance, including hedge funds, markets, mergers and acquisitions, private equity, venture capital, and Wall Street.","parent":0,"count":18937,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893164,"date":"2017-01-03T23:56:26","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T04:56:26","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893164"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T00:00:08","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T05:00:08","slug":"ford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j4OtBt","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Ford Cancels a $1.6 Billion Mexico Plant and Adds 700 Jobs in Michigan"},"content":{"plain":"Ford Motor Co f on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival General Motors Co with the threat of a &#8220;big border tax&#8221; over compact cars made in Mexico. Ford CEO Mark Fields called the move &#8220;a vote of confidence&#8221; in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. He said Ford would have made the same decision even if Trump had not been elected. Ford will cancel plans unveiled in April to spend $1.6 billion to build the new plant in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, a project Trump urged the automaker to abandon and called an &#8220;absolute disgrace&#8221; during the election campaign. The No. 2 U.S. automaker also said it would invest $700 million to expand the Flat Rock, Michigan factory and would make new electric, hybrid and autonomous vehicles there. Trump&#8217;s efforts to browbeat the U.S. car industry show he may go further than other modern presidents to try to influence corporate decisions, especially those related to trade and investment. In a Twitter post hours before Ford&#8217;s announcement, Trump wrote, &#8220;General Motors is sending Mexican made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border. Make in U.S.A. or pay big border tax!&#8221; GM, the largest U.S. automaker, said making some of the Cruze cars in the plant in Coahuila, Mexico was part of its strategy to serve global customers, not sell those vehicles in the United States. Trump&#8217;s GM tweet was his latest broadside aimed at an American company over jobs, imports and costs even before he takes office on Jan. 20. Mexico&#8217;s government said it regrets Ford&#8217;s decision and has ensured that the company will reimburse San Luis Potosi state for any costs associated with the investment. &#8220;Obviously, this isn&#8217;t a good decision for us,&#8221; said Mexico&#8217;s economy minister, Ildefonso Guajardo. Ford said it still will shift production from Michigan of its Focus compact car to an existing plant in Hermosillo, Mexico. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford&#8217;s investment in Flat Rock. Ford spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus. Ford shares closed up about 3.8 percent. GM shares rose about 0.9 percent. TRUMP NOTIFIED Top Ford executives personally notified Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence of their decision. Fields praised tax and regulatory proposals advocated by Trump and his fellow Republicans who control Congress. &#8220;Our view is that we see a more positive U.S. manufacturing business environment under President-elect Trump and the pro-growth policies and proposals that he&#8217;s talking about, so this is a vote of confidence for President-elect Trump and some of the policies that they may be pursuing,&#8221; Fields said. Union workers gathered at the Flat Rock factory cheered Fields&#8217; announcement. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said. Trump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. Trump also accused Mexico of sending criminals and rapists into the United States and vowed to build a border wall to combat illegal immigration. Since winning the Nov. 8 election, Trump has targeted a wide range of American companies also including United Technologies Inc, Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin Corp. Trump also has touted decisions by companies to keep some production in the United States, including United&#8217;s Carrier unit in Indiana. Trump previously vowed to hit companies that shift production from America to other countries with a 35 percent tax on their exports into the United States. He also has denounced the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada. Fields said there were no negotiations between Ford and the incoming president over canceling the Mexico plant or investing in Michigan. Ford will build a battery electric SUV with a 300-mile (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020. GM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. All of the sedan versions sold in the United States, about 185,500, were built at its Lordstown, Ohio plant. About 4,500 hatchback Cruze versions were assembled in Mexico and sold in the United States. This story has been updated. &nbsp;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFord Motor Co \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"f\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fford-motor-9\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ef\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgeneral-motors-8\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGeneral Motors\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Co with the threat of a &#8220;big border tax&#8221; over compact cars made in Mexico.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFord CEO Mark Fields called the move &#8220;a vote of confidence&#8221; in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford&#8217;s investment in Flat Rock.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFord spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFord shares closed up about 3.8 percent. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. All of the sedan versions sold in the United States, about 185,500, were built at its Lordstown, Ohio plant.
