HERE&#8217;s next generation mapping applications will be able to pinpoint a car&#8217;s location within centimeters, down from exactness in meters today, the company says. HERE&#8217;s current product offerings run the gamut from a consumer-oriented smartphone app called HERE WeGo to live traffic data that can be licensed and fed into car navigation systems, all built on top of its ecosystem of mapping data and related software tools.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe head of Intel&#8217;s automated driving group, Doug Davis, will join HERE&#8217;s supervisory board after the transaction is completed. The deal is expected to close before the end of the first quarter.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGoogle \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"googl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Egoogl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E has long dominated the market for digitally usable map and location data for portable devices, after it spent billions building its data sets. Apple had to play catch up after it created its own smartphone map app in 2012, relying on licensing data from Dutch provider TomTom.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut HERE started mapping the world three decades ago and built a strong position in the automotive market long before smartphones came along. Nokia \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"nok\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fnok\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Enok\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E bought the company, then known as Navteq, for $8 billion in 2007.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fintel-51\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Intel"]}," bought 15% of digital mapping service HERE on Tuesday as the chipmaker wades further into the market for self-driving cars and other autonomous devices."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Intel joins HERE's current owners\u2014carmakers Audi, BMW, and Daimler\u2014in their efforts to build a vast global map and location database that doesn't rely on information from ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Apple"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"aapl"},"content":[]}," or ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Google"]},". Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has targeted making chips and sensors for self-driving cars, automated robots, and AI-enhanced drones as one of the company's new growth market."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The carmakers bought HERE from Nokia in 2015 for $3 billion. Intel ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"intc"},"content":[]}," declined to disclose how much it paid for its 15% stake."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", Fortune's technology newsletter."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Cars are rapidly becoming some of the world\u2019s most intelligent, connected devices,\" Krzanich said in a statement. \"We look forward to working with HERE and its automotive partners to deliver an important technology foundation for smart and connected cars of the future.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Intel's aim is to help the car makers create much more robust and detailed mapping hardware and software that will be needed for truly autonomous vehicles. HERE's next generation mapping applications will be able to pinpoint a car's location within centimeters, down from exactness in meters today, the company says. HERE's current product offerings run the gamut from a consumer-oriented smartphone app called HERE WeGo to live traffic data that can be licensed and fed into car navigation systems, all built on top of its ecosystem of mapping data and related software tools."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The head of Intel's automated driving group, Doug Davis, will join HERE's supervisory board after the transaction is completed. Nokia Oyj, the world's biggest mobile-phone company, agreed to buy Navteq Corp. for $8.1billion to gain digital maps of 69 countries and compete with TomTom NV in the market for navigation devices.","title":"A Garmin GPS device displays Navteq software at a Best Buy s"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":366068442,"name":"The Mobile Executive","slug":"the-mobile-executive","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":133921,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":402,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1886811,"date":"2016-12-31T10:00:43","date_gmt":"2016-12-31T15:00:43","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1886811"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-31T10:00:44","modified_gmt":"2016-12-31T15:00:44","slug":"career-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Fcareer-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2gVgMg4","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"The Best Career Advice of 2016"},"content":{"plain":"Every day at Fortune, influential leaders, entrepreneurs, and Fortune 500 executives offer valuable insight from their experiences navigating the business world. We\u2019ve compiled some of our favorite pieces of career advice published in 2016: Sarah Kauss, founder and CEO of S\u2019well: Delegation can sometimes come off as negative\u2014like you\u2019re just pushing off work on someone else\u2014but it doesn\u2019t have to be perceived that way. Don\u2019t just say \u201cno\u201d to a request. You should, in fact, pass it along when you\u2019re too busy. And that\u2019s not a bad thing. Think of the opportunity you are giving others. A conference organizer may not always want your senior vice president when the founder or CEO can\u2019t make the event. But if you show that you trust someone else with an opportunity\u200a\u2014\u200asuch as establishing your company\u2019s brand reputation\u200a\u2014\u200ayou may be surprised by the positive reactions you\u2019ll receive. Dennis Yang, CEO of Udemy: Hiring begins with the job description itself, which needs to reflect the position\u2019s real requirements and responsibilities. Too many companies go forth in search of a left-handed, purple unicorn: that elusive individual who possesses mastery in a broad range of skills and can single-handedly do the job of many people. Unfortunately, unicorns don\u2019t exist. Companies that think they\u2019ve hired one stand to be disappointed, and candidates who represent themselves as such are either on the fast track to burnout or are overselling themselves. Your job listings need to be realistic in order to attract real candidates and give your interviewers tangible evaluation criteria. Amber Theorharis, host for the NFL Network: When [a] job opens, take it\u2014even if the salary is low. Success doesn\u2019t happen overnight, and there\u2019s nothing wrong with starting at the bottom. That\u2019s where you make mistakes that will be the least devastating to your professional reputation\u2014and you can still learn from them. The money and the position will come later, but you have to get in the game. Take a side job to pay the bills if your career can\u2019t. I waited tables after work and on weekends for almost two years while working on-air at a small TV station in Salisbury, Md. My dream was bigger than my pride. &nbsp; Jeremy Roche, president and CEO of FinancialForce: I can\u2019t express enough how important it is to throw your ego out the door. When you jump into a new career or position, there is a 100% chance you will make mistakes. No matter how much experience you have and how high up the ranks you were, when you start a new job, you will have to prove yourself all over again. And while that might sound daunting, you have to stay positive. Embrace the unknown and be willing to go back to the basics of learning new skills. This experience can build empathy, truly enhancing your leadership skills in the long run. Kim Metcalf-Kupres, vice president and chief marketing officer of Johnson Controls: Fight for change when it matters and learn to let lesser issues roll off. While gender parity continues to improve in traditionally male-dominated fields, the reality is that we all have preconceived perceptions of how things should be, and culture change does not happen overnight. In these moments, especially if they involve unconscious bias, it is essential to educate others and provide your perspective in a kind and respectful manner. Don\u2019t sweat the small stuff.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EEvery day at Fortune, influential leaders, entrepreneurs, and Fortune 500 executives offer valuable insight from their experiences navigating the business world. No matter how much experience you have and how high up the ranks you were, when you start a new job, you will have to prove yourself all over again.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EAnd while that might sound daunting, you have to stay positive. Embrace the unknown and be willing to go back to the basics of learning new skills. This experience can build empathy, truly enhancing your leadership skills in the long run.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EKim Metcalf-Kupres, vice president and chief marketing officer of \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EJohnson Controls\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E:\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFight for change when it matters and learn to let lesser issues roll off. While gender parity continues to improve in traditionally male-dominated fields, the reality is that we all have preconceived perceptions of how things should be, and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F10\u002Fhired-career-advice-employer-bias\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eculture change does not happen overnight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. In these moments, especially if they involve unconscious bias, it is essential to educate others and provide your perspective in a kind and respectful manner. Don\u2019t sweat the small stuff.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Every day at Fortune, influential leaders, entrepreneurs, and Fortune 500 executives offer valuable insight from their experiences navigating the business world. We\u2019ve compiled some of our favorite pieces of career advice published in 2016:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Sarah Kauss, founder and CEO of "]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["S\u2019well"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":[":"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Delegation can sometimes come off as negative\u2014like you\u2019re just pushing off work on someone else\u2014",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finsiders.fortune.com\u002Fhow-to-say-no-and-still-be-liked-6c3e9154a2b5#.asilujqg6","target":"_blank"},"content":["but it doesn\u2019t have to be perceived that way"]},". Don\u2019t just say \u201cno\u201d to a request. You should, in fact, pass it along when you\u2019re too busy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And that\u2019s not a bad thing. Think of the opportunity you are giving others. A conference organizer may not always want your senior vice president when the founder or CEO can\u2019t make the event. But if you show that you trust someone else with an opportunity\u200a\u2014\u200asuch as establishing your company\u2019s brand reputation\u200a\u2014\u200ayou may be surprised by the positive reactions you\u2019ll receive."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Dennis Yang, CEO of"]}]}," ",{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Udemy"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[":"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Hiring begins with the job description itself, which needs to reflect the position\u2019s real requirements and responsibilities. Too many companies go forth in search of a left-handed, purple unicorn: that elusive individual who possesses mastery in a broad range of skills and can single-handedly do the job of many people."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Unfortunately, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finsiders.fortune.com\u002Fheres-why-you-can-t-always-trust-your-gut-9883f40f7f24#.kbxkrr6os","target":"_blank"},"content":["unicorns don\u2019t exist"]},". Companies that think they\u2019ve hired one stand to be disappointed, and candidates who represent themselves as such are either on the fast track to burnout or are overselling themselves. Your job listings need to be realistic in order to attract real candidates and give your interviewers tangible evaluation criteria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Amber Theorharis, host for the "]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["NFL Network"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":[":"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When [a] job opens, take it\u2014even if the salary is low. Success doesn\u2019t happen overnight, and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F14\u002Fnfl-network-career-advice-women-business\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["there\u2019s nothing wrong with starting at the bottom"]},". That\u2019s where you make mistakes that will be the least devastating to your professional reputation\u2014and you can still learn from them. The money and the position will come later, but you have to get in the game. Take a side job to pay the bills if your career can\u2019t. I waited tables after work and on weekends for almost two years while working on-air at a small TV station in Salisbury, Md. My dream was bigger than my pride."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5237616320001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Jeremy Roche, president and CEO of "]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["FinancialForce"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":[":"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I can\u2019t express enough how important it is to ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finsiders.fortune.com\u002F5-tips-for-landing-a-job-you-didnt-go-to-school-for-951ee1e100a0#.iap5br93m","target":"_blank"},"content":["throw your ego out the door"]},". When you jump into a new career or position, there is a 100% chance you will make mistakes. No matter how much experience you have and how high up the ranks you were, when you start a new job, you will have to prove yourself all over again."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And while that might sound daunting, you have to stay positive. Embrace the unknown and be willing to go back to the basics of learning new skills. This experience can build empathy, truly enhancing your leadership skills in the long run."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Kim Metcalf-Kupres, vice president and chief marketing officer of "]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Johnson Controls"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":[":"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fight for change when it matters and learn to let lesser issues roll off. While gender parity continues to improve in traditionally male-dominated fields, the reality is that we all have preconceived perceptions of how things should be, and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F10\u002Fhired-career-advice-employer-bias\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["culture change does not happen overnight"]},". In these moments, especially if they involve unconscious bias, it is essential to educate others and provide your perspective in a kind and respectful manner. Don\u2019t sweat the small stuff."]}]},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EInfluential leaders weigh in from their experience in the business world.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":89113420,"featured_media":1886831,"parent":0,"menu_order":0,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"open","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=1886811"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=1886811"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1886811\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u networks.","mt_seo_keywords":"career advice, leadership, entrepreneurs, most powerful women, fortune 500, saying no, hiring, internship, workplace bias, finding a job","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"career advice, leadership, entrepreneurs, most powerful women, fortune 500, saying no, hiring, internship, workplace bias, finding a job","short_title":"The Best Career Advice of 2016","og_title":"The Best Career Advice of 2016","twitter_text":"The best career advice of 2016","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Fcareer-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Fcareer-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1886831,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Foverhead-business-people-gettyimages-520791880.jpg","alt":"Overhead and using a tablet computer","title":"overhead career advice"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":97521,"name":"Career Advice","slug":"career-advice","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":111260,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":127,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":291878719,"name":"Fortune Insiders","slug":"fortune-insiders","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":122920,"taxonomy":"category","description":"","parent":0,"count":2701,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1885451,"date":"2016-12-30T09:30:45","date_gmt":"2016-12-30T14:30:45","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1885451"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-30T09:30:47","modified_gmt":"2016-12-30T14:30:47","slug":"best-stocks-fortune-500-companies-2016","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fbest-stocks-fortune-500-companies-2016\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2gTKcA4","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"The Fortune 500\u2019s 7 Best-Performing Stocks of 2016"},"content":{"plain":"For 2016\u2019s best-performing Fortune 500 stocks, you can definitely call it a comeback. In a year when the S&amp;P 500 has gained a solid 10%, these Fortune 500 companies ran circles around that return: All of the stocks on this list at least doubled their share prices in 2016, and the top two winners each more than quadrupled. Still, you won\u2019t find any high-growth tech companies on this list. Most of this year&#8217;s big winners come from unsexy industries beset by struggles from which these firms are just starting to emerge. Three are steel companies whose stocks took off after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, prompting hopes of a wave of new spending on infrastructure. Also, although Fortune 500 members are, by definition, the largest companies in the U.S. by revenue, none of this year&#8217;s top gainers was among the very biggest of the big. Indeed, six of the top 10 performers come from the bottom half of the 500 list. Even though they may no longer be underdogs, the stocks of many of 2016\u2019s best performers remain well below their all-time highs, and several still look cheap. So even if you missed out on a four-bagger return this year, there may be more rallies to come for some of these stocks in 2017. Here&#8217;s the full list of 2016\u2019s biggest Fortune 500 stock winners. 1. AK Steel Holding Fortune 500 rank: No. 383 2016 return: 359% Courtesy of AK Steel Holding Iron ore and steel prices fell precipitously in 2015 on slowing demand for construction material in China. But they bounced back forcefully after hitting bottom in early 2016, as steel producers cut production dramatically. After several years of losses, AK Steel aks is expected to turn a profit in 2016, as the company continued to cut costs while also benefiting from higher prices. Still, the steepest jump in AK Steel\u2019s stock price came after Trump won the election: AK\u2019s shares are up more than 74% since Nov. 8. Not only is the Trump administration likely to green-light more infrastructure projects that will rely on heavy materials such as steel, the President-elect has signaled that he will enact trade policies that make imported steel less attractive while tipping the scales toward U.S. producers. Oh, and it doesn\u2019t hurt that Trump\u2019s nominee for secretary of commerce is Wilbur Ross, the founder and former CEO of a major steel company. \u201cTrump\u2019s impact on trade and therefore domestic steel supply and prices could be much quicker and more meaningful than Trump\u2019s infrastructure plans,\u201d write J.P. Morgan analysts, who rate AK Steel &#8220;overweight&#8221; (that is, a buy). 2.United States Steel Fortune 500 rank: No. 244 2016 return: 332% Courtesy of United States Steel Like AK Steel&#8217;s shares, United States Steel x stock surged this year as steel prices rose, then accelerated further after Trump\u2019s victory (gaining more than 70% since the election). U.S. Steel doesn\u2019t have quite as much leeway to cut costs as smaller peers like AK. That makes it extremely sensitive to steel prices\u2014and also makes it the American steel stock that could benefit the most from a recovery in that market, according to J.P. Morgan. As the amount of steel imported from China continues to decline and domestic production stays in check, the price of the metal will likely keep going up\u2014sending U.S. Steel even higher. 3. Navistar International Fortune 500 rank: No. 281 2016 return: 236% Mahindra Navistar trucks at a factory in Maharashtra, India.(Kuni Takahashi\u002FBloomberg) This year\u2019s rally in Navistar\u2019s stock\u2014which more than tripled in 2016\u2014has almost (but not quite) made up for its terrible 2015, when the shares fell 74%. Navistar nav , which makes diesel engines and trucks, took a costly wrong turn a few years ago when it tried and failed to develop its own emissions-reducing system to meet new Environmental Protection Agency standards. In March, it had to pay $7.5 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it misled shareholders about its technology\u2019s capability to cut emissions. While the end of that investigation popped the lid off Navistar\u2019s stock price, the tipping point came just after Labor Day, when Volkswagen\u2014a company that faced its own (much larger) emissions scandal\u2014announced it was taking a nearly 17% stake in the company. Navistar\u2019s shares surged 41% in a single day on the news. Other investors in the company include high-profile activist Carl Icahn. 4. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Fortune 500 rank: No. 16 (Fannie Mae) and No. 43 (Freddie Mac) 2016 return: 140% (Fannie Mae) and 136% (Freddie Mac) Fannie Mae headquarters in Washington, D.C.Photograph by Kevin Lamarque \u2014 Reuters We&#8217;ve lumped these two stocks together here because their businesses, their recent stock performance and their near-term outlooks are close to identical. Prior to the presidential election, Fannie&#8217;s and Freddie\u2019s share prices were pretty much flat for 2016. But that all changed when Trump won the White House: Both Fannie Mae fnma and Freddie Mac fmcc stock have more than doubled since the Nov. 8 vote. The reason is fairly straightforward: Trump\u2019s treasury secretary pick, former Goldman Sachs banker Steven Mnuchin, suggested privatizing Fannie and Freddie, which have been under government control since the mortgage lenders received a giant bailout during the financial crisis. That outcome would be a far cry from what was expected just a few years ago, when Fannie and Freddie\u2019s shares were worth just pennies as the government indicated that it would eventually phase them out entirely. Privatizing the quasi-governmental companies would also a huge boon to a growing contingent of hedge fund speculators, who have invested in the pair and advocated that the government allow the companies to keep more of their own profits. One indication of Fannie and Freddie\u2019s wild ride since the Great Recession? They were the top two best-performing Fortune 500 stocks in 2013, returning more than 1000% each, only to land on the list of worst performers the following year. 5.Oneok Fortune 500 rank: No. 348 2016 return: 135.6% Courtesy of Oneok An Oklahoma-based natural gas production and pipeline company, Oneok oke struggled when that commodity\u2019s price fell along with oil prices starting a couple of years ago: Oneok stock was down 46% in 2015. But as natural gas prices surged this year, Oneok\u2019s shares more than doubled. Still, they have yet to recover to where they were trading at their peak in the summer of 2014. 6. Freeport-McMoRan Fortune 500 rank: No. 175 2016 return: 106% Copper-gold concentrate from Freeport McMoRan Inc.&#8217;s Grasberg copper and gold mine is loaded onto a ship in Amamapare, Papua province, Indonesia.Dadang Tri\u2014Bloomberg After a five-year bear market in precious metals including gold, silver and copper\u2014all of which Freeport-McMoRan fcx produces at its mines\u2014the prices of those commodities rallied in 2016 as supply came down closer in line with demand. Trump\u2019s election win gave copper an additional kick, with investors believing that his administration\u2019s expected infrastructure projects will need to rely on that building material. Freeport had suffered particularly in recent years from its decision to diversify into the oil business\u2014at what turned out to be exactly the wrong time, as prices plummeted. It sold off some of its energy business this year, relieving it of some of the debt it had taken on in the process. Still, Freeport maintains substantial operations in that area that will benefit if oil prices continue to rise. 7.Steel Dynamics Fortune 500 rank: No. 356 2016 return: 100% Courtesy of Steel Dynamics Unlike its fellow steelmakers on this list\u2014AK Steel and United States Steel\u2014Steel Dynamics stld managed to ride out steel&#8217;s 2015 price downturn relatively unscathed: Its stock price only shed about 7% last year. The company also stayed profitable, generating hefty free cash flow. Still, Steel Dynamics still got a major boost from rising prices this year. And it&#8217;s particularly well positioned to profit from increasing demand for steel, as the company has greatly expanded the amount it can produce since the 2008 financial crisis.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor 2016\u2019s best-performing \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 stocks, you can definitely call it a comeback.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a year when the S&amp;P 500 has gained a solid 10%, these \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 companies ran circles around that return: All of the stocks on this list at least doubled their share prices in 2016, and the top two winners each more than quadrupled.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, you won\u2019t find any high-growth tech companies on this list. Most of this year&#8217;s big winners come from unsexy industries beset by struggles from which these firms are just starting to emerge. Three are steel companies whose stocks took off after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, prompting hopes of a wave of new spending on infrastructure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAlso, although \u003Cem\u003EFortune \u003C\u002Fem\u003E500 members are, by definition, the largest companies in the U.S. by revenue, none of this year&#8217;s top gainers was among the very biggest of the big. Indeed, six of the top 10 performers come from the bottom half of the 500 list.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEven though they may no longer be underdogs, the stocks of many of 2016\u2019s best performers remain well below their all-time highs, and several still look cheap. So even if you missed out on a four-bagger return this year, there may be more rallies to come for some of these stocks in 2017.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s the full list of 2016\u2019s biggest \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 stock winners.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1. \u003Ca \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 359%\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width alignnone\"  \u003E\u003Ca https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fak-steel-holding.jpg?w=150&amp;h=100 150w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fak-steel-holding.jpg?w=300&amp;h=200 300w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fak-steel-holding.jpg?w=768&amp;h=512 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003ECourtesy of AK Steel Holding\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIron ore and steel prices fell precipitously in 2015 on slowing demand for construction material in China. But they bounced back forcefully after hitting bottom in early 2016, as steel producers cut production dramatically. After several years of losses, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAK Steel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"aks\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eaks\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E is expected to turn a profit in 2016, as the company continued to cut costs while also benefiting from higher prices.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, the steepest jump in AK Steel\u2019s stock price came after Trump won the election: AK\u2019s shares are up more than 74% since Nov. 8. Not only is the Trump administration likely to green-light more infrastructure projects that will rely on heavy materials such as steel, the President-elect has signaled that he will enact trade policies that make imported steel less attractive while tipping the scales toward U.S. producers. Oh, and it doesn\u2019t hurt that Trump\u2019s nominee for secretary of commerce is Wilbur Ross, the founder and former CEO of a major steel company.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cTrump\u2019s impact on trade and therefore domestic steel supply and prices could be much quicker and more meaningful than Trump\u2019s infrastructure plans,\u201d write \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjpmorgan-chase-23\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJ.P. Morgan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E analysts, who rate AK Steel &#8220;overweight&#8221; (that is, a buy).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2.\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EUnited States Steel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFortune 500 rank: No. 244\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 332%\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width alignnone\"  \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Funited-states-steel.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003ECourtesy of United States Steel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELike AK Steel&#8217;s shares, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EUnited States Steel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"x\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ex\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E stock surged this year as steel prices rose, then accelerated further after Trump\u2019s victory (gaining more than 70% since the election). U.S. Steel doesn\u2019t have quite as much leeway to cut costs as smaller peers like AK. That makes it extremely sensitive to steel prices\u2014and also makes it the American steel stock that could benefit the most from a recovery in that market, according to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjpmorgan-chase-23\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJ.P. Morgan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. As the amount of steel imported from China continues to decline and domestic production stays in check, the price of the metal will likely keep going up\u2014sending U.S. Steel even higher.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENavistar International\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 281\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 236%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\"\u003EMahindra Navistar trucks at a factory in Maharashtra, India.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003E(Kuni Takahashi\u002FBloomberg)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis year\u2019s rally in Navistar\u2019s stock\u2014which more than tripled in 2016\u2014has almost (but not quite) made up for its terrible 2015, when the shares fell 74%. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENavistar\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"nav\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Enav\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, which makes diesel engines and trucks, took a costly wrong turn a few years ago when it tried and failed to develop its own emissions-reducing system to meet new Environmental Protection Agency standards. In March, it had to pay $7.5 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it misled shareholders about its technology\u2019s capability to cut emissions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile the end of that investigation popped the lid off Navistar\u2019s stock price, the tipping point came just after Labor Day, when Volkswagen\u2014a company that faced its own (much larger) emissions scandal\u2014announced it was taking a nearly 17% stake in the company. Navistar\u2019s shares surged 41% in a single day on the news. Other investors in the company include high-profile activist Carl Icahn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E4. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFannie Mae\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFreddie Mac\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 16 (Fannie Mae) and No. 43 (Freddie Mac)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 140% (Fannie Mae) and 136% (Freddie Mac)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width aligncenter\"  \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Ffannie-mae.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1324383\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002F22\u002Ffannie-mae-lund\u002Fa-man-stands-outside-fannie-mae-in-washington\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Ffannie-mae.jpg?w=840&#038;h=487\" data-orig-size=\"840,487\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;\\u00a9 Kevin Lamarque \\\u002F Reuters&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;A stands outside Fannie Mae headquarters in Washington February 21, 2014. Fannie Mae said on Friday it would soon send the U.S. Treasury $7.2 billion, a profit-related dividend that makes taxpayers whole for the 2008 bailout of the mortgage-finance giant and its sibling company Freddie Mac.\\r\\rREUTERS\\\u002FKevin Lamarque  (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS REAL ESTATE) - \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\"\u003EFannie Mae headquarters in Washington, D.C.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003EPhotograph by Kevin Lamarque \u2014 Reuters\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe&#8217;ve lumped these two stocks together here because their businesses, their recent stock performance and their near-term outlooks are close to identical.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPrior to the presidential election, Fannie&#8217;s and Freddie\u2019s share prices were pretty much flat for 2016. But that all changed when Trump won the White House: Both \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFannie Mae\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"fnma\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Efnma\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFreddie Mac\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"fmcc\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Efmcc\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E stock have more than doubled since the Nov. 8 vote.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe reason is fairly straightforward: Trump\u2019s treasury secretary pick, former \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgoldman-sachs-group-74\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoldman Sachs\u003C\u002Fa\u003E banker Steven Mnuchin, suggested privatizing Fannie and Freddie, which have been under government control since the mortgage lenders received a giant bailout during the financial crisis. That outcome would be a far cry from what was expected just a few years ago, when Fannie and Freddie\u2019s shares were worth just pennies as the government indicated that it would eventually phase them out entirely. Privatizing the quasi-governmental companies would also a huge boon to a growing contingent of hedge fund speculators, who have invested in the pair and advocated that the government allow the companies to keep more of their own profits.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne indication of Fannie and Freddie\u2019s wild ride since the Great Recession? They were the top two best-performing \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 stocks in 2013, returning more than 1000% each, only to land on the list of worst performers the following year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E5.\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Foneok-348\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EOneok\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 348\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 135.6%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width alignnone\"  \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Foneok.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1892024\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fbest-stocks-fortune-500-companies-2016\u002Foneok-4\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Foneok.jpg?w=1024&#038;h=683\" data-orig-size=\"2880,1920\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" commodities rallied in 2016 as supply came down closer in line with demand. Trump\u2019s election win gave copper an additional kick, with investors believing that his administration\u2019s expected infrastructure projects will need to rely on that building material.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFreeport had suffered particularly in recent years from its decision to diversify into the oil business\u2014at what turned out to be exactly the wrong time, as prices plummeted. It sold off some of its energy business this year, relieving it of some of the debt it had taken on in the process. Most of this year's big winners come from unsexy industries beset by struggles from which these firms are just starting to emerge. Three are steel companies whose stocks took off after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, prompting hopes of a wave of new spending on infrastructure."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Also, although ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune "]},"500 members are, by definition, the largest companies in the U.S. by revenue, none of this year's top gainers was among the very biggest of the big. Indeed, six of the top 10 performers come from the bottom half of the 500 list."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Even though they may no longer be underdogs, the stocks of many of 2016\u2019s best performers remain well below their all-time highs, and several still look cheap. So even if you missed out on a four-bagger return this year, there may be more rallies to come for some of these stocks in 2017."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Here's the full list of 2016\u2019s biggest ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]}," 500 stock winners."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["1. After several years of losses, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["AK Steel"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"aks"},"content":[]}," is expected to turn a profit in 2016, as the company continued to cut costs while also benefiting from higher prices."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Still, the steepest jump in AK Steel\u2019s stock price came after Trump won the election: AK\u2019s shares are up more than 74% since Nov. 8. Not only is the Trump administration likely to green-light more infrastructure projects that will rely on heavy materials such as steel, the President-elect has signaled that he will enact trade policies that make imported steel less attractive while tipping the scales toward U.S. producers. Oh, and it doesn\u2019t hurt that Trump\u2019s nominee for secretary of commerce is Wilbur Ross, the founder and former CEO of a major steel company."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\u201cTrump\u2019s impact on trade and therefore domestic steel supply and prices could be much quicker and more meaningful than Trump\u2019s infrastructure plans,\u201d write ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjpmorgan-chase-23\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["J.P. Morgan"]}," analysts, who rate AK Steel \"overweight\" (that is, a buy)."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["2.",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["United States Steel"]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]}]},{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune 500 rank: No. 244",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"2016 return: 332%"]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1","align":"alignnone","width":"1024"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Funited-states-steel.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Funited-states-steel.jpg","alt":"For Matt Heimer- United States Steel","width":"1024","height":"683"},"content":[]}]}," ",{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Courtesy of United States Steel"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Like AK Steel's shares, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["United States Steel"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"x"},"content":[]}," stock surged this year as steel prices rose, then accelerated further after Trump\u2019s victory (gaining more than 70% since the election). U.S. Steel doesn\u2019t have quite as much leeway to cut costs as smaller peers like AK. That makes it extremely sensitive to steel prices\u2014and also makes it the American steel stock that could benefit the most from a recovery in that market, according to ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjpmorgan-chase-23\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["J.P. Morgan"]},". As the amount of steel imported from China continues to decline and domestic production stays in check, the price of the metal will likely keep going up\u2014sending U.S. Steel even higher."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["3. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Navistar"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"nav"},"content":[]},", which makes diesel engines and trucks, took a costly wrong turn a few years ago when it tried and failed to develop its own emissions-reducing system to meet new Environmental Protection Agency standards. In March, it had to pay $7.5 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it misled shareholders about its technology\u2019s capability to cut emissions."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["While the end of that investigation popped the lid off Navistar\u2019s stock price, the tipping point came just after Labor Day, when Volkswagen\u2014a company that faced its own (much larger) emissions scandal\u2014announced it was taking a nearly 17% stake in the company. Navistar\u2019s shares surged 41% in a single day on the news. Other investors in the company include high-profile activist Carl Icahn."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["4. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Fannie Mae"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Freddie Mac"]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"Fortune 500 rank: No. 16 (Fannie Mae) and No. 43 (Freddie Mac)",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"2016 return: 140% (Fannie Mae) and 136% (Freddie Mac)",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1324383","align":"aligncenter","width":"840"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Ffannie-mae.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Ffannie-mae.jpg","alt":"","width":"840","height":"487"},"content":[]}]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Fannie Mae headquarters in Washington, D.C."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Photograph by Kevin Lamarque \u2014 Reuters"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We've lumped these two stocks together here because their businesses, their recent stock performance and their near-term outlooks are close to identical."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Prior to the presidential election, Fannie's and Freddie\u2019s share prices were pretty much flat for 2016. But that all changed when Trump won the White House: Both ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Fannie Mae"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"fnma"},"content":[]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Freddie Mac"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"fmcc"},"content":[]}," stock have more than doubled since the Nov. 8 vote."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The reason is fairly straightforward: Trump\u2019s treasury secretary pick, former ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgoldman-sachs-group-74\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Goldman Sachs"]}," banker Steven Mnuchin, suggested privatizing Fannie and Freddie, which have been under government control since the mortgage lenders received a giant bailout during the financial crisis. That outcome would be a far cry from what was expected just a few years ago, when Fannie and Freddie\u2019s shares were worth just pennies as the government indicated that it would eventually phase them out entirely. Privatizing the quasi-governmental companies would also a huge boon to a growing contingent of hedge fund speculators, who have invested in the pair and advocated that the government allow the companies to keep more of their own profits."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["One indication of Fannie and Freddie\u2019s wild ride since the Great Recession? They were the top two best-performing ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]}," 500 stocks in 2013, returning more than 1000% each, only to land on the list of worst performers the following year."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["5.",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Foneok-348\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Oneok"]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"Fortune 500 rank: No. 348",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"2016 return: 135.6%",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1","align":"alignnone","width":"1024"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Foneok.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Foneok.jpg","alt":"For Matt Heimer- Oneok","width":"1024","height":"683"},"content":[]}]}," ",{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Courtesy of Oneok"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["An Oklahoma-based natural gas production and pipeline company, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Foneok-348\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Oneok"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"oke"},"content":[]}," struggled when that commodity\u2019s price fell along with oil prices starting a couple of years ago: Oneok stock was down 46% in 2015. But as natural gas prices surged this year, Oneok\u2019s shares more than doubled. Still, they have yet to recover to where they were trading at their peak in the summer of 2014."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["6. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreeport-mcmoran-175\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Freeport-McMoRan"]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"Fortune 500 rank: No. 175",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"2016 return: 106%",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1690302","align":"aligncenter","width":"1024"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F471414456.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F471414456.jpg","alt":"Operations At Freeport-McMoRan Inc.&#039;s Grasberg Gold And Copper Mine","width":"1024","height":"683"},"content":[]}]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Copper-gold concentrate from Freeport McMoRan Inc.'s Grasberg copper and gold mine is loaded onto a ship in Amamapare, Papua province, Indonesia."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Dadang Tri\u2014Bloomberg"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["After a five-year bear market in precious metals including gold, silver and copper\u2014all of which ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreeport-mcmoran-175\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Freeport-McMoRan"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"fcx"},"content":[]}," produces at its mines\u2014the prices of those commodities rallied in 2016 as supply came down closer in line with demand. Trump\u2019s election win gave copper an additional kick, with investors believing that his administration\u2019s expected infrastructure projects will need to rely on that building material."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Freeport had suffered particularly in recent years from its decision to diversify into the oil business\u2014at what turned out to be exactly the wrong time, as prices plummeted. It sold off some of its energy business this year, relieving it of some of the debt it had taken on in the process. Still, Freeport maintains substantial operations in that area that will benefit if oil prices continue to rise."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["7.",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsteel-dynamics-356\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Steel Dynamics"]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"Fortune 500 rank: No. 356",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},"2016 return: 100%",{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1","align":"alignnone","width":"1024"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fsteel-dynamics.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fsteel-dynamics.jpg","alt":"For Matt Heimer- Steel Dynamics","width":"1024","height":"683"},"content":[]}]}," ",{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Courtesy of Steel Dynamics"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Unlike its fellow steelmakers on this list\u2014AK Steel and United States Steel\u2014",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsteel-dynamics-356\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Steel Dynamics"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"stld"},"content":[]}," managed to ride out steel's 2015 price downturn relatively unscathed: Its stock price only shed about 7% last year. The company also stayed profitable, generating hefty free cash flow."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Still, Steel Dynamics still got a major boost from rising prices this year. Trump FCC Pick Has Not Battled Net Neutrality Rules"},"content":{"plain":"The incoming administration of President-elect Donald Trump named another person to its transition team overseeing the Federal Communications Commission. And unlike past picks, this one has no record of criticizing net neutrality, the 2015 rules that prevent Internet service providers from slowing or blocking online content and services. David Morken, co-founder of Republic Wireless and an entrepreneur from Raleigh, N.C., will join three prior Trump FCC transition team members in helping set policies at the agency that regulates telecommunications, cable TV, and the Internet, Politico reported on Thursday. But unlike previous Trump FCC transition picks, Morken has no obvious and widespread record of speaking out against the agency&#8217;s moves in 2015 to protect competition on the Internet through net neutrality rules. Companies like AT&amp;T t and Verizon have complained that the rules over-regulate the industry and deter investment in networks. Rather, Morken was quoted in the Wall Street Journal on Dec. 9 expressing concern about the tilt of some of the earlier picks. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. &#8220;Traditional Republican telecom policy has favored incumbents who are heavily engaged in regulatory capture over innovators like us,&#8221; Morken was quoted saying in article about Trump&#8217;s expected FCC policies to demolish regulations that protect smaller players. Morken told the paper he was a lifelong Republican, but in &#8220;every election I have to choose between voting personal conviction or business interests.&#8221; Fortune contacted Morken for comment and will update this story if we receive a response. Trump&#8217;s first three picks had ties to the largest companies in the telecom sector and had written publicly against the FCC&#8217;s rules on net neutrality. For more on the net neutrality battle, watch: Jeff Eisenach, an economist who has been on Verizon\u2019s vz payroll, and Mark Jamison, who formerly worked on Sprint\u2019s s lobbying team and now heads the University of Florida\u2019s Public Utility Research Center, opposed the net neutrality rules and other policies of the FCC under Obama appointee Tom Wheeler. A third appointee, Roslyn Layton is a telecom industry consultant and visiting fellow at the American Enterprise Institute who has opposed both net neutrality and Internet privacy rules. The two current Republican members of the FCC, Ajit Pai and Michael O&#8217;Rielly, have said rolling back the net neutrality rules will be a top priority next year. They will constitute a majority at the agency once Wheeler steps down, as he has pledged to do next month.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe incoming administration of President-elect Donald Trump named another person to its transition team overseeing the Federal Communications Commission. And unlike past picks, this one has no record of criticizing net neutrality, the 2015 rules that prevent Internet service providers from slowing or blocking online content and services."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["David Morken, co-founder of Republic Wireless and an entrepreneur from Raleigh, N.C., will join three prior Trump FCC transition team members in helping set policies at the agency that regulates telecommunications, cable TV, and the Internet, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.politicopro.com\u002Ftech\u002Fwhiteboard\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Ftrump-transition-taps-more-ftc-fcc-aides-081467"},"content":["Politico reported"]}," on Thursday."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But unlike previous Trump FCC transition picks, Morken has no obvious and widespread record of speaking out against the agency's moves in 2015 to protect competition on the Internet through net neutrality rules. transition","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Ftrump-fcc-morken-net-neutrality\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Ftrump-fcc-morken-net-neutrality\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":995500,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F458761428.jpg","alt":"Internet Obama's comments tilt the White House against positions advocated by broadband providers and FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. Photographer: Andrew Harrer\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","title":"Internet Providers Should Guarantee Equal Access to All Users, Obama Says"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":52999,"name":"Verizon","slug":"verizon","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":59466,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":379,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1886366,"date":"2016-12-29T12:00:12","date_gmt":"2016-12-29T17:00:12","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1886366"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-29T12:46:48","modified_gmt":"2016-12-29T17:46:48","slug":"amazon-web-services-2017-outlook","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Famazon-web-services-2017-outlook\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hN1Hly","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Expect Amazon\u2019s Cloud to See Hotter Competition in 2017"},"content":{"plain":"Over the last decade, Amazon Web Services has become the focal point of every tech company, most of which are now fighting to build their own public clouds. That includes computing pioneer IBM ibm , database giant Oracle orcl and software behemoth Microsoft. Not even Amazon&#8217;s biggest rivals can question the success of AWS of late. For it&#8217;s most recently reported quarter, the cloud computing arm of Amazon reported revenue of $3.2 billion, up 55% year over year, putting it at a close-to $13 billion annual revenue run rate going into 2017. Perhaps more importantly for those who insisted that AWS was a loss-leader for its parent company, the cloud unit reported profit of $1.02 billion for that period, at least if employee stock compensation is excluded. With that compensation factored in, profit was a still-healthy $821 million, up from $428 million from the year before. But 2017 will not be a walk in the park for Amazon amzn largely because at least some of those tech rivals mentioned above have gotten their acts together, building data centers worldwide, and investing heavily in their public cloud services. Microsoft msft , in particular, has been making progress, says Dave Bartoletti, principal analyst for Forrester Research forr . Microsoft Azure is now a strong number two in public cloud while Google goog , IBM ibm , and others battle it out for the number three slot, in his view. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. In the face of that heightened competition, Amazon must continue to appeal to its core base of developers at small companies, who started flocking to its services ten years ago, using credit cards to rent servers and storage, typically circumventing IT control. And it must now also woo those same IT people, as it seeks more big corporate business. That&#8217;s a fine line. In fact, it&#8217;s almost schizophrenic. Every year at the annual AWS Re:Invent conference, one day is dedicated to products geared for IT professionals who typically work to provision servers and storage, and maintain databases. Another day is all about cutting-edge and the latest trending tech, like tools for the Internet of things. Amazon has been very strategic\u2014and ambitious\u2014with new products for that IT demographic. Two of the hardest-to-dislodge technologies in big companies are Oracle databases and VMware virtualization software. It is very difficult to move customers off these deeply entrenched products, no matter how much the companies might like to do so. &#8220;Every year one goal for most companies is to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware, and every year IT comes back and say &#8216;we didn\u2019t do it.&#8217; That&#8217;s because to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware requires risk and money,&#8221; Bartoletti says. For the past few years, AWS has targeted Oracle with such products as a MySQL database clone and a database migration tool to automate the tricky process of moving on-premises Oracle (or Microsoft) databases to AWS. This year, it announced its own managed version of PostgreSQL. PostgreSQL, is seen as a more enterprise-ready, open-source database than MySQL, which Oracle owns. For more on AWS, watch And for all those petabytes of corporate data accumulating in company data centers over the decades? This year, AWS came out with an actual truck, dubbed Snowmobile, which it says can securely ship up to 100 petabytes of data from corporate server rooms to an AWS facility in one fell swoop. It seems like brute force\u2014and it is\u2014but face it, using even a high-speed network connection moving that amount of data would take forever. Amazon says Snowmobile will enable companies to move an exabyte (or 1,000 petabytes) of data to Amazon in six months or so. That same data transfer would take 20 years over a fast, 10Gbps dedicated connection, the company said. On the VMware vmw side, AWS and VMware are working together on VMware Cloud on AWS, due out in mid-2017. In theory, it will let VMware customers run their existing VMware operations directly on AWS servers. This was pitched as a win for joint customers and both AWS and VMware. But most cloud watchers suspect that many of those VMware users will end up moving their VMware workloads to AWS and then, over time, off of VMware altogether. Time will tell. But for those who think AWS has already won the public cloud wars, remember, it&#8217;s hard to maintain technology dominance over many generations. And also remember, that big Fortune 500 companies have barely put their toes in the water yet. Most estimates hold that 5% or 6% of big company workloads are in the public cloud at this point. That&#8217;s the tippy-top of an enormous ice berg. That leaves the other cloud providers\u2014at least those with big checkbooks\u2014with room to maneuver.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EOver the last decade, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Web Services has become the focal point of every tech company, most of which are now fighting to build their own public clouds. For it&#8217;s most recently reported quarter, the cloud computing arm of Amazon reported \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F27\u002Famazons-cloud-blow-out-quarter\u002F\"\u003Erevenue of $3.2 billion\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, up 55% year over year, putting it at a close-to $13 billion annual revenue run rate going into 2017.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerhaps more importantly for those who insisted that AWS was a loss-leader for its parent company, the cloud unit reported profit of $1.02 billion for that period, at least if employee stock compensation is excluded. Microsoft Azure is now a strong number two in public cloud while \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoogle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"goog\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fgoog\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Egoog\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, IBM \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"ibm\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eibm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, and others battle it out for the number three slot, in his view.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFortune\u003Cem\u003E\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the face of that heightened competition, Amazon must continue to appeal to its core base of developers at small companies, who started flocking to its services ten years ago, using credit cards to rent servers and storage, typically circumventing IT control. And it must now also woo those same IT people, as it seeks more big corporate business. That&#8217;s a fine line.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, it&#8217;s almost schizophrenic. Every year at the annual \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ftag\u002Faws-reinvent\u002F\"\u003EAWS Re:Invent \u003C\u002Fa\u003Econference, one day is dedicated to products geared for IT professionals who typically work to provision servers and storage, and maintain databases. Another day is all about cutting-edge and the latest trending tech, like tools for the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F05\u002Famazon-iot-cloud\u002F\"\u003EInternet of things\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon has been very strategic\u2014and ambitious\u2014with new products for that IT demographic. Two of the hardest-to-dislodge technologies in big companies are Oracle databases and VMware virtualization software. It is very difficult to move customers off these deeply entrenched products, no matter how much the companies might like to do so.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Every year one goal for most companies is to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware, and every year IT comes back and say &#8216;we didn\u2019t do it.&#8217; That&#8217;s because to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware requires risk and money,&#8221; Bartoletti says.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor the past few years, AWS has targeted Oracle with such products as a MySQL database clone and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F08\u002Faws-lock-in-worry\u002F\"\u003Ea database migration tool\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to automate the tricky process of moving on-premises Oracle (or Microsoft) databases to AWS. This year, it announced its own managed version of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F22\u002Famazon-cloud-conference\u002F\"\u003EPostgreSQL\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. PostgreSQL, is seen as a more enterprise-ready, open-source database than MySQL, which Oracle owns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFor more on AWS,
