President Duterte Delegates Economy into Sweet Spot","og_title":"Philippines' President Rarely Mentions It's Now One of the World's Fastest-Growing Economies","twitter_text":"Philippines' President Rarely Mentions It's Now One of the World's Fastest-Growing Economies","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iejJg9","mt_seo_description":"Philippines' President Rodrigo Duterte presides over one of the world's fastest-growing economies, but he concentrates on busting crime.","mt_seo_keywords":"Philippines, Duterte, Rodrigo Duterte, Philippine economy, Asia, Philippine peso, Philippine drug war, killing, Philippine-U.S.","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"Philippines, Duterte, Rodrigo Duterte, Philippine economy, Asia, Philippine peso, Philippine drug war, killing, Philippine-U.S.","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Frodrigo-duterte-philippines-economy\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Frodrigo-duterte-philippines-economy\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1892239,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F630117674.jpg","alt":"PHILIPPINES-POLITICS-DIPLOMACY","caption":"Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte at a press conference at Davao international airport in Mindanao on Dec. 17, 2016.  ","credit":"MANMAN DEJETO\u002FAFP\u002FGetty Images","description":"Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte gestures during a press conference shortly after arriving from Singapore at Davao international airport in southern island of Mindanao early December 17, 2016.  \nDuterte boasted again on December 16, he had killed criminals, as he vowed no let up in his war on drugs that has already claimed thousands of lives. But after flying home from Singapore to his southern hometown of Davao, Duterte outlined how, as city mayor in 1988, he and two policemen had shot dead three men who had collected a ransom payment for a kidnapped local woman. \u002F AFP \u002F MANMAN DEJETO        (Photo credit should read MANMAN DEJETO\u002FAFP\u002FGetty Images)","title":"PHILIPPINES-POLITICS-DIPLOMACY"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":4255,"name":"Philippines","slug":"philippines","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":111660,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":45,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":5142,"name":"International","slug":"international","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46731,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News with an international focus on the global marketplace and how the world's connected economies run.","parent":0,"count":7766,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1891848,"date":"2016-12-29T11:48:54","date_gmt":"2016-12-29T16:48:54","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1891848"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-30T12:09:57","modified_gmt":"2016-12-30T17:09:57","slug":"amazon-floating-warehouses","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Famazon-floating-warehouses\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2ihAiWq","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Amazon Is Considering Drone-Friendly Floating Warehouses"},"content":{"plain":"Amazon might soon take flight in more ways than one. The e-commerce giant has been awarded a patent that describes a logistics technology it calls &#8220;airborne fulfillment center (AFC).&#8221; The AFC is essentially in airship that&#8217;s capable of flying at altitudes of 45,000 feet or more that would house items the company sells through its online marketplace. In the patent, Amazon describes a method by which drones would fly into the warehouse, pick up the items they need to deliver, and then deliver those items to the customer&#8217;s home. Amazon AMZN filed for the patent in 2014. While it was actually awarded in April, it wasn&#8217;t discovered until Wednesday by CB Insights tech analyst Zoe Leavitt. Over the last few years, Amazon has been working on drone technology through its Prime Air initiative with an aim on delivering products to customer homes without relying upon logistics companies to do it. Earlier this month, Amazon successfully completed its first drone delivery in the U.K. The company plans to expand its drone testing in 2017 in hopes of eventually relying on the unmanned aerial vehicles to deliver lightweight packages to homes. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter Currently, Amazon&#8217;s drone-delivery process requires the company to erect a warehouse to serve a particular area. Inside that warehouse is a selection of lightweight products the company sells through its e-marketplace. Once a customer places an order, those items are packaged in a box the drone can carry. The drone is then outfitted with the package and delivers it to a customer&#8217;s home within 30 minutes. The potential pitfall with drones, however, is that they can only travel so far, so Amazon would technically need to erect a large number of warehouses around the world just to accommodate customers in disparate areas. But rather than look to the ground for fulfillment centers, Amazon is apparently looking to the sky. Like their grounded alternatives, the AFCs would be home to an inventory of items Amazon sells through its online marketplace, according to the patent. New items would be added to the AFC with help from a logistics shuttle that would carry products to and from the device. When an order is placed, a drone would be outfitted with the desired products and descend from the airship. It would then deliver the items to the customer. Since the drones that Amazon is testing can&#8217;t get up to heights as high as 45,000 feet, the company says its used drones will fly back to a ground installation, where they&#8217;ll be placed in a shuttle and brought back to the AFC. Amazon says the AFC concept could be a boon for handling its logistics, and pointed to its ability to move around in anticipation of demand as one of its benefits. &#8220;The use of an AFC and shuttles also provides another benefit in that the AFC can remain airborne for extended periods of time,&#8221; the company wrote in its patent description. &#8220;In addition, because the AFC is airborne, it is not limited to a fixed location like a traditional ground based materials handling facility. In contrast, it can navigate to different areas depending on a variety of factors, such as weather, expected demand, and\u002For actual demand.&#8221; For its part, Amazon hasn&#8217;t commented on the patent and did not immediately respond to a Fortune request for comment. And like other companies, Amazon often files for patents on technologies it might never bring to the market. But it&#8217;s possible that one day, Amazon drones\u2014and airships\u2014will be flying above, delivering products to folks around the globe.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E might soon take flight in more ways than one.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe e-commerce giant has been awarded a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpatft1.uspto.gov\u002Fnetacgi\u002Fnph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&amp;Sect2=HITOFF&amp;d=PALL&amp;p=1&amp;u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&amp;r=1&amp;f=G&amp;l=50&amp;s1=9305280.PN.&amp;OS=PN\u002F9305280&amp;RS=PN\u002F9305280\"\u003Epatent\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that describes a logistics technology it calls &#8220;airborne fulfillment center (AFC).&#8221; The AFC is essentially in airship that&#8217;s capable of flying at altitudes of 45,000 feet or more that would house items the company sells through its online marketplace. In the patent, Amazon describes a method by which drones would fly into the warehouse, pick up the items they need to deliver, and then deliver those items to the customer&#8217;s home.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"AMZN\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazon-com-18\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003EAMZN\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E filed for the patent in 2014. While it was actually awarded in April, it wasn&#8217;t \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fzoe_leavitt\u002Fstatus\u002F814212767041331202\"\u003Ediscovered\u003C\u002Fa\u003E until Wednesday by CB Insights tech analyst Zoe Leavitt.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOver the last few years, Amazon has been working on drone technology through its Prime Air initiative with an aim on delivering products to customer homes without relying upon logistics companies to do it. Earlier this month, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F14\u002Famazon-prime-air-delivery\u002F\"\u003EAmazon successfully completed its first drone delivery in the U.K.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E The company plans to expand its drone testing in 2017 in hopes of eventually relying on the unmanned aerial vehicles to deliver lightweight packages to homes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECurrently, Amazon&#8217;s drone-delivery process requires the company to erect a warehouse to serve a particular area. Inside that warehouse is a selection of lightweight products the company sells through its e-marketplace. Once a customer places an order, those items are packaged in a box the drone can carry. The drone is then outfitted with the package and delivers it to a customer&#8217;s home within 30 minutes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe potential pitfall with drones, however, is that they can only travel so far, so Amazon would technically need to erect a large number of warehouses around the world just to accommodate customers in disparate areas.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut rather than look to the ground for fulfillment centers, Amazon is apparently looking to the sky. When an order is placed, a drone would be outfitted with the desired products and descend from the airship. It would then deliver the items to the customer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESince the drones that Amazon is testing can&#8217;t get up to heights as high as 45,000 feet, the company says its used drones will fly back to a ground installation, where they&#8217;ll be placed in a shuttle and brought back to the AFC.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon says the AFC concept could be a boon for handling its logistics, and pointed to its ability to move around in anticipation of demand as one of its benefits.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The use of an AFC and shuttles also provides another benefit in that the AFC can remain airborne for extended periods of time,&#8221; the company wrote in its patent description. &#8220;In addition, because the AFC is airborne, it is not limited to a fixed location like a traditional ground based materials handling facility. In contrast, it can navigate to different areas depending on a variety of factors, such as weather, expected demand, and\u002For actual demand.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor its part, Amazon hasn&#8217;t commented on the patent and did not immediately respond to a \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E request for comment. And like other companies, Amazon often files for patents on technologies it might never bring to the market. But it&#8217;s possible that one day, Amazon drones\u2014and airships\u2014will be flying above, delivering products to folks around the globe.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Amazon"]}," might soon take flight in more ways than one."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The e-commerce giant has been awarded a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fpatft1.uspto.gov\u002Fnetacgi\u002Fnph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&amp;Sect2=HITOFF&amp;d=PALL&amp;p=1&amp;u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.htm&amp;r=1&amp;f=G&amp;l=50&amp;s1=9305280.PN.&amp;OS=PN\u002F9305280&amp;RS=PN\u002F9305280"},"content":["patent"]}," that describes a logistics technology it calls \"airborne fulfillment center (AFC).\" The AFC is essentially in airship that's capable of flying at altitudes of 45,000 feet or more that would house items the company sells through its online marketplace. In the patent, Amazon describes a method by which drones would fly into the warehouse, pick up the items they need to deliver, and then deliver those items to the customer's home."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Amazon ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"AMZN"},"content":[]}," filed for the patent in 2014. While it was actually awarded in April, it wasn't ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fzoe_leavitt\u002Fstatus\u002F814212767041331202"},"content":["discovered"]}," until Wednesday by CB Insights tech analyst Zoe Leavitt."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Over the last few years, Amazon has been working on drone technology through its Prime Air initiative with an aim on delivering products to customer homes without relying upon logistics companies to do it. Earlier this month, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F14\u002Famazon-prime-air-delivery\u002F"},"content":["Amazon successfully completed its first drone delivery in the U.K."]}," The company plans to expand its drone testing in 2017 in hopes of eventually relying on the unmanned aerial vehicles to deliver lightweight packages to homes."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Currently, Amazon's drone-delivery process requires the company to erect a warehouse to serve a particular area. Inside that warehouse is a selection of lightweight products the company sells through its e-marketplace. Once a customer places an order, those items are packaged in a box the drone can carry. The drone is then outfitted with the package and delivers it to a customer's home within 30 minutes."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The potential pitfall with drones, however, is that they can only travel so far, so Amazon would technically need to erect a large number of warehouses around the world just to accommodate customers in disparate areas."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But rather than look to the ground for fulfillment centers, Amazon is apparently looking to the sky. Like their grounded alternatives, the AFCs would be home to an inventory of items Amazon sells through its online marketplace, according to the patent. New items would be added to the AFC with help from a logistics shuttle that would carry products to and from the device. When an order is placed, a drone would be outfitted with the desired products and descend from the airship. It would then deliver the items to the customer."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Since the drones that Amazon is testing can't get up to heights as high as 45,000 feet, the company says its used drones will fly back to a ground installation, where they'll be placed in a shuttle and brought back to the AFC."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Amazon says the AFC concept could be a boon for handling its logistics, and pointed to its ability to move around in anticipation of demand as one of its benefits."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"The use of an AFC and shuttles also provides another benefit in that the AFC can remain airborne for extended periods of time,\" the company wrote in its patent description. \"In addition, because the AFC is airborne, it is not limited to a fixed location like a traditional ground based materials handling facility. In contrast, it can navigate to different areas depending on a variety of factors, such as weather, expected demand, and\u002For actual demand.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For its part, Amazon hasn't commented on the patent and did not immediately respond to a ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]}," request for comment. And like other companies, Amazon often files for patents on technologies it might never bring to the market. But it's possible that one day, Amazon drones\u2014and airships\u2014will be flying above, delivering products to folks around the globe."]}]},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s a bird! of Amazon","description":"","title":"prime-air_03"},"video":{"id":"5264565774001","markup":"\u003Cdiv class=\"video-wrapper\"  data-ratio=\"0.56363636363636\" data-pos=\"13\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cobject id=\"bc-video-5264565774001-13\" class=\"BrightcoveExperience\"\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"bgcolor\" value=\"#FFFFFF\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"width\" value=\"550\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"height\" value=\"310\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"playerID\" value=\"3160175193001\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"playerKey\" value=\"AQ~~,AAAB668kGak~,LMlvL4u4ShOTHD9z00VquajMOcH97tcW\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"isVid\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"isUI\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"videoSmoothing\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"seamlessTabbing\" value=\"false\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"swliveconnect\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"dynamicStreaming\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"autoStart\" value=\"false\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"@videoPlayer\" value=\"5264565774001\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"linkBaseURL\" value=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F1CyQo0n\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"includeAPI\" value=\"true\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"templateLoadHandler\" value=\"Fortune_onTemplateLoad\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"templateReadyHandler\" value=\"Fortune_onTemplateReady\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"wmode\" value=\"opaque\"\u002F\u003E\u003Cparam name=\"adServerURL\" value=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpubads.g.doubleclick.net\u002Fgampad\u002Fads?env=vp&#038;gdfp_req=1&#038;impl=s&#038;output=xml_vast2&#038;iu=\u002F8484\u002Ffort\u002Fvideo_bc\u002Ftech_bc&#038;sz=1000x1&#038;cust_params=tags%3Damazon%2Camazondrones%2Camazonprime%2Camazonprimeairfloatingdronewarehouse%2Cdrones%26ch%3Dtech%26topic%3Damazon&#038;unviewed_position_start=1&#038;correlator=%5Btimestamp%5D\"\u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fobject\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003Cscript Gets Closer to Having Warehouses in the Sky"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5264565774001","autoplay":"1","controls":"1"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":366068442,"name":"The Mobile Executive","slug":"the-mobile-executive","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":133921,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":402,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1194482,"date":"2015-06-29T06:00:45","date_gmt":"2015-06-29T10:00:45","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1194482"},"paid":false,"modified":"2015-07-01T09:21:17","modified_gmt":"2015-07-01T13:21:17","slug":"sleep-data","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002F29\u002Fsleep-data\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F1CyQo0n","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Can big data help you get a good night\u2019s sleep?"},"content":{"plain":"I\u2019m playing tennis with Marissa Mayer, and oddly, the Yahoo YHOO CEO is wearing a pearlescent purple gown and sipping from a teacup. Her dress is just long enough to obscure her feet, so she appears to be floating across the baseline. As she strikes the ball, she tips her chin skyward and laughs in slow motion. Meanwhile, I\u2019m perched in the lotus position atop a manta ray that\u2019s hovering above the ground like some kind of Landspeeder. And I\u2019m panicking. How can I keep my balance and still hit the ball\u2014especially with my shirt collar pulling at my neck the way it is? Can\u2019t swing my racket. I jerk my head left. Then right. I claw at my jawline. The ball has cleared the net, and it\u2019s headed my way. If only. I could. Just. Move. My head. And poof. She\u2019s gone. I open my eyes in a strange room. It\u2019s pitch dark and completely silent, but I manage to find my bearings. Santa Cruz, Calif. Breathing heavily, I carefully disentangle a gaggle of wires twisted around my neck and roll over to glance at the clock. Just after 3 a.m. This scene, I now know, was merely one of 18 REM-sleep interruptions that I experienced between 11:18 p.m. and 6:16 a.m. during one long February night. What a strange setting for the only dream I\u2019ve ever had about a chief executive: in a laboratory, tethered to a byzantine apparatus designed to monitor my brain activity as well as every breath, eye movement, muscle twitch, and heartbeat. Let me explain. Like you and probably everyone you know, I\u2019ve always been confounded by my sleep routine. Why do I one morning rise ready to tackle the day and the next seem barely able to lift my head? How much rest can I be getting if I wake up sideways with the covers on the floor and my wife in the guest room? Most important, what can I do better? I don\u2019t want a magic pill. I\u2019ve tried those. I know the rules of thumb: less stress, more exercise, better diet, no afternoon caffeine, put down the damn phone. But I\u2019d kill for a personalized formula. So I subjected myself to a polysomnography test, or PSG, hoping to unravel some of the mysteries of the night. My procedure was administered in the offices of Fullpower Technologies, one floor down from where I had spent most of the evening talking with the company\u2019s founder and CEO, Philippe Kahn. A French expatriate who grew up in Paris, Kahn, 63, is a Silicon Valley oracle whose track record predates the web. He founded Borland Software (acquired by Micro Focus) MCFUF in the mid-1980s, followed by Starfish software (Motorola) and LightSurf Technologies (VeriSign) VRSN . In 1997, while anticipating the birth of his daughter, he paired a state-of-the-art Casio CSIOY camera with a Motorola Startac and became, he claims, the first person to transmit a digital photo over cellular airwaves. He\u2019s also been a leader in wearable technologies. Philippe Kahn says Fullpower is \u201coperating a huge sleep experiment unlike anything anyone has ever done.\u201dPhotograph by Ian Allen for Fortune That\u2019s precisely the focus of Fullpower, which licenses its software to other companies. Nearly five dozen framed patents for wearable-related software and devices hang on the wall in the company\u2019s lobby. The oldest dates to 2005, long before tracking steps became such a phenomenon. In the conference room there\u2019s an assembly of chairs and tables around a full-size bed, making obvious Kahn\u2019s latest obsession. Fullpower built the lab about a decade ago to capture data from sleep patterns. Of course, test subjects don\u2019t typically snooze deeply with wires glued to their skulls, chests, legs, and arms. But almost everyone manages to at least nod off for a while, and the data that subjects generate are valuable and often surprising. \u201cWhat we found early on is that sometimes you sleep less and feel more refreshed,\u201d Kahn says. \u201cIt\u2019s because you woke up in the light part of the sleep cycle.\u201d The insight led him to develop a sleep-cycle alarm that could determine the best time to alert a person within a certain window. \u201cSometimes it\u2019s better to get up at 10 of seven than at seven,\u201d he says. Kahn insists that he\u2019s on the cusp of many more such discoveries, and he\u2019s intent on dispelling some of the conventional wisdom that stresses people out. \u201cPeople say that if you can\u2019t sleep for eight hours without waking up, something\u2019s wrong with you. That\u2019s such a fallacy,\u201d he says. \u201cBefore electricity, people used to sleep in two shifts. That\u2019s how I behave. Sleep for four hours, get up and do an hour and a half of work, and then another four.\u201d He\u2019s also skeptical of the notion that a quiet room is the best environment for shut-eye and dismisses the perceived deleterious effects of repeated rousing. \u201cThe sign of good sleep hygiene may not be how many times you wake up, but rather how rapidly you fall back to sleep. Sleep should be like hunger. Eat only when you\u2019re hungry and until you\u2019re satisfied.\u201d Fullpower has oceans of data to back Kahn\u2019s theories. The company provides the sleep-tracking and activity-monitoring software for the Jawbone UP and Nike Fuel NKE wearable devices as well as a new line of Swiss-made smartwatches and the forthcoming Simmons Sleeptracker Smartbed. The products transmit a mother lode of information (with users\u2019 consent) to Kahn\u2019s team. He thinks that by combining qualitative lab data and quantitative real-world data with machine learning, artificial intelligence, and other analytics technologies, he can unlock the secrets that so many of us walking dead are looking for: a better night\u2019s sleep. \u201cWe\u2019re operating a huge sleep experiment, worldwide, unlike anything anyone has ever done,\u201d he says. \u201cWe have 250 million nights of sleep in our database, and we\u2019re using all the latest technologies to make sense of it.\u201d Kahn is not alone. He\u2019s part of a movement of brilliant entrepreneurs, data scientists, engineers, and academics who are looking at demographics, geographies, and lifestyles, and even into our genomes. They\u2019re the beneficiaries of a historic explosion in sleep data, and they\u2019re using many of the same technologies that are busily decoding some of the world\u2019s other great mysteries. Tiny sensors, big data, analytics, and cloud computing can predict machine breakage, pinpoint power outages, and build better supply chains. Why not put them to work to optimize the most valuable complex system of all, the human body? It\u2019s not an exaggeration to say lack of sleep is killing us. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention calls it a public health epidemic and estimates that as many as 70 million Americans have a sleep disorder. Sleep deprivation has been linked to clinical depression, obesity, Type 2 diabetes, and cancer. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration estimates that drowsy driving causes 1,550 deaths and 40,000 injuries annually in the U.S.\u2009 There are 84 sleep disorders, and some 100 million people\u201480% of them undiagnosed\u2014suffer from one of them in particular: Obstructive sleep apnea, generally indicated by snoring, costs the U.S. economy as much as $165 billion a year, according to a Harvard Medical School study. That\u2019s more than asthma, heart failure, stroke, hypertension, or drunk driving. And the study doesn\u2019t account for tangential effects, like loss of intimacy and divorce. BCC Research predicts that the global market for sleep-aid products\u2014everything from specialty mattresses and high-tech pillows to drugs and at-home tests\u2014will hit $76.7 billion by 2019. The financial upside for anyone who can crack the sleep code is obvious. And so the race is on. \u201cI believe that 15 years from now, if we do this right, we can actually tackle epidemics like obesity, diabetes, and high blood pressure, and any number of lifestyle diseases,\u201d says Kahn. \u201cWe\u2019re going to help people live longer and better lives.\u201d In 1934 this magazine ran a sprawling cover story under the simple headline \u201cSleep.\u201d Published about three decades after the dawn of sleep research, it explored a litany of the day\u2019s devices, concoctions, drugs, and homespun remedies designed, or at least purported, to help insomniacs. The article chronicled the merits of everything from Ovaltine to morphine and Barbital, a synthetic hypnotic that was used as a sleep aid until the mid-1950s despite being habit-forming and occasionally deadly. The story also unpacked the relationship between Zalmon G. Simmons and Harry M. Johnson. Simmons was the president of the eponymous company his father founded, which has by now sold nearly 100 million mattresses, most notably under the Beautyrest brand. Johnson was a psychology professor at Ohio State who was conducting sleep research on the side. At the time, old Zalmon was looking to solve two problems: He needed to sell more mattresses. And he needed sleep. The head of the iconic mattress maker was an insomniac! So he gave Johnson $25,000 to set up a sleep lab at the university now known as Carnegie Mellon. At the time it was believed that normal sleepers lay motionless throughout the night. Johnson collected 2.5 million data points from 160 subjects and demonstrated the folly of that theory. Normal sleepers, he determined, change positions from 20 to 85 times a night, with 35 being a sort of sweet spot. When we toss and turn more, we wake up groggy; any less, and we\u2019re stiff and sore. (The insight would pay dividends for Simmons, the company. Spurred by the revelation that proper sleep required movement, it became the first to introduce king and queen-size mattresses. Unfortunately, Zalmon didn\u2019t solve his personal problem. His insomnia devolved into depression and, in the words of the article, his \u201cfortune began to wobble. Soon after that, sleep ceased to be a problem. For Zalmon G. Simmons was dead.\u201d) Those movements are what enable today\u2019s wearable devices to monitor sleep. Gartner Group IT projects sales of 36 million smart wristbands, a category that includes most Fitbit FIT devices, Jawbone UP, and Nike Fuel, in 2015 and 2016. Fitbit is definitely king. NPD Group estimates that it has an 85% market share. Fitbit raised $732 million in a highly anticipated IPO stoked by the impressive metrics revealed in its S-1 filing: nearly $132 million in net income on $745 million in revenue last year, with $336 million in revenue in the first quarter of this year. Fitbit has sold more than 21 million devices since 2008 and has 9.5 million active users. That means Fitbit is gathering far more data in one night than Johnson did in his career. Thanks to its sleep-monitoring technology, the company can distinguish among variations in movements and has determined that the majority of its users actually wake up between three and 17 times a night\u20149.3 times being average. Most awakenings are short and probably not remembered. Fitbit\u2019s data suggest that the number of awakenings drops with age until about 45, and then remains flat. Men under 50 have, on average, one more awakening per night than women of the same age, but the discrepancy largely disappears after 50. Fitbit\u2019s research team developed the algorithms to gather and analyze all these data under the guidance of Shelten Yuen. Yuen, 36, who has a Ph.D. in engineering sciences, has worked in missile defense and has done research in surgical robotics. He was approached by Fitbit\u2019s co-founders back in 2010 to write the software underlying the wearable device they were envisioning. \u201cCrazy sensor thing?\u201d Yuen remembers thinking. \u201cThat\u2019s my deal.\u201d He signed on as employee No. 4. \u201cWe need to take the veil off of sleep,\u201d says Shelten Yuen, who leads Fitbit\u2019s research team and wrote the original software that tracks Fitbit users\u2019 movement and sleep.Photograph by Ian Allen for Fortune The first goal for Fitbit was tracking steps. Yuen figured it would be a snap\u2014until he realized that a regular accelerometer can\u2019t distinguish between a wrist that\u2019s moving with a walking gait and a wrist that\u2019s, say, shoveling food. He delivered what he thought was the perfect device. \u201cThey said, \u2018Did you try scratching your head? Did you put it in your pocket? How about strapped to a bra?\u2019 Suddenly it became a crazy, phenomenally hard problem,\u201d he remembers. Steps are easy compared with sleep. For starters, what\u2019s the difference between an absence of movement while trying to sleep and actual sleep? Wearables are beginning to incorporate heart-rate monitoring, which helps correlate sleep stages, but they don\u2019t measure respiration or neural activity like a polysomnograph and so rely more heavily on inference. Fitbit encounters skepticism from users, including me, about the accuracy of its sleep measurement. Yuen admits he hasn\u2019t achieved perfection, but he largely brushes off the incredulity, saying it stems from the fact that our instincts for how well we\u2019re sleeping don\u2019t typically match reality. For steps, users can monitor their progress, but not so with sleep. (For his part, Kahn insists that he has the formula for maximum accuracy: He says his huge quantity of rock-solid polysomnography data and wristband sleep-tracking information have helped him develop an algorithm that adjusts for the imperfections of wristband data.) Whatever the accuracy of Fitbit\u2019s data, the company has a ton of it, and is seeing some interesting patterns. Yuen calls one of his data scientists, Jacob Arnold, 31, into the conference room at Fitbit headquarters in San Francisco\u2019s South of Market neighborhood. Arnold also has a Ph.D., his in astronomy and astrophysics. Together they unveil some graphs demonstrating that people around the world get more sleep in winter and less in summer. Daylight clearly has an effect on sleep patterns; temperature might too. We sleep less on the hottest day of the year than on the longest day. The data show that the longest average duration of sleep usually occurs on the weekend following New Year\u2019s Day. Yuen also makes it clear that getting a lot of sleep is not equivalent to having a restful night. Yuen and Arnold then reveal a graph demonstrating that, statistically speaking, no one gets less sleep than the demographic group to which I belong, forty-something males. I\u2019m not sure how to take the news. Is it a body blow or a hopeful sign of more rest in my future? Establishing the norm the way these charts do is an important step from a scientific standpoint. But to be indispensable in the marketplace, Fitbit needs to empower users with real guidance. \u201cWe need to take the veil off of sleep,\u201d says Yuen. \u201cWe need to make this data much more understandable so they don\u2019t feel powerless.\u201d Fitbit co-founder and CEO James Park echoes the sentiment. Some analysts are predicting that fitness trackers have peaked, especially because of the launch of the Apple Watch (which doesn\u2019t track slumber because it needs to be charged every night). Park knows that if he can help his customers sleep better, Fitbit will become irreplaceable. \u201cA lot of clinical studies show that certain behaviors might affect sleep: light levels, noise levels, caffeine, time of exercise,\u201d says Park. \u201cThe next step is to tie prescriptive elements into it. That\u2019s one of the big opportunities for this category. Can companies actually deliver coaching services to help people sleep that consumers actually want to pay for?\u201d Not long after meeting Steve Kay, dean of the Dornsife school of arts and sciences at the University of Southern California, I notice he\u2019s wearing a Fitbit. Curious about what kind of a sleeper one of the world\u2019s leading experts in circadian rhythm would be, I ask how he\u2019d fared the night before. He looks at the app on his phone. \u201cI went to bed at a quarter past 11 and got up at 20 past four,\u201d he says with a shake of the head. Count Kay among the many of us getting less rest than we need. I\u2019m in Kay\u2019s conference room with Ross Bersot, a venture partner at Bay City Capital turned entrepreneur. Bersot, 40, and Kay, 53, are a latter-day Zalmon Simmons and Harry Johnson. A few years ago, Kay published research demonstrating that it\u2019s possible to isolate and manipulate the speed of an organism\u2019s circadian rhythm using molecular compounds. Bersot provided funding to Kay\u2019s lab in hopes of potentially starting a company based on more detailed findings. That company, Reset Therapeutics, is now real and based in the Bay Area. Like Fullpower and Fitbit, Reset is intent on getting to the heart of the nature of sleep. But while others duke it out for wrist real estate, Reset is going deep into our bodies with a different set of tools. It\u2019s pairing Kay\u2019s research with the latest advances in genomics and high-throughput screening, and partnering with personal-genetics startup 23andMe to try to develop a drug that can manipulate our circadian rhythm. Almost every living thing on earth has an internal clock\u2014or more accurately, a symphony of clocks ticking away at the cellular level\u2014that tells its owner when to rest and when to produce. It\u2019s not just humans. Monsanto recently published a paper demonstrating that it could boost soybean yields 5% by tweaking one of the plant\u2019s clock-associated genes. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to help them figure out why,\u201d says Kay, whose lab is working with Monsanto. \u201cAnd all the major ag and biotech companies are interested. When you\u2019re a plant stuck in the ground, everything is circadian. Biomass, yield, response to extreme temperatures\u2014it\u2019s all clock regulated.\u201d Human clocks are equally powerful, but we aren\u2019t quite as enslaved by them because we don\u2019t depend on photosynthesis. By some estimates, up to 70% of us live in spite of our internal clocks, or in the scientific jargon, outside our chronotype. Your chronotype predisposes you to being a night owl or a morning person or even being hungry at certain times, and many of us are guilty of ignoring our chronotypes, whether because of our lifestyle or just the call of duty. When we live largely out of sync with our chronotypes, we experience everything from grogginess and reduced productivity to digestion issues, weight gain, and accelerated aging. We also increase our risk of obesity and Type 2 diabetes. Kay cites studies that link such lifestyles to an increased rate of breast cancer. \u201cWe evolved to adapt on this planet that has periods of light and dark. But modern life is really clashing with that,\u201d he says. \u201cThe key is being internally synchronized. Your sleep-wake cycles, your food-intake cycles, your metabolic cycles are all working together. When they\u2019re out of sync, that\u2019s when (a) you feel lousy, and (b) you start seeing the disturbance of all kinds of markers. Sleep efficiency collapses. Leptin plummets. Insulin goes up.\u201d Reset wants to tweak our clocks with a drug. Such a drug would help reset the chronotypes of people who choose or need to live a different lifestyle or whose clocks are impaired. For now the development phase is limited to two so-called orphan diseases, narcolepsy\u2014a neurological disorder that causes significant daytime sleepiness and in some cases cataplectic attacks\u2014and Cushing\u2019s disease, a neuroendocrine disorder characterized by excess blood sugar, obesity, and pituitary tumors. Working with orphan diseases enables the company to help people sooner and get on the fast track to regulatory approval. \u201cWith the Cushing\u2019s program, we\u2019re focused on a protein that makes a clock run at a 24-hour cycle,\u201d says Bersot. And so far, so good: \u201cWe\u2019re restoring the rhythms to a 24-hour period, and in our early work with animals, we\u2019ve seen blood glucose and insulin levels return to normal as a result.\u201d Reset plans to take the Cushing\u2019s drug to clinical trials next year and the narcolepsy treatment after that. Bersot hopes that once the drug establishes its ability to reset the body clock for sufferers of those diseases, Reset will develop it more broadly as a sleep aid for shift workers and anyone else whose clock and lifestyle are misaligned. In the meantime the company is working with 23andMe to explore correlations between chronotypes and various genetic expressions. According to Emily Drabant Conley, 23andMe\u2019s director of business development and a Ph.D. in neuroscience, 80% of 23andMe\u2019s customers allow their genotypes to be used in research. She\u2019s scouring their files in hopes of finding correlations between genotypes and sleep-related survey data. For example, how do people of a given genetic expression most commonly answer these questions: How many hours of sleep do you average? Do you snore? Do you take sleep medication? \u201cSleep is interesting because it\u2019s not like eye color, where you have only five choices. Having a lot of data that you can mine is important,\u201d she says. \u201cBut we\u2019re just at the beginning. We\u2019ve done the first pass at the genetics of being a morning person. We know that genetics plays a role in whether you need six hours or eight hours. The prescriptive aspect will come.\u201d It\u2019s a common refrain, and despite the way it may sound to someone yearning for rest, it\u2019s hardly a cop-out. In the realm of data science there\u2019s a commonly accepted notion of how progress occurs. First comes descriptive analytics, next predictive analytics, and finally prescriptive analytics. In other words, describe the system, predict outcomes based on those descriptions, and prescribe actions to attain desired outcomes. To the layperson, prescription may sound like the most difficult phase, but in reality the hardest part is often where we are today, measuring and mapping behavior just to get to the point where it\u2019s conceivable to predict behavior and prescribe actions. Science is clearly advancing in the quest to understand sleep. We\u2019re adding data in quantities that were unimaginable even a decade ago, much less during the time that Fortune first considered the subject. Big Pharma and biotech companies are drilling into our genomes to find links between DNA and nighttime routines; they\u2019re also exploring medications that adjust the circadian rhythm. Wearable-device companies are casting nets far and wide. Fitbit recently enabled its devices to track sleep automatically, rather than as a user-triggered behavior, and some of its devices now monitor heart rate, which helps Yuen and Arnold make finer distinctions between lack of motion and restful sleep. Full-power just entered a partnership with Simmons to provide sleep-tracking technology for the mattress maker\u2019s new Sleeptracker Smartbed, which will provide noninvasive sleep-monitoring technology and is scheduled to hit the market in 2016. On top of all this, scientists around the world are using cheap wearables to conduct their own exploratory research. A quick search of Google Scholar shows dozens of wearable-powered experiments and papers detailing the efforts to unravel the mysteries of the night. All of which will\u2014one day soon, let\u2019s hope\u2014translate to a more personalized analysis and formula for how each of us can get a better night\u2019s sleep. Which brings me back to my night in Fullpower\u2019s sleep lab. A few days after my test I received a PSG report that shines a light on my own personal darkness. The prognosis was mixed. The good news: My sleep-efficiency score was a robust 93.5%\u2014\u201cYou should be proud of that,\u201d says Kahn\u2014which means that most of the time I\u2019m in bed, I\u2019m sleeping. And I\u2019m quick. I drifted off in 2.5 minutes, even with all those wires attached. The bad: I snored. In fact, I was diagnosed with \u201cmild to moderate\u201d apnea. That officially makes me part of the $165 billion problem. I was advised to see a doctor. That\u2019s not the prescription I was looking for. I\u2019m not crazy about doctors, and I\u2019m afraid of being persuaded to buy a machine that I won\u2019t use. So for now, I think I\u2019ll just keep trying to do what I know to be right. Exercise. Keep a consistent routine. Restrict the hours that I eat, try to lay off the junk food and booze, and hope that before long someone will offer me a more personalized regimen. Until then, I\u2019ll always have the memory of a laughing, volleying Marissa Mayer and the knowledge that together, on one strange night in Santa Cruz, we\u2014and whatever caused my 17 other REM interruptions\u2014slept, or at least tried to, in the name of progress. Jeffrey O\u2019Brien is a former Fortune senior editor and co-founder of StoryTK, a Bay Area studio that crafts stories for companies. A version of this article appears in the July 1, 2015 issue of Fortune magazine with the headline \u201cCracking the Sleep Code.\u201d","rendered":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EI\u2019m playing tennis with Marissa Mayer, and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003Eoddly, the Yahoo \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"YHOO\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fyahoo-513\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003EYHOO\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E CEO is wearing a pearlescent purple gown and sipping from a teacup. Her dress is just long enough to obscure her feet, so she appears to be floating across the baseline. As she strikes the ball, she tips her chin skyward and laughs in slow motion.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EMeanwhile, I\u2019m perched in the lotus position atop a manta ray that\u2019s hovering above the ground like some kind of Landspeeder. And I\u2019m panicking. How can I keep my balance and still hit the ball\u2014especially with my shirt collar pulling at my neck the way it is? Can\u2019t swing my racket. I jerk my head left. Then right. I claw at my jawline. The ball has cleared the net, and it\u2019s headed my way. If only. I could. Just. Move. My head.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EAnd poof. She\u2019s gone. I open my eyes in a strange room. It\u2019s pitch dark and completely silent, but I manage to find my bearings. Santa Cruz, Calif. Breathing heavily, I carefully disentangle a gaggle of wires twisted around my neck and roll over to glance at the clock. Just after 3 a.m.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Chr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EThis scene, I now know,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E was merely one of 18 REM-sleep interruptions that I experienced between 11:18 p.m. and 6:16 a.m. during one long February night. What a strange setting for the only dream I\u2019ve ever had about a chief executive: in a laboratory, tethered to a byzantine apparatus designed to monitor my brain activity as well as every breath, eye movement, muscle twitch, and heartbeat.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003ELet me explain. Like you and probably everyone you know, I\u2019ve always been confounded by my sleep routine. Why do I one morning rise ready to tackle the day and the next seem barely able to lift my head? How much rest can I be getting if I wake up sideways with the covers on the floor and my wife in the guest room? Most important, what can I do better? I don\u2019t want a magic pill. I\u2019ve tried those. I know the rules of thumb: less stress, more exercise, better diet, no afternoon caffeine, put down the damn phone. But I\u2019d kill for a personalized formula. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003ESo I subjected myself to a polysomnography test, or PSG, hoping to unravel some of the mysteries of the night. My procedure was administered in the offices of Fullpower Technologies, one floor down from where I had spent most of the evening talking with the company\u2019s founder and CEO, Philippe Kahn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EA French expatriate who grew up in Paris, Kahn, 63, is a Silicon Valley oracle whose track record predates the web. He founded Borland Software (acquired by Micro Focus) \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"MCFUF\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fmcfuf\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003EMCFUF\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E in the mid-1980s, followed by Starfish software (Motorola) and LightSurf Technologies (VeriSign) \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"VRSN\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fvrsn\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003EVRSN\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E. In 1997, while anticipating the birth of his daughter, he paired a state-of-the-art Casio \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"CSIOY\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fcsioy\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003ECSIOY\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E camera with a Motorola Startac and became, he claims, the first person to transmit a digital photo over cellular airwaves. He\u2019s also been a leader in wearable technologies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-medium-width aligncenter\" style=\"max-width:457px;\" \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?quality=80\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1190999\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002F29\u002Fsleep-data\u002Fsle07_c\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg\" data-orig-size=\"457,610\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;IQ260&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;1434100754&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;50&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0.0020000059391416&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"SLE.07.01.Sleep Research.02\" data-image-description=\"&lt;p&gt;contract&lt;br \u002F&gt;\nArmin Harris&lt;\u002Fp&gt;\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?w=225\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?w=457\" class=\"size-full wp-image-1190999\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?quality=80&#038;w=457&#038;h=610\" alt=\"Full Power, Philippe Kahn\" width=\"457\" height=\"610\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg 457w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?quality=80&amp;w=112&amp;h=150 112w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?quality=80&amp;w=225&amp;h=300 225w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 457px) 100vw, 457px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\"\u003EPhilippe Kahn says Fullpower is \u201coperating a huge sleep experiment unlike anything anyone has ever done.\u201d\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003EPhotograph by Ian Allen for Fortune\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EThat\u2019s precisely the focus of Fullpower, which licenses its software to other companies. Nearly five dozen framed patents for wearable-related software and devices hang on the wall in the company\u2019s lobby. The oldest dates to 2005, long before tracking steps became such a phenomenon. In the conference room there\u2019s an assembly of chairs and tables around a full-size bed, making obvious Kahn\u2019s latest obsession. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EFullpower built the lab about a decade ago to capture data from sleep patterns. Of course, test subjects don\u2019t typically snooze deeply with wires glued to their skulls, chests, legs, and arms. But almost everyone manages to at least nod off for a while, and the data that subjects generate are valuable and often surprising. \u201cWhat we found early on is that sometimes you sleep less and feel more refreshed,\u201d Kahn says. \u201cIt\u2019s because you woke up in the light part of the sleep cycle.\u201d The insight led him to develop a sleep-cycle alarm that could determine the best time to alert a person within a certain window. \u201cSometimes it\u2019s better to get up at 10 of seven than at seven,\u201d he says.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EKahn insists that he\u2019s on the cusp of many more such discoveries, and he\u2019s intent on dispelling some of the conventional wisdom that stresses people out. \u201cPeople say that if you can\u2019t sleep for eight hours without waking up, something\u2019s wrong with you. That\u2019s such a fallacy,\u201d he says. \u201cBefore electricity, people used to sleep in two shifts. That\u2019s how I behave. Sleep for four hours, get up and do an hour and a half of work, and then another four.\u201d He\u2019s also skeptical of the notion that a quiet room is the best environment for shut-eye and dismisses the perceived deleterious effects of repeated rousing. \u201cThe sign of good sleep hygiene may not be how many times you wake up, but rather how rapidly you fall back to sleep. Sleep should be like hunger. Eat only when you\u2019re hungry and until you\u2019re satisfied.\u201d\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EFullpower has oceans of data to back Kahn\u2019s theories. The company provides the sleep-tracking and activity-monitoring software for the Jawbone UP and Nike Fuel \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"NKE\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnike-91\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003ENKE\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E wearable devices as well as a new line of Swiss-made smartwatches and the forthcoming Simmons Sleeptracker Smartbed. The products transmit a mother lode of information (with users\u2019 consent) to Kahn\u2019s team. He thinks that by combining qualitative lab data and quantitative real-world data with machine learning, artificial intelligence, and other analytics technologies, he can unlock the secrets that so many of us walking dead are looking for: a better night\u2019s sleep. \u201cWe\u2019re operating a huge sleep experiment, worldwide, unlike anything anyone has ever done,\u201d he says. \u201cWe have 250 million nights of sleep in our database, and we\u2019re using all the latest technologies to make sense of it.\u201d\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EKahn is not alone. He\u2019s part of a movement of brilliant entrepreneurs, data scientists, engineers, and academics who are looking at demographics, geographies, and lifestyles, and even into our genomes. They\u2019re the beneficiaries of a historic explosion in sleep data, and they\u2019re using many of the same technologies that are busily decoding some of the world\u2019s other great mysteries. Tiny sensors, big data, analytics, and cloud computing can predict machine breakage, pinpoint power outages, and build better supply chains. Why not put them to work to optimize the most valuable complex system of all, the human body?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1194745\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002F29\u002Fsleep-data\u002Fsle1-07-01-15\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=500\" data-orig-size=\"545,500\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"sle1-07-01-15\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=500?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=500?w=545\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1194745\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=500\" alt=\"sle1-07-01-15\" width=\"545\" height=\"500\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg 545w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg?w=150&amp;h=138 150w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg?w=300&amp;h=275 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EIt\u2019s not an exaggeration to say lack of sleep is killing us. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention calls it a public health epidemic and estimates that as many as 70 million Americans have a sleep disorder. Sleep deprivation has been linked to clinical depression, obesity, Type 2 diabetes, and cancer. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration estimates that drowsy driving causes 1,550 deaths and 40,000 injuries annually in the U.S.\u2009 There are 84 sleep disorders, and some 100 million people\u201480% of them undiagnosed\u2014suffer from one of them in particular: Obstructive sleep apnea, generally indicated by snoring, costs the U.S. economy as much as $165 billion a year, according to a Harvard Medical School study. That\u2019s more than asthma, heart failure, stroke, hypertension, or drunk driving. And the study doesn\u2019t account for tangential effects, like loss of intimacy and divorce. BCC Research predicts that the global market for sleep-aid products\u2014everything from specialty mattresses and high-tech pillows to drugs and at-home tests\u2014will hit $76.7 billion by 2019. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EThe financial upside for anyone who can crack the sleep code is obvious. And so the race is on. \u201cI believe that 15 years from now, if we do this right, we can actually tackle epidemics like obesity, diabetes, and high blood pressure, and any number of lifestyle diseases,\u201d says Kahn. \u201cWe\u2019re going to help people live longer and better lives.\u201d\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Chr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EIn 1934 this magazine ran\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003Ea sprawling cover story under the simple headline \u201cSleep.\u201d Published about three decades after the dawn of sleep research, it explored a litany of the day\u2019s devices, concoctions, drugs, and homespun remedies designed, or at least purported, to help insomniacs. The article chronicled the merits of everything from Ovaltine to morphine and Barbital, a synthetic hypnotic that was used as a sleep aid until the mid-1950s despite being habit-forming and occasionally deadly. The story also unpacked the relationship between Zalmon G. Simmons and Harry M. Johnson. Simmons was the president of the eponymous company his father founded, which has by now sold nearly 100 million mattresses, most notably under the Beautyrest brand. Johnson was a psychology professor at Ohio State who was conducting sleep research on the side.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EAt the time, old Zalmon was looking to solve two problems: He needed to sell more mattresses. And he needed sleep. The head of the iconic mattress maker was an insomniac! So he gave Johnson $25,000 to set up a sleep lab at the university now known as Carnegie Mellon. At the time it was believed that normal sleepers lay motionless throughout the night. Johnson collected 2.5 million data points from 160 subjects and demonstrated the folly of that theory. Normal sleepers, he determined, change positions from 20 to 85 times a night, with 35 being a sort of sweet spot. When we toss and turn more, we wake up groggy; any less, and we\u2019re stiff and sore. (The insight would pay dividends for Simmons, the company. Spurred by the revelation that proper sleep required movement, it became the first to introduce king and queen-size mattresses. Unfortunately, Zalmon didn\u2019t solve his personal problem. His insomnia devolved into depression and, in the words of the article, his \u201cfortune began to wobble. Soon after that, sleep ceased to be a problem. For Zalmon G. Simmons was dead.\u201d) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EThose movements are what enable today\u2019s wearable devices to monitor sleep. Gartner Group \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"IT\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgartner-927\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003EIT\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E projects sales of 36 million smart wristbands, a category that includes most Fitbit \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"FIT\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Ffit\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003EFIT\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E devices, Jawbone UP, and Nike Fuel, in 2015 and 2016. Fitbit is definitely king. NPD Group estimates that it has an 85% market share. Fitbit raised $732 million in a highly anticipated IPO stoked by the impressive metrics revealed in its S-1 filing: nearly $132 million in net income on $745 million in revenue last year, with $336 million in revenue in the first quarter of this year. Fitbit has sold more than 21 million devices since 2008 and has 9.5 million active users.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EThat means Fitbit is gathering far more data in one night than Johnson did in his career. Thanks to its sleep-monitoring technology, the company can distinguish among variations in movements and has determined that the majority of its users actually wake up between three and 17 times a night\u20149.3 times being average. Most awakenings are short and probably not remembered. Fitbit\u2019s data suggest that the number of awakenings drops with age until about 45, and then remains flat. Men under 50 have, on average, one more awakening per night than women of the same age, but the discrepancy largely disappears after 50. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EFitbit\u2019s research team developed the algorithms to gather and analyze all these data under the guidance of Shelten Yuen. Yuen, 36, who has a Ph.D. in engineering sciences, has worked in missile defense and has done research in surgical robotics. He was approached by Fitbit\u2019s co-founders back in 2010 to write the software underlying the wearable device they were envisioning. \u201cCrazy sensor thing?\u201d Yuen remembers thinking. \u201cThat\u2019s my deal.\u201d He signed on as employee No. 4.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-medium-width aligncenter\" style=\"max-width:457px;\" \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?quality=80\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1191001\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002F29\u002Fsleep-data\u002Fsle07_d\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg\" data-orig-size=\"457,610\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;IQ260&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;1434161323&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;100&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0.0020000059391416&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"SLE.07.01.Sleep Research.03\" data-image-description=\"&lt;p&gt;contract&lt;br \u002F&gt;\nArmin Harris&lt;\u002Fp&gt;\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?w=225\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?w=457\" class=\"size-full wp-image-1191001\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?quality=80&#038;w=457&#038;h=610\" alt=\"Fitbit, Shelten Yuen\" width=\"457\" height=\"610\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg 457w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?quality=80&amp;w=112&amp;h=150 112w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?quality=80&amp;w=225&amp;h=300 225w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 457px) 100vw, 457px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\"\u003E\u201cWe need to take the veil off of sleep,\u201d says Shelten Yuen, who leads Fitbit\u2019s research team and wrote the original software that tracks Fitbit users\u2019 movement and sleep.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003EPhotograph by Ian Allen for Fortune\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EThe first goal for Fitbit was tracking steps. Yuen figured it would be a snap\u2014until he realized that a regular accelerometer can\u2019t distinguish between a wrist that\u2019s moving with a walking gait and a wrist that\u2019s, say, shoveling food. He delivered what he thought was the perfect device. \u201cThey said, \u2018Did you try scratching your head? Did you put it in your pocket? How about strapped to a bra?\u2019 Suddenly it became a crazy, phenomenally hard problem,\u201d he remembers. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003ESteps are easy compared with sleep. For starters, what\u2019s the difference between an absence of movement while trying to sleep and actual sleep? Wearables are beginning to incorporate heart-rate monitoring, which helps correlate sleep stages, but they don\u2019t measure respiration or neural activity like a polysomnograph and so rely more heavily on inference.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EFitbit encounters skepticism from users, including me, about the accuracy of its sleep measurement. Yuen admits he hasn\u2019t achieved perfection, but he largely brushes off the incredulity, saying it stems from the fact that our instincts for how well we\u2019re sleeping don\u2019t typically match reality. For steps, users can monitor their progress, but not so with sleep. (For his part, Kahn insists that he has the formula for maximum accuracy: He says his huge quantity of rock-solid polysomnography data and wristband sleep-tracking information have helped him develop an algorithm that adjusts for the imperfections of wristband data.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EWhatever the accuracy of Fitbit\u2019s data, the company has a ton of it, and is seeing some interesting patterns. Yuen calls one of his data scientists, Jacob Arnold, 31, into the conference room at Fitbit headquarters in San Francisco\u2019s South of Market neighborhood. Arnold also has a Ph.D., his in astronomy and astrophysics. Together they unveil some graphs demonstrating that people around the world get more sleep in winter and less in summer. Daylight clearly has an effect on sleep patterns; temperature might too. We sleep less on the hottest day of the year than on the longest day. The data show that the longest average duration of sleep usually occurs on the weekend following New Year\u2019s Day. Yuen also makes it clear that getting a lot of sleep is not equivalent to having a restful night.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EYuen and Arnold then reveal a graph demonstrating that, statistically speaking, no one gets less sleep than the demographic group to which I belong, forty-something males. I\u2019m not sure how to take the news. Is it a body blow or a hopeful sign of more rest in my future?\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1194746\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002F29\u002Fsleep-data\u002Fsle2-07-01-15\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=341\" data-orig-size=\"545,341\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"sle2-07-01-15\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=341?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=341?w=545\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-1194746\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg?w=545&#038;h=341\" alt=\"sle2-07-01-15\" width=\"545\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg 545w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg?w=150&amp;h=94 150w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg?w=300&amp;h=188 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EEstablishing the norm the way these charts do is an important step from a scientific standpoint. But to be indispensable in the marketplace, Fitbit needs to empower users with real guidance. \u201cWe need to take the veil off of sleep,\u201d says Yuen. \u201cWe need to make this data much more understandable so they don\u2019t feel powerless.\u201d\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EFitbit co-founder and CEO James Park echoes the sentiment. Some analysts are predicting that fitness trackers have peaked, especially because of the launch of the Apple Watch (which doesn\u2019t track slumber because it needs to be charged every night). Park knows that if he can help his customers sleep better, Fitbit will become irreplaceable. \u201cA lot of clinical studies show that certain behaviors might affect sleep: light levels, noise levels, caffeine, time of exercise,\u201d says Park. \u201cThe next step is to tie prescriptive elements into it. That\u2019s one of the big opportunities for this category. Can companies actually deliver coaching services to help people sleep that consumers actually want to pay for?\u201d\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Chr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003ENot long after meeting\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003ESteve Kay, dean of the Dornsife school of arts and sciences at the University of Southern California, I notice he\u2019s wearing a Fitbit. Curious about what kind of a sleeper one of the world\u2019s leading experts in circadian rhythm would be, I ask how he\u2019d fared the night before. He looks at the app on his phone. \u201cI went to bed at a quarter past 11 and got up at 20 past four,\u201d he says with a shake of the head. Count Kay among the many of us getting less rest than we need.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EI\u2019m in Kay\u2019s conference room with Ross Bersot, a venture partner at Bay City Capital turned entrepreneur. Bersot, 40, and Kay, 53, are a latter-day Zalmon Simmons and Harry Johnson. A few years ago, Kay published research demonstrating that it\u2019s possible to isolate and manipulate the speed of an organism\u2019s circadian rhythm using molecular compounds. Bersot provided funding to Kay\u2019s lab in hopes of potentially starting a company based on more detailed findings. That company, Reset Therapeutics, is now real and based in the Bay Area. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003ELike Fullpower and Fitbit, Reset is intent on getting to the heart of the nature of sleep. But while others duke it out for wrist real estate, Reset is going deep into our bodies with a different set of tools. It\u2019s pairing Kay\u2019s research with the latest advances in genomics and high-throughput screening, and partnering with personal-genetics startup 23andMe to try to develop a drug that can manipulate our circadian rhythm.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EAlmost every living thing on earth has an internal clock\u2014or more accurately, a symphony of clocks ticking away at the cellular level\u2014that tells its owner when to rest and when to produce. It\u2019s not just humans. Monsanto recently published a paper demonstrating that it could boost soybean yields 5% by tweaking one of the plant\u2019s clock-associated genes. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to help them figure out why,\u201d says Kay, whose lab is working with Monsanto. \u201cAnd all the major ag and biotech companies are interested. When you\u2019re a plant stuck in the ground, everything is circadian. Biomass, yield, response to extreme temperatures\u2014it\u2019s all clock regulated.\u201d\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?quality=80\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1194632\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002F29\u002Fsleep-data\u002Fsleep\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg\" data-orig-size=\"540,259\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"sleep\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?w=540\" class=\"aligncenter wp-image-1194632 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?quality=80&#038;w=540&#038;h=259\" alt=\"sleep\" width=\"540\" height=\"259\" srcset=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg 540w, https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?quality=80&amp;w=150&amp;h=72 150w,
