https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?quality=80&amp;w=300&amp;h=144 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EHuman clocks are equally powerful, but we aren\u2019t quite as enslaved by them because we don\u2019t depend on photosynthesis. By some estimates, up to 70% of us live in spite of our internal clocks, or in the scientific jargon, outside our chronotype. Your chronotype predisposes you to being a night owl or a morning person or even being hungry at certain times, and many of us are guilty of ignoring our chronotypes, whether because of our lifestyle or just the call of duty.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EWhen we live largely out of sync with our chronotypes, we experience everything from grogginess and reduced productivity to digestion issues, weight gain, and accelerated aging. We also increase our risk of obesity and Type 2 diabetes. Kay cites studies that link such lifestyles to an increased rate of breast cancer. \u201cWe evolved to adapt on this planet that has periods of light and dark. But modern life is really clashing with that,\u201d he says. \u201cThe key is being internally synchronized. Your sleep-wake cycles, your food-intake cycles, your metabolic cycles are all working together. When they\u2019re out of sync, that\u2019s when (a) you feel lousy, and (b) you start seeing the disturbance of all kinds of markers. Sleep efficiency collapses. Leptin plummets. Insulin goes up.\u201d\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EReset wants to tweak our clocks with a drug. Such a drug would help reset the chronotypes of people who choose or need to live a different lifestyle or whose clocks are impaired. For now the development phase is limited to two so-called orphan diseases, narcolepsy\u2014a neurological disorder that causes significant daytime sleepiness and in some cases cataplectic attacks\u2014and Cushing\u2019s disease, a neuroendocrine disorder characterized by excess blood sugar, obesity, and pituitary tumors. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EWorking with orphan diseases enables the company to help people sooner and get on the fast track to regulatory approval. \u201cWith the Cushing\u2019s program, we\u2019re focused on a protein that makes a clock run at a 24-hour cycle,\u201d says Bersot. And so far, so good: \u201cWe\u2019re restoring the rhythms to a 24-hour period, and in our early work with animals, we\u2019ve seen blood glucose and insulin levels return to normal as a result.\u201d Reset plans to take the Cushing\u2019s drug to clinical trials next year and the narcolepsy treatment after that. Bersot hopes that once the drug establishes its ability to reset the body clock for sufferers of those diseases, Reset will develop it more broadly as a sleep aid for shift workers and anyone else whose clock and lifestyle are misaligned.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EIn the meantime the company is working with 23andMe to explore correlations between chronotypes and various genetic expressions. According to Emily Drabant Conley, 23andMe\u2019s director of business development and a Ph.D. in neuroscience, 80% of 23andMe\u2019s customers allow their genotypes to be used in research. She\u2019s scouring their files in hopes of finding correlations between genotypes and sleep-related survey data. For example, how do people of a given genetic expression most commonly answer these questions: How many hours of sleep do you average? Do you snore? Do you take sleep medication? \u201cSleep is interesting because it\u2019s not like eye color, where you have only five choices. Having a lot of data that you can mine is important,\u201d she says. \u201cBut we\u2019re just at the beginning. We\u2019ve done the first pass at the genetics of being a morning person. We know that genetics plays a role in whether you need six hours or eight hours. The prescriptive aspect will come.\u201d\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Chr \u002F\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EIt\u2019s a common refrain,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and despite the way it may sound to someone yearning for rest, it\u2019s hardly a cop-out. In the realm of data science there\u2019s a commonly accepted notion of how progress occurs. First comes descriptive analytics, next predictive analytics, and finally prescriptive analytics. In other words, describe the system, predict outcomes based on those descriptions, and prescribe actions to attain desired outcomes. To the layperson, prescription may sound like the most difficult phase, but in reality the hardest part is often where we are today, measuring and mapping behavior just to get to the point where it\u2019s conceivable to predict behavior and prescribe actions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EScience is clearly advancing in the quest to understand sleep. We\u2019re adding data in quantities that were unimaginable even a decade ago, much less during the time that \u003Ci\u003EFortune \u003C\u002Fi\u003Efirst considered the subject. Big Pharma and biotech companies are drilling into our genomes to find links between DNA and nighttime routines; they\u2019re also exploring medications that adjust the circadian rhythm. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003EWearable-device companies are casting nets far and wide. Fitbit recently enabled its devices to track sleep automatically, rather than as a user-triggered behavior, and some of its devices now monitor heart rate, which helps Yuen and Arnold make finer distinctions between lack of motion and restful sleep. Full-power just entered a partnership with Simmons to provide sleep-tracking technology for the mattress maker\u2019s new Sleeptracker Smartbed, which will provide noninvasive sleep-monitoring technology and is scheduled to hit the market in 2016. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EOn top of all this, scientists around the world are using cheap wearables to conduct their own exploratory research. A quick search of Google Scholar shows dozens of wearable-powered experiments and papers detailing the efforts to unravel the mysteries of the night. All of which will\u2014one day soon, let\u2019s hope\u2014translate to a more personalized analysis and formula for how each of us can get a better night\u2019s sleep.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EWhich brings me back to my night in Fullpower\u2019s sleep lab. A few days after my test I received a PSG report that shines a light on my own personal darkness. The prognosis was mixed. The good news: My sleep-efficiency score was a robust 93.5%\u2014\u201cYou should be proud of that,\u201d says Kahn\u2014which means that most of the time I\u2019m in bed, I\u2019m sleeping. And I\u2019m quick. I drifted off in 2.5 minutes, even with all those wires attached. The bad: I snored. In fact, I was diagnosed with \u201cmild to moderate\u201d apnea. That officially makes me part of the $165 billion problem. I was advised to see a doctor.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EThat\u2019s not the prescription I was looking for. I\u2019m not crazy about doctors, and I\u2019m afraid of being persuaded to buy a machine that I won\u2019t use. So for now, I think I\u2019ll just keep trying to do what I know to be right. Exercise. Keep a consistent routine. Restrict the hours that I eat, try to lay off the junk food and booze, and hope that before long someone will offer me a more personalized regimen.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\"\u003EUntil then, I\u2019ll always have the memory of a laughing, volleying Marissa Mayer and the knowledge that together, on one strange night in Santa Cruz, we\u2014and whatever caused my 17 other REM interruptions\u2014slept, or at least tried to, in the name of progress.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EJeffrey O\u2019Brien is a former \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ci\u003E senior editor and co-founder of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.storytk.com\u002F\"\u003EStoryTK\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a Bay Area studio that crafts stories for companies.\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EA version of this article appears in the July 1, 2015 issue of Fortune magazine with the headline \u201cCracking the Sleep Code.\u201d\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I\u2019m playing tennis with Marissa Mayer, and  oddly, the Yahoo ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"YHOO"},"content":[]}," CEO is wearing a pearlescent purple gown and sipping from a teacup. Her dress is just long enough to obscure her feet, so she appears to be floating across the baseline. As she strikes the ball, she tips her chin skyward and laughs in slow motion."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Meanwhile, I\u2019m perched in the lotus position atop a manta ray that\u2019s hovering above the ground like some kind of Landspeeder. And I\u2019m panicking. How can I keep my balance and still hit the ball\u2014especially with my shirt collar pulling at my neck the way it is? Can\u2019t swing my racket. I jerk my head left. Then right. I claw at my jawline. The ball has cleared the net, and it\u2019s headed my way. If only. I could. Just. Move. My head."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And poof. She\u2019s gone. I open my eyes in a strange room. It\u2019s pitch dark and completely silent, but I manage to find my bearings. Santa Cruz, Calif. Breathing heavily, I carefully disentangle a gaggle of wires twisted around my neck and roll over to glance at the clock. Just after 3 a.m."]},{"tag":"hr","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This scene, I now know,  was merely one of 18 REM-sleep interruptions that I experienced between 11:18 p.m. and 6:16 a.m. during one long February night. What a strange setting for the only dream I\u2019ve ever had about a chief executive: in a laboratory, tethered to a byzantine apparatus designed to monitor my brain activity as well as every breath, eye movement, muscle twitch, and heartbeat."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Let me explain. Like you and probably everyone you know, I\u2019ve always been confounded by my sleep routine. Why do I one morning rise ready to tackle the day and the next seem barely able to lift my head? How much rest can I be getting if I wake up sideways with the covers on the floor and my wife in the guest room? Most important, what can I do better? I don\u2019t want a magic pill. I\u2019ve tried those. I know the rules of thumb: less stress, more exercise, better diet, no afternoon caffeine, put down the damn phone. But I\u2019d kill for a personalized formula. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So I subjected myself to a polysomnography test, or PSG, hoping to unravel some of the mysteries of the night. My procedure was administered in the offices of Fullpower Technologies, one floor down from where I had spent most of the evening talking with the company\u2019s founder and CEO, Philippe Kahn."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A French expatriate who grew up in Paris, Kahn, 63, is a Silicon Valley oracle whose track record predates the web. He founded Borland Software (acquired by Micro Focus) ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"MCFUF"},"content":[]}," in the mid-1980s, followed by Starfish software (Motorola) and LightSurf Technologies (VeriSign) ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"VRSN"},"content":[]},". In 1997, while anticipating the birth of his daughter, he paired a state-of-the-art Casio ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"CSIOY"},"content":[]}," camera with a Motorola Startac and became, he claims, the first person to transmit a digital photo over cellular airwaves. He\u2019s also been a leader in wearable technologies."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1190999","align":"aligncenter","width":"457"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?quality=80"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_c.jpg?quality=80","alt":"Full Power, Philippe Kahn","width":"457","height":"610"},"content":[]}]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Philippe Kahn says Fullpower is \u201coperating a huge sleep experiment unlike anything anyone has ever done.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Photograph by Ian Allen for Fortune"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["That\u2019s precisely the focus of Fullpower, which licenses its software to other companies. Nearly five dozen framed patents for wearable-related software and devices hang on the wall in the company\u2019s lobby. The oldest dates to 2005, long before tracking steps became such a phenomenon. In the conference room there\u2019s an assembly of chairs and tables around a full-size bed, making obvious Kahn\u2019s latest obsession. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fullpower built the lab about a decade ago to capture data from sleep patterns. Of course, test subjects don\u2019t typically snooze deeply with wires glued to their skulls, chests, legs, and arms. But almost everyone manages to at least nod off for a while, and the data that subjects generate are valuable and often surprising. \u201cWhat we found early on is that sometimes you sleep less and feel more refreshed,\u201d Kahn says. \u201cIt\u2019s because you woke up in the light part of the sleep cycle.\u201d The insight led him to develop a sleep-cycle alarm that could determine the best time to alert a person within a certain window. \u201cSometimes it\u2019s better to get up at 10 of seven than at seven,\u201d he says."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Kahn insists that he\u2019s on the cusp of many more such discoveries, and he\u2019s intent on dispelling some of the conventional wisdom that stresses people out. \u201cPeople say that if you can\u2019t sleep for eight hours without waking up, something\u2019s wrong with you. That\u2019s such a fallacy,\u201d he says. \u201cBefore electricity, people used to sleep in two shifts. That\u2019s how I behave. Sleep for four hours, get up and do an hour and a half of work, and then another four.\u201d He\u2019s also skeptical of the notion that a quiet room is the best environment for shut-eye and dismisses the perceived deleterious effects of repeated rousing. \u201cThe sign of good sleep hygiene may not be how many times you wake up, but rather how rapidly you fall back to sleep. Sleep should be like hunger. Eat only when you\u2019re hungry and until you\u2019re satisfied.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fullpower has oceans of data to back Kahn\u2019s theories. The company provides the sleep-tracking and activity-monitoring software for the Jawbone UP and Nike Fuel ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"NKE"},"content":[]}," wearable devices as well as a new line of Swiss-made smartwatches and the forthcoming Simmons Sleeptracker Smartbed. The products transmit a mother lode of information (with users\u2019 consent) to Kahn\u2019s team. He thinks that by combining qualitative lab data and quantitative real-world data with machine learning, artificial intelligence, and other analytics technologies, he can unlock the secrets that so many of us walking dead are looking for: a better night\u2019s sleep. \u201cWe\u2019re operating a huge sleep experiment, worldwide, unlike anything anyone has ever done,\u201d he says. \u201cWe have 250 million nights of sleep in our database, and we\u2019re using all the latest technologies to make sense of it.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Kahn is not alone. He\u2019s part of a movement of brilliant entrepreneurs, data scientists, engineers, and academics who are looking at demographics, geographies, and lifestyles, and even into our genomes. They\u2019re the beneficiaries of a historic explosion in sleep data, and they\u2019re using many of the same technologies that are busily decoding some of the world\u2019s other great mysteries. Tiny sensors, big data, analytics, and cloud computing can predict machine breakage, pinpoint power outages, and build better supply chains. Why not put them to work to optimize the most valuable complex system of all, the human body?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle1-07-01-15.jpg","alt":"sle1-07-01-15","width":"545","height":"500"},"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It\u2019s not an exaggeration to say lack of sleep is killing us. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention calls it a public health epidemic and estimates that as many as 70 million Americans have a sleep disorder. Sleep deprivation has been linked to clinical depression, obesity, Type 2 diabetes, and cancer. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration estimates that drowsy driving causes 1,550 deaths and 40,000 injuries annually in the U.S.\u2009 There are 84 sleep disorders, and some 100 million people\u201480% of them undiagnosed\u2014suffer from one of them in particular: Obstructive sleep apnea, generally indicated by snoring, costs the U.S. economy as much as $165 billion a year, according to a Harvard Medical School study. That\u2019s more than asthma, heart failure, stroke, hypertension, or drunk driving. And the study doesn\u2019t account for tangential effects, like loss of intimacy and divorce. BCC Research predicts that the global market for sleep-aid products\u2014everything from specialty mattresses and high-tech pillows to drugs and at-home tests\u2014will hit $76.7 billion by 2019. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The financial upside for anyone who can crack the sleep code is obvious. And so the race is on. \u201cI believe that 15 years from now, if we do this right, we can actually tackle epidemics like obesity, diabetes, and high blood pressure, and any number of lifestyle diseases,\u201d says Kahn. \u201cWe\u2019re going to help people live longer and better lives.\u201d"]},{"tag":"hr","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In 1934 this magazine ran   a sprawling cover story under the simple headline \u201cSleep.\u201d Published about three decades after the dawn of sleep research, it explored a litany of the day\u2019s devices, concoctions, drugs, and homespun remedies designed, or at least purported, to help insomniacs. The article chronicled the merits of everything from Ovaltine to morphine and Barbital, a synthetic hypnotic that was used as a sleep aid until the mid-1950s despite being habit-forming and occasionally deadly. The story also unpacked the relationship between Zalmon G. Simmons and Harry M. Johnson. Simmons was the president of the eponymous company his father founded, which has by now sold nearly 100 million mattresses, most notably under the Beautyrest brand. Johnson was a psychology professor at Ohio State who was conducting sleep research on the side."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["At the time, old Zalmon was looking to solve two problems: He needed to sell more mattresses. And he needed sleep. The head of the iconic mattress maker was an insomniac! So he gave Johnson $25,000 to set up a sleep lab at the university now known as Carnegie Mellon. At the time it was believed that normal sleepers lay motionless throughout the night. Johnson collected 2.5 million data points from 160 subjects and demonstrated the folly of that theory. Normal sleepers, he determined, change positions from 20 to 85 times a night, with 35 being a sort of sweet spot. When we toss and turn more, we wake up groggy; any less, and we\u2019re stiff and sore. (The insight would pay dividends for Simmons, the company. Spurred by the revelation that proper sleep required movement, it became the first to introduce king and queen-size mattresses. Unfortunately, Zalmon didn\u2019t solve his personal problem. His insomnia devolved into depression and, in the words of the article, his \u201cfortune began to wobble. Soon after that, sleep ceased to be a problem. For Zalmon G. Simmons was dead.\u201d) "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Those movements are what enable today\u2019s wearable devices to monitor sleep. Gartner Group ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"IT"},"content":[]}," projects sales of 36 million smart wristbands, a category that includes most Fitbit ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"FIT"},"content":[]}," devices, Jawbone UP, and Nike Fuel, in 2015 and 2016. Fitbit is definitely king. NPD Group estimates that it has an 85% market share. Fitbit raised $732 million in a highly anticipated IPO stoked by the impressive metrics revealed in its S-1 filing: nearly $132 million in net income on $745 million in revenue last year, with $336 million in revenue in the first quarter of this year. Fitbit has sold more than 21 million devices since 2008 and has 9.5 million active users."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["That means Fitbit is gathering far more data in one night than Johnson did in his career. Thanks to its sleep-monitoring technology, the company can distinguish among variations in movements and has determined that the majority of its users actually wake up between three and 17 times a night\u20149.3 times being average. Most awakenings are short and probably not remembered. Fitbit\u2019s data suggest that the number of awakenings drops with age until about 45, and then remains flat. Men under 50 have, on average, one more awakening per night than women of the same age, but the discrepancy largely disappears after 50. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fitbit\u2019s research team developed the algorithms to gather and analyze all these data under the guidance of Shelten Yuen. Yuen, 36, who has a Ph.D. in engineering sciences, has worked in missile defense and has done research in surgical robotics. He was approached by Fitbit\u2019s co-founders back in 2010 to write the software underlying the wearable device they were envisioning. \u201cCrazy sensor thing?\u201d Yuen remembers thinking. \u201cThat\u2019s my deal.\u201d He signed on as employee No. 4."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_1191001","align":"aligncenter","width":"457"},"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?quality=80"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle07_d.jpg?quality=80","alt":"Fitbit, Shelten Yuen","width":"457","height":"610"},"content":[]}]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["\u201cWe need to take the veil off of sleep,\u201d says Shelten Yuen, who leads Fitbit\u2019s research team and wrote the original software that tracks Fitbit users\u2019 movement and sleep."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Photograph by Ian Allen for Fortune"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The first goal for Fitbit was tracking steps. Yuen figured it would be a snap\u2014until he realized that a regular accelerometer can\u2019t distinguish between a wrist that\u2019s moving with a walking gait and a wrist that\u2019s, say, shoveling food. He delivered what he thought was the perfect device. \u201cThey said, \u2018Did you try scratching your head? Did you put it in your pocket? How about strapped to a bra?\u2019 Suddenly it became a crazy, phenomenally hard problem,\u201d he remembers. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Steps are easy compared with sleep. For starters, what\u2019s the difference between an absence of movement while trying to sleep and actual sleep? Wearables are beginning to incorporate heart-rate monitoring, which helps correlate sleep stages, but they don\u2019t measure respiration or neural activity like a polysomnograph and so rely more heavily on inference."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fitbit encounters skepticism from users, including me, about the accuracy of its sleep measurement. Yuen admits he hasn\u2019t achieved perfection, but he largely brushes off the incredulity, saying it stems from the fact that our instincts for how well we\u2019re sleeping don\u2019t typically match reality. For steps, users can monitor their progress, but not so with sleep. (For his part, Kahn insists that he has the formula for maximum accuracy: He says his huge quantity of rock-solid polysomnography data and wristband sleep-tracking information have helped him develop an algorithm that adjusts for the imperfections of wristband data.)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Whatever the accuracy of Fitbit\u2019s data, the company has a ton of it, and is seeing some interesting patterns. Yuen calls one of his data scientists, Jacob Arnold, 31, into the conference room at Fitbit headquarters in San Francisco\u2019s South of Market neighborhood. Arnold also has a Ph.D., his in astronomy and astrophysics. Together they unveil some graphs demonstrating that people around the world get more sleep in winter and less in summer. Daylight clearly has an effect on sleep patterns; temperature might too. We sleep less on the hottest day of the year than on the longest day. The data show that the longest average duration of sleep usually occurs on the weekend following New Year\u2019s Day. Yuen also makes it clear that getting a lot of sleep is not equivalent to having a restful night."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Yuen and Arnold then reveal a graph demonstrating that, statistically speaking, no one gets less sleep than the demographic group to which I belong, forty-something males. I\u2019m not sure how to take the news. Is it a body blow or a hopeful sign of more rest in my future?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsle2-07-01-15.jpg","alt":"sle2-07-01-15","width":"545","height":"341"},"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Establishing the norm the way these charts do is an important step from a scientific standpoint. But to be indispensable in the marketplace, Fitbit needs to empower users with real guidance. \u201cWe need to take the veil off of sleep,\u201d says Yuen. \u201cWe need to make this data much more understandable so they don\u2019t feel powerless.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fitbit co-founder and CEO James Park echoes the sentiment. Some analysts are predicting that fitness trackers have peaked, especially because of the launch of the Apple Watch (which doesn\u2019t track slumber because it needs to be charged every night). Park knows that if he can help his customers sleep better, Fitbit will become irreplaceable. \u201cA lot of clinical studies show that certain behaviors might affect sleep: light levels, noise levels, caffeine, time of exercise,\u201d says Park. \u201cThe next step is to tie prescriptive elements into it. That\u2019s one of the big opportunities for this category. Can companies actually deliver coaching services to help people sleep that consumers actually want to pay for?\u201d"]},{"tag":"hr","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Not long after meeting   Steve Kay, dean of the Dornsife school of arts and sciences at the University of Southern California, I notice he\u2019s wearing a Fitbit. Curious about what kind of a sleeper one of the world\u2019s leading experts in circadian rhythm would be, I ask how he\u2019d fared the night before. He looks at the app on his phone. \u201cI went to bed at a quarter past 11 and got up at 20 past four,\u201d he says with a shake of the head. Count Kay among the many of us getting less rest than we need."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I\u2019m in Kay\u2019s conference room with Ross Bersot, a venture partner at Bay City Capital turned entrepreneur. Bersot, 40, and Kay, 53, are a latter-day Zalmon Simmons and Harry Johnson. A few years ago, Kay published research demonstrating that it\u2019s possible to isolate and manipulate the speed of an organism\u2019s circadian rhythm using molecular compounds. Bersot provided funding to Kay\u2019s lab in hopes of potentially starting a company based on more detailed findings. That company, Reset Therapeutics, is now real and based in the Bay Area. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Like Fullpower and Fitbit, Reset is intent on getting to the heart of the nature of sleep. But while others duke it out for wrist real estate, Reset is going deep into our bodies with a different set of tools. It\u2019s pairing Kay\u2019s research with the latest advances in genomics and high-throughput screening, and partnering with personal-genetics startup 23andMe to try to develop a drug that can manipulate our circadian rhythm."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Almost every living thing on earth has an internal clock\u2014or more accurately, a symphony of clocks ticking away at the cellular level\u2014that tells its owner when to rest and when to produce. It\u2019s not just humans. Monsanto recently published a paper demonstrating that it could boost soybean yields 5% by tweaking one of the plant\u2019s clock-associated genes. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to help them figure out why,\u201d says Kay, whose lab is working with Monsanto. \u201cAnd all the major ag and biotech companies are interested. When you\u2019re a plant stuck in the ground, everything is circadian. Biomass, yield, response to extreme temperatures\u2014it\u2019s all clock regulated.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?quality=80","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Fsleep1.jpg?quality=80","alt":"sleep","width":"540","height":"259"},"content":[]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Human clocks are equally powerful, but we aren\u2019t quite as enslaved by them because we don\u2019t depend on photosynthesis. By some estimates, up to 70% of us live in spite of our internal clocks, or in the scientific jargon, outside our chronotype. Your chronotype predisposes you to being a night owl or a morning person or even being hungry at certain times, and many of us are guilty of ignoring our chronotypes, whether because of our lifestyle or just the call of duty."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When we live largely out of sync with our chronotypes, we experience everything from grogginess and reduced productivity to digestion issues, weight gain, and accelerated aging. We also increase our risk of obesity and Type 2 diabetes. Kay cites studies that link such lifestyles to an increased rate of breast cancer. \u201cWe evolved to adapt on this planet that has periods of light and dark. But modern life is really clashing with that,\u201d he says. \u201cThe key is being internally synchronized. Your sleep-wake cycles, your food-intake cycles, your metabolic cycles are all working together. When they\u2019re out of sync, that\u2019s when (a) you feel lousy, and (b) you start seeing the disturbance of all kinds of markers. Sleep efficiency collapses. Leptin plummets. Insulin goes up.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Reset wants to tweak our clocks with a drug. Such a drug would help reset the chronotypes of people who choose or need to live a different lifestyle or whose clocks are impaired. For now the development phase is limited to two so-called orphan diseases, narcolepsy\u2014a neurological disorder that causes significant daytime sleepiness and in some cases cataplectic attacks\u2014and Cushing\u2019s disease, a neuroendocrine disorder characterized by excess blood sugar, obesity, and pituitary tumors. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Working with orphan diseases enables the company to help people sooner and get on the fast track to regulatory approval. \u201cWith the Cushing\u2019s program, we\u2019re focused on a protein that makes a clock run at a 24-hour cycle,\u201d says Bersot. And so far, so good: \u201cWe\u2019re restoring the rhythms to a 24-hour period, and in our early work with animals, we\u2019ve seen blood glucose and insulin levels return to normal as a result.\u201d Reset plans to take the Cushing\u2019s drug to clinical trials next year and the narcolepsy treatment after that. Bersot hopes that once the drug establishes its ability to reset the body clock for sufferers of those diseases, Reset will develop it more broadly as a sleep aid for shift workers and anyone else whose clock and lifestyle are misaligned."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In the meantime the company is working with 23andMe to explore correlations between chronotypes and various genetic expressions. According to Emily Drabant Conley, 23andMe\u2019s director of business development and a Ph.D. in neuroscience, 80% of 23andMe\u2019s customers allow their genotypes to be used in research. She\u2019s scouring their files in hopes of finding correlations between genotypes and sleep-related survey data. For example, how do people of a given genetic expression most commonly answer these questions: How many hours of sleep do you average? Do you snore? Do you take sleep medication? \u201cSleep is interesting because it\u2019s not like eye color, where you have only five choices. Having a lot of data that you can mine is important,\u201d she says. \u201cBut we\u2019re just at the beginning. We\u2019ve done the first pass at the genetics of being a morning person. We know that genetics plays a role in whether you need six hours or eight hours. The prescriptive aspect will come.\u201d"]},{"tag":"hr","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It\u2019s a common refrain,  and despite the way it may sound to someone yearning for rest, it\u2019s hardly a cop-out. In the realm of data science there\u2019s a commonly accepted notion of how progress occurs. First comes descriptive analytics, next predictive analytics, and finally prescriptive analytics. In other words, describe the system, predict outcomes based on those descriptions, and prescribe actions to attain desired outcomes. To the layperson, prescription may sound like the most difficult phase, but in reality the hardest part is often where we are today, measuring and mapping behavior just to get to the point where it\u2019s conceivable to predict behavior and prescribe actions."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Science is clearly advancing in the quest to understand sleep. We\u2019re adding data in quantities that were unimaginable even a decade ago, much less during the time that ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune "]},"first considered the subject. Big Pharma and biotech companies are drilling into our genomes to find links between DNA and nighttime routines; they\u2019re also exploring medications that adjust the circadian rhythm. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Wearable-device companies are casting nets far and wide. Fitbit recently enabled its devices to track sleep automatically, rather than as a user-triggered behavior, and some of its devices now monitor heart rate, which helps Yuen and Arnold make finer distinctions between lack of motion and restful sleep. Full-power just entered a partnership with Simmons to provide sleep-tracking technology for the mattress maker\u2019s new Sleeptracker Smartbed, which will provide noninvasive sleep-monitoring technology and is scheduled to hit the market in 2016. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["On top of all this, scientists around the world are using cheap wearables to conduct their own exploratory research. A quick search of Google Scholar shows dozens of wearable-powered experiments and papers detailing the efforts to unravel the mysteries of the night. All of which will\u2014one day soon, let\u2019s hope\u2014translate to a more personalized analysis and formula for how each of us can get a better night\u2019s sleep."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Which brings me back to my night in Fullpower\u2019s sleep lab. A few days after my test I received a PSG report that shines a light on my own personal darkness. The prognosis was mixed. The good news: My sleep-efficiency score was a robust 93.5%\u2014\u201cYou should be proud of that,\u201d says Kahn\u2014which means that most of the time I\u2019m in bed, I\u2019m sleeping. And I\u2019m quick. I drifted off in 2.5 minutes, even with all those wires attached. The bad: I snored. In fact, I was diagnosed with \u201cmild to moderate\u201d apnea. That officially makes me part of the $165 billion problem. I was advised to see a doctor."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["That\u2019s not the prescription I was looking for. I\u2019m not crazy about doctors, and I\u2019m afraid of being persuaded to buy a machine that I won\u2019t use. So for now, I think I\u2019ll just keep trying to do what I know to be right. Exercise. Keep a consistent routine. Restrict the hours that I eat, try to lay off the junk food and booze, and hope that before long someone will offer me a more personalized regimen."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Until then, I\u2019ll always have the memory of a laughing, volleying Marissa Mayer and the knowledge that together, on one strange night in Santa Cruz, we\u2014and whatever caused my 17 other REM interruptions\u2014slept, or at least tried to, in the name of progress."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Jeffrey O\u2019Brien is a former "]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]},{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":[" senior editor and co-founder of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.storytk.com\u002F"},"content":["StoryTK"]},", a Bay Area studio that crafts stories for             "][Tech', Search', Search', Subscribe', SpaceX', SpaceX and Boeing Win 4 More NASA Manned Missions to Space', Brainstorm Health', My Crystal Ball Reading for Obamacare', diesel emissions scandal', Volkswagen Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels', CEO Daily', Trump\u2019s Industrial Policy, Part II', Photograph by Bloomberg via Getty Images', Fortune 500', Amazon Faces Questions Over How It Lists Prices', Leena Rao', Updated: Sep 22, 2016 10:55 PM UTC | Originally published: Sep 21, 2016', Amazon',  came under fire Monday after ', ProPublica ', reported', u" that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. The article pointed out that Amazon's strategy hurt shoppers, many of whom end up paying extra at checkout, and ran counter to its professed philosophy of putting customers first.", u"The article raised questions about whether Amazon's is trying to unfairly profit by funneling customers to more expensive products. The company has said previously that it ranks items based on the data it receives from its millions of customers and how they buy on the site.", For example, Amazon said its ranking favors items that ship for free and that can get to customers faster. The technology also takes into account other factors such as price, and the rating of the seller.', Related', Blue Ribbon Companies', Will Tech Titans, Pressured By Trump, Create More U.S. Factory Jobs?', Blue Ribbon Companies', Will Tech Titans, Pressured By Trump, Create More U.S. Factory Jobs?', Shipping is a big factor, Amazon says, because data shows that customers decide to buy products primarily based upon free shipping and shipping speed. Items sold or fulfilled by Amazon fall into the Prime subscription offering, which charges consumers $99 annually to get anything from toilet paper to diapers to books delivered to them in two days or less. Amazon also offers the ability for items to be included in Super Saver Shipping (which requires no Prime membership and ships orders above $49 for free).', In a statement to ', Fortune', , an Amazon spokesperson said: "The vast majority of our items ordered \u2013 9 out of 10 \u2013 can ship for free. The sorting algorithms the article refers to are designed for that 90% of items ordered, where shipping costs do not apply."', u"Of course, by prioritizing faster shipping (a.k.a. Prime-eligible items), Amazon is strongly encouraging more of its shoppers to sign up for Prime. That's a benefit for Amazon, as Prime members spend more than non-Prime members on the site. A recent ", Consumer Intelligence Research Partners study',  estimates that Prime shoppers spent about $1,200 on average last year, compared to about $500 for non-members.', u"However, ProPublica asserts that under Amazon's ranking systems, shoppers who are not Prime members can end up paying more for products if the fail to scroll more deeply into results. According the report, TheHardwareCity.com was selling superglue for $6.75 with free shipping. Fat Boy Tools was selling the same super glue for $7.27 with free shipping. But the algorithm ranked a the same glue sold by Amazon, which cost slightly more, $7.80, higher. But for non-Prime members or those who weren't interested in Super Saver Shipping, shipping costs for the Amazon glue amounted to $6.51, which increased the total price to $14.31.", Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has ', long said', u" that key to Amazon's mission is putting the customer first. ProPublica says that its algorithms don't do that.", Get Data Sheet', , ', Fortune\u2019s',  technology newsletter.', u"Other data backs up Amazon's belief that free shipping dominates purchase decisions. According to a ", 2015 comScore study,',  58% of online shoppers reported adding items to their shopping cart in order to qualify for free shipping.', It\u2019s no secret that Amazon believes its competitive advantage is in getting products to its customers faster than other retailers. The company has been exploring using drones to deliver packages to shoppers in 30 minutes and is also deploying fleets of planes and trucks to make speedier deliveries. In turn, more customers are seeking faster shipping, especially around the holidays.', The ', allure',  for many outside merchants to use and pay for Amazon to handle its shipping is to sell to Amazon\u2019s estimated 50 million Prime members. Merchants are eligible to be part of Prime delivery only if they are enrolled in the fulfillment program. Merchants must pay Amazon anywhere from $1.50 to $100 per order, depending on size and weight, for the service\u2014plus a standard fee.', ProPublica ', says', u" that some merchants can't afford to pay these fees, citing a number of examples. But merchants who don't pay for fulfillment, may also be at a disadvantage because of Amazon's rankings.", For more on Amazon, watch:', u"Besides shipping, it's also worth mentioning that there are other benefits to using Amazon's fulfillment program for merchants. As part of the program, merchants ship their items to an Amazon warehouse, and Amazon takes care of the rest including packaging the items, processing customer payments, and customer service.", Amazon has also been experimenting with letting certain merchants sell to Prime members without using fulfillment services. Amazon is working with a set of larger merchants that already have warehouses across the U.S. and are able to deliver within the Prime two-day window. Because these merchants don\u2019t need fulfillment services, they don\u2019t pay the same fees to Amazon but get access to Amazon\u2019s negotiated shipping prices with companies like ', UPS', , which are much lower than standard rates.', Correction, Sept. 22, 3:20 pm: An earlier of version of this article incorrectly said that search results considered seller ratings in the order of results. In fact, it was product listings. of Use","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fsubscription.timeinc.com\u002Fstorefront\u002Fprivacy\u002Ffortune\u002Fprivacy_terms_service.html"},{"name":"Your California Privacy Rights","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fsubscription.timeinc.com\u002Fstorefront\u002Fprivacy\u002Ffortune\u002Fgeneric_privacy_new.html?dnp-source=I#california"},{"name":"Careers","href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.timeinc.com\u002Fcareers\u002F"}]},"socialShare":{"shortList":[{"name":"Facebook"},{"name":"Twitter"}],"fullList":[{"name":"Facebook"},{"name":"Twitter"},{"name":"Email"},{"name":"Reddit"},{"name":"Pinterest"},{"name":"LinkedIn"}]},"socialFollow":{"fullList":[{"name":"Facebook","href":"\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002FFortuneMagazine"},{"name":"Twitter","href":"\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FFortuneMagazine"},{"name":"LinkedIn","href":"\u002F\u002Fwww.linkedin.com\u002Fcompany\u002Ffortune-magazine"},{"name":"Pinterest","href":"\u002F\u002Fwww.pinterest.com\u002Ffortunemagazine"},{"name":"Instagram","href":"\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Ffortunemag\u002F?hl=en"}]},"newsletterSignup":{"imageData":{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F03\u002Fcolvin-geoff.png","alt":"","title":"","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Fpowersheet\u002F"},"newsletterData":{"previewURL":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Fpowersheet\u002F","description":"Sign up for \u003Cspan\u003ETHE POWER SHEET\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and get insights, updates, and opinion on leadership and leaders","submitURL":"https:\u002F\u002Fpages.email.fortune.com\u002Fweb-opt-in\u002F","extraPostData":{"newsletter_name":"POWER_SHEET","source":"article","success_url":"https:\u002F\u002Fpages.email.fortune.com\u002Fthank-you\u002F"}}},"sectionList":"autos|careers|energy|executive-travel|finance|fortune-insiders|health|international|leadership|luxury|mpw|retail|sports|tech|the-21-century-coportation|venture|photography","isProduction":true}},"auth":{"isLoaded":false,"isVisible":false,"cookiePrefix":"ti-verify","authFlag":false},"scroll":{"isScrollAtTop":true,"isAboveTheFold":true},"editorialArticle":{"loaded":true,"loading":false,"data":{"id":1803984,"date":"2016-09-21T17:17:55","date_gmt":"2016-09-21T21:17:55","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1803984"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-09-22T18:55:06","modified_gmt":"2016-09-22T22:55:06","slug":"amazon-pricing-algorithms","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F21\u002Famazon-pricing-algorithms\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2d4pNH8","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Amazon Faces Questions Over How It Lists Prices"},"content":{"plain":"Amazon came under fire Monday after ProPublica reported that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. The article pointed out that Amazon&#8217;s strategy hurt shoppers, many of whom end up paying extra at checkout, and ran counter to its professed philosophy of putting customers first. The article raised questions about whether Amazon&#8217;s is trying to unfairly profit by funneling customers to more expensive products. The company has said previously that it ranks items based on the data it receives from its millions of customers and how they buy on the site. For example, Amazon said its ranking favors items that ship for free and that can get to customers faster. The technology also takes into account other factors such as price, and the rating of the seller. Shipping is a big factor, Amazon says, because data shows that customers decide to buy products primarily based upon free shipping and shipping speed. Items sold or fulfilled by Amazon fall into the Prime subscription offering, which charges consumers $99 annually to get anything from toilet paper to diapers to books delivered to them in two days or less. Amazon also offers the ability for items to be included in Super Saver Shipping (which requires no Prime membership and ships orders above $49 for free). In a statement to Fortune, an Amazon spokesperson said: &#8220;The vast majority of our items ordered \u2013 9 out of 10 \u2013 can ship for free. The sorting algorithms the article refers to are designed for that 90% of items ordered, where shipping costs do not apply.&#8221; Of course, by prioritizing faster shipping (a.k.a. Prime-eligible items), Amazon is strongly encouraging more of its shoppers to sign up for Prime. That&#8217;s a benefit for Amazon, as Prime members spend more than non-Prime members on the site. A recent Consumer Intelligence Research Partners study estimates that Prime shoppers spent about $1,200 on average last year, compared to about $500 for non-members. However, ProPublica asserts that under Amazon&#8217;s ranking systems, shoppers who are not Prime members can end up paying more for products if the fail to scroll more deeply into results. According the report, TheHardwareCity.com was selling superglue for $6.75 with free shipping. Fat Boy Tools was selling the same super glue for $7.27 with free shipping. But the algorithm ranked a the same glue sold by Amazon, which cost slightly more, $7.80, higher. But for non-Prime members or those who weren&#8217;t interested in Super Saver Shipping, shipping costs for the Amazon glue amounted to $6.51, which increased the total price to $14.31. Amazon founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has long said that key to Amazon&#8217;s mission is putting the customer first. ProPublica says that its algorithms don&#8217;t do that. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Other data backs up Amazon&#8217;s belief that free shipping dominates purchase decisions. According to a 2015 comScore study, 58% of online shoppers reported adding items to their shopping cart in order to qualify for free shipping. It\u2019s no secret that Amazon believes its competitive advantage is in getting products to its customers faster than other retailers. The company has been exploring using drones to deliver packages to shoppers in 30 minutes and is also deploying fleets of planes and trucks to make speedier deliveries. In turn, more customers are seeking faster shipping, especially around the holidays. The allure for many outside merchants to use and pay for Amazon to handle its shipping is to sell to Amazon\u2019s estimated 50 million Prime members. Merchants are eligible to be part of Prime delivery only if they are enrolled in the fulfillment program. Merchants must pay Amazon anywhere from $1.50 to $100 per order, depending on size and weight, for the service\u2014plus a standard fee. ProPublica says that some merchants can&#8217;t afford to pay these fees, citing a number of examples. But merchants who don&#8217;t pay for fulfillment, may also be at a disadvantage because of Amazon&#8217;s rankings. For more on Amazon, watch: Besides shipping, it&#8217;s also worth mentioning that there are other benefits to using Amazon&#8217;s fulfillment program for merchants. As part of the program, merchants ship their items to an Amazon warehouse, and Amazon takes care of the rest including packaging the items, processing customer payments, and customer service. Amazon has also been experimenting with letting certain merchants sell to Prime members without using fulfillment services. Amazon is working with a set of larger merchants that already have warehouses across the U.S. and are able to deliver within the Prime two-day window. Because these merchants don\u2019t need fulfillment services, they don\u2019t pay the same fees to Amazon but get access to Amazon\u2019s negotiated shipping prices with companies like UPS, which are much lower than standard rates. &nbsp; Correction, Sept. 22, 3:20 pm: An earlier of version of this article incorrectly said that search results considered seller ratings in the order of results. In fact, it was product listings. Clarification, Sept. 22 3:20 pm: The article&#8217;s headline has been updated to remove non-Prime customers from the title.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E came under fire Monday after \u003Cem\u003EProPublica \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.propublica.org\u002Farticle\u002Famazon-says-it-puts-customers-first-but-its-pricing-algorithm-doesnt\"\u003Ereported\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that the e-commerce giant more prominently displays its own products and those of merchants that pay for its shipping services\u2014even if other merchants sell the same products on the site for less. "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Clarification, Sept. 22 3:20 pm: The article's headline has been updated to remove non-Prime customers from the Station. On Tuesday, the administration announced that Boeing, headed by Dennis Muilenburg, and SpaceX, run by Elon Musk, had been awarded the additional missions\u2014bringing each of their total number of NASA contracts to send people into space to six. &#8220;Awarding these missions now will provide greater stability for the future space station crew rotation schedule, as well as reduce schedule and financial uncertainty for our providers,&#8221; Phil McAlister, director, NASA\u2019s Commercial Spaceflight Development Division said in a statement. \u201cThe ability to turn on missions as needed to meet the needs of the space station program is an important aspect of the Commercial Crew Program.\u201d The Commercial Crew Program was created by NASA as a way to put astronauts into space using the private sector. But both Boeing and SpaceX will first have to pass their spacecrafts through NASA certification. &nbsp; Boeing is scheduled to test an uncrewed version of its proposed flight, the CST-100 Starliner, in June 2018, followed by its crewed flight test in August 2018. vehicles"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":371748,"name":"SpaceX","slug":"spacex","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":58087,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":204,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1894032,"date":"2017-01-04T08:35:03","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:35:03","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1894032"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T08:35:56","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:35:56","slug":"brainstorm-health-01-04-intro","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fbrainstorm-health-01-04-intro\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j8LPuz","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"My Crystal Ball Reading for Obamacare"},"content":{"plain":"This essay appears in today\u2019s edition of the Fortune Brainstorm Health Daily. Get it delivered straight to your inbox. Good morning. The battle over the battle of Obamacare repeal comes to a sort-of head today as both President Obama and Vice President\u2013elect Mike Pence march to Congress to shore up their respective troops. The pep talks won\u2019t change much. Like some staged Civil War reenactment, both sides will initially hurl themselves at each other with their rhetorical Bowie knives and revolvers. But the real fight will almost certainly slog on for months, as Kelsey Snell and Mike DeBonis have reported in the Washington Post. In terms of procedure, one oft-mentioned strategy is for Republican Congressional leaders (who have only a slim majority in the Senate) to use a convoluted parliamentary workaround called \u201cbudget reconciliation\u201d to strip away the financial circuitry and plumbing of the Affordable Care Act, even as they leave the legislative framework standing. Think of that approach as marauders rushing into a new construction project and absconding with all the electrical wiring and copper pipes. But there have been increasing cries\u2014including late yesterday from the American Medical Association, the influential guild for U.S. physicians\u2014not to dismantle the existing, if flawed, Affordable Care Act before settling upon a replacement. Even some diehard Obamacare antagonists, such as Sen. Rand Paul, have upped their warnings about killing the nearly seven-year-old legislation in piecemeal fashion without having a full substitute at the ready. So what would that replacement look like? Well, let me grab my crystal ball. Hmm, I see something\u2026.faint, but ah yes, it\u2019s becoming more clear. There\u2019s a bill\u2014many months from now. It makes sure not to pull the rug out from the 20 million or so Americans who have gotten health insurance under the ACA. (They have to have coverage of some kind, of course.) And this bill keeps the provisions that Donald Trump says he wants to keep\u2014and that millions of American voters want to keep\u2014like those that prevent insurers from blacklisting people with preexisting medical conditions and that allow parents to include their slacker twentysomething kids on their own policies. And natch, this legislation has mechanisms that makes sure there\u2019s an intact marketplace of insurers, and that people aren\u2019t freeloading off of the hefty premiums paid by hardworking Americans: This is a conservative plan, after all. Sure, some will scoff and say it looks an awful lot like Obamacare. But it\u2019s nothing like it. This bill, for instance, has a rock-ribbed Republican name. Yes, I can see the letters getting sharper now in the crystal ball: Freedom-care.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis essay appears in today\u2019s edition of the \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFortune \u003Cem\u003EBrainstorm Health Daily. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetbrainstormhealth\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGet it delivered\u003C\u002Fa\u003E straight to your inbox.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGood morning. The battle over the battle of Obamacare repeal comes to a sort-of head today as both President Obama and Vice President\u2013elect Mike Pence march to Congress to shore up their respective troops. The pep talks won\u2019t change much. Like some staged Civil War reenactment, both sides will initially hurl themselves at each other with their rhetorical Bowie knives and revolvers. But the real fight will almost certainly slog on for months, as Kelsey Snell and Mike DeBonis have reported in the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fpowerpost\u002Fgops-obamacare-repeal-will-require-more-chisel-than-hammer\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F02\u002F3fbec222-d127-11e6-9cb0-54ab630851e8_story.html?utm_term=.c9474911ca42\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EWashington Post\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn terms of procedure, one oft-mentioned strategy is for Republican Congressional leaders (who have only a slim majority in the Senate) to use a convoluted parliamentary workaround called \u201c\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cbpp.org\u002Fresearch\u002Ffederal-budget\u002Fintroduction-to-budget-reconciliation\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ebudget reconciliation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u201d to strip away the financial circuitry and plumbing of the Affordable Care Act, even as they leave the legislative framework standing. Think of that approach as marauders rushing into a new construction project and absconding with all the electrical wiring and copper pipes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut there have been increasing cries\u2014including late yesterday from the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ama-assn.org\u002Fama-letter-congressional-leaders-reform-health-care-system\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmerican Medical Association\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, the influential guild for U.S. physicians\u2014not to dismantle the existing, if flawed, Affordable Care Act before settling upon a replacement. Health","slug":"brainstorm-health","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":171116,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":232,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":337,"name":"Health","slug":"health","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":139628,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News about health and health services sectors, including healthcare, biotechnology, genetic research, medicine, pharmaceuticals, and more.","parent":0,"count":2154,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1894022,"date":"2017-01-04T08:32:22","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:32:22","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1894022"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T08:32:22","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:32:22","slug":"volkswagen-driver-lawsuit-germany-over-diesels","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fvolkswagen-driver-lawsuit-germany-over-diesels\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iP3yE2","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Volkswagen Faces First Driver Lawsuit in Germany Over Diesels"},"content":{"plain":"German consumer rights champion myRight filed the first legal test case against Volkswagen in Germany on Tuesday, raising pressure on the carmaker to compensate customers in Europe over the emissions scandal. Europe&#8217;s largest automaker has pledged billions to compensate U.S. owners of Volkswagen (VW) diesel-powered cars, but has so far rejected any compensation for the 8.5 million affected vehicles in Europe where different legal rules weaken the chances of affected customers winning a pay out. Instead, VW is in the process of removing the illicit software that cheated emissions tests and insists the technical fixes will inflict no loss of value on car owners in Europe. It hopes to have completed repairs to all affected vehicles by the end of the year. MyRight, which has gathered more than 100,000 VW owners through its website, has accused VW of breaching European Union law by selling cars with software that was banned under EU rules, according to the 93-page legal document seen by Reuters. Rather than seeking compensation for a decline in value, the lawsuit aims to force VW to repurchase the vehicles at the original price, myRight founder Jan-Eike Andresen said. MyRight has mandated U.S. law firm Hausfeld to pursue the claims. Hausfeld represents aggrieved VW owners and shareholders on both sides of the Atlantic. The purpose of the proceedings by myRight is to act as a model &#8211; resolving generic or common issues for other related cases. However, unlike in a U.S. class action, it does not have the legal effect of resolving all individual claims. To read Fortune&#8217;s in-depth account of the Volkswagen scandal, click here. Wolfsburg-based Volkswagen, has said the software fitted into the engine at the center of the scandal, the EA 189, does not violate European law and declined comment on the myRight suit. &#8220;We have taken note that myRight has announced the submission of diesel lawsuits for Jan. 3. The lawsuits have not yet been made available to us which is why we cannot comment on the contents at the moment,&#8221; the carmaker said. VW is already facing criminal investigations in Germany on the suspicion that it misled investors by withholding knowledge of the diesel scandal for over a year. The company&#8217;s stock fell by more than a third when it finally disclosed the scale of its legal problems with the Environmental Protection Agency and California Air Resource Board. It has since paid over $15 billion to settle the claims of those two agencies and enact remedial measures. &nbsp;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EGerman consumer rights champion myRight filed the first legal test case against Volkswagen in Germany on Tuesday, raising pressure on the carmaker to compensate customers in Europe over the emissions scandal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEurope&#8217;s largest automaker has pledged billions to compensate U.S. owners of Volkswagen (VW) diesel-powered cars, but has so far rejected any compensation for the 8.5 million affected vehicles in Europe where different legal rules weaken the chances of affected customers winning a pay out.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EInstead, VW is in the process of removing the illicit software that cheated emissions tests and insists the technical fixes will inflict no loss of value on car owners in Europe. It hopes to have completed repairs to all affected vehicles by the end of the year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMyRight, which has gathered more than 100,000 VW owners through its website, has accused VW of breaching European Union law by selling cars with software that was banned under EU rules, according to the 93-page legal document seen by My post yesterday about Trump\u2019s industrial policy was followed within hours by an announcement from Ford that it will kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico and increase employment at a Michigan plant by 700 people instead. CEO Mark Fields said it was the right decision for the business, but also called it a \u201cvote of confidence\u201d in Trump\u2019s economic agenda. Expect more companies to follow suit. The combination of Trump\u2019s big stick \u2013 his bully Twitter pulpit plus the threat of punitive tariffs \u2013 combined with his even bigger bag of carrots \u2013 potential reductions in taxes, particularly on repatriated earnings, and in regulations \u2013 is a powerful combination. It\u2019s only a matter of time before Apple, IBM, and other companies follow suit. Never mind the fact that Trump\u2019s attacks on companies are neither very precise nor entirely fair. Yesterday, he went after GM \u2013 whose chief executive Mary Barra sits on his jobs council \u2013 for selling Chevrolet Cruzes assembled in Mexico to U.S. car dealers, when in fact almost all of the Cruzes sold in the U.S. last year were assembled in Lordstown, Ohio. As we now all know, factual accuracy is not the President-elect&#8217;s strong suit. Historically, this sort of meddling in markets was decried by free-market conservatives on the right. Yet Trump\u2019s latest moves are being criticized mainly from the left \u2013 with press outlets like Salon (Trump&#8217;s latest con job), Slate (Ford isn&#8217;t adding American jobs because of Donald Trump), and MSNBC arguing Trump is exaggerating his own role, or that the number of workers involved is relatively small. What these critics miss is that after decades of debating the merits of first Japanese-style and then Chinese-style national industrial policies, the U.S. suddenly has one of its own. Even before assuming office, Trump has tilted the playing field in a significant way. And it is going to be fascinating to watch the results.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EGood morning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMy post yesterday about Trump\u2019s industrial policy was followed within hours by an announcement from Ford that it will kill \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump\u002F\"\u003Ea planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and increase employment at a Michigan plant by 700 people instead. TALKING","description":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E[bs_bullet_primary] \u003Cstrong\u003EOut-Foxed.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EIt's shaping up to be a big week for two powerful women who helped make Fox News the juggernaut it is today. First, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmegyn-kelly-leaving-fox-for-nbc\u002F\"\u003EMegyn Kelly made headlines\u003C\u002Fa\u003Ewith her decision to leave the network, instead signing with competitor NBC News. Kelly was apparently lured by NBC's offer of a three-part role: She will reportedly host her own daytime news program, anchor a Sunday night news show, and take regular part in the network\u2019s special political programming. No financial terms of the deal were disclosed, but as the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fbusiness\u002Fmedia\u002Fmegyn-kelly-nbc-fox-news.html?hp&amp;action=click&amp;pgtype=Homepage&amp;clickSource=story-heading&amp;module=second-column-region&amp;region=top-news&amp;WT.nav=top-news\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENew York Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E put it\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \"even a modest raise would place her among television\u2019s highest paid journalists.\" (For a look at what her hire means for the future of NBC News, check out \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fnbc-megyn-kelly\u002F\"\u003Ethis piece\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by \u003Cem\u003EFortune'\u003C\u002Fem\u003Es Mathew Ingram.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThe second piece of news came from Gretchen Carlson, who was fired by Fox in June of last year and who then sued former network chief Roger Ailes. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fgretchen-carlson-today-show-host\u002F\"\u003ECarlson returned to the small screen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the first time yesterday, co-hosting a segment of the \u003Cem\u003EToday Show.\u003C\u002Fem\u003EShe used the appearance to announce that she issetting up a fund to \"empower women and young girls\"\u2014and that she plans to become a regular columnist for our fellow Time Inc. publication \u003Cem\u003EMotto\u003C\u002Fem\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EOf course, Kelly and Carlson have more than a former network in common\u2014both have said that they were sexually harassed by Roger Ailes.
