conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893763,"date":"2017-01-03T19:58:07","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T00:58:07","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893763"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T19:58:07","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T00:58:07","slug":"facebook-ceo-mark-zuckerberg-plans-epic-2017-road-trip","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ffacebook-ceo-mark-zuckerberg-plans-epic-2017-road-trip\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2i7WUYx","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Plans Epic 2017 Road Trip"},"content":{"plain":"Mark Zuckerberg plans to do a lot of traveling in the New Year. The Facebook fb CEO and Fortune\u2019s pick for 2016\u2019s Businessperson of the Year, said Tuesday that he plans to visit roughly 30 states in 2017\u2014presumably ones where he&#8217;s never been before\u2014to achieve the goal of meeting with people in every U.S. state. The interstate road trip is Zuckerberg\u2019s latest annual personal challenge that he undertakes for personal growth. Last year, Zuckerberg built for his home a crude-version of Amazon&#8217;s popular voice-controlled digital assistant Alexa that can turn on house lights and play music on command. He&#8217;s also pledged in past years to learn Mandarin Chinese, eat only meat from animals that he personally killed, and read a new book every other week. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Zuckerberg said that his new personal challenge would help him \u201cget out and talk to more people about how they&#8217;re living, working and thinking about the future\u201d in light of a \u201ctumultuous last year,\u201d which he did not elaborate on. This is a popular theme, particularly following Donald Trump&#8217;s unexpected ascendancy to president and the feeling among some elites that they have lost touch with a large swath of America. For more about Facebook, watch: Here\u2019s Zuckerberg\u2019s full post via Facebook: Every year I take on a personal challenge to learn new things and grow outside of my work. In recent years, I&#8217;ve run 365 miles, built a simple AI for my home, read 25 books and learned Mandarin. My personal challenge for 2017 is to have visited and met people in every state in the US by the end of the year. I&#8217;ve spent significant time in many states already, so I&#8217;ll need to travel to about 30 states this year to complete this challenge. After a tumultuous last year, my hope for this challenge is to get out and talk to more people about how they&#8217;re living, working and thinking about the future. Priscilla and I have enjoyed taking road trips together since we started dating. Recently, I&#8217;ve traveled around the world and visited many cities, and now I&#8217;m excited to explore more of our country and meet more people here. Going into this challenge, it seems we are at a turning point in history. For decades, technology and globalization have made us more productive and connected. This has created many benefits, but for a lot of people it has also made life more challenging. This has contributed to a greater sense of division than I have felt in my lifetime. We need to find a way to change the game so it works for everyone. My work is about connecting the world and giving everyone a voice. I want to personally hear more of those voices this year. It will help me lead the work at Facebook and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative so we can make the most positive impact as the world enters an important new period.\u201d My trips this year will take different forms &#8212; road trips with Priscilla, stops in small towns and universities, visits to our offices across the country, meetings with teachers and scientists, and trips to fun places you recommend along the way. I&#8217;ve enjoyed doing these challenges with our community and I&#8217;ll post tomorrow about how everyone around the world can join in. I&#8217;m looking forward to this challenge and I hope to see you out there!","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMark Zuckerberg plans to do a lot of traveling in the New Year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Facebook \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"fb\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffacebook-157\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Efb\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E CEO and \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u2019s\u003C\u002Fem\u003E pick for 2016\u2019s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffacebook-mark-zuckerberg-business\u002F\"\u003EBusinessperson of the Year\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, said Tuesday that he \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Fzuck\u002Fposts\u002F10103385178272401?notif_t=notify_me&amp;notif_id=1483479845570349\"\u003Eplans to visit\u003C\u002Fa\u003E roughly 30 states in 2017\u2014presumably ones where he&#8217;s never been before\u2014to achieve the goal of meeting with people in every U.S. state. This is a popular theme, particularly following Donald Trump's unexpected ascendancy to president and the feeling among some elites that they have lost touch with a large swath of America."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["For more about Facebook, watch:"]}," "]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5231067902001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Here\u2019s Zuckerberg\u2019s full post via ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Fzuck\u002Fposts\u002F10103385178272401?notif_t=notify_me&amp;notif_id=1483479845570349"},"content":["Facebook"]},":"]},{"tag":"blockquote","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Every year I take on a personal challenge to learn new things and grow outside of my work. In recent years, I've run 365 miles, built a simple AI for my home, read 25 books and learned Mandarin."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["My personal challenge for 2017 is to have visited and met people in every state in the US by the end of the year. I've spent significant time in many states already, so I'll need to travel to about 30 states this year to complete this challenge."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["After a tumultuous last year, my hope for this challenge is to get out and talk to more people about how they're living, working and thinking about the future."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Priscilla and I have enjoyed taking road trips together since we started dating. Recently, I've traveled around the world and visited many cities, and now I'm excited to explore more of our country and meet more people here."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Going into this challenge, it seems we are at a turning point in history. For decades, technology and globalization have made us more productive and connected. This has created many benefits, but for a lot of people it has also made life more challenging. This has contributed to a greater sense of division than I have felt in my lifetime. We need to find a way to change the game so it works for everyone."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["My work is about connecting the world and giving everyone a voice. I want to personally hear more of those voices this year. It will help me lead the work at Facebook and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative so we can make the most positive impact as the world enters an important new period.\u201d"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["My trips this year will take different forms -- road trips with Priscilla, stops in small towns and universities, visits to our offices across the country, meetings with teachers and scientists, and trips to fun places you recommend along the way."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I've enjoyed doing these challenges with our community and I'll post tomorrow about how everyone around the world can join in. I'm looking forward to this challenge and I hope to see you out there!"]}]}]},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ECEO wants to reach goal of meeting people in every U.S. CEO Mark Zuckerberg To Visit Every U.S. State By End Of 2017","mt_seo_description":"Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said he plans to meet with people in every U.S. state by the end of 2017 as part of his annual list of goals.","mt_seo_keywords":"Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, Businessperson of the Year, Alexa, Amazon,","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, Businessperson of the Year, Alexa, Amazon,","short_title":"Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Plans Epic 2017 Road Trip","og_title":"Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Plans Epic 2017 Road Trip","og_description":"CEO wants to reach goal of meeting people in every U.S. state.","twitter_text":"Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg plans epic 2017 road trip","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2i7WUYx","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ffacebook-ceo-mark-zuckerberg-plans-epic-2017-road-trip\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ffacebook-ceo-mark-zuckerberg-plans-epic-2017-road-trip\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1855419,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F163292239.jpg","alt":"Facebook To Detail Updates To News Feed At Press Event","caption":"Mark Zuckerberg, CEO and founder of Facebook.","credit":"Photograph by Bloomberg \u2014 Getty Images","description":"","title":"Facebook To Detail Updates To News Feed At Press Event"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":46232791,"name":"Businessperson of the Year","slug":"businessperson-of-the-year","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":49158,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":110,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893743,"date":"2017-01-03T19:15:15","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T00:15:15","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893743"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T08:40:41","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:40:41","slug":"media-trump-lies","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmedia-trump-lies\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hNr6am","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Dan Rather Is Right, the Media Should Call Trump\u2019s Lies What They Are"},"content":{"plain":"What should the media do when the U.S. president says something that is clearly and unequivocally not true? This might have seemed like an academic ethical question in the past, but with business mogul Donald Trump set to move into the Oval Office soon, it has become much more pressing, and more than a little contentious. During a weekend interview on Meet the Press that included both New York Times executive editor Dean Baquet and Wall Street Journal editor Gerard Baker, the latter was asked whether he thought inaccurate statements by Trump should be specifically called out as lies. Baker said that he didn&#8217;t think so, because the word &#8220;lie&#8221; implies that the person told an untruth on purpose. Instead, the Journal editor argued that media outlets should simply present the facts and leave it up to readers to determine the truth. The word lie &#8220;implies much more than just saying something that&#8217;s false. It implies a deliberate intent to mislead,&#8221; Baker said. &#8220;I think it&#8217;s up to the reader to make up their own mind&#8230; If you start ascribing a moral intent, as it were, to someone by saying that they&#8217;ve lied, I think you run the risk that you look like you\u2019re not being objective.&#8221; Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Legendary news anchor Dan Rather, however, took issue with this approach in a post on his Facebook page that was widely shared among journalists. Rather called Baker&#8217;s argument &#8220;deeply disturbing.&#8221; It is not the proper role of journalists, the former anchor said, &#8220;to meet lies \u2014 especially from someone of Mr. Trump\u2019s stature and power \u2014 by hiding behind semantics and euphemisms. Our role is to call it as we see it, based on solid reporting. When something is, in fact, a demonstrable lie, it is our responsibility to say so.&#8221; In his NBC interview, Baker referred to Trump&#8217;s repeated statements that Muslims were seen cheering in New Jersey when the World Trade Center towers fell. The Journal reported that there was no evidence this had actually occurred, Baker said, and then left it to the reader to decide. But even if the standard principle is that something can only be called a lie if we know the intent of the speaker\u2014as the Journal editor argues it should be\u2014can we not assume that Trump was making those statements with a deliberate intent to mislead voters about Muslim behavior? After all, he said it multiple times, even after it had been proven false. The same thing goes for many other Trump statements on a wide range of issues. He has repeatedly said that millions of people voted illegally, which isn&#8217;t true, and that ending the &#8220;stop and frisk&#8221; campaign in New York increased crime, which it didn&#8217;t. There are literally hundreds of such examples. At what point does repeating them stop being a falsehood and become an outright lie? In addition to winning the Electoral College in a landslide, I won the popular vote if you deduct the millions of people who voted illegally &mdash; Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) November 27, 2016 Baker&#8217;s argument is very similar to the one made by moderators like Fox News host Chris Wallace and MSNBC host Chris Matthews during the presidential debates. Wallace said he didn&#8217;t think it was a moderator&#8217;s job to be a &#8220;truth squad,&#8221; while Matthews said calling out lies would be equivalent to expressing an opinion, which journalists shouldn&#8217;t do. Those comments came up in large part because Matt Lauer of NBC was widely criticized for failing to challenge Trump during an interview when the candidate claimed that he never supported the war in Iraq, despite abundant evidence to the contrary. In a Twitter debate on Monday with a number of journalists, including Fusion writer Felix Salmon and former New York Observer editor Elizabeth Spiers, Time Inc.&#8217;s chief content officer Alan Murray (who is also editor of this magazine) defended Baker&#8217;s approach, saying journalists should be careful about using the word &#8220;lie&#8221; without proof that the speaker deliberately intended to mislead. Words matter. &quot;False&quot; and &quot;lie&quot; are not the same thing. https:\u002F\u002Ft.co\u002FACM5exCej2 &mdash; Alan Murray (@alansmurray) January 3, 2017 Spiers and others, however, said journalists make intelligent inferences about a politician&#8217;s motives all the time, and catching one in a lie is no different. Former Fortune writer Dan Primack, who is now with the media startup Axios, said: &#8220;I agree about being careful. But if you can prove the shoe fits, then put it on.&#8221; Washington Post writer Greg Sargent argued that &#8220;Donald Trump lies. A lot. And news organizations should say so.&#8221; These are all of Trump&#8217;s potential conflicts of interest: Inaccurate statements aren&#8217;t always lies. As Murray pointed out, Ronald Reagan said a lot of things that turned out not to be true, but not all of them were lies. But he didn&#8217;t repeatedly tell the same untruths over and over in the face of all the available evidence, the way Trump has done throughout his campaign, behavior he will presumably continue once he is in office. How can a self-respecting journalistic organization not call those lies? In the kind of broken media landscape we currently have, something Trump took advantage of better than anyone else during the campaign, not calling out obvious lies risks providing him with the headlines he wants\u2014apparently reinforcing his questionable claims\u2014with the evidence against his statements buried in the lower parts of a story that no one will read.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWhat should the media do when the U.S. president says something that is clearly and unequivocally not true? This might have seemed like an academic ethical question in the past, but with business mogul Donald Trump set to move into the Oval Office soon, it has become much more pressing, and more than a little contentious.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring a weekend interview on \u003Cem\u003EMeet the Press\u003C\u002Fem\u003E that included both \u003Cem\u003ENew York Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E executive editor Dean Baquet and \u003Cem\u003EWall Street Journal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E editor Gerard Baker, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077\"\u003Ethe latter was asked\u003C\u002Fa\u003E whether he thought inaccurate statements by Trump should be specifically called out as lies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBaker said that he didn&#8217;t think so, because the word &#8220;lie&#8221; implies that the person told an untruth on purpose. Instead, the \u003Cem\u003EJournal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E editor argued that media outlets should simply present the facts and leave it up to readers to determine the truth.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe word lie &#8220;implies much more than just saying something that&#8217;s false. It implies a deliberate intent to mislead,&#8221; \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077\"\u003EBaker said\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;I think it&#8217;s up to the reader to make up their own mind&#8230; If you start ascribing a moral intent, as it were, to someone by saying that they&#8217;ve lied, I think you run the risk that you look like you\u2019re not being objective.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELegendary news anchor Dan Rather, however, took issue with this approach \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002FtheDanRather\u002Fposts\u002F10157986074875716\"\u003Ein a post\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on his Facebook page that was widely shared among journalists.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERather called Baker&#8217;s argument &#8220;deeply disturbing.&#8221; It is not the proper role of journalists, the former anchor said, &#8220;to meet lies \u2014 especially from someone of Mr. Trump\u2019s stature and power \u2014 by hiding behind semantics and euphemisms. Our role is to call it as we see it, based on solid reporting. When something is, in fact, a demonstrable lie, it is our responsibility to say so.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn his NBC interview, Baker referred to Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politifact.com\u002Ftruth-o-meter\u002Fstatements\u002F2015\u002Fnov\u002F22\u002Fdonald-trump\u002Ffact-checking-trumps-claim-thousands-new-jersey-ch\u002F\"\u003Erepeated statements\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that Muslims were seen cheering in New Jersey when the World Trade Center towers fell. As Murray \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Falansmurray\u002Fstatus\u002F816107216835145728\"\u003Epointed out\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Ronald Reagan said a lot of things that turned out not to be true, but not all of them were lies. But he didn&#8217;t repeatedly tell the same untruths over and over in the face of all the available evidence, the way Trump has done throughout his campaign, behavior he will presumably continue once he is in office. How can a self-respecting journalistic organization not call those lies?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the kind of broken media landscape we currently have, something Trump \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F07\u002Ftrump-media-broken\u002F\"\u003Etook advantage of\u003C\u002Fa\u003E better than anyone else during the campaign, not calling out obvious lies risks providing him with \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fplum-line\u002Fwp\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Fmemo-to-the-media-stop-giving-trump-the-headlines-he-wants\u002F\"\u003Ethe headlines he wants\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u2014apparently reinforcing his questionable claims\u2014with the evidence against his statements buried in the lower parts of a story that no one will read.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["What should the media do when the U.S. president says something that is clearly and unequivocally not true? This might have seemed like an academic ethical question in the past, but with business mogul Donald Trump set to move into the Oval Office soon, it has become much more pressing, and more than a little contentious."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["During a weekend interview on ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Meet the Press"]}," that included both ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["New York Times"]}," executive editor Dean Baquet and ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Wall Street Journal"]}," editor Gerard Baker, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077"},"content":["the latter was asked"]}," whether he thought inaccurate statements by Trump should be specifically called out as lies."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Baker said that he didn't think so, because the word \"lie\" implies that the person told an untruth on purpose. Instead, the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]}," editor argued that media outlets should simply present the facts and leave it up to readers to determine the truth."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The word lie \"implies much more than just saying something that's false. It implies a deliberate intent to mislead,\" ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077"},"content":["Baker said"]},". \"I think it's up to the reader to make up their own mind... If you start ascribing a moral intent, as it were, to someone by saying that they've lied, I think you run the risk that you look like you\u2019re not being objective.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Legendary news anchor Dan Rather, however, took issue with this approach ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002FtheDanRather\u002Fposts\u002F10157986074875716"},"content":["in a post"]}," on his Facebook page that was widely shared among journalists."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Rather called Baker's argument \"deeply disturbing.\" It is not the proper role of journalists, the former anchor said, \"to meet lies \u2014 especially from someone of Mr. Trump\u2019s stature and power \u2014 by hiding behind semantics and euphemisms. Our role is to call it as we see it, based on solid reporting. When something is, in fact, a demonstrable lie, it is our responsibility to say so.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In his NBC interview, Baker referred to Trump's ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politifact.com\u002Ftruth-o-meter\u002Fstatements\u002F2015\u002Fnov\u002F22\u002Fdonald-trump\u002Ffact-checking-trumps-claim-thousands-new-jersey-ch\u002F"},"content":["repeated statements"]}," that Muslims were seen cheering in New Jersey when the World Trade Center towers fell. The ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]}," reported that there was no evidence this had actually occurred, Baker said, and then left it to the reader to decide."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But even if the standard principle is that something can only be called a lie if we know the intent of the speaker\u2014as the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]}," editor argues it should be\u2014can we not assume that Trump was making those statements with a deliberate intent to mislead voters about Muslim behavior? After all, he said it multiple times, even after it had been proven false."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The same thing goes for many other Trump statements on a wide range of issues. He has repeatedly ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FrealDonaldTrump\u002Fstatus\u002F802972944532209664"},"content":["said that millions"]}," of people voted illegally, which isn't true, and that ending the \"stop and frisk\" campaign in New York increased crime, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F28\u002Fnyregion\u002Fwhat-donald-trump-got-wrong-on-stop-and-frisk.html"},"content":["which it didn't"]},". There are literally hundreds of such examples. At what point does repeating them stop being a falsehood and become an outright lie?"]},{"tag":"oembed","attributes":{"raw_html":"&lt;div class=&quot;embed-twitter&quot;&gt;&lt;blockquote class=&quot;twitter-tweet&quot; data-width=&quot;500&quot;&gt;&lt;p lang=&quot;en&quot; dir=&quot;ltr&quot;&gt;In addition to winning the Electoral College in a landslide, I won the popular vote if you deduct the millions of people who voted illegally&lt;\u002Fp&gt;&mdash; Donald J. are","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hNr6am","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmedia-trump-lies\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmedia-trump-lies\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1892813,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F630618314.jpg","alt":"US-POLITICS-TRUMP","caption":"US ","credit":"DON EMMERT\u002FAFP\u002FGetty Images","description":"US President-elect Donald Trump speaks to reporters between meetings December 28, 2016 at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida. \u002F AFP \u002F DON EMMERT        (Photo credit should read DON EMMERT\u002FAFP\u002FGetty Images)","title":"US-POLITICS-TRUMP"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":189091,"name":"Donald Trump","slug":"donald-trump","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":118275,"taxonomy":"person","description":"","parent":0,"count":2575,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893184,"date":"2017-01-03T19:09:12","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T00:09:12","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893184"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T19:09:12","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T00:09:12","slug":"hacked-vermont-utility-washington-post-report-wrong","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fhacked-vermont-utility-washington-post-report-wrong\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j4Pbid","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"What the Washington Post\u2019s Hacked Electrical Grid Report Got Wrong"},"content":{"plain":"A Washington Post report on Friday said that Russian hackers had breached the nation&#8217;s power grid via a utility in Vermont, citing unnamed U.S. officials. Almost immediately, digital security experts panned the story, criticizing it as prematurely alarmist and lacking key details. The supposed discovery linked &#8220;code&#8221; found on the utility&#8217;s computer network to Russian election meddlers, who were widely believed to be Kremlin-sponsored and associated with state security and intelligence agencies such as the FSB and GRU. The finding came a day after the government published an intelligence report, criticized by many as overly broad, claiming to contain evidence of a Moscow-backed election interference campaign dubbed &#8220;Grizzly Steppe.&#8221; Soon after the initial Post story appeared, Burlington Electric came forward as the reportedly hacked organization. The municipally-owned utility clarified that had it had &#8220;detected the malware&#8221; on a single laptop, separate from its grid systems. In other words, the main premise of the Post story\u2014indeed, its headline\u2014turned out to be incorrect. The breach involved a solitary laptop and no penetration of the grid, the Post said in an editor&#8217;s note appended Saturday. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. A day later, Burlington Electric revealed more information about the incident, debunking suspicions. The code presumably associated with the Russian hacking operation turned out to be nothing more than a &#8220;specific type of Internet traffic&#8221; that had &#8220;been observed elsewhere in the country and is not unique to Burlington Electric,&#8221; the utility said in a second press release. The code in question was not a malicious software program, as some people suspected, but rather the appearance of a certain Internet connection. In a follow-up story published Monday evening, a different set of Post reporters\u2014citing more unnamed officials\u2014revealed that a security alert at Burlington Electric had tripped when an employee accessed a Yahoo yhoo email account. The alerts had been put in place after the Department of Homeland Security issued an industry-wide warning to the nation&#8217;s utilities, pointing to certain IP addresses contained in its &#8220;Grizzly Steppe&#8221; report, jointly produced with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The second Post story also reported that investigators later discovered malicious software on the Burlington Electric employee&#8217;s laptop. This was a common malware program called Neutrino that&#8217;s commonly deployed through online advertising networks, and likely unrelated to the Russian campaign &#8220;Grizzly Steppe.&#8221; For more on cybersecurity, watch: Before the investigators who were responding to Burlington Electric&#8217;s findings could suss out what really happened within the utility&#8217;s computer network, U.S. officials had apparently tipped the Post to an incomplete version of the news. It&#8217;s unclear whether the U.S. officials relayed inaccurate information, whether the reporters made false assumptions, or a combination. Then, the report spread like a computer worm. The dubious attribution to Russian hackers in the Burlington Electric incident\u2014specifically, to Russian hackers associated with U.S. election mischief\u2014arose because the utility had detected Internet connections that seemed to be linked to &#8220;Grizzly Steppe,&#8221; per the government&#8217;s report, despite the intelligence containing a range of IP addresses not exclusive to that hacking campaign. Indeed, a significant chunk of the IP addresses listed in the joint report mapped to ordinary proxy servers that privacy advocates, digital attackers, and others use to mask their tracks, as analyses of the set have showed. Cybersecurity experts who had pored over the White House-mandated &#8220;Grizzly Steppe&#8221; report, expecting to find revelations about the tactics of Russian election hackers, were disappointed to discover that the paper contained little actionable information. For security teams looking to find and block Russian malware, the data was &#8220;nearly useless,&#8221; as one expert, Robert Lee, founder of Dragos Security, put it in a widely read critique. Poor threat intelligence of this sort can be a costly distraction for resource-strapped security teams. The Washington Post Is Hiring Reporters, Bucking the Media Trend Burlington Electric, for its part, lamented the leaky lips of federal investigators when the organization was just trying to follow proper protocols in reporting the potential threat. &#8220;It\u2019s unfortunate that an official or officials improperly shared inaccurate information with one media outlet, leading to multiple inaccurate reports around the country,&#8221; said Mike Kanarick, communications director for the utility, in a statement. &#8220;Media reports stating that Burlington Electric was hacked or that the electric grid was breached are false,&#8221; he added. Quite a ruckus for a false alarm.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA \u003Cem\u003EWashington Post\u003C\u002Fem\u003E report on Friday said that Russian hackers had \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fworld\u002Fnational-security\u002Frussian-hackers-penetrated-us-electricity-grid-through-a-utility-in-vermont\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002F8fc90cc4-ceec-11e6-b8a2-8c2a61b0436f_story.html\"\u003Ebreached the nation&#8217;s power grid\u003C\u002Fa\u003E via a utility in Vermont, citing unnamed U.S. officials. Almost immediately, digital security experts \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Frussian-malware-vermont-electric\u002F\"\u003Epanned the story\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, criticizing it as prematurely alarmist and lacking key details.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe supposed discovery linked &#8220;code&#8221; found on the utility&#8217;s computer network to Russian election meddlers, who were widely believed to be Kremlin-sponsored and associated with state security and intelligence agencies such as the FSB and GRU. The finding came a day after the government published an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.us-cert.gov\u002Fsites\u002Fdefault\u002Ffiles\u002Fpublications\u002FJAR_16-20296A_GRIZZLY%20STEPPE-2016-1229.pdf\"\u003Eintelligence report\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, criticized by many as overly broad, claiming to contain evidence of a Moscow-backed election interference campaign dubbed &#8220;Grizzly Steppe.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESoon after the initial \u003Cem\u003EPost\u003C\u002Fem\u003E story appeared, Burlington Electric \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.burlingtonelectric.com\u002Fnews\u002F3908\u002FBurlington-Electric-Department-Statement-\"\u003Ecame forward\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as the reportedly hacked organization. The municipally-owned utility clarified that had it had &#8220;detected the malware&#8221; on a single laptop, separate from its grid systems.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn other words, the main premise of the \u003Cem\u003EPost\u003C\u002Fem\u003E story\u2014indeed, its headline\u2014turned out to be incorrect. The breach involved a solitary laptop and no penetration of the grid, the \u003Cem\u003EPost\u003C\u002Fem\u003E said in an editor&#8217;s note appended Saturday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E,\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Fortune\u003Cem\u003E\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA day later, Burlington Electric revealed more information about the incident, debunking suspicions. The code presumably associated with the Russian hacking operation turned out to be nothing more than a &#8220;specific type of Internet traffic&#8221; that had &#8220;been observed elsewhere in the country and is not unique to Burlington Electric,&#8221; the utility said in \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.burlingtonelectric.com\u002Fnews\u002F3910\u002FBurlington-Electric-Department-Statement%3A-No-Indication-that-Electric-Grid-or-Customer-Information-Compromised\"\u003Ea second press release\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe code in question was not a malicious software program, as some people suspected, but rather the appearance of a certain Internet connection.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fworld\u002Fnational-security\u002Frussian-government-hackers-do-not-appear-to-have-targeted-vermont-utility-say-people-close-to-investigation\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F02\u002F70c25956-d12c-11e6-945a-76f69a399dd5_story.html\"\u003Efollow-up story\u003C\u002Fa\u003E published Monday evening, a different set of \u003Cem\u003EPost\u003C\u002Fem\u003E reporters\u2014citing more unnamed officials\u2014revealed that a security alert at Burlington Electric had tripped when an employee accessed a Yahoo \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"yhoo\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fyahoo-513\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eyhoo\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E email account. Photographer: Jeremy Piper\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","title":"Ausgrid Transmission Towers As China Builds an Empire of Electricity With Australia as Target"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":16981,"name":"hack","slug":"hack","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":115130,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":107,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893128,"date":"2017-01-03T17:00:32","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T22:00:32","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893128"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T17:00:36","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T22:00:36","slug":"ces-qualcomm-chips","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fces-qualcomm-chips\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iLncjY","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Qualcomm Doubles Down On Smartphones And Cars With New Chips"},"content":{"plain":"Qualcomm unveiled several new chips on Tuesday that are mostly focused on what it believes are fast-growth areas. The new Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 mobile processor, shown off at the CES consumer electronics show in Las Vegas, will be the company&#8217;s high-end chip for smartphones, virtual-reality headsets, and mobile computers. It is smaller than Qualcomm&#8217;s previous chips, more power efficient, and provides faster Internet connectivity over mobile networks, according to the company. While Qualcomm QCOM didn&#8217;t say which high-end smartphones or tablets might support its new processor, the company did say it will be compatible with Google&#8217;s Android and Microsoft&#8217;s Windows operating systems. It also will be used in some upcoming smartglasses, which were previously announced by hardware maker Osterhout Design Group (ODG) and are targeted to consumers. Smartglasses are an emerging device category with companies like Microsoft and Google jumping into the fray. Considered alternately to be a potentially hot product or a flop after some early efforts failed to catch on, smartglasses let users interact with the world around them while seeing virtual objects overlaid onto the real environment. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter ODG company is working on two smartglasses ,to be shipped by July, that use both virtual reality and augmented reality technology. ODG said in a statement accompanying the Snapdragon 835 announcement that the processor would help those smartglasses deliver better visuals and enhanced performance. Additionally, Qualcomm said that its processors and LTE modems would be embedded in some Volkswagen cars so they can connect to cellular networks. The first set of Volkswagen vehicles running its Snapdragon 820A processor will start hitting the road in 2019, and those using its other new chips, like the X12 and X5 LTE, will be available in 2018. For more about Qualcomm, watch: Also, Qualcomm said that it planned to offer high-speed, Gigabit LTE chips for connected cars so they can access the Internet. The LTE chip, which can reach speeds of 1 gigabit per second, or speeds that are dramatically faster than most home Internet connections, will be available to car manufacturers in the first half of 2017. Chipmakers like Qualcomm and Intel see big opportunities in the connected car market. An increasing number of cars use wireless connections to automatically provide performance information to their manufacturers to help with repairs and upgrades. Connections can also be used to get drivers and their passengers onto the Internet over wireless networks. Looking ahead, Internet connectivity could prove to be critical for self-driving cars, which must quickly see what other cars are doing and respond accordingly.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EQualcomm unveiled several new chips on Tuesday that are mostly focused on what it believes are fast-growth areas.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe new Qualcomm Snapdragon 835 mobile processor, shown off at the CES consumer electronics show in Las Vegas, will be the company&#8217;s high-end chip for smartphones, virtual-reality headsets, and mobile computers. 2017: Qualcomm Doubles Down On Smartphones And Cars With New Chips","mt_seo_description":"Qualcomm has unveiled the new Snapdragon 835 processor designed for premium smartphones, tablets, and other devices.","mt_seo_keywords":"CES, CES 2017, Qualcomm, Qualcomm Snapdragon, Snapdragon 835, smartglasses, connected cars","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"CES, CES 2017, Qualcomm, Qualcomm Snapdragon, Chips","og_description":"And some smartglasses, too.","twitter_text":"Qualcomm doubles down on smartphones and cars with new chips","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iLncjY","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fces-qualcomm-chips\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fces-qualcomm-chips\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893445,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fsnapdrgaon-835-and-penny.jpg","alt":"Qualcomm Executive","slug":"the-mobile-executive","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":133921,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":402,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893224,"date":"2017-01-03T16:01:56","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T21:01:56","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893224"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T16:22:05","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T21:22:05","slug":"tech-ford-trump-jobs","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ftech-ford-trump-jobs\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j0NUop","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Will Tech Titans, Pressured By Trump, Create More U.S. Factory Jobs?"},"content":{"plain":"A surprise move by Ford on Tuesday to kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico and move that work instead to Michigan may be a sign that business leaders have listened to President-elect Donald Trump, who has blasted U.S. companies for shipping jobs overseas. A big question is whether tech giants like Apple, IBM and Microsoft, all of whom rely heavily on foreign manufacturers, will follow Ford&#8217;s f lead. To be fair, while Trump tends to take credit for saving all these jobs\u2014he had threatened Ford with a 35% tariff on Mexican-built vehicles sold in the U.S.\u2014 Ford chief executive Mark Fields told CNN that the company &#8220;didn&#8217;t cut a deal with Trump. We did it for our business.&#8221; Whether you believe Ford&#8217;s move was due to Trump himself, or to a growing belief among voters that the country needs to maintain its own manufacturing capabilities, or that it just makes financial sense, as Fields argued, it is noteworthy. Last month, telecommunications company Sprint and satellite provider OneWeb announced plans to hire 5,000 U.S. workers. Although Trump claimed credit for those jobs, they were, in fact, part of a planned $50 billion U.S. investment by SoftBank Group founder Masayoshi Son before Trump&#8217;s election victory. SoftBank owns stakes in both Sprint and OneWeb. About 3,000 of those jobs would be at a new Florida factory where OneWeb says it will build low-cost satellites. It was unclear how many of the other jobs would be in manufacturing, but the fact that two tech companies committed so publicly to investing in American workers was noteworthy. And it was also great public relations since SoftBank also wants to revive a Sprint s merger with T-Mobile tmus that was proposed in 2014 but dropped in the face of U.S. regulatory resistance. SoftBank\u002FSprint might have better luck getting approval of the deal in a Trump administration. Apple, criticized by Trump in the past for its outsourced manufacturing, is a bellwether for tech stalwarts. Apple aapl has talked with Foxconn and Pegatron, two Asian contract manufacturers that build iPhones, to move some of their work stateside, according to unconfirmed reports. Furthermore, Apple CEO Tim Cook, along with his Microsoft and IBM counterparts Satya Nadella and Ginni Rometty respectively, attended Trump&#8217;s tech summit in New York last month. Creating U.S. jobs was one hot topic of the event. In an emailed statement, an Apple spokesman said the company: is responsible for creating more than two million jobs across the United States, from engineers, retail and call center employees to operations and delivery drivers. We work with over 8,000 suppliers from coast to coast and are investing heavily in American jobs and innovation. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. In a blog posted the day after the election, Microsoft president Brad Smith pointed out the need for more highly educated workers. He cited research showing that the U.S. economy added 35 million jobs over the last 25 years, but that the number of jobs held by those without a high school diploma fell 13% to 7.3 million while jobs for those with four-year degrees doubled. He stressed the need for private-public sector collaboration to boost jobs and innovation in the U.S. and elsewhere. But Smith made no mention of whether the company Microsoft would start making its Surface tablet devices in the U.S. or push its Asian manufacturing partners to open facilities here. For more on Ford&#8217;s factory move, watch: IBM&#8217;s Rometty, likewise, stated a need for companies to work with the U.S. government to improve the climate for job creation. In an open letter to Trump in November, she spoke about a need to train people for skilled jobs that don&#8217;t require two- or four-year college degrees. But again, there was little in the way of specifics and no mention of moving any services or manufacturing work to the U.S. from elsewhere. Fortune contacted Microsoft msft and IBM ibm for comment about their U.S. job plans and will update this article as needed. Toni Sacconaghi, senior research analyst with Bernstein Research said he hasn&#8217;t heard much from tech players about bringing jobs\u2014manufacturing or otherwise\u2014to the U.S. from abroad. And, Rometty&#8217;s plans, as spelled out in her letter, are &#8220;tough to interpret,&#8221; he said in an email. Thus far, SoftBank affiliates Sprint and OneWeb seem to be the only tech companies that have promised specific action on the domestic jobs front in the near term. The rest of the tech community has remained silent, at least publicly, about bringing manufacturing jobs back to the U.S. But then again, it&#8217;s early. One thing is certain, says Jeff Matthews, managing partner for RAM Partners, a Naples, Florida-based hedge fund, via email: &#8220;Every company I talk to is thinking about how to do more in America. I&#8217;m not sure that they will, but it is now something that&#8217;s on everybody&#8217;s radar, which can&#8217;t hurt.&#8221;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA surprise move by Ford on Tuesday \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump\u002F\"\u003Eto kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Mexico and move that work instead to Michigan may be a sign that business leaders have listened to President-elect Donald Trump, who has blasted U.S. companies for shipping jobs overseas. A big question is whether tech giants like \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EApple\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, IBM and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fmicrosoft-25\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMicrosoft\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, all of whom rely heavily on foreign manufacturers, will follow Ford&#8217;s \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"f\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fford-motor-9\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ef\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E lead.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETo be fair, while Trump tends to take credit for saving all these jobs\u2014he had threatened Ford with a 35% tariff on Mexican-built vehicles sold in the U.S.\u2014 Ford chief executive \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fmoney.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fnews\u002Feconomy\u002Fford-700-jobs-trump\u002Findex.html\"\u003EMark Fields told CNN\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that the company &#8220;didn&#8217;t cut a deal with Trump. We did it for our business.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhether you believe Ford&#8217;s move was due to Trump himself, or to a growing belief among voters that the country needs to maintain its own manufacturing capabilities, or that it just makes financial sense, as Fields argued, it is noteworthy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELast month, telecommunications company Sprint and satellite provider OneWeb announced \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F28\u002Ftrump-sprint-jobs\u002F\"\u003Eplans to hire 5,000 U.S. workers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Although Trump claimed credit for those jobs, they were, in fact, part of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fdonald-trump-masayoshi-son-softbank\u002F\"\u003Ea planned $50 billion U.S. investment\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by SoftBank Group founder Masayoshi Son before Trump&#8217;s election victory. SoftBank owns stakes in both Sprint and OneWeb.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAbout 3,000 of those jobs would be at a new Florida factory where OneWeb says it will build low-cost satellites.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt was unclear how many of the other jobs would be in manufacturing, but the fact that two tech companies committed so publicly to investing in American workers was noteworthy. And it was also great public relations since SoftBank also wants to revive a Sprint \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"s\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fs\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Es\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E merger with T-Mobile \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"tmus\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Ftmus\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Etmus\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003Ethat was proposed in 2014 but dropped in the face of U.S. regulatory resistance. SoftBank\u002FSprint might have better luck getting approval of the deal in a Trump administration.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EApple, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fdonald-trump-companies\u002F\"\u003Ecriticized by Trump in the past for its\u003C\u002Fa\u003E outsourced manufacturing, is a bellwether for tech stalwarts. Creating \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.usatoday.com\u002Fstory\u002Ftech\u002Fnews\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F11\u002Ftrump-fills-out-his-tech-summit-attendee-list\u002F95300462\u002F\"\u003EU.S. jobs was one hot topic\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of the event.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn an emailed statement, an Apple spokesman said the company:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003Eis responsible for creating more than two million jobs across the United States, from engineers, retail and call center employees to operations and delivery drivers. We work with over 8,000 suppliers from coast to coast and are investing heavily in American jobs and innovation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFortune\u003Cem\u003E\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fblogs.microsoft.com\u002Fon-the-issues\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F09\u002Fmoving-forward-together-thoughts-us-election\u002F#_ftn1\"\u003E blog\u003C\u002Fa\u003E posted the day after the election, Microsoft president Brad Smith pointed out the need for more highly educated workers. He cited research showing that the U.S. economy added 35 million jobs over the last 25 years, but that the number of jobs held by those without a high school diploma fell 13% to 7.3 million while jobs for those with four-year degrees doubled.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHe stressed the need for private-public sector collaboration to boost jobs and innovation in the U.S. and elsewhere. Kelly&#8217;s contract with Fox News isn&#8217;t officially up until July, but she began discussions in October with several broadcasters after a widely-reported tiff with then-presidential candidate Donald Trump boosted her public profile. It&#8217;s not clear what NBCUniversal will be paying her, but she was reportedly making $15 million a year at Fox. Despite her disagreement with Trump\u2014and a few tense exchanges with host Bill O&#8217;Reilly after she said she was sexually harassed by former Fox chairman Roger Ailes\u2014there&#8217;s no question that Kelly has been a key player at the conservative-leaning network. So does her hiring suggest that NBC is trying to move to the right in order to appeal to the kind of conservative audience that helped elect Trump? It&#8217;s hard not to see it in that light. (Fortune requested a comment from NBCUniversal on the implications of Kelly&#8217;s hire, and if one arrives, it will be added to this post). Make no mistake: despite everything, Megyn Kelly is an embodiment of Fox News and her move to NBC is a victory for its brand of journalism &mdash; Jack Mirkinson (@jackmirkinson) January 3, 2017 NBCUniversal News Group chairman Andrew Lack\u2014the architect of the Kelly hire, according to a report in the New York Times that broke the news of her departure\u2014said in a release that she is &#8220;an exceptional journalist.&#8221; A glowing profile in Vanity Fair last year described her as a &#8220;female role model who transcends politics.&#8221; Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. All that said, however, Kelly also has a reputation for promoting right-wing views on a variety of topics, including race. For example, she talked about an alleged plan by President Obama to force white neighborhoods to diversify, and also repeatedly criticized the Black Lives Matter movement, casting doubt on whether police shootings had anything to do with race. Kelly has also made critical comments about gay and transgender issues on a number of occasions, according to the left-leaning media watchdog group Media Matters, and has repeatedly hosted anti-gay groups such as the Family Research Council, which believes that homosexuality is a sin and that gay men routinely recruit children to be homosexual. congrats to NBC on hiring on a woman who made a name for herself through blithe, insidious racism https:\u002F\u002Ft.co\u002F7FbJu0PD1S pic.twitter.com\u002F7UegCoLz7x &mdash; Ashley Feinberg (@ashleyfeinberg) January 3, 2017 The Fox anchor also spent a considerable amount of time on her show pushing the idea that the Obama administration was somehow involved in voter intimidation efforts in 2008 involving a group called the New Black Panther Party, despite a conspicuous lack of evidence to that effect. On a network like Fox News, Kelly might have appeared to be a moderate voice, especially after she stood up to Trump&#8217;s repeated public bullying. But she is clearly a leading voice for right-wing viewpoints, which is why Fox reportedly offered her $20 million a year to stay. These are all of Trump&#8217;s potential conflicts of interest: And Kelly isn&#8217;t the only conservative voice making the move from Fox fox to NBCUniversal cmcsa . Former host Greta Van Susteren, who left the network in September, will reportedly have a show on MSNBC soon, and former anchor Gretchen Carlson\u2014who triggered the departure of Ailes with her sexual harassment lawsuit\u2014recently guest-hosted the Today Show. For a network like NBC, embracing right-wing views by hiring and promoting hosts like Kelly may seem like a pragmatic move given what Trump&#8217;s election appears to say about the stance that many U.S. voters take on a number of issues. But what effect will this right-ward shift have on the rest of the population and their news consumption?","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EAfter months of negotiations with a number of major networks, Fox News star Megyn Kelly announced on Tuesday that \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpress.nbcnews.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmegyn-kelly-joins-nbc-news\u002F\"\u003Eshe is joining NBC News\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, where she will host a daytime TV show and a weekly feature program, as well as being involved in the network&#8217;s political coverage.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKelly&#8217;s contract with Fox News isn&#8217;t officially up until July, but she began discussions in October with several broadcasters after a widely-reported tiff with then-presidential candidate Donald Trump boosted her public profile. In this video, Kelly talks about where she gets her news (yes, she watches Fox News\u2014but that's not all), why she still uses a Blackberry, and what it really takes to make a dramatic change in your life.","title":"3 questions with Megyn Kelly"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"4417060979001","autoplay":"1","controls":"1"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":10767387,"name":"Tech Debate","slug":"tech-debate","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":110241,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":207,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1892996,"date":"2017-01-03T14:33:29","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T19:33:29","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1892996"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T14:33:29","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T19:33:29","slug":"ces-lenovo-smart-assistant","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fces-lenovo-smart-assistant\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2i5Q1Hg","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Lenovo\u2019s Smart Assistant Is An Amazon Echo Alternative"},"content":{"plain":"The list of devices that incorporate Amazon&#8217;s virtual assistant Alexa has grown. Lenovo unveiled a new smart home appliance on Tuesday called the Lenovo Smart Assistant that uses Alexa to field spoken commands to turn on the lights, play music, and create to-do lists. The new device adds to the growing number of household hubs that already includes Amazon&#8217;s Echo and Google&#8217;s Home. Amazon is letting other hardware manufacturers bundle Alexa into their devices as a way to expand Amazon&#8217;s reach in the emerging smart home market. Companies are trying to get as many people as possible to use their virtual assistants to capitalize if the technology becomes widely used for shopping, searching for information, and for third party services like booking Lyft rides. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter Later this year, GE Lighting plans to incorporate Alexa into a table lamp, The C by GE LED Lamp. Meanwhile, small companies like Jam have already adopted Alexa for its Jam Voice, another smart home hub. Lenovo&#8217;s Smart Assistant has eight microphones to listen to user voice commands, which the company says, will allow it to hear from all angles at long distances. Customers will be able to buy an upgraded version of the device that comes with Harman Kardon premium audio speakers instead of the standard speakers. Lenovo&#8217;s Smart Assistant, to be available in May, will come in several colors including grey and green. The standard version will sell for $130 while the one with Harman Kardon speakers will cost $180. For more about Amazon Echo, watch: Lenovo explained its entry into the smart home appliances by pointing to a Gartner study that says nearly 2 billion smart home devices will ship worldwide by 2019. The smart home market will generate nearly $500 billion in revenue that year, Lenovo says, implying that there is plenty of room for growth.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe list of devices that incorporate Amazon&#8217;s virtual assistant Alexa has grown.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELenovo unveiled a new smart home appliance on Tuesday called the Lenovo Smart Assistant that uses Alexa to field spoken commands to turn on the lights, play music, and create to-do lists. Android-Powered Smart Bikes Are Coming to the U.S."},"content":{"plain":"Tech giants like Alphabet&#8217;s Google have already brought smart features to our wristwatches, cars, and TVs. Now they&#8217;re coming for our bikes. Chinese company LeEco announced that its smart bicycles will be coming to the U.S. in the second quarter of this year. The vehicle will be available in a road and sport model, and each one comes equipped with a 4-inch touchscreen that runs on a modified version of Android goog . This enables the bikes to display turn-by-turn directions based on the Here Maps service, play music both online and offline, log rides, and function as a walkie talkie for other nearby LeEco bike riders. Pricing has not been announced yet. Other sensors found on the bikes are meant to help riders keep track of their health data and physical performance. The bikes can, for instance, detect wheel and crank speeds and are compatible with third party heart rate sensors. A security feature alerts the owner when the bike&#8217;s alarm has been triggered, allowing them to see the vehicle&#8217;s location on their phone via an app. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. The LeEco Smart Mountain Bike weights 26.9 pounds, while the Smart Road Bike is 18.5 pounds. The tech inside both models is water resistant, meaning rain and other inclement weather conditions shouldn&#8217;t inflict any damage. The launch will come months after LeEco made its splashy debut in the U.S. this past October. The addition of these new smart bikes will help LeEco diversify its product lineup in the U.S., where it currently sells gadgets like smartphones and TVs. Related: Uber and Lyft Carpooling Services Could Replace 75% of Vehicles LeEco isn&#8217;t the only technology company with intentions to outfit bicycles with technology. In 2014, Samsung unveiled a prototype of its Smart Bike, which can project laser beams that create individual bike lanes and can connect to a Samsung smartphone.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ETech giants like Alphabet&#8217;s Google have already brought smart features to our wristwatches, cars, and TVs. conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893353,"date":"2017-01-03T13:45:34","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T18:45:34","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893353"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T15:32:54","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T20:32:54","slug":"intel-buys-mapping-app-here","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fintel-buys-mapping-app-here\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j17NM0","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why Intel Wants a Piece of Mapping App HERE"},"content":{"plain":"Intel bought 15% of digital mapping service HERE on Tuesday as the chipmaker wades further into the market for self-driving cars and other autonomous devices. Intel joins HERE&#8217;s current owners\u2014carmakers Audi, BMW, and Daimler\u2014in their efforts to build a vast global map and location database that doesn&#8217;t rely on information from Apple aapl or Google. Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has targeted making chips and sensors for self-driving cars, automated robots, and AI-enhanced drones as one of the company&#8217;s new growth market. The carmakers bought HERE from Nokia in 2015 for $3 billion. Intel intc declined to disclose how much it paid for its 15% stake. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. &#8220;Cars are rapidly becoming some of the world\u2019s most intelligent, connected devices,&#8221; Krzanich said in a statement. &#8220;We look forward to working with HERE and its automotive partners to deliver an important technology foundation for smart and connected cars of the future.&#8221; Intel&#8217;s aim is to help the car makers create much more robust and detailed mapping hardware and software that will be needed for truly autonomous vehicles. HERE&#8217;s next generation mapping applications will be able to pinpoint a car&#8217;s location within centimeters, down from exactness in meters today, the company says. HERE&#8217;s current product offerings run the gamut from a consumer-oriented smartphone app called HERE WeGo to live traffic data that can be licensed and fed into car navigation systems, all built on top of its ecosystem of mapping data and related software tools. The head of Intel&#8217;s automated driving group, Doug Davis, will join HERE&#8217;s supervisory board after the transaction is completed. The deal is expected to close before the end of the first quarter. Google googl has long dominated the market for digitally usable map and location data for portable devices, after it spent billions building its data sets. Apple had to play catch up after it created its own smartphone map app in 2012, relying on licensing data from Dutch provider TomTom. But HERE started mapping the world three decades ago and built a strong position in the automotive market long before smartphones came along. Nokia nok bought the company, then known as Navteq, for $8 billion in 2007.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fintel-51\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIntel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E bought 15% of digital mapping service HERE on Tuesday as the chipmaker wades further into the market for self-driving cars and other autonomous devices.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIntel joins HERE&#8217;s current owners\u2014carmakers Audi, BMW, and Daimler\u2014in their efforts to build a vast global map and location database that doesn&#8217;t rely on information from \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EApple\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"aapl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eaapl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E or \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoogle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. But Arnold Schwarzenegger&#8217;s hosting debut wasn&#8217;t enough to give the network a ratings win for the show&#8217;s premiere. The latest iteration of Comcast-owned NBC&#8217;s Apprentice reality TV franchise\u2014which featured now president-elect Donald Trump as host for more than a decade\u2014lost the ratings battle with rival networks ABC and CBS cbs during the 8 p.m. ET primetime slot on Monday night. With Schwarzenegger now in the hosting chair, The New Celebrity Apprentice averaged roughly 4.9 million total viewers across its two-hour premiere, according to Nielsen&#8217;s tracking numbers. ABC&#8217;s two-hour The Bachelor premiere pulled in nearly 6.6 million viewers by comparison, while CBS averaged more than 6 million viewers between four half-hour sitcoms that aired between 8 p.m. and 10 p.m. While NBC heavily promoted Schwarzenegger&#8217;s Apprentice takeover ahead of the show&#8217;s January debut, the movie star and former California governor&#8217;s reality TV turn got off to a mediocre start, especially when compared with the ratings of his predecessor. The ratings for last night&#8217;s Celebrity Apprentice premiere were down more than 22% from the debut episode of Trump&#8217;s most recent season hosting (2014-2015). The show averaged 7.6 million nightly viewers in that season, and the ratings for the key demographic (viewers aged 18 to 49) across that season was roughly 46% higher than what Schwarzenegger&#8217;s debut scored on Monday. The network has been pushing the show&#8217;s new host and new season for months, including weathering last month&#8217;s controversy over the fact that president-elect Trump will continue receiving an executive producer credit on the show going forward. (As Fortune reported at the time, Trump has a large stake in the show that he co-created with fellow producer Mark Burnett, but will reportedly be compensated by MGM, which owns the majority stake in the production company that owns the rights to the Apprentice franchise.) To be fair, the Celebrity Apprentice premiere faced stiff Monday night competition that included The Bachelor premiere as well as a thrilling college football game in the Penn State-USC Rose Bowl matchup on ESPN dis . Still, NBC cmcsa was likely hoping for a more impressive start to the post-Trump era of its Apprentice franchise, even though some early reviews for the Schwarzenegger-led show were not particularly kind. When reached for comment, NBC ratings guru Tom Bierbaum noted that last year&#8217;s season premiere of the Celebrity Apprentice did not face major sports competition and that Monday&#8217;s premiere still managed to provide a strong lead-in for new NBC gameshow The Wall, which retained most of the Apprentice&#8217;s viewers to share the top ratings in the 10 p.m. time-slot among the key younger demographic.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ENBC&#8217;s \u003Cem\u003ECelebrity Apprentice\u003C\u002Fem\u003E returned to television on Monday night with a new host and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4620434\u002Farnold-schwarzenegger-the-apprentice-catchphrase\u002F\"\u003Ea new catchphrase\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. With Schwarzenegger now in the hosting chair, \u003Cem\u003EThe New\u003C\u002Fem\u003E \u003Cem\u003ECelebrity Apprentice \u003C\u002Fem\u003Eaveraged roughly 4.9 million total viewers across its two-hour premiere, according to Nielsen&#8217;s tracking numbers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EABC&#8217;s two-hour \u003Cem\u003EThe Bachelor\u003C\u002Fem\u003E premiere pulled in nearly 6.6 million viewers by comparison, while CBS averaged more than 6 million viewers between four half-hour sitcoms that aired between 8 p.m. and 10 p.m.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile NBC \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=obegLRvSUzM\"\u003Eheavily\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fvariety.com\u002F2017\u002Ftv\u002Fnews\u002Farnold-schwarzenegger-donald-trump-new-celebrity-apprentice-nbc-catchphrase-1201951107\u002F\"\u003Epromoted\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Schwarzenegger&#8217;s \u003Cem\u003EApprentice\u003C\u002Fem\u003E takeover ahead of the show&#8217;s January debut, the movie star and former California governor&#8217;s reality TV turn got off to a mediocre start, especially when compared with the ratings of his predecessor. The ratings for last night&#8217;s \u003Cem\u003ECelebrity Apprentice\u003C\u002Fem\u003E premiere were \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.hollywoodreporter.com\u002Flive-feed\u002Fhow-arnolds-apprentice-perform-outrate-donald-trump-959993\"\u003Edown more than 22%\u003C\u002Fa\u003E from the debut episode of Trump&#8217;s most recent season hosting (2014-2015). The show \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.thewrap.com\u002Fcelebrity-apprentice-trump-tv-ratings-arnold\u002F\"\u003Eaveraged 7.6 million\u003C\u002Fa\u003E nightly viewers in that season, and the ratings for the key demographic (viewers aged 18 to 49) across that season was roughly 46% higher than what Schwarzenegger&#8217;s debut scored on Monday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe network has been pushing the show&#8217;s new host and new season for months, including weathering \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F09\u002Fdonald-trump-celebrity-apprentice-nbc\u002F\"\u003Elast month&#8217;s controversy\u003C\u002Fa\u003E over the fact that president-elect Trump will continue receiving an executive producer credit on the show going forward. (As \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F09\u002Fdonald-trump-celebrity-apprentice-nbc\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E reported\u003C\u002Fa\u003E at the time, Trump has a large stake in the show that he co-created with fellow producer Mark Burnett, but will reportedly be compensated by MGM, which owns the majority stake in the production company that owns the rights to the \u003Cem\u003EApprentice\u003C\u002Fem\u003E franchise.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"video-wrapper\"
