Intelligence","slug":"market-intelligence","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":159689,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":631,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":384,"name":"Entertainment","slug":"entertainment","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":130744,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News about the business of entertainment, including the music, film and TV industries, as well as the celebrities and people who work in them. ","parent":0,"count":3223,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893266,"date":"2017-01-03T12:43:08","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T17:43:08","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893266"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T12:44:16","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T17:44:16","slug":"fridgecam-waste-food","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ffridgecam-waste-food\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iLEptP","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Meet the $150 Refrigerator Device That Wants to Help You Waste Less Food"},"content":{"plain":"Smarter is unveiling its FridgeCam, a refrigerator camera that can tell you when your food is about to expire or when you are running low on groceries. The London-based company unveiled the product \u2014 which is part of the ever-growing Internet of Things (making everyday objects smart and connected) \u2014 at CES 2017, the big tech trade show in Las Vegas this week. Smarter\u2019s FridgeCam is a wireless camera with an app that allows users to see the contents of their fridge from anywhere, receive reminders about expiration dates, and pick up groceries that are running low. Scheduled for release in the first quarter of 2017, the Smarter FridgeCam was designed to help address the global food waste crisis by notifying consumers of approaching expiration dates and suggesting ways to use foods before they go bad. Related: Tim Ferriss\u2019 Secret to Achieving a Breakthrough? Ask Absurd Questions. Additional features include alerts when the refrigerator temperature ventures outside the ideal range, notifications when food items are removed from the fridge, and auto-replenish ordering via the user\u2019s preferred online grocer. Geo-location reminders will alert the user when a grocery store is nearby, so milk, eggs, or other essentials can be purchased. The Smarter FridgeCam will sell for $150. Christian Lane, creator of Smarter, launched his first company at 19 with the backing of investors from Dragon\u2019s Den, the U.K. version of Shark Tank. Christian launched Smarter in 2013, with the goal of making people\u2019s lives easier through connected technology. He is the recipient of 2015 Great Britain Young Entrepreneur of the Year, London Design Awards, and other accolades for his IoT contributions. \u201cWe are very excited to showcase our FridgeCam with its full range of functions for the first time anywhere in the world,\u201d Lane said in a statement. \u201cWe created the FridgeCam to not only save people money, time, and energy, but also tackle food waste head-on in the process. In the U.S., average households can waste anywhere between $1,365 to $2,275 of food every year.\u201d Smarter\u2019s other products, the iKettle and Smarter Coffee Maker, are sold in more than 1,000 stores in the U.K. and Europe. By the end of 2017, Smarter expects to become a global connected platform that connects consumers to their kitchens, making grocery shopping and food waste a thing of the past. Smarter is self-funded and it has 20 employees. This article originally appeared on VentureBeat. All rights reserved.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.smarter.am\u002F\"\u003ESmarter \u003C\u002Fa\u003Eis unveiling its FridgeCam, a refrigerator camera that can tell you when your food is about to expire or when you are running low on groceries.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe London-based company unveiled the product \u2014 which is part of the ever-growing Internet of Things (making everyday objects smart and connected) \u2014 at CES 2017, the big tech trade show in Las Vegas this week.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESmarter\u2019s FridgeCam is a wireless camera with an app that allows users to see the contents of their fridge from anywhere, receive reminders about expiration dates, and pick up groceries that are running low.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EScheduled for release in the first quarter of 2017, the Smarter FridgeCam was designed to help address the global food waste crisis by notifying consumers of approaching expiration dates and suggesting ways to use foods before they go bad.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ERelated: \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F02\u002Ftim-ferriss-asks-absurd-questions\u002F\"\u003ETim Ferriss\u2019 Secret to Achieving a Breakthrough? Ask Absurd Questions.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAdditional features include alerts when the refrigerator temperature ventures outside the ideal range, notifications when food items are removed from the fridge, and auto-replenish ordering via the user\u2019s preferred online grocer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGeo-location reminders will alert the user when a grocery store is nearby, so milk, eggs, or other essentials can be purchased. The Smarter FridgeCam will sell for $150.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EChristian Lane, creator of Smarter, launched his first company at 19 with the backing of investors from \u003Cem\u003EDragon\u2019s Den,\u003C\u002Fem\u003E the U.K. version of \u003Cem\u003EShark Tank\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. Christian launched Smarter in 2013, with the goal of making people\u2019s lives easier through connected technology. He is the recipient of 2015 Great Britain Young Entrepreneur of the Year, London Design Awards, and other accolades for his IoT contributions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cWe are very excited to showcase our FridgeCam with its full range of functions for the first time anywhere in the world,\u201d Lane said in a statement. \u201cWe created the FridgeCam to not only save people money, time, and energy, but also tackle food waste head-on in the process. In the U.S., average households can waste anywhere between $1,365 to $2,275 of food every year.\u201d\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESmarter\u2019s other products, the iKettle and Smarter Coffee Maker, are sold in more than 1,000 stores in the U.K. and Europe. By the end of 2017, Smarter expects to become a global connected platform that connects consumers to their kitchens, making grocery shopping and food waste a thing of the past.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESmarter is self-funded and it has 20 employees.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis article originally appeared on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fventurebeat.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fsmarters-fridgecam-tells-you-when-your-food-will-expire\u002F\"\u003EVentureBeat\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Smarter","description":"","title":"smarter-cam"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":6,"name":"technology","slug":"technology","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":58660,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":271,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":10585,"name":"Venture","slug":"venture","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46732,"taxonomy":"category","description":"Fortune disruptors.","parent":0,"count":2347,"filter":"raw"}]}}]],"fortune:related":[[{"id":1893224,"date":"2017-01-03T16:01:56","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T21:01:56","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893224"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T16:22:05","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T21:22:05","slug":"tech-ford-trump-jobs","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Ftech-ford-trump-jobs\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j0NUop","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Will Tech Titans, Pressured By Trump, Create More U.S. Factory Jobs?"},"content":{"plain":"A surprise move by Ford on Tuesday to kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant in Mexico and move that work instead to Michigan may be a sign that business leaders have listened to President-elect Donald Trump, who has blasted U.S. companies for shipping jobs overseas. A big question is whether tech giants like Apple, IBM and Microsoft, all of whom rely heavily on foreign manufacturers, will follow Ford&#8217;s f lead. To be fair, while Trump tends to take credit for saving all these jobs\u2014he had threatened Ford with a 35% tariff on Mexican-built vehicles sold in the U.S.\u2014 Ford chief executive Mark Fields told CNN that the company &#8220;didn&#8217;t cut a deal with Trump. We did it for our business.&#8221; Whether you believe Ford&#8217;s move was due to Trump himself, or to a growing belief among voters that the country needs to maintain its own manufacturing capabilities, or that it just makes financial sense, as Fields argued, it is noteworthy. Last month, telecommunications company Sprint and satellite provider OneWeb announced plans to hire 5,000 U.S. workers. Although Trump claimed credit for those jobs, they were, in fact, part of a planned $50 billion U.S. investment by SoftBank Group founder Masayoshi Son before Trump&#8217;s election victory. SoftBank owns stakes in both Sprint and OneWeb. About 3,000 of those jobs would be at a new Florida factory where OneWeb says it will build low-cost satellites. It was unclear how many of the other jobs would be in manufacturing, but the fact that two tech companies committed so publicly to investing in American workers was noteworthy. And it was also great public relations since SoftBank also wants to revive a Sprint s merger with T-Mobile tmus that was proposed in 2014 but dropped in the face of U.S. regulatory resistance. SoftBank\u002FSprint might have better luck getting approval of the deal in a Trump administration. Apple, criticized by Trump in the past for its outsourced manufacturing, is a bellwether for tech stalwarts. Apple aapl has talked with Foxconn and Pegatron, two Asian contract manufacturers that build iPhones, to move some of their work stateside, according to unconfirmed reports. Furthermore, Apple CEO Tim Cook, along with his Microsoft and IBM counterparts Satya Nadella and Ginni Rometty respectively, attended Trump&#8217;s tech summit in New York last month. Creating U.S. jobs was one hot topic of the event. In an emailed statement, an Apple spokesman said the company: is responsible for creating more than two million jobs across the United States, from engineers, retail and call center employees to operations and delivery drivers. We work with over 8,000 suppliers from coast to coast and are investing heavily in American jobs and innovation. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. In a blog posted the day after the election, Microsoft president Brad Smith pointed out the need for more highly educated workers. He cited research showing that the U.S. economy added 35 million jobs over the last 25 years, but that the number of jobs held by those without a high school diploma fell 13% to 7.3 million while jobs for those with four-year degrees doubled. He stressed the need for private-public sector collaboration to boost jobs and innovation in the U.S. and elsewhere. But Smith made no mention of whether the company Microsoft would start making its Surface tablet devices in the U.S. or push its Asian manufacturing partners to open facilities here. For more on Ford&#8217;s factory move, watch: IBM&#8217;s Rometty, likewise, stated a need for companies to work with the U.S. government to improve the climate for job creation. In an open letter to Trump in November, she spoke about a need to train people for skilled jobs that don&#8217;t require two- or four-year college degrees. But again, there was little in the way of specifics and no mention of moving any services or manufacturing work to the U.S. from elsewhere. Fortune contacted Microsoft msft and IBM ibm for comment about their U.S. job plans and will update this article as needed. Toni Sacconaghi, senior research analyst with Bernstein Research said he hasn&#8217;t heard much from tech players about bringing jobs\u2014manufacturing or otherwise\u2014to the U.S. from abroad. And, Rometty&#8217;s plans, as spelled out in her letter, are &#8220;tough to interpret,&#8221; he said in an email. Thus far, SoftBank affiliates Sprint and OneWeb seem to be the only tech companies that have promised specific action on the domestic jobs front in the near term. The rest of the tech community has remained silent, at least publicly, about bringing manufacturing jobs back to the U.S. But then again, it&#8217;s early. One thing is certain, says Jeff Matthews, managing partner for RAM Partners, a Naples, Florida-based hedge fund, via email: &#8220;Every company I talk to is thinking about how to do more in America. I&#8217;m not sure that they will, but it is now something that&#8217;s on everybody&#8217;s radar, which can&#8217;t hurt.&#8221;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA surprise move by Ford on Tuesday \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump\u002F\"\u003Eto kill a planned $1.6 billion auto plant\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Mexico and move that work instead to Michigan may be a sign that business leaders have listened to President-elect Donald Trump, who has blasted U.S. companies for shipping jobs overseas. SoftBank\u002FSprint might have better luck getting approval of the deal in a Trump administration.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EApple, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fdonald-trump-companies\u002F\"\u003Ecriticized by Trump in the past for its\u003C\u002Fa\u003E outsourced manufacturing, is a bellwether for tech stalwarts. Apple \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"aapl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eaapl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E has talked with Foxconn and Pegatron, two Asian contract manufacturers that build iPhones, to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fasia.nikkei.com\u002FBusiness\u002FAC\u002FApple-could-make-iPhones-in-US-in-future-sources\"\u003Emove some of their work stateside\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, according to unconfirmed reports.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFurthermore, Apple CEO Tim Cook, along with his Microsoft and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIBM\u003C\u002Fa\u003E counterparts Satya Nadella and Ginni Rometty respectively, attended Trump&#8217;s tech summit in New York last month. Creating \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.usatoday.com\u002Fstory\u002Ftech\u002Fnews\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F11\u002Ftrump-fills-out-his-tech-summit-attendee-list\u002F95300462\u002F\"\u003EU.S. jobs was one hot topic\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of the event.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn an emailed statement, an Apple spokesman said the company:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cblockquote\u003E\u003Cp\u003Eis responsible for creating more than two million jobs across the United States, from engineers, retail and call center employees to operations and delivery drivers. We work with over 8,000 suppliers from coast to coast and are investing heavily in American jobs and innovation.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fblockquote\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFortune\u003Cem\u003E\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fblogs.microsoft.com\u002Fon-the-issues\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F09\u002Fmoving-forward-together-thoughts-us-election\u002F#_ftn1\"\u003E blog\u003C\u002Fa\u003E posted the day after the election, Microsoft president Brad Smith pointed out the need for more highly educated workers. He cited research showing that the U.S. economy added 35 million jobs over the last 25 years, but that the number of jobs held by those without a high school diploma fell 13% to 7.3 million while jobs for those with four-year degrees doubled.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHe stressed the need for private-public sector collaboration to boost jobs and innovation in the U.S. and elsewhere. But Smith made no mention of whether the company Microsoft would start making its \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F20\u002Fmicrosoft-surface-pro-4-big-business\u002F\"\u003ESurface\u003C\u002Fa\u003E tablet devices in the U.S. or push its Asian manufacturing partners to open facilities here.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFor more on Ford&#8217;s factory move, watch:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E \u003Cdiv And, Rometty&#8217;s plans, as spelled out in her letter, are &#8220;tough to interpret,&#8221; he said in an email.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThus far, SoftBank affiliates Sprint and OneWeb seem to be the only tech companies that have promised specific action on the domestic jobs front in the near term. The rest of the tech community has remained silent, at least publicly, about bringing manufacturing jobs back to the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut then again, it&#8217;s early.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne thing is certain, says Jeff Matthews, managing partner for RAM Partners, a Naples, Florida-based hedge fund, via email: &#8220;Every company I talk to is thinking about how to do more in America. Photographer: Daniel Acker\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","title":"Nissan Factory 2016"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":237556496,"name":"Blue Ribbon Companies","slug":"blue-ribbon-companies","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":72323,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":18,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893353,"date":"2017-01-03T13:45:34","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T18:45:34","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893353"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T15:32:54","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T20:32:54","slug":"intel-buys-mapping-app-here","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fintel-buys-mapping-app-here\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j17NM0","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why Intel Wants a Piece of Mapping App HERE"},"content":{"plain":"Intel bought 15% of digital mapping service HERE on Tuesday as the chipmaker wades further into the market for self-driving cars and other autonomous devices. Intel joins HERE&#8217;s current owners\u2014carmakers Audi, BMW, and Daimler\u2014in their efforts to build a vast global map and location database that doesn&#8217;t rely on information from Apple aapl or Google. Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has targeted making chips and sensors for self-driving cars, automated robots, and AI-enhanced drones as one of the company&#8217;s new growth market. The carmakers bought HERE from Nokia in 2015 for $3 billion. Intel intc declined to disclose how much it paid for its 15% stake. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. &#8220;Cars are rapidly becoming some of the world\u2019s most intelligent, connected devices,&#8221; Krzanich said in a statement. &#8220;We look forward to working with HERE and its automotive partners to deliver an important technology foundation for smart and connected cars of the future.&#8221; Intel&#8217;s aim is to help the car makers create much more robust and detailed mapping hardware and software that will be needed for truly autonomous vehicles. HERE&#8217;s next generation mapping applications will be able to pinpoint a car&#8217;s location within centimeters, down from exactness in meters today, the company says. HERE&#8217;s current product offerings run the gamut from a consumer-oriented smartphone app called HERE WeGo to live traffic data that can be licensed and fed into car navigation systems, all built on top of its ecosystem of mapping data and related software tools. The head of Intel&#8217;s automated driving group, Doug Davis, will join HERE&#8217;s supervisory board after the transaction is completed. The deal is expected to close before the end of the first quarter. Google googl has long dominated the market for digitally usable map and location data for portable devices, after it spent billions building its data sets. Apple had to play catch up after it created its own smartphone map app in 2012, relying on licensing data from Dutch provider TomTom. But HERE started mapping the world three decades ago and built a strong position in the automotive market long before smartphones came along. Nokia nok bought the company, then known as Navteq, for $8 billion in 2007.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fintel-51\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIntel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E bought 15% of digital mapping service HERE on Tuesday as the chipmaker wades further into the market for self-driving cars and other autonomous devices.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIntel joins HERE&#8217;s current owners\u2014carmakers Audi, BMW, and Daimler\u2014in their efforts to build a vast global map and location database that doesn&#8217;t rely on information from \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EApple\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"aapl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eaapl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E or \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoogle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Apple Maps?","twitter_text":"Why Intel Wants a Piece of Mapping App HERE","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fintel-buys-mapping-app-here\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fintel-buys-mapping-app-here\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1782269,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F94589600.jpg","alt":"A Nokia Oyj, the world's biggest mobile-phone company, agreed to buy Navteq Corp. for $8.1billion to gain digital maps of 69 countries and compete with TomTom NV in the market for navigation devices.","title":"A Garmin GPS device displays Navteq software at a Best Buy s"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":366068442,"name":"The Mobile Executive","slug":"the-mobile-executive","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":133921,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":402,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1886811,"date":"2016-12-31T10:00:43","date_gmt":"2016-12-31T15:00:43","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1886811"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-31T10:00:44","modified_gmt":"2016-12-31T15:00:44","slug":"career-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Fcareer-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2gVgMg4","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"The Best Career Advice of 2016"},"content":{"plain":"Every day at Fortune, influential leaders, entrepreneurs, and Fortune 500 executives offer valuable insight from their experiences navigating the business world. We\u2019ve compiled some of our favorite pieces of career advice published in 2016: Sarah Kauss, founder and CEO of S\u2019well: Delegation can sometimes come off as negative\u2014like you\u2019re just pushing off work on someone else\u2014but it doesn\u2019t have to be perceived that way. Don\u2019t just say \u201cno\u201d to a request. You should, in fact, pass it along when you\u2019re too busy. And that\u2019s not a bad thing. Think of the opportunity you are giving others. A conference organizer may not always want your senior vice president when the founder or CEO can\u2019t make the event. But if you show that you trust someone else with an opportunity\u200a\u2014\u200asuch as establishing your company\u2019s brand reputation\u200a\u2014\u200ayou may be surprised by the positive reactions you\u2019ll receive. Dennis Yang, CEO of Udemy: Hiring begins with the job description itself, which needs to reflect the position\u2019s real requirements and responsibilities. Too many companies go forth in search of a left-handed, purple unicorn: that elusive individual who possesses mastery in a broad range of skills and can single-handedly do the job of many people. Unfortunately, unicorns don\u2019t exist. Companies that think they\u2019ve hired one stand to be disappointed, and candidates who represent themselves as such are either on the fast track to burnout or are overselling themselves. Your job listings need to be realistic in order to attract real candidates and give your interviewers tangible evaluation criteria. Amber Theorharis, host for the NFL Network: When [a] job opens, take it\u2014even if the salary is low. Success doesn\u2019t happen overnight, and there\u2019s nothing wrong with starting at the bottom. That\u2019s where you make mistakes that will be the least devastating to your professional reputation\u2014and you can still learn from them. The money and the position will come later, but you have to get in the game. Take a side job to pay the bills if your career can\u2019t. I waited tables after work and on weekends for almost two years while working on-air at a small TV station in Salisbury, Md. My dream was bigger than my pride. &nbsp; Jeremy Roche, president and CEO of FinancialForce: I can\u2019t express enough how important it is to throw your ego out the door. When you jump into a new career or position, there is a 100% chance you will make mistakes. No matter how much experience you have and how high up the ranks you were, when you start a new job, you will have to prove yourself all over again. And while that might sound daunting, you have to stay positive. Embrace the unknown and be willing to go back to the basics of learning new skills. This experience can build empathy, truly enhancing your leadership skills in the long run. Kim Metcalf-Kupres, vice president and chief marketing officer of Johnson Controls: Fight for change when it matters and learn to let lesser issues roll off. While gender parity continues to improve in traditionally male-dominated fields, the reality is that we all have preconceived perceptions of how things should be, and culture change does not happen overnight. In these moments, especially if they involve unconscious bias, it is essential to educate others and provide your perspective in a kind and respectful manner. Don\u2019t sweat the small stuff.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EEvery day at Fortune, influential leaders, entrepreneurs, and Fortune 500 executives offer valuable insight from their experiences navigating the business world. We\u2019ve compiled some of our favorite pieces of career advice published in 2016:\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ESarah Kauss, founder and CEO of \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ES\u2019well\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E:\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EDelegation can sometimes come off as negative\u2014like you\u2019re just pushing off work on someone else\u2014\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finsiders.fortune.com\u002Fhow-to-say-no-and-still-be-liked-6c3e9154a2b5#.asilujqg6\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ebut it doesn\u2019t have to be perceived that way\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. Don\u2019t just say \u201cno\u201d to a request. You should, in fact, pass it along when you\u2019re too busy.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EAnd that\u2019s not a bad thing. Think of the opportunity you are giving others. A conference organizer may not always want your senior vice president when the founder or CEO can\u2019t make the event. But if you show that you trust someone else with an opportunity\u200a\u2014\u200asuch as establishing your company\u2019s brand reputation\u200a\u2014\u200ayou may be surprised by the positive reactions you\u2019ll receive.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EDennis Yang, CEO of\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EUdemy\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHiring begins with the job description itself, which needs to reflect the position\u2019s real requirements and responsibilities. Too many companies go forth in search of a left-handed, purple unicorn: that elusive individual who possesses mastery in a broad range of skills and can single-handedly do the job of many people.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EUnfortunately, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finsiders.fortune.com\u002Fheres-why-you-can-t-always-trust-your-gut-9883f40f7f24#.kbxkrr6os\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eunicorns don\u2019t exist\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. Companies that think they\u2019ve hired one stand to be disappointed, and candidates who represent themselves as such are either on the fast track to burnout or are overselling themselves. Your job listings need to be realistic in order to attract real candidates and give your interviewers tangible evaluation criteria.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EAmber Theorharis, host for the \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ENFL Network\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E:\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EWhen [a] job opens, take it\u2014even if the salary is low. Success doesn\u2019t happen overnight, and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F14\u002Fnfl-network-career-advice-women-business\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ethere\u2019s nothing wrong with starting at the bottom\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. That\u2019s where you make mistakes that will be the least devastating to your professional reputation\u2014and you can still learn from them. The money and the position will come later, but you have to get in the game. Take a side job to pay the bills if your career can\u2019t. I waited tables after work and on weekends for almost two years while working on-air at a small TV station in Salisbury, Md. My dream was bigger than my pride.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-wrapper\"  data-ratio=\"0.56363636363636\" data-pos=\"2\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cobject name=\"adServerURL\" Roche, president and CEO of \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EFinancialForce\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E:\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finsiders.fortune.com\u002F5-tips-for-landing-a-job-you-didnt-go-to-school-for-951ee1e100a0#.iap5br93m\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ethrow your ego out the door\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. When you jump into a new career or position, there is a 100% chance you will make mistakes. No matter how much experience you have and how high up the ranks you were, when you start a new job, you will have to prove yourself all over again.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EAnd while that might sound daunting, you have to stay positive. Embrace the unknown and be willing to go back to the basics of learning new skills. This experience can build empathy, truly enhancing your leadership skills in the long run.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EKim Metcalf-Kupres, vice president and chief marketing officer of \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EJohnson Controls\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E:\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFight for change when it matters and learn to let lesser issues roll off. While gender parity continues to improve in traditionally male-dominated fields, the reality is that we all have preconceived perceptions of how things should be, and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F10\u002Fhired-career-advice-employer-bias\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eculture change does not happen overnight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. In these moments, especially if they involve unconscious bias, it is essential to educate others and provide your perspective in a kind and respectful manner. Don\u2019t sweat the small stuff.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Every day at Fortune, influential leaders, entrepreneurs, and Fortune 500 executives offer valuable insight from their experiences navigating the business world. Advice of 2016","og_title":"The Best Career Advice of 2016","twitter_text":"The best career advice of 2016","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Fcareer-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F31\u002Fcareer-advice-best-of-2016-leadership-entrepreneurs-most-powerful-women-fortune-500\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1886831,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Foverhead-business-people-gettyimages-520791880.jpg","alt":"Overhead and using a tablet computer","title":"overhead career advice"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":97521,"name":"Career Advice","slug":"career-advice","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":111260,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":127,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":291878719,"name":"Fortune Insiders","slug":"fortune-insiders","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":122920,"taxonomy":"category","description":"","parent":0,"count":2701,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1885451,"date":"2016-12-30T09:30:45","date_gmt":"2016-12-30T14:30:45","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1885451"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-30T09:30:47","modified_gmt":"2016-12-30T14:30:47","slug":"best-stocks-fortune-500-companies-2016","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fbest-stocks-fortune-500-companies-2016\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2gTKcA4","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"The Fortune 500\u2019s 7 Best-Performing Stocks of 2016"},"content":{"plain":"For 2016\u2019s best-performing Fortune 500 stocks, you can definitely call it a comeback. In a year when the S&amp;P 500 has gained a solid 10%, these Fortune 500 companies ran circles around that return: All of the stocks on this list at least doubled their share prices in 2016, and the top two winners each more than quadrupled. Still, you won\u2019t find any high-growth tech companies on this list. Most of this year&#8217;s big winners come from unsexy industries beset by struggles from which these firms are just starting to emerge. Three are steel companies whose stocks took off after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, prompting hopes of a wave of new spending on infrastructure. Also, although Fortune 500 members are, by definition, the largest companies in the U.S. by revenue, none of this year&#8217;s top gainers was among the very biggest of the big. Indeed, six of the top 10 performers come from the bottom half of the 500 list. Even though they may no longer be underdogs, the stocks of many of 2016\u2019s best performers remain well below their all-time highs, and several still look cheap. So even if you missed out on a four-bagger return this year, there may be more rallies to come for some of these stocks in 2017. Here&#8217;s the full list of 2016\u2019s biggest Fortune 500 stock winners. 1. AK Steel Holding Fortune 500 rank: No. 383 2016 return: 359% Courtesy of AK Steel Holding Iron ore and steel prices fell precipitously in 2015 on slowing demand for construction material in China. But they bounced back forcefully after hitting bottom in early 2016, as steel producers cut production dramatically. After several years of losses, AK Steel aks is expected to turn a profit in 2016, as the company continued to cut costs while also benefiting from higher prices. Still, the steepest jump in AK Steel\u2019s stock price came after Trump won the election: AK\u2019s shares are up more than 74% since Nov. 8. Not only is the Trump administration likely to green-light more infrastructure projects that will rely on heavy materials such as steel, the President-elect has signaled that he will enact trade policies that make imported steel less attractive while tipping the scales toward U.S. producers. Oh, and it doesn\u2019t hurt that Trump\u2019s nominee for secretary of commerce is Wilbur Ross, the founder and former CEO of a major steel company. \u201cTrump\u2019s impact on trade and therefore domestic steel supply and prices could be much quicker and more meaningful than Trump\u2019s infrastructure plans,\u201d write J.P. Morgan analysts, who rate AK Steel &#8220;overweight&#8221; (that is, a buy). 2.United States Steel Fortune 500 rank: No. 244 2016 return: 332% Courtesy of United States Steel Like AK Steel&#8217;s shares, United States Steel x stock surged this year as steel prices rose, then accelerated further after Trump\u2019s victory (gaining more than 70% since the election). U.S. Steel doesn\u2019t have quite as much leeway to cut costs as smaller peers like AK. That makes it extremely sensitive to steel prices\u2014and also makes it the American steel stock that could benefit the most from a recovery in that market, according to J.P. Morgan. As the amount of steel imported from China continues to decline and domestic production stays in check, the price of the metal will likely keep going up\u2014sending U.S. Steel even higher. 3. Navistar International Fortune 500 rank: No. 281 2016 return: 236% Mahindra Navistar trucks at a factory in Maharashtra, India.(Kuni Takahashi\u002FBloomberg) This year\u2019s rally in Navistar\u2019s stock\u2014which more than tripled in 2016\u2014has almost (but not quite) made up for its terrible 2015, when the shares fell 74%. Navistar nav , which makes diesel engines and trucks, took a costly wrong turn a few years ago when it tried and failed to develop its own emissions-reducing system to meet new Environmental Protection Agency standards. In March, it had to pay $7.5 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it misled shareholders about its technology\u2019s capability to cut emissions. While the end of that investigation popped the lid off Navistar\u2019s stock price, the tipping point came just after Labor Day, when Volkswagen\u2014a company that faced its own (much larger) emissions scandal\u2014announced it was taking a nearly 17% stake in the company. Navistar\u2019s shares surged 41% in a single day on the news. Other investors in the company include high-profile activist Carl Icahn. 4. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Fortune 500 rank: No. 16 (Fannie Mae) and No. 43 (Freddie Mac) 2016 return: 140% (Fannie Mae) and 136% (Freddie Mac) Fannie Mae headquarters in Washington, D.C.Photograph by Kevin Lamarque \u2014 Reuters We&#8217;ve lumped these two stocks together here because their businesses, their recent stock performance and their near-term outlooks are close to identical. Prior to the presidential election, Fannie&#8217;s and Freddie\u2019s share prices were pretty much flat for 2016. But that all changed when Trump won the White House: Both Fannie Mae fnma and Freddie Mac fmcc stock have more than doubled since the Nov. 8 vote. The reason is fairly straightforward: Trump\u2019s treasury secretary pick, former Goldman Sachs banker Steven Mnuchin, suggested privatizing Fannie and Freddie, which have been under government control since the mortgage lenders received a giant bailout during the financial crisis. That outcome would be a far cry from what was expected just a few years ago, when Fannie and Freddie\u2019s shares were worth just pennies as the government indicated that it would eventually phase them out entirely. Privatizing the quasi-governmental companies would also a huge boon to a growing contingent of hedge fund speculators, who have invested in the pair and advocated that the government allow the companies to keep more of their own profits. One indication of Fannie and Freddie\u2019s wild ride since the Great Recession? They were the top two best-performing Fortune 500 stocks in 2013, returning more than 1000% each, only to land on the list of worst performers the following year. 5.Oneok Fortune 500 rank: No. 348 2016 return: 135.6% Courtesy of Oneok An Oklahoma-based natural gas production and pipeline company, Oneok oke struggled when that commodity\u2019s price fell along with oil prices starting a couple of years ago: Oneok stock was down 46% in 2015. But as natural gas prices surged this year, Oneok\u2019s shares more than doubled. Still, they have yet to recover to where they were trading at their peak in the summer of 2014. 6. Freeport-McMoRan Fortune 500 rank: No. 175 2016 return: 106% Copper-gold concentrate from Freeport McMoRan Inc.&#8217;s Grasberg copper and gold mine is loaded onto a ship in Amamapare, Papua province, Indonesia.Dadang Tri\u2014Bloomberg After a five-year bear market in precious metals including gold, silver and copper\u2014all of which Freeport-McMoRan fcx produces at its mines\u2014the prices of those commodities rallied in 2016 as supply came down closer in line with demand. Trump\u2019s election win gave copper an additional kick, with investors believing that his administration\u2019s expected infrastructure projects will need to rely on that building material. Freeport had suffered particularly in recent years from its decision to diversify into the oil business\u2014at what turned out to be exactly the wrong time, as prices plummeted. It sold off some of its energy business this year, relieving it of some of the debt it had taken on in the process. Still, Freeport maintains substantial operations in that area that will benefit if oil prices continue to rise. 7.Steel Dynamics Fortune 500 rank: No. 356 2016 return: 100% Courtesy of Steel Dynamics Unlike its fellow steelmakers on this list\u2014AK Steel and United States Steel\u2014Steel Dynamics stld managed to ride out steel&#8217;s 2015 price downturn relatively unscathed: Its stock price only shed about 7% last year. The company also stayed profitable, generating hefty free cash flow. Still, Steel Dynamics still got a major boost from rising prices this year. And it&#8217;s particularly well positioned to profit from increasing demand for steel, as the company has greatly expanded the amount it can produce since the 2008 financial crisis.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor 2016\u2019s best-performing \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 stocks, you can definitely call it a comeback.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn a year when the S&amp;P 500 has gained a solid 10%, these \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 companies ran circles around that return: All of the stocks on this list at least doubled their share prices in 2016, and the top two winners each more than quadrupled.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, you won\u2019t find any high-growth tech companies on this list. Most of this year&#8217;s big winners come from unsexy industries beset by struggles from which these firms are just starting to emerge. Three are steel companies whose stocks took off after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, prompting hopes of a wave of new spending on infrastructure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAlso, although \u003Cem\u003EFortune \u003C\u002Fem\u003E500 members are, by definition, the largest companies in the U.S. by revenue, none of this year&#8217;s top gainers was among the very biggest of the big. Indeed, six of the top 10 performers come from the bottom half of the 500 list.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEven though they may no longer be underdogs, the stocks of many of 2016\u2019s best performers remain well below their all-time highs, and several still look cheap. So even if you missed out on a four-bagger return this year, there may be more rallies to come for some of these stocks in 2017.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s the full list of 2016\u2019s biggest \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 stock winners.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAK Steel Holding\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 383\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 359%\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width alignnone\"  \u003E\u003Ca \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003ECourtesy of AK Steel Holding\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIron ore and steel prices fell precipitously in 2015 on slowing demand for construction material in China. But they bounced back forcefully after hitting bottom in early 2016, as steel producers cut production dramatically. After several years of losses, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAK Steel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"aks\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eaks\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E is expected to turn a profit in 2016, as the company continued to cut costs while also benefiting from higher prices.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, the steepest jump in AK Steel\u2019s stock price came after Trump won the election: AK\u2019s shares are up more than 74% since Nov. 8. Not only is the Trump administration likely to green-light more infrastructure projects that will rely on heavy materials such as steel, the President-elect has signaled that he will enact trade policies that make imported steel less attractive while tipping the scales toward U.S. producers. Oh, and it doesn\u2019t hurt that Trump\u2019s nominee for secretary of commerce is Wilbur Ross, the founder and former CEO of a major steel company.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u201cTrump\u2019s impact on trade and therefore domestic steel supply and prices could be much quicker and more meaningful than Trump\u2019s infrastructure plans,\u201d write \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjpmorgan-chase-23\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJ.P. Morgan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E analysts, who rate AK Steel &#8220;overweight&#8221; (that is, a buy).\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E2.\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EUnited States Steel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFortune 500 rank: No. 244\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 332%\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003ECourtesy of United States Steel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELike AK Steel&#8217;s shares, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EUnited States Steel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"x\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-states-steel-244\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ex\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E stock surged this year as steel prices rose, then accelerated further after Trump\u2019s victory (gaining more than 70% since the election). U.S. Steel doesn\u2019t have quite as much leeway to cut costs as smaller peers like AK. That makes it extremely sensitive to steel prices\u2014and also makes it the American steel stock that could benefit the most from a recovery in that market, according to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjpmorgan-chase-23\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJ.P. Morgan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. As the amount of steel imported from China continues to decline and domestic production stays in check, the price of the metal will likely keep going up\u2014sending U.S. Steel even higher.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E3. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENavistar International\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 281\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 236%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\"\u003EMahindra Navistar trucks at a factory in Maharashtra, India.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003E(Kuni Takahashi\u002FBloomberg)\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis year\u2019s rally in Navistar\u2019s stock\u2014which more than tripled in 2016\u2014has almost (but not quite) made up for its terrible 2015, when the shares fell 74%. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENavistar\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"nav\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Enav\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, which makes diesel engines and trucks, took a costly wrong turn a few years ago when it tried and failed to develop its own emissions-reducing system to meet new Environmental Protection Agency standards. In March, it had to pay $7.5 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it misled shareholders about its technology\u2019s capability to cut emissions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile the end of that investigation popped the lid off Navistar\u2019s stock price, the tipping point came just after Labor Day, when Volkswagen\u2014a company that faced its own (much larger) emissions scandal\u2014announced it was taking a nearly 17% stake in the company. Navistar\u2019s shares surged 41% in a single day on the news. Other investors in the company include high-profile activist Carl Icahn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E4. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFannie Mae\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFreddie Mac\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 16 (Fannie Mae) and No. 43 (Freddie Mac)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 140% (Fannie Mae) and 136% (Freddie Mac)\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width aligncenter\"  \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Ffannie-mae.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1324383\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002F22\u002Ffannie-mae-lund\u002Fa-man-stands-outside-fannie-mae-in-washington\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002Ffannie-mae.jpg?w=840&#038;h=487\" data-orig-size=\"840,487\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;\\u00a9 Kevin Lamarque \\\u002F Reuters&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;A stands outside Fannie Mae headquarters in Washington February 21, 2014. Fannie Mae said on Friday it would soon send the U.S. Treasury $7.2 billion, a profit-related dividend that makes taxpayers whole for the 2008 bailout of the mortgage-finance giant and its sibling company Freddie Mac.\\r\\rREUTERS\\\u002FKevin Lamarque  (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS REAL ESTATE) - \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\"\u003EFannie Mae headquarters in Washington, D.C.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003EPhotograph by Kevin Lamarque \u2014 Reuters\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe&#8217;ve lumped these two stocks together here because their businesses, their recent stock performance and their near-term outlooks are close to identical.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPrior to the presidential election, Fannie&#8217;s and Freddie\u2019s share prices were pretty much flat for 2016. But that all changed when Trump won the White House: Both \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFannie Mae\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"fnma\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffannie-mae-16\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Efnma\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFreddie Mac\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"fmcc\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreddie-mac-43\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Efmcc\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E stock have more than doubled since the Nov. 8 vote.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe reason is fairly straightforward: Trump\u2019s treasury secretary pick, former \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgoldman-sachs-group-74\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoldman Sachs\u003C\u002Fa\u003E banker Steven Mnuchin, suggested privatizing Fannie and Freddie, which have been under government control since the mortgage lenders received a giant bailout during the financial crisis. That outcome would be a far cry from what was expected just a few years ago, when Fannie and Freddie\u2019s shares were worth just pennies as the government indicated that it would eventually phase them out entirely. Privatizing the quasi-governmental companies would also a huge boon to a growing contingent of hedge fund speculators, who have invested in the pair and advocated that the government allow the companies to keep more of their own profits.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne indication of Fannie and Freddie\u2019s wild ride since the Great Recession? They were the top two best-performing \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 stocks in 2013, returning more than 1000% each, only to land on the list of worst performers the following year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E5.\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Foneok-348\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EOneok\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr starting a couple of years ago: Oneok stock was down 46% in 2015. Still, they have yet to recover to where they were trading at their peak in the summer of 2014.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E6. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreeport-mcmoran-175\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFreeport-McMoRan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 175\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 106%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width aligncenter\"  \u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F471414456.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"1690302\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F08\u002Ffortune-500-ten-billion-losers\u002Foperations-at-freeport-mcmoran-inc-s-grasberg-gold-and-copper-mine\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F471414456.jpg?w=1024&#038;h=683\" data-orig-size=\"4000,2667\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;20&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;Bloomberg&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;Canon EOS 60D&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;Copper-gold concentrate from Freeport McMoRan Inc.&#039;s Grasberg copper and gold mine is loaded onto a ship at the company&#039;s loading facility in the port of Amamapare, Papua province, Indonesia, on Tuesday, April 21, 2015. of which \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreeport-mcmoran-175\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFreeport-McMoRan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ffreeport-mcmoran-175\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Efcx\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E produces at its mines\u2014the prices of those commodities rallied in 2016 as supply came down closer in line with demand. Trump\u2019s election win gave copper an additional kick, with investors believing that his administration\u2019s expected infrastructure projects will need to rely on that building material.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFreeport had suffered particularly in recent years from its decision to diversify into the oil business\u2014at what turned out to be exactly the wrong time, as prices plummeted. It sold off some of its energy business this year, relieving it of some of the debt it had taken on in the process. Still, Freeport maintains substantial operations in that area that will benefit if oil prices continue to rise.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E7.\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsteel-dynamics-356\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ESteel Dynamics\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\nFortune 500 rank: No. 356\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n2016 return: 100%\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-image-default-width alignnone\"  \u003E\u003Ca \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\"\u003ECourtesy of Steel Dynamics\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnlike its fellow steelmakers on this list\u2014AK Steel and United States Steel\u2014\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsteel-dynamics-356\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ESteel Dynamics\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"stld\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsteel-dynamics-356\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Estld\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E managed to ride out steel&#8217;s 2015 price downturn relatively unscathed: Its stock price only shed about 7% last year. The company also stayed profitable, generating hefty free cash flow.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, Steel Dynamics still got a major boost from rising prices this year. And it&#8217;s particularly well positioned to profit from increasing demand for steel, as the company has greatly expanded the amount it can produce since the 2008 financial crisis.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For 2016\u2019s best-performing ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]}," 500 stocks, you can definitely call it a comeback."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In a year when the S&amp;P 500 has gained a solid 10%, these ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]}," 500 companies ran circles around that return: All of the stocks on this list at least doubled their share prices in 2016, and the top two winners each more than quadrupled."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Still, you won\u2019t find any high-growth tech companies on this list. Most of this year's big winners come from unsexy industries beset by struggles from which these firms are just starting to emerge. Three are steel companies whose stocks took off after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, prompting hopes of a wave of new spending on infrastructure."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Also, although ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune "]},"500 members are, by definition, the largest companies in the U.S. by revenue, none of this year's top gainers was among the very biggest of the big. Indeed, six of the top 10 performers come from the bottom half of the 500 list."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Even though they may no longer be underdogs, the stocks of many of 2016\u2019s best performers remain well below their all-time highs, and several still look cheap. After several years of losses, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fak-steel-holding-383\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["AK Steel"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"aks"},"content":[]}," is expected to turn a profit in 2016, as the company continued to cut costs while also benefiting from higher prices."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Still, the steepest jump in AK Steel\u2019s stock price came after Trump won the election: AK\u2019s shares are up more than 74% since Nov. 8. Not only is the Trump administration likely to green-light more infrastructure projects that will rely on heavy materials such as steel, the President-elect has signaled that he will enact trade policies that make imported steel less attractive while tipping the scales toward U.S. producers. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnavistar-international-281\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Navistar"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"nav"},"content":[]},", which makes diesel engines and trucks, took a costly wrong turn a few years ago when it tried and failed to develop its own emissions-reducing system to meet new Environmental Protection Agency standards. That outcome would be a far cry from what was expected just a few years ago, when Fannie and Freddie\u2019s shares were worth just pennies as the government indicated that it would eventually phase them out entirely. Privatizing the quasi-governmental companies would also a huge boon to a growing contingent of hedge fund speculators, who have invested in the pair and advocated that the government allow the companies to keep more of their own profits."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["One indication of Fannie and Freddie\u2019s wild ride since the Great Recession? Street.","parent":0,"count":18937,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1892098,"date":"2016-12-29T17:35:57","date_gmt":"2016-12-29T22:35:57","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1892098"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-29T17:35:57","modified_gmt":"2016-12-29T22:35:57","slug":"trump-fcc-morken-net-neutrality","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Ftrump-fcc-morken-net-neutrality\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2imOikr","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Latest Trump FCC Pick Has Not Battled Net Neutrality Rules"},"content":{"plain":"The incoming administration of President-elect Donald Trump named another person to its transition team overseeing the Federal Communications Commission. And unlike past picks, this one has no record of criticizing net neutrality, the 2015 rules that prevent Internet service providers from slowing or blocking online content and services. David Morken, co-founder of Republic Wireless and an entrepreneur from Raleigh, N.C., will join three prior Trump FCC transition team members in helping set policies at the agency that regulates telecommunications, cable TV, and the Internet, Politico reported on Thursday. But unlike previous Trump FCC transition picks, Morken has no obvious and widespread record of speaking out against the agency&#8217;s moves in 2015 to protect competition on the Internet through net neutrality rules. Companies like AT&amp;T t and Verizon have complained that the rules over-regulate the industry and deter investment in networks. Rather, Morken was quoted in the Wall Street Journal on Dec. 9 expressing concern about the tilt of some of the earlier picks. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. &#8220;Traditional Republican telecom policy has favored incumbents who are heavily engaged in regulatory capture over innovators like us,&#8221; Morken was quoted saying in article about Trump&#8217;s expected FCC policies to demolish regulations that protect smaller players. Morken told the paper he was a lifelong Republican, but in &#8220;every election I have to choose between voting personal conviction or business interests.&#8221; Fortune contacted Morken for comment and will update this story if we receive a response. Trump&#8217;s first three picks had ties to the largest companies in the telecom sector and had written publicly against the FCC&#8217;s rules on net neutrality. For more on the net neutrality battle, watch: Jeff Eisenach, an economist who has been on Verizon\u2019s vz payroll, and Mark Jamison, who formerly worked on Sprint\u2019s s lobbying team and now heads the University of Florida\u2019s Public Utility Research Center, opposed the net neutrality rules and other policies of the FCC under Obama appointee Tom Wheeler. A third appointee, Roslyn Layton is a telecom industry consultant and visiting fellow at the American Enterprise Institute who has opposed both net neutrality and Internet privacy rules. The two current Republican members of the FCC, Ajit Pai and Michael O&#8217;Rielly, have said rolling back the net neutrality rules will be a top priority next year. They will constitute a majority at the agency once Wheeler steps down, as he has pledged to do next month.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe incoming administration of President-elect Donald Trump named another person to its transition team overseeing the Federal Communications Commission. And unlike past picks, this one has no record of criticizing net neutrality, the 2015 rules that prevent Internet service providers from slowing or blocking online content and services.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDavid Morken, co-founder of Republic Wireless and an entrepreneur from Raleigh, N.C., will join three prior Trump FCC transition team members in helping set policies at the agency that regulates telecommunications, cable TV, and the Internet, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.politicopro.com\u002Ftech\u002Fwhiteboard\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Ftrump-transition-taps-more-ftc-fcc-aides-081467\"\u003EPolitico reported\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on Thursday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut unlike previous Trump FCC transition picks, Morken has no obvious and widespread record of speaking out against the agency&#8217;s moves in 2015 to protect competition on the Internet through net neutrality rules. Companies like \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fatt-10\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAT&amp;T\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"t\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fatt-10\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Et\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fverizon-13\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EVerizon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have complained that the rules over-regulate the industry and deter investment in networks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERather, Morken was quoted in the \u003Cem\u003EWall Street Journal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E on Dec. 9 expressing concern about the tilt of some of the earlier picks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Traditional Republican telecom policy has favored incumbents who are heavily engaged in regulatory capture over innovators like us,&#8221; Morken \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.wsj.com\u002Farticles\u002Ftelecom-industry-sees-relief-in-trump-policy-agenda-1481284804\"\u003Ewas quoted saying\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in article about Trump&#8217;s expected FCC policies to demolish regulations that protect smaller players. Trump FCC Pick Is First Without Record Opposing Net Neutrality","mt_seo_description":"President-elect Trump appointed a North Carolina entrepreneur who has not opposed net neutrality rules to help oversee the FCC transition.","mt_seo_keywords":"David Morken, FCC, telecommunications, net neutrality, regulation, Donald Trump, AT&amp;T, Verizon, Sprint, T-Mobile","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"David Morken, FCC, telecommunications, net neutrality, regulation, Donald Trump, AT&amp;T, Verizon, Sprint, T-Mobile, comcast","short_title":"Latest Trump FCC Pick Has Not Battled Net Neutrality Rules","og_title":"Finally Trump Picks An FCC Transition Member Who Doesn't Hate Net Neutrality","og_description":"North Carolina entrepreneur had expressed worry over earlier moves","twitter_text":"Trump names entrepreneur who has not battled net neutrality rules to help oversee FCC transition","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Ftrump-fcc-morken-net-neutrality\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Ftrump-fcc-morken-net-neutrality\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":995500,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F458761428.jpg","alt":"Internet
