President Barack Obama called for the \"strongest possible rules\" to protect the open Internet, advocating stricter controls than a regulator he appointed and causing shares of Comcast Corp. and other broadband providers to drop. Obama's comments tilt the White House against positions advocated by broadband providers and FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. Photographer: Andrew Harrer\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","title":"Internet Providers Should Guarantee Equal Access to All Users, Obama Says"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":52999,"name":"Verizon","slug":"verizon","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":59466,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":379,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1886366,"date":"2016-12-29T12:00:12","date_gmt":"2016-12-29T17:00:12","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1886366"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-29T12:46:48","modified_gmt":"2016-12-29T17:46:48","slug":"amazon-web-services-2017-outlook","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Famazon-web-services-2017-outlook\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hN1Hly","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Expect Amazon\u2019s Cloud to See Hotter Competition in 2017"},"content":{"plain":"Over the last decade, Amazon Web Services has become the focal point of every tech company, most of which are now fighting to build their own public clouds. That includes computing pioneer IBM ibm , database giant Oracle orcl and software behemoth Microsoft. Not even Amazon&#8217;s biggest rivals can question the success of AWS of late. For it&#8217;s most recently reported quarter, the cloud computing arm of Amazon reported revenue of $3.2 billion, up 55% year over year, putting it at a close-to $13 billion annual revenue run rate going into 2017. Perhaps more importantly for those who insisted that AWS was a loss-leader for its parent company, the cloud unit reported profit of $1.02 billion for that period, at least if employee stock compensation is excluded. With that compensation factored in, profit was a still-healthy $821 million, up from $428 million from the year before. But 2017 will not be a walk in the park for Amazon amzn largely because at least some of those tech rivals mentioned above have gotten their acts together, building data centers worldwide, and investing heavily in their public cloud services. Microsoft msft , in particular, has been making progress, says Dave Bartoletti, principal analyst for Forrester Research forr . Microsoft Azure is now a strong number two in public cloud while Google goog , IBM ibm , and others battle it out for the number three slot, in his view. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. In the face of that heightened competition, Amazon must continue to appeal to its core base of developers at small companies, who started flocking to its services ten years ago, using credit cards to rent servers and storage, typically circumventing IT control. And it must now also woo those same IT people, as it seeks more big corporate business. That&#8217;s a fine line. In fact, it&#8217;s almost schizophrenic. Every year at the annual AWS Re:Invent conference, one day is dedicated to products geared for IT professionals who typically work to provision servers and storage, and maintain databases. Another day is all about cutting-edge and the latest trending tech, like tools for the Internet of things. Amazon has been very strategic\u2014and ambitious\u2014with new products for that IT demographic. Two of the hardest-to-dislodge technologies in big companies are Oracle databases and VMware virtualization software. It is very difficult to move customers off these deeply entrenched products, no matter how much the companies might like to do so. &#8220;Every year one goal for most companies is to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware, and every year IT comes back and say &#8216;we didn\u2019t do it.&#8217; That&#8217;s because to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware requires risk and money,&#8221; Bartoletti says. For the past few years, AWS has targeted Oracle with such products as a MySQL database clone and a database migration tool to automate the tricky process of moving on-premises Oracle (or Microsoft) databases to AWS. This year, it announced its own managed version of PostgreSQL. PostgreSQL, is seen as a more enterprise-ready, open-source database than MySQL, which Oracle owns. For more on AWS, watch And for all those petabytes of corporate data accumulating in company data centers over the decades? This year, AWS came out with an actual truck, dubbed Snowmobile, which it says can securely ship up to 100 petabytes of data from corporate server rooms to an AWS facility in one fell swoop. It seems like brute force\u2014and it is\u2014but face it, using even a high-speed network connection moving that amount of data would take forever. Amazon says Snowmobile will enable companies to move an exabyte (or 1,000 petabytes) of data to Amazon in six months or so. That same data transfer would take 20 years over a fast, 10Gbps dedicated connection, the company said. On the VMware vmw side, AWS and VMware are working together on VMware Cloud on AWS, due out in mid-2017. In theory, it will let VMware customers run their existing VMware operations directly on AWS servers. This was pitched as a win for joint customers and both AWS and VMware. But most cloud watchers suspect that many of those VMware users will end up moving their VMware workloads to AWS and then, over time, off of VMware altogether. Time will tell. But for those who think AWS has already won the public cloud wars, remember, it&#8217;s hard to maintain technology dominance over many generations. And also remember, that big Fortune 500 companies have barely put their toes in the water yet. Most estimates hold that 5% or 6% of big company workloads are in the public cloud at this point. That&#8217;s the tippy-top of an enormous ice berg. That leaves the other cloud providers\u2014at least those with big checkbooks\u2014with room to maneuver.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EOver the last decade, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Web Services has become the focal point of every tech company, most of which are now fighting to build their own public clouds. That includes computing pioneer \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIBM\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"ibm\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eibm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, database giant \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Foracle-77\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EOracle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"orcl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Foracle-77\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eorcl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and software behemoth \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fmicrosoft-25\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMicrosoft\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENot even Amazon&#8217;s biggest rivals can question the success of AWS of late. For it&#8217;s most recently reported quarter, the cloud computing arm of Amazon reported \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F27\u002Famazons-cloud-blow-out-quarter\u002F\"\u003Erevenue of $3.2 billion\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, up 55% year over year, putting it at a close-to $13 billion annual revenue run rate going into 2017.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerhaps more importantly for those who insisted that AWS was a loss-leader for its parent company, the cloud unit reported profit of $1.02 billion for that period, at least if employee stock compensation is excluded. With that compensation factored in, profit was a still-healthy $821 million, up from $428 million from the year before.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut 2017 will not be a walk in the park for Amazon \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"amzn\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazon-com-18\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan have gotten their acts together, building data centers worldwide, and investing heavily in their public cloud services.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMicrosoft \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"msft\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, in particular, has been making progress, says Dave Bartoletti, principal analyst for Forrester Research \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"forr\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fforr\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E. Microsoft Azure is now a strong number two in public cloud while \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoogle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"goog\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fgoog\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Egoog\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, IBM \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"ibm\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eibm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, and others battle it out for the number three slot, in his view.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003C\u002Fem\u003EFortune\u003Cem\u003E\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the face of that heightened competition, Amazon must continue to appeal to its core base of developers at small companies, who started flocking to its services ten years ago, using credit cards to rent servers and storage, typically circumventing IT control. And it must now also woo those same IT people, as it seeks more big corporate business. That&#8217;s a fine line.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn fact, it&#8217;s almost schizophrenic. Every year at the annual \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ftag\u002Faws-reinvent\u002F\"\u003EAWS Re:Invent \u003C\u002Fa\u003Econference, one day is dedicated to products geared for IT professionals who typically work to provision servers and storage, and maintain databases. Another day is all about cutting-edge and the latest trending tech, like tools for the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F05\u002Famazon-iot-cloud\u002F\"\u003EInternet of things\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmazon has been very strategic\u2014and ambitious\u2014with new products for that IT demographic. Two of the hardest-to-dislodge technologies in big companies are Oracle databases and VMware virtualization software. It is very difficult to move customers off these deeply entrenched products, no matter how much the companies might like to do so.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Every year one goal for most companies is to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware, and every year IT comes back and say &#8216;we didn\u2019t do it.&#8217; That&#8217;s because to reduce spending on Oracle and VMware requires risk and money,&#8221; Bartoletti says.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor the past few years, AWS has targeted Oracle with such products as a MySQL database clone and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F10\u002F08\u002Faws-lock-in-worry\u002F\"\u003Ea database migration tool\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to automate the tricky process of moving on-premises Oracle (or Microsoft) databases to AWS. This year, it announced its own managed version of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F22\u002Famazon-cloud-conference\u002F\"\u003EPostgreSQL\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. PostgreSQL, is seen as a more enterprise-ready, open-source database than MySQL, which Oracle owns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFor more on AWS, in company data centers over the decades? This year, AWS came out with an actual \u003Cem\u003Etruck\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, dubbed \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Faws.amazon.com\u002Fsnowmobile\u002F\"\u003ESnowmobile\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which it says can securely ship up to 100 petabytes of data from corporate server rooms to an AWS facility in one fell swoop. It seems like brute force\u2014and it is\u2014but face it, using even a high-speed network connection moving that amount of data would take forever. Amazon says Snowmobile will enable companies to move an exabyte (or 1,000 petabytes) of data to Amazon in six months or so. That same data transfer would take 20 years over a fast, 10Gbps dedicated connection, the company said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn the VMware \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"vmw\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fvmw\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Evmw\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E side, AWS and VMware are working together on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F14\u002Faws-and-vmware-winners-losers\u002F\"\u003EVMware Cloud on AWS\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, due out in mid-2017. In theory, it will let VMware customers run their existing VMware operations directly on AWS servers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis was pitched as a win for joint customers and both AWS and VMware. But most cloud watchers suspect that many of those VMware users will end up moving their VMware workloads to AWS and then, over time, off of VMware altogether. Time will tell.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut for those who think AWS has already won the public cloud wars, remember, it&#8217;s hard to maintain technology dominance over many generations. And also remember, that big \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 500 companies have barely put their toes in the water yet. Most estimates hold that 5% or 6% of big company workloads are in the public cloud at this point. AWS","short_title":"Amazon Web Services to Tread Fine Line in 2017","og_title":"Expect Amazon's Cloud Unit to See Better Competition in 2017","twitter_text":"Amazon's large lead in cloud will be tested in 2017","og_description":"Watch out for Microsoft!","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Famazon-web-services-2017-outlook\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Famazon-web-services-2017-outlook\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1870153,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002Faws-reinvent-2016-1.jpg","alt":"","caption":"AWS 2016","title":"aws-reinvent-2016-1"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":42751983,"name":"PointCloud","slug":"pointcloud","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":143855,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":578,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1884483,"date":"2016-12-29T10:30:18","date_gmt":"2016-12-29T15:30:18","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1884483"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-29T16:36:02","modified_gmt":"2016-12-29T21:36:02","slug":"heavy-combat-cable-wireless","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Fheavy-combat-cable-wireless\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hzeW94","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Expect Heavy Combat Between Cable and Wireless in 2017"},"content":{"plain":"For over a decade, AT&amp;T has been ramping up its television programming offerings. Last year&#8217;s $49 billion acquisition of satellite TV provider DirecTV, combined with the company&#8217;s U-verse cable offering, gave AT&amp;T the largest pay TV subscriber base in the industry \u2014though growing that audience much bigger has proven challenging. But in 2017, big cable is poised to strike back. Comcast and Charter Communications, the two largest cable TV companies, are promising to get into the mobile phone business, and things could interesting in a hurry. The cable companies say they will pitch a bundled service that includes TV, Internet, and mobile features. Bundling\u2014at the right price\u2014can lower the risk of customers defecting to one of the growing number of Internet-based video services. And instead of spending billions on airwave licenses, the cable companies have cut a deal with Verizon to lease wireless data and calling capacity. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. Starting in mid-2017, Comcast is planning to offer &#8220;an attractively-priced multi-product bundle&#8221; CEO Brian Roberts told analysts in October. Charter CEO Tom Rutledge seemed to be speaking from the same cue cards when he told analysts last month his company will be &#8220;offering an attractively priced product bundle&#8221; with an eye towards reducing customer churn. The economic key to the cable wireless services, however, will be the companies&#8217; vast networks of wifi routers deployed across their service territories. Using Verizon&#8217;s wireless capacity could get expensive, but piggybacking mobile customers on wifi signals is virtually cost-free. A few tiny carriers have sprung up trying to use such a hybrid approach to reduce costs, but Comcast cmcsa and Charter chtr will be operating on a vastly greater scale. Comcast, for its part, says it has 15 million hotspots deployed. The question remains just how many cable customers want to handcuff their wireless service to their broadband and television provider. Cable companies have long suffered from poor customer satisfaction ratings and convincing subscribers to sign up for a new hybrid form of mobile service could be difficult. For more on Comcast&#8217;s wireless plans, watch: In the past, the benefits of bundling haven&#8217;t been all that attractive, Jan Dawson, chief analyst at Jackdaw Research says. &#8220;It\u2019s never really seemed to capture customers\u2019 attention, in part because it means two of your biggest monthly bills get combined and there\u2019s little benefit beyond maybe a $5 discount or something,&#8221; Dawson says. In theory, new, strong competition for AT&amp;T, Verizon vz , Sprint s , and T-Mobile tmus should bring down prices and improve features for consumers. But the cable companies may be more interested in preserving their existing businesses than in disrupting wireless, Dawson adds. &#8220;We\u2019ll see to what extent this is really about saving consumers money or providing other really meaningful benefits versus simple bundling,&#8221; he says. Previous cable efforts to get into wireless didn&#8217;t get very far. Comcast and other cable companies were early backers of upstart wireless firm Clearwire but dumped an agreement to resell service back in 2011 after almost no customers signed up. Clearwire ended up being acquired by Sprint shortly thereafter. Even before that, cable companies spent billions buying airwave rights in 2006 but most never offered any service and Verizon bought the licenses in 2011. Part of that deal included the leasing rights that Comcast and Charter will use next year when they enter the market. Even if they don&#8217;t win many customers, the cable incursion could wound the wireless industry in one important way, however. This year, the four big telecom carriers were among the best performing stocks in the market, led by Sprint&#8217;s 144% gain, as of December 29. T-Mobile was up 49%, AT&amp;T t rose 24% and Verizon added 16%. But just as the perception of cord cutting hurt some media stocks this summer out of proportion to its actual impact on financial results, the much hyped entry of cable into wireless could spook telecom investors. &#8220;We don\u2019t expect cable to have any significant impact on the wireless market until around 2020,&#8221; industry analyst Craig Moffett at MoffettNathanson Research wrote recently. &#8220;When they do enter the wireless space, however, it won\u2019t be good news for the incumbents.&#8221; How Taylor Swift Could Help AT&amp;T Win Over Cord Cutters Meanwhile, AT&amp;T is getting even more into TV and could dent the cable industry&#8217;s revenue with its new Internet-based video service called DirecTV Now. Offering more than 100 cable channels at a starting price of $35, the service is being pitched to the 20 million or so households that don&#8217;t currently pay for TV, so-called cord cutters and cord nevers. But it&#8217;s pretty easy to see how the low price could also prove alluring to regular cable customers tired of paying an average of over $100 per month for TV service. Still, cable has a solid strategy to fight back, according to analyst Moffett. Cable companies are the leading provider of broadband Internet service, which customers will still need, even after they decide to drop cable TV service for DirecTV Now or other, similar services. And by manipulative pricing of different bundles, cable companies have &#8220;a very powerful pricing counter-balance,&#8221; Moffett says. So expect a lot more headlines about cable versus wireless competition next year. But the actual impact on consumers&#8217; pocketbooks may be harder to discern.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor over a decade, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fatt-10\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAT&amp;T\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has been ramping up its television programming offerings. This year, the four big telecom carriers were among the best performing stocks in the market, led by Sprint&#8217;s 144% gain, as of December 29. T-Mobile was up 49%, AT&amp;T \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"t\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fatt-10\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Et\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E rose 24% and Verizon added 16%. But just as the perception of cord cutting hurt some media stocks this summer out of proportion to its actual impact on financial results, the much hyped entry of cable into wireless could spook telecom investors.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We don\u2019t expect cable to have any significant impact on the wireless market until around 2020,&#8221; industry analyst Craig Moffett at MoffettNathanson Research wrote recently. &#8220;When they do enter the wireless space, however, it won\u2019t be good news for the incumbents.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp align=\"center\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F13\u002Ftaylor-swift-att-cord-cutters\"\u003EHow Taylor Swift Could Help AT&amp;T Win Over Cord Cutters\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMeanwhile, AT&amp;T is getting even more into TV and could dent the cable industry&#8217;s revenue with its new Internet-based video service called DirecTV Now. Offering more than 100 cable channels at a starting price of $35, the service is \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F21\u002Fatts-internet-tv-cord-cutters\u002F\"\u003Ebeing pitched to the 20 million or so households\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that don&#8217;t currently pay for TV, so-called cord cutters and cord nevers. But it&#8217;s pretty easy to see how the low price could also prove alluring to regular cable customers tired of paying an average of over $100 per month for TV service.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, cable has a solid strategy to fight back, according to analyst Moffett. Cable companies are the leading provider of broadband Internet service, which customers will still need, even after they decide to drop cable TV service for DirecTV Now or other, similar services. And by manipulative pricing of different bundles, cable companies have &#8220;a very powerful pricing counter-balance,&#8221; Moffett says.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo expect a lot more headlines about cable versus wireless competition next year. But the actual impact on consumers&#8217; pocketbooks may be harder to discern.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For over a decade, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fatt-10\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["AT&amp;T"]}," has been ramping up its television programming offerings. Charter CEO Tom Rutledge seemed to be speaking from the same cue cards when he told analysts last month his company will be \"offering an attractively priced product bundle\" with an eye towards reducing customer churn."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The economic key to the cable wireless services, however, will be the companies' vast networks of wifi routers deployed across their service territories. A few tiny carriers have sprung up trying to use such ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fischool.syr.edu\u002Finfospace\u002F2013\u002F09\u002F06\u002Fthree-alternative-cell-service-providers-to-watch\u002F"},"content":["a hybrid approach to reduce costs"]},", but Comcast ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"cmcsa"},"content":[]}," and Charter ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"chtr"},"content":[]}," will be operating on a vastly greater scale. Comcast, for its part, says it has 15 million hotspots deployed."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The question remains just how many cable customers want to handcuff their wireless service to their broadband and television provider. Clearwire ended up being acquired by Sprint shortly thereafter. Part of that deal included the leasing rights that Comcast and Charter will use next year when they enter the market."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Even if they don't win many customers, the cable incursion could wound the wireless industry in one important way, however. Now operating as part of the company Access in Alphabet&#8217;s &#8220;other bets&#8221; division, the fiber service has recently seen its CEO depart without being replaced, halted expansion in new cities, and laid off almost 10% of its staff. On Thursday, that convergence of factors prompted speculation by the tech news web site The Information that Google is likely getting ready to dispose of the service, which was a pioneer in bringing gigabit Internet download speeds to consumers. Telecom operator CenturyLink\u2014which is in the process of buying Level 3 Communications lvlt for $34 billion\u2014is a &#8220;possible acquirer,&#8221; the web site said without citing a source. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. Fortune reached out to Google googl for comment and will update this story if any response is received. CenturyLink ctl declined to comment. Just two months ago, Alphabet CFO Ruth Porat had defended the project publicly, telling analysts on a quarterly earnings call that the fiber service was &#8220;making great progress&#8221; and remained &#8220;committed to growth&#8221; in its already active markets. The likelihood of the speculated sale would depend heavily on the fiber business&#8217;s financials as there is no obvious reason the unit would be appealing to any buyer. Stringing fiber optic high speed Internet connections to homes around the country is exceedingly expensive\u2014as Google has discovered\u2014and requires competing with deeply entrenched monopoly cable and telephone operators. The service has not reached critical mass in any of the eight scattered markets from Austin to Nashville to Salt Lake City that it has entered in the past six years. CEO Craig Barratt left in October and has not been replaced. At that time, the unit also reportedly laid off about 130 out of 1,500 workers. A few months prior, the service had announced it was revamping its business model to use more wireless technology as it paused all planned expansions into brand new cities. Google is hardly the first company to run into cost issues while trying to provide consumer Internet and cable TV service, even before the era of high-speed fiber optic connections. Dozens of upstart carriers went bankrupt in the 1990s and early 2000s trying to break into the telecommunications and cable markets.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ERecent cutbacks and turbulence at Alphabet&#8217;s Google Fiber service are generating speculation about a possible sale or spin off of the business.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow operating as part of the company Access in Alphabet&#8217;s &#8220;other bets&#8221; division, the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffiber.google.com\u002Fabout\u002F\"\u003Efiber service\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has recently seen its CEO depart without being replaced, halted expansion in new cities, and laid off almost 10% of its staff.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn Thursday, that convergence of factors prompted speculation by the tech news web site \u003Cem\u003EThe Information\u003C\u002Fem\u003E that Google is likely \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.theinformation.com\u002Fwhy-google-might-sell-its-fiber-business\u002F\"\u003Egetting ready to dispose of the service\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which was a pioneer in bringing gigabit Internet download speeds to consumers. CenturyLink \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"ctl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fcenturylink-159\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ectl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E declined to comment.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EJust two months ago, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAlphabet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E CFO Ruth Porat had \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F28\u002Fgoogle-fiber-lives-on\u002F\"\u003Edefended the project publicly\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, telling analysts on a quarterly earnings call that the fiber service was &#8220;making great progress&#8221; and remained &#8220;committed to growth&#8221; in its already active markets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe likelihood of the speculated sale would depend heavily on the fiber business&#8217;s financials as there is no obvious reason the unit would be appealing to any buyer. Stringing fiber optic high speed Internet connections to homes around the country is exceedingly expensive\u2014as Google has discovered\u2014and requires competing with deeply entrenched monopoly cable and telephone operators. The service has not reached critical mass in any of the eight scattered markets from Austin to Nashville to Salt Lake City that it has entered in the past six years.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECEO Craig Barratt \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ffiber.googleblog.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002Fadvancing-our-amazing-bet.html\"\u003Eleft in October\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and has not been replaced. At that time, the unit also \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F26\u002Fgoogle-fiber-layoffs\u002F\"\u003Ereportedly laid off about 130\u003C\u002Fa\u003E out of 1,500 workers. A few months prior, the service had announced it was revamping its business model to use \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F11\u002Fgoogle-ultra-fast-internet\u002F\"\u003Emore wireless technology\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as it \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F15\u002Fgoogle-fiber-strategy\u002F\"\u003Epaused all planned expansions\u003C\u002Fa\u003E into brand new cities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGoogle is hardly the first company to run into cost issues while trying to provide consumer Internet and cable TV service, even before the era of high-speed fiber optic connections. Dozens of upstart carriers went bankrupt in the 1990s and early 2000s trying to break into the telecommunications and cable markets.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Recent cutbacks and turbulence at Alphabet's Google Fiber service are generating speculation about a possible sale or spin off of the business."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now operating as part of the company Access in Alphabet's \"other bets\" division, the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ffiber.google.com\u002Fabout\u002F"},"content":["fiber service"]}," has recently seen its CEO depart without being replaced, halted expansion in new cities, and laid off almost 10% of its staff."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["On Thursday, that convergence of factors prompted speculation by the tech news web site ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["The Information"]}," that Google is likely ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.theinformation.com\u002Fwhy-google-might-sell-its-fiber-business\u002F"},"content":["getting ready to dispose of the service"]},", which was a pioneer in bringing gigabit Internet download speeds to consumers. But famed short sellers at Citron Research say Nvidia&#8217;s stock is poised to fall about 20% after its big rally. Citron, which generally picks stocks its thinks will decline in value, says there are half a dozen problems ahead for Nvidia, mainly related to top competitors Intel and Advanced Micro Devices. While Nvidia has been touting its progress in cracking new markets like computer chips tuned for artificial intelligence, most of its success in 2016 came from gains in its traditional PC and gaming graphics chips, the firm said in a report on Wednesday. That could leave it more vulnerable to traditional competition than many investors expect, the firm wrote. Nvidia shares fell 5% in mid-day trading on Wednesday after the report was released. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. Citron, run by Andrew Left, is among the most prominent short sellers, or investors who bet stocks will decline in value. Last year, Left called Valeant Pharmaceuticals vrx as overvalued\u2014dubbing it the &#8220;pharmaceutical Enron&#8221;\u2014before its stock crashed. Nvidia&#8217;s 2016 stock rise came as its revenue and profit have skyrocketed. Last quarter, revenue rose 54% from the same period a year earlier to a record $2 billion while net income increased 120% to $542 million. But Citron said not much of the gain was from new markets, but rather from seizing larger market share in the gaming market from AMD. Such gains can&#8217;t continue at the same pace in the future, limiting potential growth. Nvidia nvda has also targeted selling more chips for large data center servers, but massive competition is coming in 2017 from new high performance chips from Intel intc and AMD amd , Citron noted. And some of the largest data center owners, like Google googl , are shifting to their own custom chips. Apple aapl could possibly do the same for graphics chips it buys from Nvidia, Citron said, though recent Mac models use AMD chips. For more on Intel&#8217;s plans, watch: Another problem could hit Nvidia&#8217;s profit margin as it competes more directly with Intel. Nvidia doesn&#8217;t own chip fabricating factories, as Intel does, and instead relies on outsourcing to manufacturers like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing tsmc . That gives Intel greater pricing flexibility, which could put pressure on Nvidia, Citron wrote. Intel could reduce the price of its chips by 37% and still have an 80% margin. Also, a deal to license intellectual property to Intel is coming to end, which will cut off a highly lucrative royalty stream, Citron says. As fans of Amazon amzn and Netflix nflx found out in 2016, one year&#8217;s top performing stock is rarely a great bet for the subsequent year. For investors who made a killing in Nvidia this year, it may be wise to move on.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EShares of chipmaker Nvidia have gained 237% this year, making the company one of the best performing stocks of 2016. name=\"adServerURL\" value=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpubads.g.doubleclick.net\u002Fgampad\u002Fads?env=vp&#038;gdfp_req=1&#038;impl=s&#038;output=xml_vast2&#038;iu=\u002F8484\u002Ffort\u002Fvideo_bc\u002Ftech_bc&#038;sz=1000x1&#038;cust_params=tags%3Dadm%2Cadvancedmicrodevices%2Cgamingtechnology%2Clisasu%2Cvideogames%2Cvirtualreality%26ch%3Dtech%26topic%3Dadvancedmicrodevices&#038;unviewed_position_start=1&#038;correlator=%5Btimestamp%5D\"\u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fobject\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003Cscript type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\tbrightcove.createExperiences();\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E","caption":"The CEO explains how she turned around the company.\r\n","description":"Black Friday and Cyber Monday were great days for Sony and Microsoft: Playstation and Xbox consoles flew off shelves. But it was also a big win for Advanced Micro Devices, the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based semiconductor company that designs the chips the consoles need to make cool graphics and special effects possible.\r\n\r\nThe holiday sales pop is a remarkable accomplishment for CEO Lisa Su, who was tapped two years ago to helm the money-losing AMD. There were doubts Su could do much for a company many speculated was about to go out of business. But she turned out to be the game changer AMD needed: The company recently reported a 23% jump in quarterly revenues, it posted a small profit, and the stock has more than quadrupled since Su took charge.\r\n\r\nSu tells \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u2019s\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Susie Gharib that the key to the turnaround was \u201cfocus.\u201d\r\n\r\n\u201cThere are so many good things to do,\u201d she explains. \u201cWe needed to choose the things that we are really good at.\u201d Her decision to specialize in the fast-growing game technology business, and to back away from the slow-growing PC business, really paid off.\r\n\r\nNow Su is focusing on virtual reality. She\u2019s predicting it will be the \u201cbiggest thing\u201d over the next five years and she wants AMD to build on its leadership position.\r\n\r\n\u201cWe love virtual reality,\u201d she says. \u201cToday there may be a couple million people using virtual reality. We\u2019d like to see that be 100 million over the next five years.\u201d","title":"Lisa Su Was the Game Changer AMD Needed"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5257417085001","controls":"1"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":35186,"name":"Nvidia","slug":"nvidia","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":122648,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":54,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1885076,"date":"2016-12-28T12:00:53","date_gmt":"2016-12-28T17:00:53","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1885076"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-28T13:06:34","modified_gmt":"2016-12-28T18:06:34","slug":"microsoft-2017","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F28\u002Fmicrosoft-2017\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hOWlpZ","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why 2017 Might Be a Difficult Year for Microsoft"},"content":{"plain":"Microsoft has become Wall Street&#8217;s darling again after a few rough years in the late Steve Ballmer era. But the company still has a lot riding on executing well next year. First and foremost, Microsoft, under Satya Nadella\u2014who stepped in as chief executive, replacing Ballmer about three years ago\u2014must prove it can do big acquisitions well. Microsoft&#8217;s record there is checkered following misfires with Nokia and aQuantive\u2014both purchases resulting in huge write-offs. That means all eyes will be on how the software giant does with its just completed $26 billion purchase of LinkedIn. There&#8217;s no shortage of opinions about where LinkedIn is weak. With a clunky interface, it incessantly nudges users to share information and interact with people they may or may not want to engage. Does anyone actually appreciate reminders to send holiday greetings to long-forgotten associates? But LinkedIn has strengths as well\u2014chief among them the sheer amount of information it holds. That&#8217;s a big data treasure trove Microsoft msft hopes to parlay to boost the prospects of its business-focused customer relationship management software (CRM), used by sales people to enter and track sales leads. LinkedIn, despite the interface and spammy tendencies, has data on some 467 million users worldwide. Microsoft hopes to parlay that data to grow its own business software portfolio. If you&#8217;re a sales person using Microsoft Dynamics CRM for sales management, it would be useful to automatically search for people with certain titles at top companies and automatically import them into your prospect list. That is why CRM leader Salesforce.com crm also wanted to acquire LinkedIn\u2014only to be outbid. Benioff, founder and chief executive of Salesforce.com even dusted off the &#8220;M&#8221; word in referring to Microsoft&#8217;s &#8220;monopolistic&#8221; tendencies. Most hadn&#8217;t thought of Microsoft in those terms since the early part of the century, when it was deemed a monopoly by a federal court judge, only to have that ruling over turned on a technicality. Since then, the advent of a resurging Apple aapl , along with Google googl , Amazon amzn Web Services (AWS), and Salesforce itself ended any illusion of Microsoft as overly huge and powerful. Benioff blasted the proposed Microsoft deal as anti-competitive, charging that Microsoft could keep software rivals from using that LinkedIn data. The purchase nonetheless passed muster with regulatory agencies although European regulators mandated that Microsoft must give outside social networks the same access to the Microsoft Graph and Microsoft Office plug-ins and programming interfaces that LinkedIn gets. Microsoft will need to add value to LinkedIn in part by improving the aforementioned interface\u2014which it has said is in the works\u2014but also monetize that LinkedIn data without alienating users with more spam. For more on Microsoft and LinkedIn, watch: Azure cloud is the other key area Microsoft must push hard in 2017 and no one doubts that it will do so. Forrester Research forr principal analyst Dave Bartoletti says the software giant has thus far executed very well in cloud with a huge investment, he noted. Very few other tech companies can &#8220;find&#8221; $5 or $6 billion to pour into cloud data centers, he added. Microsoft&#8217;s effort to make Azure, a massive stockpile of connected servers and storage running in data centers worldwide, a home to open-source software including the Linux operating system, formerly anathema to the Windows company, has also helped make the company&#8217;s cloud more attractive to developers outside the hard-core Windows world. Having said that, the company needs to demonstrate more Azure usage going forward. Azure is seen as the second largest public cloud, but a distant second to AWS. Microsoft claims huge cloud growth but the numbers it releases lump Azure in with other non-cloud software including Windows Server that run on premises. the world will likely not get a real look at how much money Azure generates until Microsoft breaks out that figure, and that probably won&#8217;t happen till the Azure numbers compare well with AWS revenue, which, for the most recent quarter, was $3.2 billion. Microsoft has a compelling story here if customers can run the same set of Microsoft software in their own server rooms that runs in Azure. That would mean that risk-averse companies like banks or pharmaceutical companies could keep some data and = software running on their own hardware, while tapping into Microsoft Azure data centers as needed for less sensitive work. That mix of private and public computing facilities is what is referred to in the tech industry as the hybrid cloud model. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s daily technology newsletter. However, Microsoft can&#8217;t really deliver on that promise until the middle of 2017. That&#8217;s when the company says it will make Azure Stack available, after a delay. Azure Stack is a sort of &#8220;mini-me&#8221; version of the software Microsoft uses to run its huge public cloud data centers around the world, but will instead operate in a customer&#8217;s own smaller facilities. In theory, that means the customer&#8217;s private data centers can work in tandem with the Microsoft-run Azure cloud allowing a segregation of workloads between internal and outside data centers. This is a very big promise. If Microsoft cannot make good on it, one of its biggest arguments that it offers a better cloud solution for risk-averse customers than AWS will ring hollow.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fmicrosoft-25\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMicrosoft\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has become Wall Street&#8217;s darling again after\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.vanityfair.com\u002Fnews\u002Fbusiness\u002F2012\u002F08\u002Fmicrosoft-lost-mojo-steve-ballmer\"\u003E a few rough years\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in the late Steve Ballmer era. But the company still has a lot riding on executing well next year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFirst and foremost, Microsoft, under Satya Nadella\u2014who \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgigaom.com\u002F2014\u002F02\u002F04\u002Fnadellas-the-one-microsoft-names-new-ceo-gates-stays-on-board-thompson-is-chairman\u002F\"\u003Estepped in as chief executive\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, replacing Ballmer about three years ago\u2014must prove it can do big acquisitions well. Microsoft&#8217;s record there is checkered following misfires with \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F07\u002F08\u002Fwas-microsoft-nokia-deal-a-disaster\u002F\"\u003ENokia\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fmoney.cnn.com\u002F2012\u002F07\u002F02\u002Ftechnology\u002Fmicrosoft-aquantive\u002F\"\u003EaQuantive\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u2014both purchases resulting in huge write-offs. That means all eyes will be on how the software giant does with its \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F08\u002Fsatya-nadella-microsoft-linkedin\u002F\"\u003Ejust completed\u003C\u002Fa\u003E $26 billion purchase \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F13\u002Fmicrosoft-buying-linkedin\u002F\"\u003Eof LinkedIn\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere&#8217;s no shortage of opinions about \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F23\u002Fmicrosoft-linkedin-wish-list\u002F\"\u003Ewhere LinkedIn is weak\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. With a clunky interface, it incessantly nudges users to share information and interact with people they may or may not want to engage. Does anyone actually appreciate reminders to send holiday greetings to long-forgotten associates?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut LinkedIn has strengths as well\u2014chief among them the sheer amount of information it holds. That&#8217;s a big data treasure trove Microsoft \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"msft\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fmicrosoft-25\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Emsft\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E hopes to parlay to boost the prospects of its business-focused \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F13\u002Fmicrosoft-linkedin-dynamics-software\u002F\"\u003Ecustomer relationship management software\u003C\u002Fa\u003E (CRM), used by sales people to enter and track sales leads.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELinkedIn, despite the interface and spammy tendencies, has data on some \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fpress.linkedin.com\u002Fabout-linkedin\"\u003E467 million users worldwide\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMicrosoft hopes to parlay that data to grow its own business software portfolio. If you&#8217;re a sales person using Microsoft Dynamics CRM for sales management, it would be useful to automatically search for people with certain titles at top companies and automatically import them into your prospect list. That is why CRM leader \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsalesforcecom-386\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ESalesforce\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.com \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"crm\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsalesforce-com-386\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ecrm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E also wanted to acquire LinkedIn\u2014only to be outbid. Benioff, founder and chief executive of Salesforce.com even dusted off the &#8220;M&#8221; word in referring to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F14\u002Fmarc-benioff-microsoft-oracle\u002F\"\u003EMicrosoft&#8217;s &#8220;monopolistic&#8221; tendencies.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMost hadn&#8217;t thought of Microsoft in those terms since the early part of the century, when it was \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2000\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fbusiness\u002Fus-vs-microsoft-overview-us-judge-says-microsoft-violated-antitrust-laws-with.html\"\u003Edeemed a monopoly by a federal court judge, \u003C\u002Fa\u003Eonly to have that ruling over turned on a technicality. Since then, the advent of a resurging \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EApple\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan in 2017 and no one doubts that it will do so.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EForrester Research \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"forr\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fforr\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eforr\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E principal analyst Dave Bartoletti says the software giant has thus far executed very well in cloud with a huge investment, he noted. Very few other tech companies can &#8220;find&#8221; $5 or $6 billion to pour into cloud data centers, he added.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMicrosoft&#8217;s effort to make Azure, a massive stockpile of connected servers and storage running in data centers worldwide, a home to open-source software including the Linux operating system, formerly anathema to the Windows company, has also helped make the company&#8217;s cloud more attractive to developers outside the hard-core Windows world.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHaving said that, the company needs to demonstrate more Azure usage going forward. Azure is seen as \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F04\u002Famazon-microsoft-cloud-race\u002F\"\u003Ethe second largest public cloud\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, but a distant second to AWS.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMicrosoft claims huge cloud growth but the numbers it releases \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F07\u002F19\u002Fmicrosoft-azure-shines\u002F\"\u003Elump Azure in with other non-cloud software\u003C\u002Fa\u003E including Windows Server that run on premises. the world will likely not get a real look at how much money Azure generates until Microsoft breaks out that figure, and that probably won&#8217;t happen till the Azure numbers compare well with AWS revenue, which, for the most recent quarter, was \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F27\u002Famazons-cloud-blow-out-quarter\u002F\"\u003E$3.2 billion.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMicrosoft has a compelling story here if customers can run the same set of Microsoft software in their own server rooms that runs in Azure. That would mean that risk-averse companies like banks or pharmaceutical companies could keep some data and = software running on their own hardware, while tapping into Microsoft Azure data centers as needed for less sensitive work. That mix of private and public computing facilities is what is referred to in the tech industry as the hybrid cloud model.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Fortune\u2019s daily technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, Microsoft can&#8217;t really deliver on that promise until the middle of 2017. That&#8217;s when the company says it will make Azure Stack available, after a delay. Azure Stack is a sort of &#8220;mini-me&#8221; version of the software Microsoft uses to run its huge public cloud data centers around the world, but will instead operate in a customer&#8217;s own smaller facilities. In theory, that means the customer&#8217;s private data centers can work in tandem with the Microsoft-run Azure cloud allowing a segregation of workloads between internal and outside data centers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis is a very big promise. If Microsoft cannot make good on it, one of its biggest arguments that it offers a better cloud solution for risk-averse customers than AWS will ring hollow.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fmicrosoft-25\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Microsoft"]}," has become Wall Street's darling again after",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.vanityfair.com\u002Fnews\u002Fbusiness\u002F2012\u002F08\u002Fmicrosoft-lost-mojo-steve-ballmer"},"content":[" a few rough years"]}," in the late Steve Ballmer era. Azure is seen as ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F04\u002Famazon-microsoft-cloud-race\u002F"},"content":["the second largest public cloud"]},", but a distant second to AWS."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Microsoft claims huge cloud growth but the numbers it releases ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F07\u002F19\u002Fmicrosoft-azure-shines\u002F"},"content":["lump Azure in with other non-cloud software"]}," including Windows Server that run on premises. the world will likely not get a real look at how much money Azure generates until Microsoft breaks out that figure, and that probably won't happen till the Azure numbers compare well with AWS revenue, which, for the most recent quarter, was ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F27\u002Famazons-cloud-blow-out-quarter\u002F"},"content":["$3.2 billion."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Microsoft has a compelling story here if customers can run the same set of Microsoft software in their own server rooms that runs in Azure. That would mean that risk-averse companies like banks or pharmaceutical companies could keep some data and = software running on their own hardware, while tapping into Microsoft Azure data centers as needed for less sensitive work. That mix of private and public computing facilities is what is referred to in the tech industry as the hybrid cloud model."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", Fortune\u2019s daily technology newsletter."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["However, Microsoft can't really deliver on that promise until the middle of 2017. That's when the company says it will make Azure Stack available, after a delay. Azure Stack is a sort of \"mini-me\" version of the software Microsoft uses to run its huge public cloud data centers around the world, but will instead operate in a customer's own smaller facilities. In theory, that means the customer's private data centers can work in tandem with the Microsoft-run Azure cloud allowing a segregation of workloads between internal and outside data centers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This is a very big promise. If Microsoft cannot make good on it, one of its biggest arguments that it offers a better cloud solution for risk-averse customers than AWS will ring hollow."]}]},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ESome big tasks lie ahead for Satya Nadella&#8217;s Satya Nadella's Microsoft","og_title":"Why 2017 Might Be a Difficult Year for Microsoft","twitter_text":"For Microsoft, 2017 will be a pivotal year.","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F28\u002Fmicrosoft-2017\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F28\u002Fmicrosoft-2017\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1855838,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002Ffor-web161006-fortune-satyanadella-378-copy-copy.jpg","alt":"LONDON, (Picture by Veronique de Viguerie\u002F Reportage by Getty Images)","caption":"Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella in London, October 6th, 2016.","credit":"Photograph by Veronique de Viguerie","description":"LONDON, UK - OCT, 6th, 2016: Satya Nadella. (Picture by Veronique de Viguerie\u002F Reportage by Getty Images)","title":"NAD12_NEW CROP LEDE"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":42751983,"name":"PointCloud","slug":"pointcloud","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":143855,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":578,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1890512,"date":"2016-12-28T09:54:30","date_gmt":"2016-12-28T14:54:30","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1890512"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-28T13:08:35","modified_gmt":"2016-12-28T18:08:35","slug":"amazon-vmware-cloud","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F28\u002Famazon-vmware-cloud\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hnnmj5","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"How Amazon\u2019s Cloud Infrastructure for VMware Could Find More Uses"},"content":{"plain":"One surprising thing about what Amazon Web Services has done to run VMware&#8217;s popular virtualization software in its own cloud data centers is just how&#8230;un-cloud-like it seems. Amazon is assembling masses of &#8220;bare metal&#8221; computers, which unlike the rest of the AWS servers, come with no virtualization. That&#8217;s because VMware&#8217;s software is built using its own flavor of virtualization and that, in turn, meant AWS had to offer VMware a phalanx of servers stripped of the Xen virtualization, which runs the rest of Amazon&#8217;s computers, known collectively as Elastic Compute Cloud or EC2. As AWS head of product Matt Wood explained it to Fortune in November: We partnered with VMware to bring their existing software stack over to EC2. Customers told us they wanted the benefits of AWS and all the benefits of VMware, but didn&#8217;t want to run our hypervisor so we worked on a new part of EC2 that allows VMware to run natively on EC2. Think of VMware as offering a peanut butter and jelly sandwich using its customers&#8217; bread. Now the customer wants to use Amazon&#8217;s bread, except that the only bread Amazon offers comes with the peanut butter built in. Continuing this analogy, Amazon has agreed to strip the peanut butter from many loaves so VMware can craft sandwiches using its own special PB&amp;J formulation on Amazon&#8217;s bread. In theory, that means all those big business customers\u2014and there are many\u2014that use VMware vmw to run their own data centers can more easily forklift their workloads over to AWS data centers using the upcoming product known as VMware cloud for AWS. That&#8217;s an attractive proposition for companies that just want to keep running their virtualized applications as is, instead of re-jiggering them to run on Amazon&#8217;s infrastructure. Virtualization, which lets one set of hardware run more than one set of tasks, is a key linchpin of cloud computing, which is why bare metal is seen as sort of uncloudy. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter When this bare metal work was announced in October, it was painted as a VMware-only option. But there are potentially other big uses for those Xen-free AWS servers. Bare metal, for example, tends to be faster than virtualized hardware for applications like databases that send a lot of data in and out of disk storage. &#8220;There&#8217;s also a growing trend to put containers on bare metal to save on virtualization licensing costs and overhead, but that&#8217;s usually for private cloud,&#8221; says Sebastian Stadil, chief executive of Scalr, a cloud management company. Containers are a modern way developers package up software applications that can run almost anywhere. Bare metal is also useful for older, but still important applications that can&#8217;t be virtualized for various reasons, he notes. Clearly, others have seen opportunity. IBM ibm and Rackspace offer bare metal along with other more heavily-virtualized cloud options. When asked in November if AWS had other potential uses for these bare metal servers, Wood replied there was &#8220;nothing to announce at this time.&#8221; Opinion is mixed among AWS watchers if the company will parlay this bare metal capability beyond VMware or simply use it as a way to attract VMware customers to Amazon data centers and then\u2014as some suspect\u2014try to move them completely to Amazon (minus VMware). &#8220;It would be reasonable to assume that, once those workloads reach AWS, there is value in beginning to rearchitect some (maybe even all, one day) of them to run natively on AWS\u2019 own infrastructure, without the overhead of a VMware license,&#8221; says Paul Miller, a senior analyst with Forrester Research. Sateesh Narahari, vice president of products for Managed Methods, a cloud security company, also views those VMware bare metal instances &#8220;as a transitional state to going full cloud.&#8221; It&#8217;s possible that not even AWS execs know yet what will happen. The cloud giant is nothing if not pragmatic. If Amazon amzn sees opportunity once VMware for AWS Cloud materializes in the middle of 2017, it will capitalize on it. For more on Amazon and VMware, watch: &#8220;If AWS can make the economics and infrastructure management work\u2014and they tend to be good at that\u2014it does seem plausible that we&#8217;ll see a generic AWS bare metal offering sooner rather than later,&#8221; says Forrester&#8217;s Miller.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EOne surprising thing about what \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F05\u002Fvmware-amazon-cloud-pact\u002F\"\u003EAmazon Web Services\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has done \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F14\u002Faws-and-vmware-winners-losers\u002F\"\u003Eto run VMware&#8217;s popular virtualization software\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in its own cloud data centers is just how&#8230;un-cloud-like it seems.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is assembling masses of &#8220;bare metal&#8221; computers, which unlike the rest of the AWS servers, come with no virtualization. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F05\u002Fvmware-amazon-cloud-pact\u002F"},"content":["Amazon Web Services"]}," has done ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F14\u002Faws-and-vmware-winners-losers\u002F"},"content":["to run VMware's popular virtualization software"]}," in its own cloud data centers is just how...un-cloud-like it seems."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Amazon"]}," is assembling masses of \"bare metal\" computers, which unlike the rest of the AWS servers, come with no virtualization. That's because VMware's software is built using its own flavor of virtualization and that, in turn, meant AWS had to offer VMware a phalanx of servers stripped of the Xen virtualization, which runs the rest of Amazon's computers, known collectively as Elastic Compute Cloud or EC2."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["As AWS head of product Matt Wood explained it to ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Fortune"]}," in November:"]},{"tag":"blockquote","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We partnered with VMware to bring their existing software stack over to EC2. Customers told us they wanted the benefits of AWS and all the benefits of VMware, but didn't want to run our hypervisor so we worked on a new part of EC2 that allows VMware to run natively on EC2."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Think of VMware as offering a peanut butter and jelly sandwich using its customers' bread. Now the customer wants to use Amazon's bread, except that the only bread Amazon offers comes with the peanut butter built in. Continuing this analogy, Amazon has agreed to strip the peanut butter from many loaves so VMware can craft sandwiches using its own special PB&amp;J formulation on Amazon's bread."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In theory, that means all those big business customers\u2014and there are many\u2014that use VMware ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"vmw"},"content":[]}," to run their own data centers can more easily forklift their workloads over to AWS data centers using the upcoming product known as ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F13\u002Famazon-vmware-partnership-cloud-computing"},"content":["VMware cloud for AWS"]},". That's an attractive proposition for companies that just want to keep running their virtualized applications as is, instead of re-jiggering them to run on Amazon's infrastructure."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Virtualization, which lets one set of hardware run more than one set of tasks, is a key linchpin of cloud computing, which is why bare metal is seen as sort of uncloudy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When this bare metal work was ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F10\u002F13\u002Famazon-vmware-partnership-cloud-computing\u002F"},"content":["announced"]}," in October, it was painted as a VMware-only option. But there are potentially other big uses for those Xen-free AWS servers. Bare metal, for example, tends to be faster than virtualized hardware for applications like databases that send a lot of data in and out of disk storage."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"There's also a growing trend to put containers on bare metal to save on virtualization licensing costs and overhead, but that's usually for private cloud,\" says Sebastian Stadil, chief executive of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.scalr.com\u002F"},"content":["Scalr"]},", a cloud management company. Containers are a modern way developers package up software applications that can run almost anywhere."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Bare metal is also useful for older, but still important applications that can't be virtualized for various reasons, he notes. Clearly, others have seen opportunity. ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["IBM"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"ibm"},"content":[]}," and Rackspace offer bare metal along with other more heavily-virtualized cloud options."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When asked in November if AWS had other potential uses for these bare metal servers, Wood replied there was \"nothing to announce at this time.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Opinion is mixed among AWS watchers if the company will parlay this bare metal capability beyond VMware or simply use it as a way to attract VMware customers to Amazon data centers and then\u2014as some suspect\u2014try to move them completely to Amazon (minus VMware)."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"It would be reasonable to assume that, once those workloads reach AWS, there is value in beginning to rearchitect some (maybe even all, one day) of them to run natively on AWS\u2019 own infrastructure, without the overhead of a VMware license,\" says Paul Miller, a senior analyst with Forrester Research."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Sateesh Narahari, vice president of products for ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fmanagedmethods.com\u002F"},"content":["Managed Methods"]},", a cloud security company, also views those VMware bare metal instances \"as a transitional state to going full cloud.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It's possible that not even AWS execs know yet what will happen. The cloud giant is nothing if not pragmatic. If Amazon ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"amzn"},"content":[]}," sees opportunity once VMware for AWS Cloud materializes in the middle of 2017, it will capitalize on it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["For more on Amazon and VMware, watch:"]}," Starts Sending Out Killer Update for Samsung Galaxy Note 7"},"content":{"plain":"T-Mobile has started distributing a software update for Samsung Galaxy Note 7 phones called &#8220;N930TUVU2APL2.&#8221; But despite the meaningless title, the update will be the most significant offered yet for the recalled Note 7 and its dangerous battery. Once a T-Mobile customer installs the update, the Note 7 will no longer be able to charge or connect to networks. AT&amp;T, Verizon, and Sprint will also be sending out the update in coming weeks. The update also displays a reminder that the Note 7 has been recalled and instructions for returning the phone. T-Mobile tmus and Samsung, along with other carriers, agreed to take the unprecedented step of issuing the killer update after some Note 7 owners continued to use their devices despite the recall and many dozens of incidents of batteries exploding, smoking, or catching fire. About 7% of the Note 7 devices sold in the United States were still in use two weeks ago, Samsung said. Get Data Sheet, Fortune&#8217;s technology newsletter. Verizon vz and AT&amp;T t will start distributing the update on January 5. Sprint s will roll it out beginning on January 8. Anyone who bought a Note 7, which has a 5.7- inch screen and comes with a stylus, can return the device to the store or carrier where they bought it and exchange it for a different model or get a refund. Samsung is offering a $100 bill credit to customers who exchange a Note 7 for another Samsung smartphone. Customers who want a refund or opt for another brand qualify for a $25 credit. The Note 7 went on sale in August, but was quickly beset by reports of batteries smoking and catching fire. On September 2, Samsung said it was voluntarily recalling 2.5 million of the devices that had been shipped up to that point. Two weeks later, the Consumer Product Safety Commission formally issued a recall for 1 million Note 7 phones sold in the United States. And after battery problems cropped up even in some of replacement Note 7 devices, Samsung said on October 11 it was killing off the entire product.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ET-Mobile has started distributing a software update for Samsung Galaxy Note 7 phones called &#8220;N930TUVU2APL2.&#8221; But despite the meaningless title, the update will be the most significant offered yet for the recalled Note 7 and its dangerous battery.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOnce a T-Mobile customer installs the update, the Note 7 will no longer be able to charge or connect to networks. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fatt-10\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAT&amp;T\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fverizon-13\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EVerizon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and Sprint will also be sending out the update in coming weeks.
