offerings, however. The company has taken an all-of-the-above approach to connectivity in the car. It&#8217;s keeping Sync, the in-car communications and entertainment system that lets you use your voice to make a call, listen to music, and select apps with its AppLink technology.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAt the same time, Ford is also adding Apple CarPlay and Android Auto to new models.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Automakers are scrambling to offer connectivity to their increasingly tech-savvy consumer base and offer seamless integration between cars and smartphones. But not all are keen to connect with systems developed by ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Apple"]}," or ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Google"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford Motor ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"f"},"content":[]}," and Toyota Motor ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"tm"},"content":[]}," have formed a consortium to accelerate the deployment of open source software aimed at giving consumers more options in how they connect and control their smartphone apps."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The organization is called the SmartDeviceLink (SDL) Consortium, a reference to an open source software version of Ford's AppLink."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Mazda Motor ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"mzday"},"content":[]},", PSA Group, Fuji Heavy Industries ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"fujhy"},"content":[]},", and Suzuki Motor ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"szkmy"},"content":[]},", are the first automaker members of the consortium. Suppliers Elektrobit ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"ebttf"},"content":[]},", Harman ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"har"},"content":[]},", Luxoft ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"lxft"},"content":[]},", QNX, and Xevo have also joined the nonprofit organization."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", "]},"Fortune",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["\u2019s"]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" technology newsletter."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The formation of the consortium follows Toyota's announcement last January that it planned to use the SDL software in its cars to give drivers command and control of smartphone apps through dashboard buttons, display screens, and voice recognition tech. Toyota plans to commercialize an infotainment system using SDL around 2018."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The unusual agreement between the typically competitive companies showed the wariness of some automakers to hand over control to third-party companies\u2014namely Apple ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"aapl"},"content":[]}," and Google ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"googl"},"content":[]},". Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are two connectivity systems that allow a smartphone to take over a car\u2019s center screen. Once users plug their smartphones into the car\u2019s USB ports, the phones' maps and navigation, music, and selected apps are integrated onto the central screen."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford and Toyota argue that an open source code is a better approach, because developers and automakers working together can increase the quality and security of the software. If the industry adopts the software, developers would gain access to millions of vehicles and their drivers worldwide, while participating companies would still be able to retain control over the level of access outside parties have to vehicle data, the companies said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"4913546721001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford has abandoned Apple's and Google's offerings, however. It's keeping Sync, the in-car communications and entertainment system that lets you use your voice to make a call, listen to music, and select apps with its AppLink technology."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["At the same time, Ford is also adding Apple CarPlay and Android Auto to new models."]}]},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe two automakers want the industry to embrace open source \u002Fposts\u002F1893860\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893860\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893860\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893860\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893860\u002Fprimary_section"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893860\u002Fbrand"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:meta":[{"mt_seo_title":"Toyota, Agreement","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j7iXTB","twitter_text":"Ford and Toyota Just Became Allies in an Unusual Agreement","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fford-and-toyota-just-became-allies-in-an-unusual-agreement\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F04\u002Fford-and-toyota-just-became-allies-in-an-unusual-agreement\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1156186,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F06\u002Ffordsync3-1.jpg","alt":"Ford 3"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":2449302,"name":"Global 500","slug":"global-500","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":156716,"taxonomy":"person","description":"","parent":0,"count":0,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":6688,"name":"Autos","slug":"autos","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46736,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and analysis of the automobile industry, from the latest cars to the latest executive shakeups at GM, Ford, Chrysler, and other motor vehicle manufacturers.","parent":0,"count":3395,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893164,"date":"2017-01-03T23:56:26","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T04:56:26","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893164"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T00:00:08","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T05:00:08","slug":"ford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fford-cancels-mexico-plant-trump\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2j4OtBt","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Ford Cancels a $1.6 Billion Mexico Plant and Adds 700 Jobs in Michigan"},"content":{"plain":"Ford Motor Co f on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival General Motors Co with the threat of a &#8220;big border tax&#8221; over compact cars made in Mexico. Ford CEO Mark Fields called the move &#8220;a vote of confidence&#8221; in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. He said Ford would have made the same decision even if Trump had not been elected. Ford will cancel plans unveiled in April to spend $1.6 billion to build the new plant in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, a project Trump urged the automaker to abandon and called an &#8220;absolute disgrace&#8221; during the election campaign. The No. 2 U.S. automaker also said it would invest $700 million to expand the Flat Rock, Michigan factory and would make new electric, hybrid and autonomous vehicles there. Trump&#8217;s efforts to browbeat the U.S. car industry show he may go further than other modern presidents to try to influence corporate decisions, especially those related to trade and investment. In a Twitter post hours before Ford&#8217;s announcement, Trump wrote, &#8220;General Motors is sending Mexican made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border. Make in U.S.A. or pay big border tax!&#8221; GM, the largest U.S. automaker, said making some of the Cruze cars in the plant in Coahuila, Mexico was part of its strategy to serve global customers, not sell those vehicles in the United States. Trump&#8217;s GM tweet was his latest broadside aimed at an American company over jobs, imports and costs even before he takes office on Jan. 20. Mexico&#8217;s government said it regrets Ford&#8217;s decision and has ensured that the company will reimburse San Luis Potosi state for any costs associated with the investment. &#8220;Obviously, this isn&#8217;t a good decision for us,&#8221; said Mexico&#8217;s economy minister, Ildefonso Guajardo. Ford said it still will shift production from Michigan of its Focus compact car to an existing plant in Hermosillo, Mexico. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford&#8217;s investment in Flat Rock. Ford spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus. Ford shares closed up about 3.8 percent. GM shares rose about 0.9 percent. TRUMP NOTIFIED Top Ford executives personally notified Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence of their decision. Fields praised tax and regulatory proposals advocated by Trump and his fellow Republicans who control Congress. &#8220;Our view is that we see a more positive U.S. manufacturing business environment under President-elect Trump and the pro-growth policies and proposals that he&#8217;s talking about, so this is a vote of confidence for President-elect Trump and some of the policies that they may be pursuing,&#8221; Fields said. Union workers gathered at the Flat Rock factory cheered Fields&#8217; announcement. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said. Trump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. Trump also accused Mexico of sending criminals and rapists into the United States and vowed to build a border wall to combat illegal immigration. Since winning the Nov. 8 election, Trump has targeted a wide range of American companies also including United Technologies Inc, Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin Corp. Trump also has touted decisions by companies to keep some production in the United States, including United&#8217;s Carrier unit in Indiana. Trump previously vowed to hit companies that shift production from America to other countries with a 35 percent tax on their exports into the United States. He also has denounced the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada. Fields said there were no negotiations between Ford and the incoming president over canceling the Mexico plant or investing in Michigan. Ford will build a battery electric SUV with a 300-mile (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020. GM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. All of the sedan versions sold in the United States, about 185,500, were built at its Lordstown, Ohio plant. About 4,500 hatchback Cruze versions were assembled in Mexico and sold in the United States. This story has been updated. &nbsp;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFord Motor Co \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"f\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fford-motor-9\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ef\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgeneral-motors-8\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGeneral Motors\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Co with the threat of a &#8220;big border tax&#8221; over compact cars made in Mexico.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFord CEO Mark Fields called the move &#8220;a vote of confidence&#8221; in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford&#8217;s investment in Flat Rock.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFord spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFord shares closed up about 3.8 percent. GM shares rose about 0.9 percent.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETRUMP NOTIFIED\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETop Ford executives personally notified Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence of their decision. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. All of the sedan versions sold in the United States, about 185,500, were built at its Lordstown, Ohio plant. About 4,500 hatchback Cruze versions were assembled in Mexico and sold in the United States.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis story has been updated.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford Motor Co ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"f"},"content":[]}," on Tuesday scrapped a planned Mexican car factory and added 700 jobs in Michigan following criticism by Donald Trump, as the U.S. president-elect turned his attention toward rival ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fgeneral-motors-8\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["General Motors"]}," Co with the threat of a \"big border tax\" over compact cars made in Mexico."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford CEO Mark Fields called the move \"a vote of confidence\" in Trump, but primarily a response to a decline in North American demand for small cars like those that would have been made at the Mexican plant. He said Ford would have made the same decision even if Trump had not been elected."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford will cancel plans unveiled in April to spend $1.6 billion to build the new plant in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, a project Trump urged the automaker to abandon and called an \"absolute disgrace\" during the election campaign."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The No. 2 U.S. automaker also said it would invest $700 million to expand the Flat Rock, Michigan factory and would make new electric, hybrid and autonomous vehicles there."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump's efforts to browbeat the U.S. car industry show he may go further than other modern presidents to try to influence corporate decisions, especially those related to trade and investment."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In a Twitter post hours before Ford's announcement, Trump wrote, \"General Motors is sending Mexican made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border. Make in U.S.A. or pay big border tax!\" GM, the largest U.S. automaker, said making some of the Cruze cars in the plant in Coahuila, Mexico was part of its strategy to serve global customers, not sell those vehicles in the United States."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump's GM tweet was his latest broadside aimed at an American company over jobs, imports and costs even before he takes office on Jan. 20."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Mexico's government said it regrets Ford's decision and has ensured that the company will reimburse San Luis Potosi state for any costs associated with the investment."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Obviously, this isn't a good decision for us,\" said Mexico's economy minister, Ildefonso Guajardo."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford said it still will shift production from Michigan of its Focus compact car to an existing plant in Hermosillo, Mexico. Fields said he expects Michigan to give incentives for Ford's investment in Flat Rock."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford spokeswoman Jennifer Flake said the automaker will save $500 million by not opening the new plant in the near term, but will have some undisclosed costs to retool the other Mexican plant to build the Focus."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford shares closed up about 3.8 percent. GM shares rose about 0.9 percent."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TRUMP NOTIFIED"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Top Ford executives personally notified Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence of their decision. Fields praised tax and regulatory proposals advocated by Trump and his fellow Republicans who control Congress."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Our view is that we see a more positive U.S. manufacturing business environment under President-elect Trump and the pro-growth policies and proposals that he's talking about, so this is a vote of confidence for President-elect Trump and some of the policies that they may be pursuing,\" Fields said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Union workers gathered at the Flat Rock factory cheered Fields' announcement. Hiring of the 700 new workers there will probably start in 2018 with the majority of it in 2020, Fields said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump said during the presidential campaign that if elected he would not allow Ford to open the new plant in Mexico and would slap hefty tariffs on imported Ford vehicles. Trump also accused Mexico of sending criminals and rapists into the United States and vowed to build a border wall to combat illegal immigration."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Since winning the Nov. 8 election, Trump has targeted a wide range of American companies also including ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Funited-technologies-45\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["United Technologies"]}," Inc, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fboeing-24\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Boeing"]}," Co and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Flockheed-martin-60\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Lockheed Martin"]}," Corp. Trump also has touted decisions by companies to keep some production in the United States, including United's Carrier unit in Indiana."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump previously vowed to hit companies that shift production from America to other countries with a 35 percent tax on their exports into the United States. He also has denounced the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fields said there were no negotiations between Ford and the incoming president over canceling the Mexico plant or investing in Michigan."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5269310978001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ford will build a battery electric SUV with a 300-mile (482-km) driving range at the Michigan plant by 2020, and will launch production there by 2021 of a fully autonomous vehicle without a steering wheel or a brake pedal for use in ride services fleets. Ford also plans new hybrid versions of its F-150 pickup truck, Mustang and police vehicles by 2020."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["GM said it sold about 190,000 Cruze cars in the United States in 2016. instead\r\n","description":"","title":"Ford Cancels Plans for Factory In Mexico"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5269239440001","autoplay":"1","controls":"1"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":34917787,"name":"Ford","slug":"ford","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46975,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":298,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":6688,"name":"Autos","slug":"autos","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46736,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and analysis of the automobile industry, from the latest cars to the latest executive shakeups at GM, Ford, Chrysler, and other motor vehicle manufacturers.","parent":0,"count":3395,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893668,"date":"2017-01-03T20:10:59","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T01:10:59","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893668"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T20:17:12","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T01:17:12","slug":"xerox-spinoff-conduent-ashok-vemuri","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fxerox-spinoff-conduent-ashok-vemuri\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hOIMqZ","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Conduent CEO Talks Splitting From Xerox and Competing with IBM and HPE"},"content":{"plain":"It&#8217;s a new beginning for Xerox&#8217;s spawn. Xerox&#8217;s sibling business services unit, Conduent, spun off into a separate company on Tuesday. It must now find a way to lift its growth amid stagnant sales and a tough market. Xerox acquired the roots of Conduent, which handles everything from human resources services for healthcare companies to mobile parking apps for the city of Los Angeles, by buying Affiliated Computer Services for nearly $6.4 billion in 2010. The deal was supposed to help Xerox find another source of revenue beyond it&#8217;s core copier and printing business. But like other big business tech companies like IBM and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Xerox&#8217;s overall revenue has declined in recent years. With few people printing and copying, Xerox&#8217;s annual sales have dropped each year since 2011. During much of that time, Xerox&#8217;s business services group struggled. In a nine-month period ending in September, Conduent had $4.9 billion in revenue, or nearly flat compared to the previous year. Xerox&#8217;s executives say that two smaller, more nimble businesses will be able to better adapt to a rapidly changing technology world. The argument echoes that of Hewlett Packard, which split into two companies last year. But Wall Street didn&#8217;t exactly give Conduent a happy birthday. In its first day of trading, the company&#8217;s shares fell 8% to $13.72. In this edited interview with Fortune, Conduent CEO Ashok Vemuri talks about splitting from Xerox xrx , competing with IBM ibm and HPE hpe , and new beginnings. Fortune: Tell me about splitting from Xerox. Vemuri: If you go back six to seven years when Xerox acquired a company called ACS [Affiliated Computer Services] in 2010, the thesis of that acquisition was that Xerox was a hardware manufacturing company. This was during a recession, and management thought the best would be to serve your clients soup-to-nuts, if you will, by acquiring a services company. It was very similar to other companies\u2014think Dell with Perot [$3.9 billion deal was announced in 2009], HP with EDS [$13.9 billion deal was announced in 2008] That construct of combining hardware with services didn\u2019t necessarily pan out. So, it was thought that our two companies would be better served if they were sliced off and were allowed to control their own destiny and serve their own clients, their own market, their own technology, etc. Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Why did hardware companies think that they also had to have business services? It was the height of the recession. This was considered a sort of natural hedge in terms of buying revenue. Secondly, it was believed that if you sold a piece of equipment to a client, they were servicing that equipment with somebody else. So why would I not, if I sold you that equipment, service it instead? Thirdly, services companies were on the ascendancy. Remember, even 10 years ago, print, paper, ink was on decline, and it continues to be so. The services business is where the margins are\u2014where the cash flow is\u2014and your need for spending is much less. If you look at an equipment provider like Xerox, it\u2019s more a finance operating lease company, because they fund your purchase of a printer. A services business is asset light. It does not require you to invest your balance sheet in a big way. Some analysts believe the downside of a service company, however, are the costs of hiring employees, which can eat into profitability. That\u2019s wrong. That is the conventional way of thinking about services businesses. In our model, 80% of our business is transactions based. We do everything off the back of technology. That allows me to add a multitude of services off a particular platform. Let me give you an example. If I have three or four clients, I cannot repurpose my people because they aren\u2019t fungible. I can\u2019t say, \u201cHey, for two hours you be on the call center, for two hours you do transaction processing, for two hours you work for Client A, and for two hours you work for Client B.\u201d But I can do it if I do it on the back of technology, because my platform aggregates and creates air pockets that allow me to work for multiple clients. I can repurpose my platform to do multiple functions. With people, I can\u2019t expect them to work more than eight hours. What are the services that your company does? We serve two broad segments. One is the public sector. We work with all 50 U.S. states and over 500 government entities worldwide. We do a lot of work in transportation. Think about parking: You use a parking app pay over the phone, and the phone reminds you after 45 minutes to pay more We are now handling road tolls\u2014so think EasyPass in California and SunPass in Florida. We are the world\u2019s largest prepaid card processor. We do things like welfare, Social Security, Food Stamps. The other part of the business is commercial. We work with 74 of the top Fortune 100 companies. We support them on mission-critical systems. Apple aapl co-founder Steve Jobs once publicly criticized Xerox for not capitalizing on its technology. Correct. In a similar way, a lot of Conduent\u2019s technology was invented in Xerox over the last six years. The ACS story is six years old; a little is left, but a lot of that is new and a lot of that was invented in Xerox. Now that you\u2019re an independent company, how do you balance spending on research into new technologies with pleasing investors? Clearly today, technology is at a place where you don\u2019t necessarily have to build components in-house; you can buy them from others. We have to rid ourselves of the sensibility we\u2019ve had that if it\u2019s not invented in-house it\u2019s not worth looking at. We are now a public company, so our research dollars have to give a return in the year that I give the dollar in, unlike in the past in which the time to yield was like five to seven years. Having said that, technology will be the underpinning of every process we bring. Therefore we must invest in our technology platform and make it modern. The speed of technology is changing and the way it is being consumed is dramatically changing in such a short time frame that our investments have to reflect that time horizon as well as the fact that these changes are happening. Who are your biggest competitors? We are in a wide range of industries, so we have a lot of them. A lot of them are very niche and specialized companies. Across our various businesses, we see as competitors like Accenture, we see IBM, we see HPE. My advantage is I\u2019m a pure-play business process provider. I\u2019m the largest in revenue and in size and scale. For more about enterprise technology, watch: How do you distinguish yourselves from the big business services groups of companies like IBM that may brag that their technology separates them from the pack? Technology is a commodity. I can buy technology every other day at half the price I paid the day before yesterday. The technology product isn\u2019t going to give you any differentiation. What gives you differentiation is what you do with that technology. If I understand processes and have functional and domain knowledge, then I can actually leverage that technology and literally make it jump through hoops to provide me the answer or the outcome that the business really needs.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s a new beginning for Xerox&#8217;s spawn.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EXerox&#8217;s sibling business services unit, Conduent, spun off into a separate company on Tuesday. It must now find a way to lift its growth amid stagnant sales and a tough market.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EXerox acquired the roots of Conduent, which handles everything from human resources services for healthcare companies to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F01\u002F28\u002Fxerox-los-angeles-traffic\u002F\"\u003Emobile parking apps\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the city of Los Angeles, by \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.xerox.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-archive\u002F2009\u002Fswe-acquire-affiliated-computer-services\u002Fsvse.html\"\u003Ebuying\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Affiliated Computer Services for nearly $6.4 billion in 2010. The deal was supposed to help Xerox find another source of revenue beyond it&#8217;s core copier and printing business.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut like other big business tech companies like IBM and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Xerox&#8217;s overall revenue has declined in recent years. With few people printing and copying, Xerox&#8217;s annual sales have \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.democratandchronicle.com\u002Fstory\u002Fmoney\u002Fbusiness\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fxerox-conduent-split-complete\u002F96100654\u002F\"\u003Edropped\u003C\u002Fa\u003E each year since 2011.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring much of that time, Xerox&#8217;s business services group struggled. In a nine-month period \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.sec.gov\u002FArchives\u002Fedgar\u002Fdata\u002F1677703\u002F000167770316000004\u002F0001677703-16-000004-index.htm\"\u003Eending\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in September, Conduent had $4.9 billion in revenue, or nearly flat compared to the previous year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EXerox&#8217;s executives say that two smaller, more nimble businesses will be able to better adapt to a rapidly changing technology world. The argument echoes that of Hewlett Packard, which \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fhewlett-packard-split-infrastructure\u002F\"\u003Esplit into two companies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E last year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut Wall Street didn&#8217;t exactly give Conduent a happy birthday. In its first day of trading, the company&#8217;s shares fell 8% to $13.72.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn this edited interview with \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, Conduent CEO Ashok Vemuri talks about splitting from Xerox \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"xrx\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fxerox-150\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Exrx\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, competing with IBM \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"ibm\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eibm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E and HPE \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"hpe\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fhpe\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ehpe\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, and new beginnings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E: Tell me about splitting from Xerox.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EVemuri: If you go back six to seven years when \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fxerox-150\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EXerox\u003C\u002Fa\u003E acquired a company called ACS [Affiliated Computer Services] in 2010, the thesis of that acquisition was that Xerox was a hardware manufacturing company. This was during a recession, and management thought the best would be to serve your clients soup-to-nuts, if you will, by acquiring a services company.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt was very similar to other companies\u2014think Dell \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F12\u002F24\u002Fdell-perot-systems-acquisition\u002F\"\u003Ewith Perot\u003C\u002Fa\u003E [$3.9 billion deal was \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.google.com\u002Fsearch?q=dell+buys+perot&amp;ie=utf-8&amp;oe=utf-8\"\u003Eannounced\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in 2009], \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fhp-20\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EHP\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F09\u002F16\u002Freal-reason-for-hps-woes\u002F\"\u003Ewith EDS\u003C\u002Fa\u003E [$13.9 billion deal was \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww8.hp.com\u002Fus\u002Fen\u002Fhp-news\u002Fpress-release.html?id=169924#.WGxJPnCTtGA\"\u003Eannounced\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in 2008] That construct of combining hardware with services didn\u2019t necessarily pan out. So, it was thought that our two companies would be better served if they were sliced off and were allowed to control their own destiny and serve their own clients, their own market, their own technology, etc.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy did hardware companies think that they also had to have business services?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt was the height of the recession. This was considered a sort of natural hedge in terms of buying revenue. Secondly, it was believed that if you sold a piece of equipment to a client, they were servicing that equipment with somebody else. So why would I not, if I sold you that equipment, service it instead? Thirdly, services companies were on the ascendancy. Remember, even 10 years ago, print, paper, ink was on decline, and it continues to be so. The services business is where the margins are\u2014where the cash flow is\u2014and your need for spending is much less. If you look at an equipment provider like Xerox, it\u2019s more a finance operating lease company, because they fund your purchase of a printer. A services business is asset light. It does not require you to invest your balance sheet in a big way.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ESome analysts believe the downside of a service company, however, are the costs of hiring employees, which can eat into profitability.\u003Cbr \u002F\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat\u2019s wrong. That is the conventional way of thinking about services businesses. In our model, 80% of our business is transactions based. We do everything off the back of technology. That allows me to add a multitude of services off a particular platform. Let me give you an example. If I have three or four clients, I cannot repurpose my people because they aren\u2019t fungible. I can\u2019t say, \u201cHey, for two hours you be on the call center, for two hours you do transaction processing, for two hours you work for Client A, and for two hours you work for Client B.\u201d But I can do it if I do it on the back of technology, because my platform aggregates and creates air pockets that allow me to work for multiple clients. I can repurpose my platform to do multiple functions. With people, I can\u2019t expect them to work more than eight hours.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat are the services that your company does?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe serve two broad segments. One is the public sector. We work with all 50 U.S. states and over 500 government entities worldwide. We do a lot of work in transportation. Think about parking: You use a parking app pay over the phone, and the phone reminds you after 45 minutes to pay more We are now handling road tolls\u2014so think \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.actransit.org\u002Frider-info\u002Feasypass\u002F\"\u003EEasyPass\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in California and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.sunpass.com\u002Findex\"\u003ESunPass\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Florida.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe are the world\u2019s largest prepaid card processor. We do things like welfare, Social Security, Food Stamps. The other part of the business is commercial. We work with 74 of the top \u003Cem\u003EFortune\u003C\u002Fem\u003E 100 companies. We support them on mission-critical systems.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EApple \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"aapl\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eaapl\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E co-founder Steve Jobs once publicly \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=X3NASGb5m8s\"\u003Ecriticized\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Xerox for not capitalizing on its technology.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECorrect. In a similar way, a lot of Conduent\u2019s technology was invented in Xerox over the last six years. The ACS story is six years old; a little is left, but a lot of that is new and a lot of that was invented in Xerox.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ENow that you\u2019re an independent company, how do you balance spending on research into \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F28\u002Fhewlett-packard-enterprise-machine-computing\u002F\"\u003Enew technologies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E with pleasing investors?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EClearly today, technology is at a place where you don\u2019t necessarily have to build components in-house; you can buy \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F18\u002Fred-hat-ceo-james-whitehurst-microsoft-google-software\u002F\"\u003Ethem from others\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. We have to rid ourselves of the sensibility we\u2019ve had that if it\u2019s not invented in-house it\u2019s not worth looking at. We are now a public company, so our research dollars have to give a return in the year that I give the dollar in, unlike in the past in which the time to yield was like five to seven years.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHaving said that, technology will be the underpinning of every process we bring. Therefore we must invest in our technology platform and make it modern. The speed of technology is changing and the way it is being consumed is dramatically changing in such a short time frame that our investments have to reflect that time horizon as well as the fact that these changes are happening.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWho are your biggest competitors?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWe are in a wide range of industries, so we have a lot of them. A lot of them are very niche and specialized companies. Across our various businesses, we see as competitors like Accenture, we see \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIBM\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, we see HPE. My advantage is I\u2019m a pure-play business process provider. I\u2019m the largest in revenue and in size and scale.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFor more about enterprise technology, the big business services groups of companies like IBM that may brag that their technology separates them from the pack?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETechnology is a commodity. I can buy technology every other day at half the price I paid the day before yesterday. The technology product isn\u2019t going to give you any differentiation. What gives you differentiation is what you do with that technology. If I understand processes and have functional and domain knowledge, then I can actually leverage that technology and literally make it jump through hoops to provide me the answer or the outcome that the business really needs.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It's a new beginning for Xerox's spawn."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Xerox's sibling business services unit, Conduent, spun off into a separate company on Tuesday. It must now find a way to lift its growth amid stagnant sales and a tough market."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Xerox acquired the roots of Conduent, which handles everything from human resources services for healthcare companies to ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F01\u002F28\u002Fxerox-los-angeles-traffic\u002F"},"content":["mobile parking apps"]}," for the city of Los Angeles, by ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.xerox.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-archive\u002F2009\u002Fswe-acquire-affiliated-computer-services\u002Fsvse.html"},"content":["buying"]}," Affiliated Computer Services for nearly $6.4 billion in 2010. In a nine-month period ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.sec.gov\u002FArchives\u002Fedgar\u002Fdata\u002F1677703\u002F000167770316000004\u002F0001677703-16-000004-index.htm"},"content":["ending"]}," in September, Conduent had $4.9 billion in revenue, or nearly flat compared to the previous year."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Xerox's executives say that two smaller, more nimble businesses will be able to better adapt to a rapidly changing technology world. The argument echoes that of Hewlett Packard, which ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2015\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fhewlett-packard-split-infrastructure\u002F"},"content":["split into two companies"]}," last year."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But Wall Street didn't exactly give Conduent a happy birthday. The speed of technology is changing and the way it is being consumed is dramatically changing in such a short time frame that our investments have to reflect that time horizon as well as the fact that these changes are happening."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Who are your biggest competitors?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We are in a wide range of industries, so we have a lot of them. A lot of them are very niche and specialized companies. Across our various businesses, we see as competitors like Accenture, we see ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fibm-31\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["IBM"]},", we see HPE. My advantage is I\u2019m a pure-play business process provider. I\u2019m the largest in revenue and in size and scale."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["For more about enterprise technology, watch:"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"4728445300001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["How do you distinguish yourselves from the big business services groups of companies like IBM that may brag that their technology separates them from the pack?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Technology is a commodity. I can buy technology every other day at half the price I paid the day before yesterday. The technology product isn\u2019t going to give you any differentiation. What gives you differentiation is what you do with that technology. If I understand processes and have functional and domain knowledge, then I can actually leverage that technology and literally make it jump through hoops to provide me the answer or the outcome that the business really needs."]}]},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ECEO Ashok Vemuri talks splitting from Xerox, competing with IBM and HPE, and new beginnings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":84897230,"featured_media":1893344,"parent":0,"menu_order":0,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"open","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=1893668"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=1893668"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fprimary_section"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893668\u002Fbrand"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:meta":[{"short_title":"Xerox company","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hOIMqZ","mt_seo_keywords":"cloud Xerox, printer, hardware, IBM, business services, Ashok Vemuri, Conduent,","mt_seo_title":"Conduent CEO Ashok Vemuri Talks Splitting From Xerox","mt_seo_description":"Conduent CEO Ashok Vemuri talks splitting From Xerox, competing with IBM and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, and new beginnings.","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fxerox-spinoff-conduent-ashok-vemuri\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fxerox-spinoff-conduent-ashok-vemuri\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893344,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fconduent-nyse-2017-gettyimages-630849198.jpg","alt":"First U.S. stocks rose Tuesday, pointing to the biggest gain in a month for Wall Street's first session of the new year, helped by a string of robust economic data from China and Europe. Photographer: Michael Nagle\u002FBloomberg via Getty Images","title":"Conduent 2017"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":42751983,"name":"PointCloud","slug":"pointcloud","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":143855,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":578,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":318,"name":"Tech","slug":"tech","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46728,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News, analysis, and insight into technology and business, including Silicon Valley giants like Apple, Google, Facebook, and our annual Brainstorm Tech conference.","parent":0,"count":36555,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893743,"date":"2017-01-03T19:15:15","date_gmt":"2017-01-04T00:15:15","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893743"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-04T08:40:41","modified_gmt":"2017-01-04T13:40:41","slug":"media-trump-lies","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fmedia-trump-lies\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hNr6am","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Dan Rather Is Right, the Media Should Call Trump\u2019s Lies What They Are"},"content":{"plain":"What should the media do when the U.S. president says something that is clearly and unequivocally not true? This might have seemed like an academic ethical question in the past, but with business mogul Donald Trump set to move into the Oval Office soon, it has become much more pressing, and more than a little contentious. During a weekend interview on Meet the Press that included both New York Times executive editor Dean Baquet and Wall Street Journal editor Gerard Baker, the latter was asked whether he thought inaccurate statements by Trump should be specifically called out as lies. Baker said that he didn&#8217;t think so, because the word &#8220;lie&#8221; implies that the person told an untruth on purpose. Instead, the Journal editor argued that media outlets should simply present the facts and leave it up to readers to determine the truth. The word lie &#8220;implies much more than just saying something that&#8217;s false. It implies a deliberate intent to mislead,&#8221; Baker said. &#8220;I think it&#8217;s up to the reader to make up their own mind&#8230; If you start ascribing a moral intent, as it were, to someone by saying that they&#8217;ve lied, I think you run the risk that you look like you\u2019re not being objective.&#8221; Get Data Sheet, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter. Legendary news anchor Dan Rather, however, took issue with this approach in a post on his Facebook page that was widely shared among journalists. Rather called Baker&#8217;s argument &#8220;deeply disturbing.&#8221; It is not the proper role of journalists, the former anchor said, &#8220;to meet lies \u2014 especially from someone of Mr. Trump\u2019s stature and power \u2014 by hiding behind semantics and euphemisms. Our role is to call it as we see it, based on solid reporting. When something is, in fact, a demonstrable lie, it is our responsibility to say so.&#8221; In his NBC interview, Baker referred to Trump&#8217;s repeated statements that Muslims were seen cheering in New Jersey when the World Trade Center towers fell. The Journal reported that there was no evidence this had actually occurred, Baker said, and then left it to the reader to decide. But even if the standard principle is that something can only be called a lie if we know the intent of the speaker\u2014as the Journal editor argues it should be\u2014can we not assume that Trump was making those statements with a deliberate intent to mislead voters about Muslim behavior? After all, he said it multiple times, even after it had been proven false. The same thing goes for many other Trump statements on a wide range of issues. He has repeatedly said that millions of people voted illegally, which isn&#8217;t true, and that ending the &#8220;stop and frisk&#8221; campaign in New York increased crime, which it didn&#8217;t. There are literally hundreds of such examples. At what point does repeating them stop being a falsehood and become an outright lie? In addition to winning the Electoral College in a landslide, I won the popular vote if you deduct the millions of people who voted illegally &mdash; Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) November 27, 2016 Baker&#8217;s argument is very similar to the one made by moderators like Fox News host Chris Wallace and MSNBC host Chris Matthews during the presidential debates. Wallace said he didn&#8217;t think it was a moderator&#8217;s job to be a &#8220;truth squad,&#8221; while Matthews said calling out lies would be equivalent to expressing an opinion, which journalists shouldn&#8217;t do. Those comments came up in large part because Matt Lauer of NBC was widely criticized for failing to challenge Trump during an interview when the candidate claimed that he never supported the war in Iraq, despite abundant evidence to the contrary. In a Twitter debate on Monday with a number of journalists, including Fusion writer Felix Salmon and former New York Observer editor Elizabeth Spiers, Time Inc.&#8217;s chief content officer Alan Murray (who is also editor of this magazine) defended Baker&#8217;s approach, saying journalists should be careful about using the word &#8220;lie&#8221; without proof that the speaker deliberately intended to mislead. Words matter. &quot;False&quot; and &quot;lie&quot; are not the same thing. https:\u002F\u002Ft.co\u002FACM5exCej2 &mdash; Alan Murray (@alansmurray) January 3, 2017 Spiers and others, however, said journalists make intelligent inferences about a politician&#8217;s motives all the time, and catching one in a lie is no different. Former Fortune writer Dan Primack, who is now with the media startup Axios, said: &#8220;I agree about being careful. But if you can prove the shoe fits, then put it on.&#8221; Washington Post writer Greg Sargent argued that &#8220;Donald Trump lies. A lot. And news organizations should say so.&#8221; These are all of Trump&#8217;s potential conflicts of interest: Inaccurate statements aren&#8217;t always lies. As Murray pointed out, Ronald Reagan said a lot of things that turned out not to be true, but not all of them were lies. But he didn&#8217;t repeatedly tell the same untruths over and over in the face of all the available evidence, the way Trump has done throughout his campaign, behavior he will presumably continue once he is in office. How can a self-respecting journalistic organization not call those lies? In the kind of broken media landscape we currently have, something Trump took advantage of better than anyone else during the campaign, not calling out obvious lies risks providing him with the headlines he wants\u2014apparently reinforcing his questionable claims\u2014with the evidence against his statements buried in the lower parts of a story that no one will read.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWhat should the media do when the U.S. president says something that is clearly and unequivocally not true? This might have seemed like an academic ethical question in the past, but with business mogul Donald Trump set to move into the Oval Office soon, it has become much more pressing, and more than a little contentious.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDuring a weekend interview on \u003Cem\u003EMeet the Press\u003C\u002Fem\u003E that included both \u003Cem\u003ENew York Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E executive editor Dean Baquet and \u003Cem\u003EWall Street Journal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E editor Gerard Baker, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077\"\u003Ethe latter was asked\u003C\u002Fa\u003E whether he thought inaccurate statements by Trump should be specifically called out as lies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBaker said that he didn&#8217;t think so, because the word &#8220;lie&#8221; implies that the person told an untruth on purpose. Instead, the \u003Cem\u003EJournal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E editor argued that media outlets should simply present the facts and leave it up to readers to determine the truth.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe word lie &#8220;implies much more than just saying something that&#8217;s false. It implies a deliberate intent to mislead,&#8221; \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077\"\u003EBaker said\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;I think it&#8217;s up to the reader to make up their own mind&#8230; If you start ascribing a moral intent, as it were, to someone by saying that they&#8217;ve lied, I think you run the risk that you look like you\u2019re not being objective.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F\"\u003EGet Data Sheet\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELegendary news anchor Dan Rather, however, took issue with this approach \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002FtheDanRather\u002Fposts\u002F10157986074875716\"\u003Ein a post\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on his Facebook page that was widely shared among journalists.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ERather called Baker&#8217;s argument &#8220;deeply disturbing.&#8221; It is not the proper role of journalists, the former anchor said, &#8220;to meet lies \u2014 especially from someone of Mr. Trump\u2019s stature and power \u2014 by hiding behind semantics and euphemisms. Our role is to call it as we see it, based on solid reporting. When something is, in fact, a demonstrable lie, it is our responsibility to say so.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn his NBC interview, Baker referred to Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politifact.com\u002Ftruth-o-meter\u002Fstatements\u002F2015\u002Fnov\u002F22\u002Fdonald-trump\u002Ffact-checking-trumps-claim-thousands-new-jersey-ch\u002F\"\u003Erepeated statements\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that Muslims were seen cheering in New Jersey when the World Trade Center towers fell. As Murray \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Falansmurray\u002Fstatus\u002F816107216835145728\"\u003Epointed out\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Ronald Reagan said a lot of things that turned out not to be true, but not all of them were lies. But he didn&#8217;t repeatedly tell the same untruths over and over in the face of all the available evidence, the way Trump has done throughout his campaign, behavior he will presumably continue once he is in office. How can a self-respecting journalistic organization not call those lies?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the kind of broken media landscape we currently have, something Trump \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F07\u002Ftrump-media-broken\u002F\"\u003Etook advantage of\u003C\u002Fa\u003E better than anyone else during the campaign, not calling out obvious lies risks providing him with \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fplum-line\u002Fwp\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F29\u002Fmemo-to-the-media-stop-giving-trump-the-headlines-he-wants\u002F\"\u003Ethe headlines he wants\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u2014apparently reinforcing his questionable claims\u2014with the evidence against his statements buried in the lower parts of a story that no one will read.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["What should the media do when the U.S. president says something that is clearly and unequivocally not true? This might have seemed like an academic ethical question in the past, but with business mogul Donald Trump set to move into the Oval Office soon, it has become much more pressing, and more than a little contentious."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["During a weekend interview on ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Meet the Press"]}," that included both ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["New York Times"]}," executive editor Dean Baquet and ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Wall Street Journal"]}," editor Gerard Baker, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077"},"content":["the latter was asked"]}," whether he thought inaccurate statements by Trump should be specifically called out as lies."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Baker said that he didn't think so, because the word \"lie\" implies that the person told an untruth on purpose. Instead, the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]}," editor argued that media outlets should simply present the facts and leave it up to readers to determine the truth."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The word lie \"implies much more than just saying something that's false. It implies a deliberate intent to mislead,\" ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politico.com\u002Fblogs\u002Fon-media\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fembargo-new-york-times-wall-street-journal-editor-on-trump-and-the-media-233077"},"content":["Baker said"]},". \"I think it's up to the reader to make up their own mind... If you start ascribing a moral intent, as it were, to someone by saying that they've lied, I think you run the risk that you look like you\u2019re not being objective.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"text-align:center;"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fgetdatasheet\u002F"},"content":["Get Data Sheet"]},", Fortune\u2019s technology newsletter."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Legendary news anchor Dan Rather, however, took issue with this approach ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002FtheDanRather\u002Fposts\u002F10157986074875716"},"content":["in a post"]}," on his Facebook page that was widely shared among journalists."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Rather called Baker's argument \"deeply disturbing.\" It is not the proper role of journalists, the former anchor said, \"to meet lies \u2014 especially from someone of Mr. Trump\u2019s stature and power \u2014 by hiding behind semantics and euphemisms. Our role is to call it as we see it, based on solid reporting. When something is, in fact, a demonstrable lie, it is our responsibility to say so.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In his NBC interview, Baker referred to Trump's ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politifact.com\u002Ftruth-o-meter\u002Fstatements\u002F2015\u002Fnov\u002F22\u002Fdonald-trump\u002Ffact-checking-trumps-claim-thousands-new-jersey-ch\u002F"},"content":["repeated statements"]}," that Muslims were seen cheering in New Jersey when the World Trade Center towers fell. The ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]}," reported that there was no evidence this had actually occurred, Baker said, and then left it to the reader to decide."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But even if the standard principle is that something can only be called a lie if we know the intent of the speaker\u2014as the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]}," editor argues it should be\u2014can we not assume that Trump was making those statements with a deliberate intent to mislead voters about Muslim behavior? After all, he said it multiple times, even after it had been proven false."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The same thing goes for many other Trump statements on a wide range of issues. account\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":99234087,"featured_media":1893567,"parent":0,"menu_order":0,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"open","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=1893543"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=1893543"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1893543\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\ Twitter War: User Shut Down Account","mt_seo_description":"A Twitter war against Wendy's resulted in the user shutting down his or her account on the social media website.","mt_seo_keywords":"wendy's twitter war, wendy's twitter troll, wendy's twitter, wendy's twitter account, wendy's social media, wendy's","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"wendy's twitter war, wendy's twitter troll, wendy's twitter, wendy's twitter account, wendy's social media, wendy's","og_title":"Wendy's Kicks Off 2017 By Winning a Twitter Feud","og_description":"Causing a user to delete his account","twitter_text":"Wendy's kicks off 2017 by winning a Twitter feud","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2i76CKZ","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fwendys-twitter-feud-beef-patties\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fwendys-twitter-feud-beef-patties\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1893567,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002Fgettyimages-538458576.jpg","alt":"Wendy's Retail Location I","caption":"Indianapolis, US - June 7, 2016: Wendy's Retail Location. Wendy's is an International Fast Food Restaurant Chain I","credit":"jetcityimage Getty Images","description":"A Twitter war against Wendy's caused one user to deactivate their account.","title":"Wendy's Retail Location I"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":112978,"name":"Wendy's","slug":"wendys","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":112521,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":30,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":13879,"name":"Retail","slug":"retail","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46735,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and updates on the retail sector, including companies like Wal-Mart, Target, Costco, Sears, Home Depot, and other places to shop.","parent":0,"count":7410,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1893306,"date":"2017-01-03T15:48:07","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T20:48:07","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1893306"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T15:48:07","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T20:48:07","slug":"greece-euro-2017","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fgreece-euro-2017\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2ivUV3j","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"How Greece\u2019s Troubled Economy Could Turn Around in 2017"},"content":{"plain":"Violating the terms of its bailout program, the Greek government recently announced that it will distribute a sizeable \u201cChristmas gift\u201d to Greek pensioners even though this requires additional borrowing from the EU since the Greek budget is not balanced and Greece cannot borrow from money markets. The move has prompted the EU finance ministers to freeze implementation of debt restructuring. Greece is at the brink again. This is the modern-day, Greek economic tragedy. But unlike the three-acts ancient Greek tragedies, we\u2019ve seen many acts and often the horrible events happen on stage. Of the main actors, the Greek government repeatedly threatens with suicide elections; the IMF tries to apply the same rules to all countries irrespective of development level; the EU bureaucrats paint a rosy picture with no grounding in reality or economics, and German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble keeps reading the same austerity rulebook no matter what the circumstances. Even worse, there is practically no dialogue among the actors \u2013 they deliver their monologues past each other, each trying to please a different chorus. How did we get here (again), is there hope, and, more importantly, and how does it end? After two large bailouts in 2010 and 2012 from the EU and the IMF, and after a negotiated haircut of \u20ac100 billion off its bonds, Greece was close to recovery in 2014. It had reversed the 2010 15-plus percent deficit and achieved a small primary surplus (before paying interest), reached growth after four years of recession, and even issued new bonds. However, the fiscal consolidation did not happen through spending cuts but rather through large increases in taxation, resulting in a multi-year recession. With Greeks having lost 25% of their income, and unemployment at 25%, disaffected voters brought to power a tiny, radical left party in early 2015. Following a defiant stance in early 2015, which resulted in closed banks, capital controls, reversal of growth and exclusion from money markets, the present radical left Greek government signed an onerous agreement. The agreement provided Greece a new loan of \u20ac87 billion, yet required that Greece achieve a 3.5% of GDP surplus (through more austerity) for a number of years. This target was clearly not feasible, and the Bank of Greece proposed a surplus of 1.5% to 2% of GDP. The IMF agreed with this target, and has asked the EU to restructure Greek debt obligations consistent with this target as well as for implementation of structural reforms that would make the Greek economy competitive. However, the EU has insisted on the 3.5% surplus target and painted an unrealistically rosy picture of the Greek economy to make this target appear feasible, while not pressing Greece on reforms. Greece\u2019s choice was a no-brainer: side with the IMF, have less austerity, have immediate and deep debt restructuring, and implement reforms that will make Greece more competitive and bring it out of the crisis. Instead, the Greek government sided with the EU, accepted higher austerity and less debt restructuring. Why? The Greek government wants to avoid reforming and shrinking the State because civil servants are its main block of voters. Compounding this error, the Greek government has now violated the fiscal agreement and reverted to the defiant tactics of the first half of 2015. But there\u2019s still hope. The solution to the Greek crisis is obvious and has been obvious for some time: make reforms, cut state expenditure, cut taxes, simplify investment procedures, open markets to competition, and proceed with privatizations. The present Greek government has failed in all of these dimensions. Fortunately, for Greece, a pro-reforms consensus is emerging. All opposition parties with the exception of the Communist and the Nazi party are now pro-reform. Additionally, a reformist politician, Kyriakos Mistotakis, has been elected leader of the main opposition party, center-right New Democracy, which presently has a large lead in polls. He has advocated a strictly reformist agenda. There are two additional factors that make reforms more likely to succeed now. First, the IMF fully supports the reforms and is willing to battle with the Europeans for debt restructuring, less austerity, and more reforms. Second, many Greeks, having tried everything else, now see reforms as the only way out of the crisis. Reforms and fiscal discipline is the only way for Greece to survive and prosper in the European Union. The alternative, Grexit, would plunge Greece to poverty and hyperinflation leading to a crisis a-la-Venezuela in Europe. Nicholas Economides is a professor of economics at the NYU Stern School of Business and has advised the Greek government and Bank of Greece.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EViolating the terms of its bailout program, the Greek government recently announced that it will distribute a sizeable \u201cChristmas gift\u201d to Greek pensioners even though this requires additional borrowing from the EU since the Greek budget is not balanced and Greece cannot borrow from money markets. The move has prompted the EU finance ministers to freeze implementation of debt restructuring. The alternative, Grexit, would plunge Greece to poverty and hyperinflation leading to a crisis a-la-Venezuela in Europe.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENicholas Economides is a professor of economics at the NYU Stern School of Business and has advised the Greek government and Bank of Greece\u003C\u002Fem\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Violating the terms of its bailout program, the Greek government recently announced that it will distribute a sizeable \u201cChristmas gift\u201d to Greek pensioners even though this requires additional borrowing from the EU since the Greek budget is not balanced and Greece cannot borrow from money markets. Greece\u2019s Troubled Economy Could Turn Around in 2017","mt_seo_description":"Economic reform and fiscal discipline is the only way Greece can keep from teetering on the brink.","mt_seo_keywords":"Greece, Brexit, bailout, Euro crisis, European Union","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"Greece, Brexit, bailout, Euro crisis, European Union","short_title":"How Greece\u2019s
