2017","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2ivUV3j","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fgreece-euro-2017\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fgreece-euro-2017\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1612626,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F04\u002Fgreece.jpg","alt":"","caption":"","credit":"Photograph by Pacific Press LightRocket via Getty Images","description":"","title":"greece"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":5142,"name":"International","slug":"international","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46731,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News with an international focus on the global marketplace and how the world's connected economies run.","parent":0,"count":7766,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":291878719,"name":"Fortune Insiders","slug":"fortune-insiders","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":122920,"taxonomy":"category","description":"","parent":0,"count":2701,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1891787,"date":"2017-01-03T11:52:35","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T16:52:35","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1891787"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T11:52:35","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T16:52:35","slug":"2017-tech-trends","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002F2017-tech-trends\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hvl9C4","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"15 Trends Every Business Leader Should Watch in 2017"},"content":{"plain":"As technology and digital marketing tools continue to improve, businesses will have to adapt to trends in marketing and consumer behavior. Businesses that are attentive to the trends and changes of 2017 will be able to quickly implement new tools and strategies for greater success and improved customer interaction. Here are 15 trends and changes in products, marketing, and leadership to keep an eye on in the new year. 1. The Internet of Things In 2016, we found our smart devices to be more efficient and capable than ever. Products like Nest allow us to change the environment in our home remotely through other smart devices. In 2017, we\u2019ll continue to see advancements in sensors, software and technology that will allow our devices to be interconnected and speak to one another. Related: The Biggest News Stories That Got Us Talking In 2016 2. Green products Consumers care about corporations that are socially responsible and sustainable. The younger generation is increasingly likely to buy into companies who follow a TOMS give-back model or feature environmentally friendly products and packaging. Companies are aware that millennials are giving priority to those who are socially-conscious and are adapting their products and values accordingly. 3. Companies that connect Rather than directly selling a product, we\u2019ve seen a rise in companies looking to connect consumers with a service. Airbnb, Uber, and Trunk Club allow millennials to lead an asset-light life. The connections these companies provide help build a sense of community while consumers feel they\u2019re getting a service they need. 4. Personalized products Companies are going out of their way to touch each consumer and make products tailored to the individual. Consumers want a sense of independence and will buy from companies who value their individuality. We see examples of this trend in everything from Nike\u2019s Customizable Sneakers to Tesla allowing consumers to completely build and personalize every detail of their new automobile from scratch. Related: Here\u2019s What Your Breakfast Might Look Like in 2017 5. Virtual and augmented reality In 2016, virtual reality became available to consumers through products like the Oculus and Google Daydream Viewer Headset. In 2017, we\u2019ll continue to see advancements in VR and businesses will benefit in areas such as training, education, and productivity. Augmented reality is built on top of VR, with the most recent example being the Microsoft HoloLens which allows for 3D Holograms. 6. Drone technology Drones have become the must-have toy for hobbyists throughout the world. Businesses are starting to leverage the technology for enhanced customer experiences. One example worth noting is VILLAWAY, a company initiating drone property tours of vacation homes in 2017. The use of drone technology for enhanced consumer education is something we will continue to see in the future. 7. Creating a personal brand New and emerging digital platforms allow businesses and individuals to distinguish themselves from competitors by building a personal brand. This personal brand is how a business will gain individuality when marketing themselves to an audience. Social media tools such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and YouTube allow audiences to feel connected to businesses while learning about the brand values and vision. 8. Artificial intelligence In 2017, we\u2019ll see the rise of machines that can learn and complete tasks that would normally require human intelligence. We\u2019ve already caught a glimpse of machines that can problem-solve on their own, like self-driving cars. In the next year, we\u2019ll be exposed to more machines that can adapt and learn skills only we as humans have possessed thus far. You can already even request a fully autonomous Uber. 9. Remote employees As the digital space allows employees to complete work assignments from just about anywhere, more employees are seeking a flexible schedule and the comfort of working from home. Remote employees allow an employer to have access to talent all over the world. Communication tools such as Google Hangouts, FaceTime, and Skype allow employers to have face-to-face meetings with employees who are not physically present. 10. E-commerce The ease and convenience of online shopping is something consumers value, especially with perks like free same-day shipping from Amazon Prime. Social media marketing and Google Adwords make it easy for e-commerce companies to reach their target audience and ensure their ads are being seen by the eyes that matter most. 11. Fitness wearables Consumers are gravitating toward fitness wearables as new technology allows us to track what we eat, how far we walk, and what kinds of exercises we do throughout the day. Fitbit and the Nike Running App provide a competitive and gamified way for consumers to stay active and healthy. We\u2019ll likely see the release of wearables with even more intuitive software in 2017. 12. Big Data and analytics We\u2019ve seen a struggle this last year with businesses gathering misleading data. In 2017, we\u2019ll continue to see even more accurate measurements and customer data. With Facebook continually upgrading and improving analytics, companies will be able to gather even more information about consumers to inform marketing decisions. 13. Video content We\u2019ll see even more brands begin to utilize video content as VR and augmented reality become more mainstream. With the ability to share video content easily on social media through platforms like Snapchat or Facebook Live, brands are looking for new, innovative ways to capture an audience\u2019s attention through video. 14. Social media marketing Social media has become a crucial addition to every brand\u2019s marketing strategy. Platforms such as Instagram and Facebook will continue to improve ads and analytics, making it easier for brands to reach their target consumers. Social media will continue to be an important way for brands to maintain relationships and build a community of loyal customers. 15. Chatbots We\u2019ll continue to see intelligent chatbots like Siri and Alexa who can perform simple tasks and pull information. As the software improves, we\u2019ll see artificial intelligence and human characteristics used to improve the quality of information provided. We may also see chatbots that are able to learn a user\u2019s preferences and utilize those preferences when providing information. Machines will keep getting smarter and new technology will increase productivity among businesses. Remote workers and virtual tours will allow businesses to connect with consumers and employees all over the world. \u2013 Chirag Kulkarni is the co-founder of Taco and Insightfully","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EAs technology and digital marketing tools continue to improve, businesses will have to adapt to trends in marketing and consumer behavior.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EBusinesses that are attentive to the trends and changes of 2017 will be able to quickly implement new tools and strategies for greater success and improved customer interaction.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHere are 15 trends and changes in products, marketing, and leadership t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eo keep an eye on in the new year.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E1. internet of things, drones, green products, personalized technology, chatbots","twitter_text":"15 trends every business leader should watch in 2017.","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2hvl9C4","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002F2017-tech-trends\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002F2017-tech-trends\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1765421,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002Fdrone-2.jpg","alt":"","caption":"","credit":"Photograph by Bruce Bennett -- Getty Images","description":"","title":"drone 2"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":447818820,"name":"predictions 2017","slug":"predictions-2017","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":185763,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":2,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":10585,"name":"Venture","slug":"venture","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46732,"taxonomy":"category","description":"Fortune Venture is a destination committed to inspiring and informing entrepreneurial founders, creators, and disruptors.","parent":0,"count":2347,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1887580,"date":"2017-01-03T10:23:48","date_gmt":"2017-01-03T15:23:48","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1887580"},"paid":false,"modified":"2017-01-03T10:23:48","modified_gmt":"2017-01-03T15:23:48","slug":"why-2017-will-see-desperate-department-stores-and-anxious-apparel-chains","type":"post","subtype":"list","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fwhy-2017-will-see-desperate-department-stores-and-anxious-apparel-chains\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2i6Q2OM","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why 2017 Will See Desperate Department Stores and Anxious Apparel Chains"},"content":{"plain":"It was a hard year for many retailers. Amazon.com amzn continued to run away with the e-commerce prize, and consumers, though in much better shape financially than they have been in many years, are getting increasingly bargain-hungry. The result has been declining sales at many major retailers (particularly department stores) and store closings by the hundreds. But a new year offers the industry a clean slate, whether it be a new CEO or new initiatives to break that sales skid. Indeed, 2017 will be a decisive year for many retailers, as investors will feel many have had enough time to show they can figure out a way to update how they do business in the e-commerce era. Target tgt and Kohl&#8217;s kss in particular are under pressure to show their turnarounds are still on track. Meanwhile Walmart wmt can&#8217;t let up for a second if it hopes to begin to narrow the e-commerce gap with Amazon. Department stores up and down the price spectrum are under growing pressure to show they can still be relevant and central to the shopping experience. And apparel chains have been talking for about two years about how they plan to address fast fashion and increase the quality of their products agin. 2017 promises to be a decisive year in which retailers plow ahead in the internet era and which get left behind, possibly for good. Here are the top 10 stories in Fortune will follow most closely in 2017. 1) What Will Macy&#8217;s New CEO Change? Macy&#8217;s m announced in June its long time CEO Terry Lundgren would be stepping down in 2017 and be replaced by veteran Macy&#8217;s executive Jeff Gennette. Though well regarded, he&#8217;ll have to prove that a 33-year company veteran will be up to the task of renewing the department store chain with fresh ideas at a time people are buying their clothes and beauty products elsewhere. Macy&#8217;s has been closing dozens of stores and doing everything from beefing up its wedding business to adding Apple aapl boutiques, and yet the sales declines go on. 2) Will Gap Inc Snap Its Losing Streak? The owner of Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic has reported seven straight quarters of comparable sales declines and the turnaround CEO Art Peck has been promising has been slow in coming. He is trying to make the apparel giant more nimble and better able to react to trends and increase the quality of clothes at a time consumer see apparel as a commodity. The company has managed to cut costs, and Old Navy, its biggest brand seems to be back on track, but Peck has now been in the corner office for almost two years, so any continuation of Gap Inc&#8217;s problems in 2017 will be on him. 3) Will Barnes &amp; Noble Find a CEO Who&#8217;ll Stay? Barnes &amp; Noble stunned the retail world this summer when it fired CEO Ron Boir after barely more than year, pronouncing the former Sears Canada CEO a &#8220;poor fit&#8221; with the bookseller, and dealing with its third chief executive exit in three year. So the retailer turned to founder and top shareholder Len Riggio to steer the ship while it looks yet again for a new boss. Barnes &amp; Noble got a bit of a break from the plateauing of e-books, but its online sales are in decline and its stores in need of an update. The retailer needs to show there is a room for it between Amazon.com and the resurgence of independent bookstores. 4) What Will Happen Next With Target&#8217;s Food Business? One of Target tgt CEO Brian Cornell&#8217;s big plans when he started two years ago was to fix the discounter&#8217;s food business and give it a more defined raison d&#8217;tre. But in 2016, the executive he brought in to fix the grocery business left and Cornell himself said Target had no intention of becoming a full service grocer. So that leaves unanswered questions about Target&#8217;s food strategy. Grocery is a key driver of shopper traffic and with Walmart aggressively upgrading its food areas, Target stands to lose a lot of its overall business while it figures this out. 5) Will Jet.com Send Walmart&#8217;s Online Sales Through the Roof? Walmart surprised many this summer when it shelled out $3 billion to buy Jet.com in the hopes of rejuvenating and re-igniting its online business. The retailer has added millions of items to its online assortment thanks to its marketplace overhaul and online sales growth is on the upswing again. At the same time, it remains to be seen how Jet.com itself can help Walmart&#8217;s namesake website and there is the chance for cultural clashes between the two as they integrate. 6) Will Sears Make It Through the Year? Well it should, despite itself. Sears Holdings shld has already shown us for the past decade how a retailer can hang on for a loooong time despite sharply declining sales year in, year out. But lately, Sears sales declines are getting worse and it is running out of things to sell off to maintain a cash cushion. And a new threat has emerged: J.C. Penney jcp has resumed selling appliances for the first time since 1983, taking aim at one of Sears&#8217; biggest businesses. CEO Eddie Lampert&#8217;s promised turnaround still hasn&#8217;t materialized, in fact its problems are worsening. And he&#8217;ll be able to kick the can down the road for only so much longer. 7) Can Whole Foods&#8217; New 365 Chain Win It New Shoppers? Whole Foods Market wfm opened its first low price &#8220;365&#8221; grocery stores this year and plans to ramp that up significantly with 10 more in 2017, a much bigger test for a chain meant to win the grocer derided by some as &#8220;Whole Paycheck&#8221; for its high prices more millennial shoppers. But Whole Foods will be going up against a Walmart that has spent a fortune upgrading its grocery aisles and added many fancier items. At the same time, with business slowing at its main grocery chain, Whole Foods needs 365 to be a home run. 8) Here Come More Germans! The ramped up expansion of German discount grocer Aldi in the last few years has put a ton of pressure on the likes of Walmart and Kroger kr in the competition for lower income consumers with its inexpensive, no frills stores and popular private brands. But in 2017, a brand new German rival is hitting U.S. shores: Lidl is planning to open 150 stores, with more to come later. The growing ubiquity of small format, low cost food stores threatens to upend the U.S. grocery industry and force Walmart, Whole Foods et al to really raise their game. 9) Will Luxury Department Stores Get Back on Track? Upscale retailers Neiman Marcus, Macy&#8217;s m Bloomingdale&#8217;s, Nordstrom and HBC&#8217;s hbc Saks Fifth Avenue have all had trouble this year getting people to come to their department stores. (Their outlet chains are doing fine.) Shoppers no longer want to wait nine months from when they see something at a runway to show to when they can buy it. And the internet has made it easier to comparison-shop turning even luxury items into commodities. So these chains are all investing in upgrading their stores, focusing on getting more exclusive product to win back some pricing power and seeking to quicken the product cycle to react more quickly to how younger luxe shoppers buy, rather than their older mainstay customers. 10) Can J.C. Penney Continue to Outperform Rivals? Penney has worn the Comeback Kid moniker for a couple of years now, regularly outperforming Kohl&#8217;s and Macy&#8217;s, among others in sales growth. And under CEO Marvin Ellison, the retailer has shifted the focus away from apparel, boosted its private label brands, returned to appliance sales and updated its woefully inadequate e-commerce. So far that has worked. But Penney&#8217;s comparable sales declined in the third quarter of 2016 and it has cut the long hanging fruit in its cost reductions. With Macy&#8217;s and Sears closing dozens of stores each, many malls they co-anchor with Penney will lose traffic, something that will hurt Penney. Ellison is betting the market share he will win from those rivals will more than offset sales lost to shoppers who are going AWOL at the mall.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIt was a hard year for many retailers. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazoncom-18\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmazon.com\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"amzn\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Famazon-com-18\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eamzn\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F02\u002Famazon-cyber-monday-2\u002F\"\u003Econtinued to run away with the e-commerce prize\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and consumers, though in much better shape financially than they have been in many years, are getting increasingly bargain-hungry. The result has been declining sales at many major retailers (particularly department stores) and store closings by the hundreds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut a new year offers the industry a clean slate, whether it be a new CEO or new initiatives to break that sales skid. Barnes &amp; Noble got a bit of a break from the plateauing of e-books, but its online sales are in decline and its stores in need of an update. The retailer needs to show there is a room for it between Amazon.com and the resurgence of independent bookstores.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E4) What Will Happen Next With Target&#8217;s Food Business?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne of Target \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"tgt\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Ftarget-38\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Etgt\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003ECEO Brian Cornell&#8217;s big plans when he started two years ago was to fix the discounter&#8217;s food business and give it a more defined raison d&#8217;tre. But in 2016, the executive he brought in to fix the grocery business left and Cornell himself said Target had \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F14\u002Ftarget-grocery\u002F\"\u003Eno intention of becoming a full service grocer\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. So that leaves unanswered questions about Target&#8217;s food strategy. Grocery is a key driver of shopper traffic and with Walmart aggressively upgrading its food areas, Target stands to lose a lot of its overall business while it figures this out.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E5) Will Jet.com Send Walmart&#8217;s Online Sales Through the Roof?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWalmart surprised many this summer when it \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F20\u002Fwalmart-acquisition-jetcom\u002F\"\u003Eshelled out $3 billion to buy Jet.com\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in the hopes of rejuvenating and re-igniting its online business. The retailer has added millions of items to its online assortment thanks to its marketplace overhaul and online sales growth is on the upswing again. At the same time, it remains to be seen how Jet.com itself can help Walmart&#8217;s namesake website and there is the chance for cultural clashes between the two as they integrate.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E6) Will Sears Make It Through the Year?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWell it should, despite itself. Sears Holdings \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"shld\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsears-holdings-111\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Eshld\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E has already shown us for the past decade how a retailer can hang on for a loooong time despite \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F08\u002Fsears-stores-sales-results\u002F\"\u003Esharply declining sales year in, year out\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. But lately, Sears sales declines are getting worse and it is running out of things to sell off to maintain a cash cushion. And a new threat has emerged: \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjc-penney-228\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJ.C. Penney\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"jcp\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fjc-penney-228\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ejcp\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E has resumed selling appliances for the first time since 1983, taking aim at one of Sears&#8217; biggest businesses. CEO Eddie Lampert&#8217;s promised turnaround still hasn&#8217;t materialized, in fact its problems are worsening. And he&#8217;ll be able to kick the can down the road for only so much longer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E7) Can Whole Foods&#8217; New 365 Chain Win It New Shoppers?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fwhole-foods-market-181\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EWhole Foods\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Market \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"wfm\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fwhole-foods-market-181\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ewfm\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E opened its first low price &#8220;365&#8221; grocery stores this year and plans to ramp that up \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F04\u002F28\u002Fwhole-foods-365-chain\u002F\"\u003Esignificantly with 10 more in 2017\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a much bigger test for a chain meant to win the grocer derided by some as &#8220;Whole Paycheck&#8221; for its high prices more millennial shoppers. But Whole Foods will be going up against a Walmart that has spent a fortune \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F02\u002Fwalmart-is-giving-its-grocery-aisles-a-makeover\u002F\"\u003Eupgrading its grocery aisles\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and added many fancier items. At the same time, with business slowing at its main grocery chain, Whole Foods needs 365 to be a home run.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E8) Here Come More Germans!\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe ramped up expansion of German discount grocer Aldi in the last few years has put a ton of pressure on the likes of Walmart and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fkroger-17\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EKroger\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"kr\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fkroger-17\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ekr\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E in the competition for lower income consumers with its inexpensive, no frills stores and popular private brands. But in 2017, a brand new German rival is hitting U.S. shores: \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.businessinsider.com\u002Flidls-expansion-plans-in-the-us-2016-9\"\u003ELidl is planning to open 150 stores,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E with more to come later. The growing ubiquity of small format, low cost food stores threatens to upend the U.S. grocery industry and force Walmart, Whole Foods et al to really raise their game.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E9) Will Luxury Department Stores Get Back on Track?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUpscale retailers Neiman Marcus, Macy&#8217;s \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"m\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fmacys-103\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Em\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E Bloomingdale&#8217;s, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnordstrom-197\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENordstrom\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and HBC&#8217;s \u003Cspan class=\"tickershortcode quotecard_hook unprocessed neutral\" data-symbol=\"hbc\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"wrapper trend-wrapper\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003Ca class=\"exit_trigger_set\" href=\"\u002Fcompany\u002Fhbc\u002F\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"ticker\"\u003Ehbc\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\u003Cspan class=\"change percent\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\n\t\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E Saks Fifth Avenue have all had trouble this year getting people to come to their department stores. (Their outlet chains are doing fine.) Shoppers \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F13\u002Fneiman-marcus-sales-report\u002F\"\u003Eno longer want to wait nine months\u003C\u002Fa\u003E from when they see something at a runway to show to when they can buy it. And the internet has made it easier to comparison-shop turning even luxury items into commodities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo these chains are all investing in upgrading their stores, focusing on getting more exclusive product to win back some pricing power and seeking to quicken the product cycle to react more quickly to how younger luxe shoppers buy, rather than their older mainstay customers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Ch2\u003E10) Can J.C. Penney Continue to Outperform Rivals?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPenney has worn the Comeback Kid moniker for a couple of years now, regularly outperforming Kohl&#8217;s and Macy&#8217;s, among others in sales growth. And under CEO Marvin Ellison, the retailer has shifted the focus away from apparel, boosted its private label brands, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fj-c-penney-reinvention\u002F\"\u003Ereturned to appliance sales and updated its woefully inadequate e-commerce\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. So far that has worked. But Penney&#8217;s comparable sales declined in the third quarter of 2016 and it has cut the long hanging fruit in its cost reductions. With Macy&#8217;s and Sears closing dozens of stores each, many malls they co-anchor with Penney will lose traffic, something that will hurt Penney. Ellison is betting the market share he will win from those rivals will more than offset sales lost to shoppers who are going AWOL at the mall.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It was a hard year for many retailers. The result has been declining sales at many major retailers (particularly department stores) and store closings by the hundreds."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But a new year offers the industry a clean slate, whether it be a new CEO or new initiatives to break that sales skid. Though well regarded, he'll have to prove that a 33-year company veteran will be up to the task of renewing the department store chain with fresh ideas at a time people are buying their clothes and beauty products elsewhere. Macy's has been closing dozens of stores and doing everything from beefing up its wedding business to adding ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fapple-3\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Apple"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"aapl"},"content":[]}," boutiques, and yet the sales declines go on."]},{"tag":"h2","attributes":[],"content":["2) Will Gap Inc Snap Its Losing Streak?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The owner of Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic has reported ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.gapinc.com\u002Fcontent\u002Fattachments\u002Fgapinc\u002FComp-Sales\u002Fcomp_sales_doc2014.pdf"},"content":["seven straight quarters of comparable sales declines"]}," and the turnaround CEO Art Peck has been promising has been slow in coming. He is trying to make the apparel giant more nimble and better able to react to trends and increase the quality of clothes at a time consumer see apparel as a commodity. The company has managed to cut costs, and Old Navy, its biggest brand seems to be back on track, but Peck has now been in the corner office for almost two years, so any continuation of Gap Inc's problems in 2017 will be on him."]},{"tag":"h2","attributes":[],"content":["3) Will Barnes &amp; Noble Find a CEO Who'll Stay?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fbarnes-noble-427\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Barnes &amp; Noble"]}," stunned the retail world this summer when it f",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F16\u002Fbarnes-noble-ceo\u002F"},"content":["ired CEO Ron Boir after barely more than year"]},", pronouncing the former ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fsears-holdings-111\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Sears"]}," Canada CEO a \"poor fit\" with the bookseller, and dealing with its third chief executive exit in three year. So the retailer turned to founder and top shareholder Len Riggio to steer the ship while it looks yet again for a new boss. Barnes &amp; Noble got a bit of a break from the plateauing of e-books, but its online sales are in decline and its stores in need of an update. The retailer needs to show there is a room for it between Amazon.com and the resurgence of independent bookstores."]},{"tag":"h2","attributes":[],"content":["4) What Will Happen Next With Target's Food Business?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["One of Target ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"tgt"},"content":[]},"CEO Brian Cornell's big plans when he started two years ago was to fix the discounter's food business and give it a more defined raison d'tre. But in 2016, the executive he brought in to fix the grocery business left and Cornell himself said Target had ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F14\u002Ftarget-grocery\u002F"},"content":["no intention of becoming a full service grocer"]},". So that leaves unanswered questions about Target's food strategy. Grocery is a key driver of shopper traffic and with Walmart aggressively upgrading its food areas, Target stands to lose a lot of its overall business while it figures this out."]},{"tag":"h2","attributes":[],"content":["5) Will Jet.com Send Walmart's Online Sales Through the Roof?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Walmart surprised many this summer when it ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F20\u002Fwalmart-acquisition-jetcom\u002F"},"content":["shelled out $3 billion to buy Jet.com"]}," in the hopes of rejuvenating and re-igniting its online business. The retailer has added millions of items to its online assortment thanks to its marketplace overhaul and online sales growth is on the upswing again. At the same time, it remains to be seen how Jet.com itself can help Walmart's namesake website and there is the chance for cultural clashes between the two as they integrate."]},{"tag":"h2","attributes":[],"content":["6) Will Sears Make It Through the Year?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Well it should, despite itself. But lately, Sears sales declines are getting worse and it is running out of things to sell off to maintain a cash cushion. Penney"]}," ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"jcp"},"content":[]}," has resumed selling appliances for the first time since 1983, taking aim at one of Sears' biggest businesses. CEO Eddie Lampert's promised turnaround still hasn't materialized, in fact its problems are worsening. And he'll be able to kick the can down the road for only so much longer."]},{"tag":"h2","attributes":[],"content":["7) Can Whole Foods' New 365 Chain Win It New Shoppers?"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fwhole-foods-market-181\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Whole Foods"]}," Market ",{"tag":"stock","attributes":{"symbol":"wfm"},"content":[]}," opened its first low price \"365\" grocery stores this year and plans to ramp that up ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F04\u002F28\u002Fwhole-foods-365-chain\u002F"},"content":["significantly with 10 more in 2017"]},", a much bigger test for a chain meant to win the grocer derided by some as \"Whole Paycheck\" for its high prices more millennial shoppers. What will Macy's new CEO change?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EMacy's [fortune-stock symbol=\"m\"] announced in June its long time CEO Terry Lundgren would be stepping down in 2017 and be replaced by \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F23\u002Fmacys-next-ceo\u002F\"\u003Eveteran Macy's executive Jeff Gennette\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Though well regarded, he'll have to prove that a 33-year company veteranwill be up to the task of renewing the department store chain with fresh ideas at a time people are buying their clothes and beauty products elsewhere. Macy's has been closing dozens of stores and doing everything from beefing up its wedding business to adding Apple [fortune-stock symbol=\"aapl\"] boutiques, and yet the sales declines go on.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":769559},{"title":"2) Will Gap Inc snap its losing streak?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EThe owner of Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic has reported \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.gapinc.com\u002Fcontent\u002Fattachments\u002Fgapinc\u002FComp-Sales\u002Fcomp_sales_doc2014.pdf\"\u003Eseven straight quarters of comparable sales declines\u003C\u002Fa\u003Eand the turnaround CEO Art Peck has been promising has been slow in coming. He is trying to make the apparel giant more nimble and better able to react to trends and increase the quality of clothes at a time consumer see apparel as a commodity. The company has managed to cut costs, and Old Navy, its biggest brand seems to be back on track, but Peck has now been in the corner office for almost two years, so any continuation of Gap Inc's problems in 2017 will be on him.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1493671},{"title":"3) Will Barnes & Noble find a CEO who'll stay?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EBarnes &amp; Noble stunned the retail world this summer when it f\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F08\u002F16\u002Fbarnes-noble-ceo\u002F\"\u003Eired CEO Ron Boir after barely more than year\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, pronouncing the former Sears Canada CEO a \"poor fit\" with the bookseller, and dealing with its third chief executive exit in three year. So the retailer turned to founder and top shareholder Len Riggio to steer the ship while it looks yet again for a new boss. Barnes &amp; Noble got a bit of a break from the plateauing of e-books, but its online sales are in decline and its stores in need of an update. The retailer needs to show there is a room for it between Amazon.com and the resurgence of independent bookstores.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1709311},{"title":"4) What will happen next with Target's food business?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EOne of Target [fortune-stock symbol=\"tgt\"]CEO Brian Cornell's big plans when he started two years ago was to fix the discounter's food business and give it a more defined raison d'tre. But in 2016, the executive he brought in to fix the grocery business left and Cornell himself said Target had \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F14\u002Ftarget-grocery\u002F\"\u003Eno intention of becoming a full service grocer\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. So that leaves unanswered the question of what exactly does Target stand for in the food aisle. Grocery is a key driver of shopper traffic and with Walmart aggressively upgrading its food areas, Target stands to lose a lot of its overall business while it figures this out.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1426046},{"title":"5) Will Jet.com send Walmart's online sales through the roof?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EWalmart surprised many this summer when it \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F09\u002F20\u002Fwalmart-acquisition-jetcom\u002F\"\u003Eshelled out $3 billion to buy jet.com\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in the hopes of rejuvenating and re-igniting its online business. The retailer has added millions of items to its online assortment thanks to its marketplace overhaul and online sales growth is on the upswing again. At the same time, it remains to be soon how jet.com itself can help Walmart's namesake web site and there is the chance for cultural clashes between the two as they integrate.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1759107},{"title":"6) Will Sears make it through the year?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EWell it should, despite itself. Sears Holdings[fortune-stock symbol=\"shld\"] has already shown us for the past decade how a retailer can hang on for a loooong time despite \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F08\u002Fsears-stores-sales-results\u002F\"\u003Esharply declining sales year in, year out\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. But lately, Sears sales declines are getting worse and it is running out of things to sell off to maintain a cash cushion. And a new threat has emerged: J.C. Penney [fortune-stock symbol=\"jcp\"] has resumed selling appliances for the first time since 1983, taking aimed at one of Sears' biggest businesses.CEO Eddie Lampert's promised turnaround still hasn't materialized, in fact its problems are worsening. And he'll be able to kick the can down the road for only so much longer.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1663808},{"title":"7) Will Whole Foods' new 365 chain win it new shoppers?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EWhole Foods Market [fortune-stock symbol=\"wfm\"] opened its first low price \"365\" grocery stores this year and plans to ramp that up \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F04\u002F28\u002Fwhole-foods-365-chain\u002F\"\u003Esignificantly with 10 more in 2017\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a much bigger test for achain meant to win thegrocer derided by some as \"Whole Paycheck\" for its high prices more millennial shoppers. But Whole Foods will be going up against a Walmart that has spent a fortune \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F06\u002F02\u002Fwalmart-is-giving-its-grocery-aisles-a-makeover\u002F\"\u003Eupgrading its grocery aisles\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and added many fancier items. At the same time, with business slowing at its main grocery chain, Whole Foods needs 365 to be a home run.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1707677},{"title":"8) Here come (more) Germans!","description":"\u003Cp\u003EThe ramped up expansion of German discount grocer Aldi in the last few years has put a ton of pressure on the likes of Walmart and Kroger [fortune-stock symbol=\"kr\"] in the competition for lower income consumers, what with its inexpensive, no frills stores and popular private brands. But in 2017, a brand new German rival is hitting U.S. shores: \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.businessinsider.com\u002Flidls-expansion-plans-in-the-us-2016-9\"\u003ELidl is planning to open 150 stores,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E with more to come later. The growing ubiquity of small format, low cost food stores threatens to upend the U.S. grocery industry and force Walmart, Whole Foods et al to really raise their game.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1567402},{"title":"9) Will luxury department stores get back on track?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EUpscale retailers Neiman Marcus, Macy's [fortune-stock symbol=\"m\"] Bloomingdale's, Nordstrom and HBC's [fortune-stock symbol=\"hbc\"] Saks Fifth Avenue have all had trouble this year getting people to come to their department stores. (Their outlet chains are doing fine.) Shoppers \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F13\u002Fneiman-marcus-sales-report\u002F\"\u003Eno longer want to wait nine months\u003C\u002Fa\u003E from when they see something at a runway to show to when they can buy it. And the internet has made it easier to comparison-shop turning even luxury items into commodities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo these chains are all investing in upgrading their stores, focusing on getting more exclusive product to win back some pricing power and seeking to quicken the product cycle to react more quickly to how younger luxe shoppers buy, rather than their older mainstay customers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":908743},{"title":"10) Can J.C. Penney continue to outperform rivals?","description":"\u003Cp\u003EPenney has worn the Comeback Kid moniker for a couple of years now, regularly outperforming Kohl's and Macy's, among others in sales growth. And under CEO Marvin Ellison, the retailer has shifted the focus away from apparel, boosted its private label brands, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fj-c-penney-reinvention\u002F\"\u003Ereturned to appliance sales and updated its woefully inadequate e-commerce\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. So far that has worked. But Penney's comparable sales declined in the third quarter of 2016 and it has cut the long hanging fruit in its cost reductions. With Macy's and Sears closing dozens of stores each, many malls they co-anchor with Penney will lose traffic, something that will hurt Penney. Ellison is betting the market share he will win from those rivals will more than offset sales lost to shoppers who are going AWOL at the mall.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","image":1865398}]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2i6Q2OM","mt_seo_title":"Retail Trends for 2017: Walmart, Macy's, Target and Amazon","mt_seo_description":"A look ahead at retail in 2017 as many stores, particularly department stores and specialty clothing chains, look to grow again.","mt_seo_keywords":"apparel, retail, department stores, amazon, e-commerce, grocery, walmart, target, whole foods","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"apparel, retail, department stores, amazon, e-commerce, grocery, walmart, target, whole foods","short_title":"2017: The Year Ahead in Retail","twitter_text":"Here is a look ahead at the year in retail in 2017.","og_title":"Why 2017 Will See Desperate Department Stores and Anxious Apparel Chains","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fwhy-2017-will-see-desperate-department-stores-and-anxious-apparel-chains\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F03\u002Fwhy-2017-will-see-desperate-department-stores-and-anxious-apparel-chains\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1868057,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F11\u002F625644584.jpg","alt":"US-ECONOMY-SHOPPING","caption":"Thanksgiving Day shoppers push loaded up carts during the \"Black Friday\" sales at a Target store in Culver City, California on November 24, 2016. \nUS retailers kicked off the unofficial start of the holiday retail season with sales that begin on the Thanksgiving holiday. \u002F AFP \u002F Mark RALSTON        (Photo credit should read MARK RALSTON\u002FAFP\u002FGetty Images)","credit":"MARK RALSTON AFP\u002FGetty Images","description":"","title":"US-ECONOMY-SHOPPING"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":13879,"name":"Retail","slug":"retail","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46735,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and updates on the retail sector, including companies like Wal-Mart, Target, Costco, Sears, Home Depot, and other places to shop.","parent":0,"count":7410,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":13879,"name":"Retail","slug":"retail","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":46735,"taxonomy":"category","description":"News and updates on the retail sector, including companies like Wal-Mart, Target, Costco, Sears, Home Depot, and other places to shop.","parent":0,"count":7410,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1891198,"date":"2016-12-30T05:00:26","date_gmt":"2016-12-30T10:00:26","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1891198"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-30T15:55:53","modified_gmt":"2016-12-30T20:55:53","slug":"euro-outlook-2017","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Feuro-outlook-2017\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iqEP8X","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Why 2017 Could See the Collapse of the Euro"},"content":{"plain":"Europe has not been doing well. Just this year, GDP per capita for the Eurozone as a whole finally returned to pre-crisis levels. It is claiming victory in Spain\u2014even though unemployment remains near 20% and youth unemployment is more than twice that\u2014simply because things are better today than they have been since the euro crisis began a half decade ago. Greece remains in a severe depression. Growth for the Eurozone over the past year has been an anemic 1.6%, and that number is twice the average growth rate from 2005 to 2015. Historians are already speaking of the Eurozone\u2019s lost decade, and it\u2019s possible they\u2019ll soon be writing about its last decade, too. The euro was introduced in 2002, but the cracks in the single currency arrangement, which began in 1999, became evident with the 2008 global financial crisis. Economists had predicted that the test of the euro would occur when the region faced a shock, and Europe was unlucky in facing such a big shock coming from across the Atlantic so soon after its creation. By 2010, the euro crisis had become full blown, with interest rates on the sovereign debt of the \u201cperiphery\u201d\u2014Greece, Spain, Ireland, and Portugal\u2014soaring to unheard-of levels. But a closer look at the Eurozone shows imbalances building up from the very beginning\u2014with money rushing into the periphery countries in the misguided belief that eliminating exchange rate risk had somehow eliminated all risk. This illustrates one of the key flaws in the construction of the Eurozone: It was based on the belief that if only government didn\u2019t mess things up\u2014if it kept deficits below 3% of GDP, debt below 60% of GDP, and inflation below 2% per annum\u2014the market would ensure growth and stability. Those numbers, and the underlying ideas, had no basis in either theory or evidence. Ireland and Spain, two of the worst afflicted countries, actually had surpluses before the crisis. The crisis caused their deficits and debt, not the other way around. The hope was that fiscal and monetary discipline would result in convergence, enabling the single-currency system to work even better. Instead, there has been divergence, with the rich countries getting richer and the poor getting poorer, and within countries, the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer. But it was the very structure of the Eurozone that predictably led to this. The single market, for instance, made it easy for money to leave the banks of the weaker countries, forcing these banks to contract lending, weakening the weak further. Economists assessing the prospects of a single currency arrangement some quarter century ago emphasized the importance of sufficient labor mobility and an adequately large common budget to buffer against shocks as well as sufficient economic similarity among the countries. But the euro took away two of the critical instruments for adjustment\u2014the exchange and interest rates\u2014and didn\u2019t put anything in their place. There was no common deposit insurance, no common way of resolving problems in the banking sector, and no common unemployment insurance scheme. Equally important, these early discussions ignored the importance of intellectual convergence: There is a huge gap in perceptions of what makes for good policies, especially between Germany and much of the rest of Europe. These differences are longstanding. They were evident to me when I chaired the Economic Policy Committee of the OECD in the mid-1990s. If anything, there has been divergence here, too. Thus, the austerity policy\u2014which Germany thought should have brought a quick return to growth\u2014has failed miserably in virtually every country in which it has been tried. The consequences were predictable, and predicted by most serious economists around the world. So too, many of the particular structural reforms have actually weakened the countries on which they have been imposed, lowering growth and increasing their trade deficits. A huge democratic deficit has since opened up: citizens in Greece, Spain, and Portugal have all voted in large numbers for parties opposed to austerity. Yet, they have felt they have no choice but to accept the demands of Germany. Citizens were never told that when they joined the euro, they would be giving up their economic sovereignty. The ambition of the euro was to bring greater prosperity to Europe. This, in turn, would promote economic and political integration. The euro was a political project, but the politics weren\u2019t strong enough to create the institutional arrangements that would ensure success. With the euro leading to stagnation and worse, it is no surprise that it has led to increasing divisiveness rather than to more solidarity. Today, it seems that the euro, which was supposed to be a means to an end, has become an end in itself\u2014the pursuit of which poses perhaps the single most important threat to the European project. In response to the repeated crises, Europe has made reforms, but they have been too little, too late. Some may actually be counterproductive: Having a system of common supervision, without adequate sensitivity to local macro-conditions and without common deposit insurance may actually exacerbate divergence. Meanwhile, the region has the misfortune of being repeatedly bombarded with crises, especially the refugee crisis. With unemployment in so many countries so high\u2014at least partly because of the euro\u2014those seeking a new future wish to move to where there are jobs, resulting in a few countries bearing the brunt of the wave of migrants. And naturally, countries where unemployment is high resist having new workers competing for the scarce jobs. Europe has been engaged in brinkmanship, but the danger of brinkmanship is that there is a high probability that eventually one goes over the brink. Markets sense that the system is not viable in the long run\u2014speculators attack when they smell blood. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi\u2019s assertion that he will do \u201cwhatever it takes\u201d has worked wonders\u2014for longer than anyone expected. But it is a confidence trick: It works only because market participants believe it will work. These market forces are intertwined with politics. Voters who should be unhappy\u2014simply because they have done so poorly for such a long time\u2014have expressed their anger by voting against the centrist parties of the left and right. The dissidents are in the ascendancy. &nbsp; Perhaps European leaders, sensing the urgency of the moment, will finally make the reforms in the structure of the Eurozone that will enable a single currency arrangement to work\u2014to achieve a shared prosperity. Perhaps 2017 will be the year in which the reform of the Eurozone really takes hold. In order for a single currency system to work, there has to be more Europe\u2014more solidarity; more willingness of the stronger countries to help the weaker; more willingness to create institutions like a common deposit insurance and a common unemployment scheme\u2014than the current halfway house, which is simply not viable. But the failures of the Eurozone make such reforms increasingly hard. It is at least as likely that the political forces are going in the other direction, and if that is the case, it may be only a matter of time before Europe looks back on the euro as an interesting, well-intentioned experiment that failed\u2014at great cost to the citizens of Europe and their democracies. Joseph E. Stiglitz is a professor at Columbia University, recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, 2001, and most recently, author of The Euro: How a Common Currency Threatens the Future of Europe, W.W. Norton, 2016.","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EEurope has not been doing well. Just this year, GDP per capita for the Eurozone as a whole finally returned to pre-crisis levels. It is claiming victory in Spain\u2014even though unemployment remains near 20% and youth unemployment is more than twice that\u2014simply because things are better today than they have been since the euro crisis began a half decade ago. Greece remains in a severe depression. value=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpubads.g.doubleclick.net\u002Fgampad\u002Fads?env=vp&#038;gdfp_req=1&#038;impl=s&#038;output=xml_vast2&#038;iu=\u002F8484\u002Ffort\u002Fvideo_bc\u002Finternational_bc&#038;sz=1000x1&#038;cust_params=tags%3Dbrexit%2Ceuro%2Ceurozone%2Ceurozonecollapse%2Cjamiedimon%2Cjpmorgan%26ch%3Dinternational%26topic%3Dbrexit&#038;unviewed_position_start=1&#038;correlator=%5Btimestamp%5D\"\u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fobject\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\t\t\t\u003Cscript type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E\n\t\t\t\tbrightcove.createExperiences();\n\t\t\t\u003C\u002Fscript\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPerhaps European leaders, sensing the urgency of the moment, will finally make the reforms in the structure of the Eurozone that will enable a single currency arrangement to work\u2014to achieve a shared prosperity. Perhaps 2017 will be the year in which the reform of the Eurozone really takes hold.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn order for a single currency system to work, there has to be more Europe\u2014more solidarity; more willingness of the stronger countries to help the weaker; more willingness to create institutions like a common deposit insurance and a common unemployment scheme\u2014than the current halfway house, which is simply not viable. But the failures of the Eurozone make such reforms increasingly hard. It is at least as likely that the political forces are going in the other direction, and if that is the case, it may be only a matter of time before Europe looks back on the euro as an interesting, well-intentioned experiment that failed\u2014at great cost to the citizens of Europe and their democracies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EJoseph E. Stiglitz is a professor at Columbia University, recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, 2001, and most recently, author of The Euro: How a Common Currency Threatens the Future of Europe, W.W. Norton, 2016. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Europe has not been doing well. Just this year, GDP per capita for the Eurozone as a whole finally returned to pre-crisis levels. It is claiming victory in Spain\u2014even though unemployment remains near 20% and youth unemployment is more than twice that\u2014simply because things are better today than they have been since the euro crisis began a half decade ago. Greece remains in a severe depression. Growth for the Eurozone over the past year has been an anemic 1.6%, and that number is ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["twice "]},"the average growth rate from 2005 to 2015. Historians are already speaking of the Eurozone\u2019s lost decade, and it\u2019s possible they\u2019ll soon be writing about its ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["last "]},"decade, too."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The euro was introduced in 2002, but the cracks in the single currency arrangement, which began in 1999, became evident with the 2008 global financial crisis. Economists had predicted that the test of the euro would occur when the region faced a shock, and Europe was unlucky in facing such a big shock coming from across the Atlantic so soon after its creation. By 2010, the euro crisis had become full blown, with interest rates on the sovereign debt of the \u201cperiphery\u201d\u2014Greece, Spain, Ireland, and Portugal\u2014soaring to unheard-of levels. But a closer look at the Eurozone shows imbalances building up from the very beginning\u2014with money rushing into the periphery countries in the misguided belief that eliminating exchange rate risk had somehow eliminated all risk."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This illustrates one of the key flaws in the construction of the Eurozone: It was based on the belief that if only government didn\u2019t mess things up\u2014if it kept deficits below 3% of GDP, debt below 60% of GDP, and inflation below 2% per annum\u2014the market would ensure growth and stability. Those numbers, and the underlying ideas, had no basis in either theory or evidence. Ireland and Spain, two of the worst afflicted countries, actually had surpluses before the crisis. The crisis caused their deficits and debt, not the other way around."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The hope was that fiscal and monetary discipline would result in ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["convergence, "]},"enabling the single-currency system to work even better. Instead, there has been divergence, with the rich countries getting richer and the poor getting poorer, and within countries, the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer. But it was the very structure of the Eurozone that predictably led to this. The single market, for instance, made it easy for money to leave the banks of the weaker countries, forcing these banks to contract lending, weakening the weak further."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Economists assessing the prospects of a single currency arrangement some quarter century ago emphasized the importance of sufficient labor mobility and an adequately large common budget to buffer against shocks as well as sufficient ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["economic "]},"similarity among the countries. But the euro took away two of the critical instruments for adjustment\u2014the exchange and interest rates\u2014and didn\u2019t put anything in their place. There was no common deposit insurance, no common way of resolving problems in the banking sector, and no common unemployment insurance scheme."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Equally important, these early discussions ignored the importance of ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["intellectual "]},"convergence: There is a huge gap in perceptions of what makes for good policies, especially between Germany and much of the rest of Europe. These differences are longstanding. They were evident to me when I chaired the Economic Policy Committee of the OECD in the mid-1990s. If anything, there has been divergence here, too. Thus, the austerity policy\u2014which Germany thought should have brought a quick return to growth\u2014has failed miserably in virtually every country in which it has been tried. The consequences were predictable, and predicted by most serious economists around the world. So too, many of the particular structural reforms have actually weakened the countries on which they have been imposed, lowering growth and increasing their trade deficits."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A huge democratic deficit has since opened up: citizens in Greece, Spain, and Portugal have all voted in large numbers for parties opposed to austerity.  Yet, they have felt they have no choice but to accept the demands of Germany. Citizens were never told that when they joined the euro, they would be giving up their economic sovereignty."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The ambition of the euro was to bring greater prosperity to Europe. This, in turn, would promote economic and political integration. The euro was a political project, but the politics weren\u2019t strong enough to create the institutional arrangements that would ensure success. With the euro leading to stagnation and worse, it is no surprise that it has led to increasing divisiveness rather than to more solidarity. Today, it seems that the euro, which was supposed to be a means to an end, has become an end in itself\u2014the pursuit of which poses perhaps the single most important threat to the European project."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In response to the repeated crises, Europe has made reforms, but they have been too little, too late. Some may actually be counterproductive: Having a system of common supervision, without adequate sensitivity to local macro-conditions and without common deposit insurance may actually exacerbate divergence. Meanwhile, the region has the misfortune of being repeatedly bombarded with crises, especially the refugee crisis. With unemployment in so many countries so high\u2014at least partly because of the euro\u2014those seeking a new future wish to move to where there are jobs, resulting in a few countries bearing the brunt of the wave of migrants. And naturally, countries where unemployment is high resist having new workers competing for the scarce jobs."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Europe has been engaged in brinkmanship, but the danger of brinkmanship is that there is a high probability that eventually one goes over the brink. Markets sense that the system is not viable in the long run\u2014speculators attack when they smell blood. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi\u2019s assertion that he will do \u201cwhatever it takes\u201d has worked wonders\u2014for longer than anyone expected. But it is a confidence trick: It works only because market participants believe it will work."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["These market forces are intertwined with politics. Voters who should be unhappy\u2014simply because they have done so poorly for such a long time\u2014have expressed their anger by voting against the centrist parties of the left and right. The dissidents are in the ascendancy."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"videoid":"5162880726001","controls":"1"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Perhaps European leaders, sensing the urgency of the moment, will finally make the reforms in the structure of the Eurozone that will enable a single currency arrangement to work\u2014to achieve a shared prosperity. Perhaps 2017 will be the year in which the reform of the Eurozone really takes hold."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In order for a single currency system to work, there has to be more Europe\u2014more solidarity; more willingness of the stronger countries to help the weaker; more willingness to create institutions like a common deposit insurance and a common unemployment scheme\u2014than the current halfway house, which is simply not viable. But the failures of the Eurozone make such reforms increasingly hard. It is at least as likely that the political forces are going in the other direction, and if that is the case, it may be only a matter of time before Europe looks back on the euro as an interesting, well-intentioned experiment that failed\u2014at great cost to the citizens of Europe and their democracies."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Joseph E. Stiglitz is a professor at Columbia University, recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, 2001, and most recently, author of The Euro: How a Common Currency Threatens the Future of Europe, W.W. sts\u002F1891198\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1891198\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1891198\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1891198\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1891198\u002Fprimary_section"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F1891198\u002Fbrand"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:meta":[{"mt_seo_description":"Joseph Stiglitz, a professor at Columbia University and recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, 2001, explains.","mt_seo_keywords":"euro, Eurozone, European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, Europe, outlook of euro, 2017, Joseph Stiglitz, unemployment, economy","short_title":"Why 2017 Could See the Collapse of the Euro","og_title":"Why 2017 Could See the Collapse of the Euro","twitter_text":"Why 2017 could see the collapse of the euro","protected":0,"og_image":null,"listicle":{"items":{"item":[]},"display":{"ranking":false,"order":"ASC"},"social":{"tweet_text":""}},"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iqEP8X","mt_seo_title":"Euro Outlook for 2017","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"euro, Eurozone, European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, Europe, outlook of euro, 2017, Joseph Stiglitz, unemployment, economy","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Feuro-outlook-2017\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ffortune\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Feuro-outlook-2017\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"article_full","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":1891237,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ffortunedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Feuro-coin-gettyimages-613741828.jpg","alt":"Currency Trading Fluctuates After UK's EU Referendum Result","caption":"In this photo illustration,  a Euro coin and a one pound sterling coin are seen on top of a UK passport on October 10, 2016 in Bath, England. ","credit":"Matt Cardy\u2014Getty Images","description":"BATH, ENGLAND - OCTOBER 10:  In this photo illustration,  a Euro coin and a one pound sterling coin are seen on top of a UK passport on October 10, 2016 in Bath, England. Since the UK voted to leave the European Union in June, the UK's currency has been fluctuating in value against other currencies, including the Euro and the dollar, and looks likely to remain doing so while the uncertainty remains surrounding the terms of the UK's departure from the EU.  (Photo by Matt Cardy\u002FGetty Images)","title":"euro coin"},"video":null,"structured":null}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":56491,"name":"euro","slug":"euro","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":111944,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":84,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":291878719,"name":"Fortune Insiders","slug":"fortune-insiders","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":122920,"taxonomy":"category","description":"","parent":0,"count":2701,"filter":"raw"}]}},{"id":1892231,"date":"2016-12-30T03:27:37","date_gmt":"2016-12-30T08:27:37","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F?p=1892231"},"paid":false,"modified":"2016-12-30T03:56:05","modified_gmt":"2016-12-30T08:56:05","slug":"rodrigo-duterte-philippines-economy","type":"post","subtype":"article","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F12\u002F30\u002Frodrigo-duterte-philippines-economy\u002F","shortlink":"http:\u002F\u002Ffor.tn\u002F2iejJg9","dunce":"8432334743","title":{"rendered":"Philippines\u2019 President Rarely Mentions It\u2019s Now One of the World\u2019s Fastest-Growing Economies"},"content":{"plain":"After six months at the helm in the Philippines, Rodrigo Duterte has been touting just two achievements of his presidency &#8211; a vicious war on drugs and a surprise alliance with his country&#8217;s bitter rival, China. Yet behind the curse-laden bluster and populist demagoguery that has defined Duterte&#8217;s rule, he presides over one of the world&#8217;s fastest-growing economies, and has put cabinet colleagues to work on drafting reforms and legislation to tackle the economy&#8217;s most stubborn structural problems. Advisers say Duterte&#8217;s economic successes come from using a strategy he honed as the long-time mayor of Davao City at a national level. He concentrates on busting crime and deliberately delegates the handling of the economy to others. By his own admission, Duterte says he is no expert on the economy and leaves it to &#8220;the bright guys&#8221; in his cabinet. Economic Planning Secretary Ernesto Pernia sees the president only twice monthly and rarely hears feedback. He said Duterte was focused almost entirely on crime and drugs. &#8220;That has been his obsession,&#8221; he told Reuters. &#8220;He essentially leaves other issues and concerns to the cabinet.&#8221; The strategy seems to have worked so far although economists are beginning to question how long it can last. &#8220;That&#8217;s what we&#8217;re hoping for, that his core economic team can prevail,&#8221; said Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI) economist Emilio S. Neri. &#8220;The fundamentals are there but we are leaning towards deficit spending and stimulus-driven growth and some unsustainable populist policies are worrisome.&#8221; At the national level, Duterte&#8217;s signature campaigns have included his tilt toward China while turning his back on long-term ally the United States in addition to the war on drugs. He rarely mentions it, but the economy has boomed under his watch, although some of the gains have been ascribed to the previous administration&#8217;s policies and Duterte&#8217;s decision to retain them. Growth reached an annual 7.1% in the third quarter of the year, Asia&#8217;s second-highest and the country&#8217;s strongest quarter in three years. The government expects full-year growth around 7%. The economy is expected to grow 6.5-7.5% in 2017, but there are worries that Duterte&#8217;s erratic behavior could impact policy, with political risk over his drugs crackdown and foul-mouthed outbursts at some big donors and investors. Markets have signaled their concern. In the six months since Duterte took over, the main stock index has lost nearly 20% in dollar terms and is among the worst performers in Asia. Over the same period, the peso currency is down around 5% to the dollar, but other currencies in the region are also depressed. DECISIVE LEADERSHIP But Duterte has plenty of supporters, who say his decisive leadership and intolerance of bad governance will be a long-term boon for the economy. In Davao City, he helped lure investors, dramatically cut red tape and fired inept officials. In 2014, Davao saw growth of a 9.3%, compared to 6.1% nationwide. Analaysts at Nomura have said his populist, development-centered approach suggests he is &#8220;strongly motivated&#8221; to address the Philippines&#8217; biggest weakness &#8211; infrastructure. Expenditure on infrastructure, including on flood management schemes, ports, a rapid-transit bus system and a rail line, makes up a quarter of next year&#8217;s record $67 billion budget. Consumer spending is strong, helped by $22 billion of remittances in the first 10 months from Filipinos overseas, a 4% rise. Unemployment was a record low 4.7% in the third quarter, from 5.7% a year earlier. &#8220;He should deserve credit,&#8221; Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez told Reuters. &#8220;Unfortunately, people are always looking at the controversial statements. But if you judge it, he has done an excellent job &#8230;the important thing is the trust and confidence of businesses in him is very high.&#8221; JITTERS Duterte&#8217;s volatility and seemingly unilateral foreign policy has caused jitters and confusion, especially when he turned hostile towards the United States and then started cosying up to China, with which the Philippines has a history of mistrust over the South China Sea. Duterte announced his &#8220;separation&#8221; from the United States in Beijing in October, shocking even his own ministers, who scrambled to assure investors &#8211; without his consent &#8211; that his policy was to diversify, not sever ties. It&#8217;s a gambit that could pay off, with an intractable dispute with Beijing now on the back burner and China pledging to provide the Philippines with billions of dollars in infrastructure loans and ramp up farm and fisheries imports. Nevertheless, economists warn that hot-headedness and willingness to take big risks could be a problem if it spills into policymaking, especially if it impacts U.S. firms, which account for three-quarters of the country&#8217;s $23 billion business-processing outsourcing (BPO) sector. Some big U.S. firms have delayed BPO investments to undergo more due diligence. Capital Economics notes a &#8220;growing risk that Duterte makes it harder&#8221; to attract big investment. Moody&#8217;s has a stable outlook, expecting &#8220;continued economic outperformance relative to peers,&#8221; assuming Duterte&#8217;s drugs war doesn&#8217;t distract him from his economic reforms. &#8220;There&#8217;s lots of focus going into the anti-drugs program,&#8221; said BPI&#8217;s Neri. &#8220;In six months, economic policy reforms seem to have taken a back seat.&#8221;","rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EAfter six months at the helm in the Philippines, Rodrigo Duterte has been touting just two achievements of his presidency &#8211; a vicious war on drugs and a surprise alliance with his country&#8217;s bitter rival, China.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYet behind the curse-laden bluster and populist demagoguery that has defined Duterte&#8217;s rule, he presides over one of the world&#8217;s fastest-growing economies, and has put cabinet colleagues to work on drafting reforms and legislation to tackle the economy&#8217;s most stubborn structural problems.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAdvisers say Duterte&#8217;s economic successes come from using a strategy he honed as the long-time mayor of Davao City at a national level.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHe concentrates on busting crime and deliberately delegates the handling of the economy to others. By his own admission, Duterte says he is no expert on the economy and leaves it to &#8220;the bright guys&#8221; in his cabinet.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp style=\"text-align:center;\"\u003E\u003Cdiv
